The Garlic nann is outstanding. The butter chicken is so crisp on the outside and so most and tender on the inside. Same ratings
for the tandoori chicken. Same ratings for the  Afghani Nan, Chicken Boti .I am not a chi tea drinker, but theirs was made from scratch and I had 4 glasses of it. Despite the health warnings, I found the restrooms xclean. Ice water was ice cold.  Despite the negatives I will come back here again and again,
author: Peter F.

description: Service was great! I asked for my Saag Paneer to have a little extra cheese and they put double the amount for no extra charge, although it needed a little salt. The cheese nan was amazing, and so was the chicken masala. Clean and good portions.
author: Christine R.

description: For Staying or pick up!!! best TIKKA MASALA  chicken in SF !! highly recommended!!!!
author: Andrea E.

description: This place is amazing, the food takes some time if you sit in the restaurant to eat but believe me it is worth the wait! The people are very nice and my best suggestion is to call ahead to order your food they have it out quick. It has such a great authentic taste and nothing like any bigger restaurants in the city, this is the best definitely go here if you are visiting. Don't pass this place up it is very delicious!
author: Karli S.

description: Thus far the best south Asian restaurant I have eaten at in the city- and not to toot my own horn, but I used to live in India and am pretty picky when it come to this type of cuisine- so means a lot for me to say this. Highly recommend all the curries, and well.... Pretty much everything. Bahut accha Lahore Karahi- shabash!
author: Jason D.

description: Love this kind of food, however, would avoid this place. The restaurant is not clean at all, a cockroach ran across our table while we were having dinner. Not surprised to see poor food safety score notification from yelp.
author: John S.

description:
Oh my gosh, this place is one of the best kept secrets in the TL. It's just steps away from Naan and Curry (or "Naan and "Fury" as it's sometimes called) and the food is cheaper and much better. I'm not even sure if Naan and Curry can even say they serve halal meat.

This is one of those places that completely take you by surprise. Looking in, it's nothing special but you're immediately greeted by genuinely friendly faces and a cheerful conversation. The menu is simple, made to order and the restaurant is clean and has a direct view of the open kitchen. 

We ordered a Chicken Vindaloo and Lamb Korma  with two sides of onion kulcha and garlic naan. I asked for the chicken vinadaloo to be extra spicy and they did not disappoint! I felt like standing up on the chair and whistling 'cause it was just that dam good. Eating good Indian food just brings me back to great childhood memories of Chicago and exploring new restaurants on Devon Ave. 

The chicken vindaloo has hardly any oil seeping in the bottom, the sauce didn't separate, their was no trace of fat or mystery parts of chicken and the spices kicked my butt. The lamb korma was tender, almost like cutting through butter and a little gamey which I was all too impressed with but that's why I ordered chicken vindaloo. The naan and kulcha was hot, fluffy and complimented the spices in the vindaloo well. We spoiled our appetite by eating bread before coming to the restaurant so we had to wrap up the food but that didn't stop us from ordering dessert.

We split a kheer and honest to God, it was the first decent kheer I've ever had in San Francisco during the 2+ years here. I'm a big fan of rice pudding and this was real rice pudding that almost looked green! There was so much pistachio and just enough milk that it was a thick pudding that just exploded with flavor. Usually, Indian restaurants do the opposite where you have to search for the pistachio and it's swimming in a pool of milk but they don't cut corners here and I really do appreciate that. 

The owner was so nice that he even shared his homemade ice cream with it. I have no idea what was in it really but it was thick, hardly melted and had thick pieces of pistachio, mango and all kinds of other bits of yum. It was a difficult task to keep eating after the sensation to pop open a button happened, but I kept pushing onward because genuine warm hospitality like that is hard to come by. 

I even noticed the server turned the lights on brighter after taking note of me looking up at all the light bulbs in the center of the restaurant. I don't mind a dim lit place, especially if we're the only table but he took notice and acted on it. I was touched and definitely coming back because of the little touches they make sure happen.
author: Jessica K.

description:
This is one of those meals you have to save in your "brain folder":

[ coreyg@yelp ] $   pwd
[ coreyg@yelp ] $   /usr/dining/ecstasy/2010/Lahore Karahi

The night before I left my debit card at a bar.  The next day, this got me to thinking.  What if I wasn't able to pay for my meal at Lahore Karahi?  The bill would come, I would pull out my empty pockets and flash a sad face.  Would they send me to the kitchen to wash dishes?

I could only hope.  

As I sat at my table, I daydreamed about how Guddu the chef would order me to the sink to clean all the pots, pans, plates, etc.  I'd sadly meander back to the sink with my head down, and then (when he wasn't looking) I'd flash a wink & a smile to myself and get to work.  It would be my duty to lick every living morsel, spice, and drip of sauce off of everything.  Since my crime was so dire, I'd have to do this for hours.  

Ah, to dream.  But alas, I had cash in hand.  Let's go to the beginning.....

I was staying in the Tenderloin for the weekend, and Lahore Karahi was bookmarked months in advance.  I finally had a free afternoon, so I slushed and slogged through the San Francisco rain to Guddu's Pakistani/Indian dining mecca.  

The dining area is small.  I patiently waited & shivered at the entry for a few minutes.  I noticed many happy & smile-y faces.  I watched Guddu performing his magic in the kitchen (Yeah, I could do some dish washing/licking in there).    Within seconds I was warmed up.  I was then seated at the table next to the door (it was a little cold there, and I waited a bit, but it made the end result all the more better).

The server was very apologetic about the wait.  As I waited, I did notice some useful info--they are applying for their liquor license so they can serve beer and wine.  They also received an "A" grade for cleanliness.

I went for a standard (Chicken Tikka Masala) and Garlic Naan.  Within a few minutes, the coolness of where I sat was enveloped in steam as my food was brought to me (and my pores were cleared).  

Oh the aroma.

I smiled.  I wafted the steamy fragrant aroma to my face with my hands a few times, and let it soak in for a good minute before touching anything.

I then tore a piece of the naan, and placed it on my tongue.  THIS.  WAS. THE.  BEST.  NAAN.  I'VE.  EVER.  HAD!  Oh man, it's been a few weeks, but I still have dreams about the flavor & texture of it.  

The Chicken Tikka Masala was more subtle.  The taste didn't hit you quite in the face as the garlic naan.  But y'know, that's what I liked about it.  

It was like a slow and quiet orchestral piece.  It builds.  The way my taste buds soaked it in was an experience in that all of my little taste buds had a party with every bite.  The crescendo for the party was at the end.  I don't know how food can tell stories, but Guddu's cuisine does it.

I was transported.
author: Corey G.

description:
As a first time visitor, I did not know what to expect from Lahore Karahi, but I have to agree with the other reviewers.  If this place was once great, its Yelp page should have been retired when the restaurant changed hands.  Everything at Lahore Karahi is average at best.  

The food is OK, but my socks were not blown off.  Time for an adjustment in spice level. We shared the Saag Panner, Bengan Bharta, Lamb Vindaloo, Bhindi Gosht and Garlic Naan.  While nothing was bad, nothing stood out above currys from Trader Joes.

Additionally, the walls may have been recently painted, but the atmosphere is still severely lacking.  Please explain to me why  restaurants keep the front door open all winter?  Is it so that people don't linger?  Is it to cool off the kitchen?  What does that tell you about how much they respect their patrons?

What it does have going for it is it's cheap.  Out the door for under $12 a person.
author: Nicole R.

description:
I been addicted to Indian food for a while, and when I came to SF it took me a while to find a great Indian place, then I found this one!
Best Indian Food in the city!
The prices are good and the food is good, I love their Chicken Tikka Masala.
It's not a romantic place and no service by the table, but if you just want great Indian food - this is the place!
author: Linda E.

description:
Although Shalimar is still my favorite place for curry, Lahore Kahari is right up there.  While at Shalimar I prefer the vegetarian curries, at Lahore Kahari it's the fish that really shines.  On the recommendation of Yelpers I ordered the Tandoori Fish and Bengan Bartha.  

Here I'll have to digress and give you some tips to ease your time here.  The owner is the cook.  The only cook.  So do yourself a favor and do not come here with a group of 10 people during lunch.  You can imagine how long it took to cook dishes for our table plus the other tables with only 1 cook and 2 burners.  If you do come here hungry, the food comes out in the order of 1) biryani, 2) curry and 3) tandoori.  They were nice and gave us dishes of complimentary pappadams.  Also, if the chai tea runs out, they will make more last, after all the food is finishes and the kitchen is quiet.  I'm not complaining; I want my food.  Just FYI.

The Bengan Bartha was really smooth and smoky.  Not too oily.  I would recommend this.  While I was waiting for my Tandoori Fish I had the opportunity to try the Chicken Biryani (good) and Chicken (korma).  The naan was pretty good but not amazing like I was expecting.  The garlic naan was very garlicky.  At the end of the meal the Tandoori Fish came out.  Wow.  It was totally worth waiting for.  It's unlike any fish dish I've had before.  Fresh (coriander, lime?) and hot (chilies).  I also recommend the Fish Tikka Masala.  Not quite a traditional Tikka Masala sauce but very good.  

I would go back just for the Tandoori Fish.
author: Jean K.

description: Pretty good food, but we ordered takeout, and they got half our order wrong. Unfortunately I didn't check too closely when we picked it up, just peeked in the bag and checked their receipt to make sure it was mine. Got back to the hotel and found we'd been given veg samosa instead of veg pakora, and kulfi instead of gulab jamun. Luckily the samosas were pretty good, as was the aloo saag, and the chicken tikka was great. But the kulfi was melted by the time we figured out it wasn't gulab jamun (it was heavily wrapped in tin foil) and it was just ok. Decent food, careless service.
author: Susanna W.

description: Excellent! Not my favorite part of town at night, but definitely worth it. The tandoori fish was the highlight of my culinary week, and the garlic naan was incredible.
author: Jeremy A.

description:
larhore karahi is a-okay. this little hole in the wall in the heart of the tenderloin does pretty well amongst all the gazillion indian places in the area. the food is good and more importantly, not overpriced. i ordered the lamb samosas, garlic naan, fish tikka masala and mango lassi. the samosas, naan and lassi were perfect. the tikka masala sauce was a wee bit too watery and the color is a little too light and not spicy- it didn't have enough cumin, cayenne pepper, or paprika. the fish itself was done very well- it just falls apart when you put it in your mouth.

so overall 3 stars. why? the place was good but nothing extraordinary. the masala sauce needs a little more spice. they didn't have gulab jamun (crazy! i know) and the staff could definitely crack a smile once in a while.
author: The Hangry Chef O.

description:
My favorite Indian Pakistani in the city. Try everything :) and it's spicy, and very affordable.  YUM :)

But it's in a sketch neighborhood -- so beware!
author: ThuZ W.

description:
When people say things like, "I am going to take you to the best ____ restaurant ever" My expectations are often unmet because the build up was so big. Definitely not the case with Lahore. 

This is a quick, but sketchy walk from Union Square where we stayed. My boyfriend has been raving about this place from college days and no Indian food we have had could ever compare for him. 

Let me tell you, Lahore did not disappoint And I am 100% in agreement with him that this is the best Indian food. 

Went with the basics- Chicken tikka masala and Chicken Lahore, garlic naan.  Chicken Lahore was juicy and flavorful and tikka masala hit the spot. 

Atmosphere is perfect because it feels authentic and they certainly do not try too hard.... It's all about the food. Oh yeah, BYOB.
author: Rebecca S.

description:
Great place for some delicious Indian goodness! 
Big selection, very affordable prices and the food is oh so good. Flavorful, fresh and generous portions. They have the best naan I have ever had in San Francisco. There's also unlimited supply of chai tea, which I just couldn't get enough of!
author: Alexandra B.

description:
There is not much I can say here that hasn't been said. Lahore Karahi is the best indian food I have ever had, meanin yes it is the best indian food in the bay area. It is the high bar that all other indian food are judged by. Yes it is in a sketchy neighborhood, so just bring your mace spray or get a cab it's worth it. The food is also very inexpensive and it is BYOB. I know you're asking yourself a question right now, the answer is yes you will smell of Lahore until sunrise.

I usually get the Daal Masala, Chicken Tikka Masala (best I ever had!), and the garlic cheese naan (not on the menu, you have to ask for it.).  The chef/owner Guddu is also very nice.
author: Michael C.

description: The place where I had my first and fell in love with Indian/Pakistani food. Chicken tikka masala on naan got me so good. Great food at low cost places like Lahore couldn't get any better!
author: J A.

description:
I walked into this eatery and got kicked square to the face. A shot right in the nose by a little Indian ninja or something.

Metaphorically of course. Kicked in the face with the aroma of a slew of Indian spices, right when I opened the door. Something is lost in restaurants where kitchens are tucked far to the back. The sounds and smells of the food being prepared are part of the journey to a good meal.

I walked in and to the left was the chef on a 4 burner stove, 4 pans of food, all going at once, cooking like a mad man yet still having everything under control. He didn't even looked phased. The smell was captivating.

My food wasn't quite ready so I watched as he rotated through the pans, stirring and tending, tossing and spicing. The line cook was singing away, a sure sign of a happy employee. Happy employees make happy food. The vibe small and welcoming, I was disappointed I had chosen food to go.

My mixed veggie dish, the Mill Juli Sabzi with accompanying rice and garlic naan, was packed up and I was sent on my way. 

I was home for 2 minutes tops before my entire apartment smelled like I had been cooking Indian food all day. Hopefully my neighbors think so and are impressed, then they'll come ask me to cook for them and I can laugh and tell them no. The first bite I took I could tell the meal at a mere $11 was a steal. Many Indian places in SF would charge $11 for the dish alone, and that's before rice, naan, and tax.

I asked for medium to hot on the spicy scale and I could not have asked for it to be more accurate. It was absolutely delicious.

I have to give a shout out to Jessica V. on this one, had she not alerted me to the presence of this joint I'd likely never have even stopped to check a menu.

Soooooooooooo good.
author: Justin N.

description:
This is my new favorite Pakistani food spot in the city now. Its a whole in the wall, with great food and slow service. Well, actually the service seems slower because they make all their food fresh, so if your food is taking time its because they're preparing it fresh rather then just heating up left overs from yesterday.

Their beef seekh kebab is a must try, its the most authentic Pakistani style Kebab I've had outside of Pakistan. I have also tried their Karahi, which was very flavorful and had the right amount of spices. The Naans, buttered up, had the right amount of crispiness and softness. 

The interior isn't any special, much better then that of Shalimar though and as noted earlier, be prepared to wait for your food. 

Lahore Karahi is now my go to spot for Pakistani food (sorry Shalimar and Punjab).
author: Saadullah S.

description:
I ate here tonight, and my experience was stupid. It was a stupid experience and it made me angry. This is Yelp, and Yelp is a place where I'm going to talk about my Emotions, and my Emotions after eating at Lahore Karahi were as follows:

(1) Stupid.
(2) Angry.

But hold on, I'm getting ahead of myself. First things first. What did I get? Well, I'm glad you asked! I got the tandoori fish. It was delicious. It was spicy and zesty and sizzling and really kind of unique. I don't know where else in the city I'd get tandoori fish. So good work on the tandoori fish, Lahore Karahi! You tandoori'ed the heck out of that fish. That fish had no idea what was coming to it, and what came to it was a tandoor.

Better still: the menu was generally impressive, and there were a lot of things that I don't normally see on Indian restaurant menus that I wanted to try.

And oh man, that naan sure did look good. It looked very good! It looked better than any naan I've ever seen in my life, and let me tell you, I almost certainly have seen a greater-than-average amount of naan in my life. (Provided you take the average across Americans, rather than a worldwide average, in which case it's actually quite possible that I've seen a lower-than-average amount of naan in my life.)

Which brings me to the "stupid" part of my review.

Look, I'm no restauranteur, so I may be talking out of my butt here. But it seems to me that the problem of taking orders and serving customers has been encountered innumerable times throughout the history of the world, in practically every corner of the planet. Surely the top handful of solutions to this problem would have been determined by now.

For instance, an example methodology might be to have hosts to seat customers and waiters to communicate their orders to the kitchen staff. This is by no means the only possible methodology, nor the most efficient one in every case; it's merely an example of the sort of thing I'm talking about.

Furthermore, the benefits of adopting one of these efficient service methodologies seem clear: increased customer throughput, higher accuracy in fulfilling orders, quicker service, etc. Even if you don't give a care about customer satisfaction, the sheer economic logic of increasing customer throughput seems to demand that you adopt one of these time-tested methodologies.

I mention all this, because as soon as you walk into Lahore Karahi it is apparent that they have closely scrutinized the book of well-established customer service methodologies, stroked their metaphorical chin thoroughly for a few seconds, and then promptly tossed the book over their shoulder with a dismissive, "Naaaaah, we don't need that."

As far as I can tell, this is how it's supposed to go at Lahore Karahi:

- Walk in, grab your own menu, and seat yourself.
- Decide on what you want.
- Walk up to the counter and write down on your ticket what you'd like to order. (!)
- Hand this ticket to someone working behind the counter and sit back down.
- After some indeterminate period of time, someone will walk over to you with your food.
- When you are done eating, you go up to the counter, whereupon someone there will know what you ordered and how much to charge you. You pay and are done.

It is entirely mysterious how they are supposed to know who you are and what you ordered.

It is considerably less mysterious once you consider that they appear to get it wrong a lot of the time.

And this, THIS is what gets my goat. This is the whole point of this ridiculous essay I've written. Concretely, it's because I ordered a garlic naan and did not get it. Abstractly, it's because I'm an engineer, and it's my job to obsess over things like efficiency and fault-tolerance. This is my trade; it's how my brain works. I simply cannot believe that Lahore Karahi's byzantine order fulfillment methodology is the most effective possible solution. And this fact saddens me, and it hurts me inside.

Heck, if this system were *practical* at the expense of pure efficiency, I would be okay with that. Maybe the most theoretically efficient system is weird and difficult to explain and impossible to get people to participate in. But the thing is: so is Lahore Karahi's system! I mean, who the heck has ever written down their own order on the order ticket? How is that a normal thing at all in California? How is anyone supposed to know how to do this a priori?

So you get the worst of both worlds: a system that regularly gets people's orders wrong, yet still burdens the customer with a weird learning curve.

Anyway, that it. That's all I've got. Maybe I'm being a jerky jerk McJerkface for writing this idiotically long and ranty review. Maybe I'm just a close-minded dummy who perceives everything different as being weird and terrible. Maybe I just need to relax, chill out, and recognize that sometimes, occasionally, stuff ain't perfect.

Or maybe everyone needs to just recognize that I'm right about everything, all the time, forever.
author: Greg P.

description:
When it comes to tasty, yet affordable Indian food in San Francisco... I highly doubt there's a better balance than what's being offered at Lahore Karahi in the TL.

The ol' ball & chain has been wanting to hit this place up for a while, and we finally had an opportunity to grub it up after bar hopping along Geary earlier this evening. 

It's a rather unassuming spot along O'Farrell, and like most good culinary gems, it was a total 'hole in the wall.' While that term is almost as watered down as the term 'dive bar,' this fits the bill pretty well. Semi-run down, florescent lighting, small quarters and odd linens/place settings. Our table had the classic checkerboard table covers, and none of the plates even came close to matching. In fact, one plate was seemingly smuggled from a Chinese restaurant down the street, as the dish was littered in sinographs. Good stuff!

As for the food, it was great. We both went with chicken dishes, and while mine was a spicy as Salma Hayek with Tapitio on her naughty bits, causing me to break out in a sweat, it was divine. The lady opted for the vanilla of Indian/Pakistani cuisine (chicken masala), and it was surprisingly delicious. Usually, it's a pretty bland option... but this baby had some kick! While I'm usually not an advocate of the ho-hum menu choices, I'd definitely order that again. We also added some naan and a few drinks... and our bill was only $20!

$20? Are we in San Francisco, or San Bernadino? Not only is that a deal... that's a steal! 

To ask if I'd head back ASAP would be akin to asking me if a three-legged duck swam in a circle. The answer? Uhhh, duh, mother trucker!
author: Ruggy J.

description:
Absolutely Fabulous. Darling.

The Tandoori Fish is so mouth watering just thinking about it now makes me want to go there! The Kulfi (mango) is so good. You are required to save room for it. The Saag Paneer isn't he best, but the Palak Methi Aloo is to die for. My roommate loves the Butter Chicken. I love everything.

menu: http://www.lahorekarahisf.com/pakistani-menu.htm
author: Jennifer P.

description: A bit pricier than Shalimar/Chutney but excellent lamb vindaloo.
author: Daniel Y.

description:
Closed until December 1st due to family emergency! :( 

Lahore (not "Tha Whore) possibly serves some of the best tasting and cheap Indian/Pakistani food around. 

Tip: Get to the counter. Fill out the check yourself with all the yummies that you want, then fill yourself up some delicious free chai! 

Got the chicken saag, lamb vindaloo, sesame naan (don't recommend this one), and basmati rice. 

This will make you go "Mmmmmm" in the TL.
author: Kenny L.

description: A hidden gem! We were on a hunt for tasty tikka masala. A local recommended we try this place, but warned us that it was a "hole in the wall and dirty". We were happily surprised to find thar the restaurant is actually very clean and run by some adorable people. They obviously take pride in their food and location. Sure, its a little older building, but the bathrooms were extremely clean and staff were very friendly and doting. The tikka masala and garlic naan were very tasty! Just what we were craving. Don't forget to order a side of rice, it comes separately. Will visit again on our next trip.
author: Amy R.

description: I prefer Chutney which is nearby.  The garlic naan was bland and almost stale.  All was mediocre.  The portions were decent.  1 star because we found a roach behind the cup stand after we ate.  Will not be returning.
author: Jacquelynne S.

description:
My taxi driver on the way to Lahore told me he was friends with the owner. When I asked what he'd recommend to eat he told me he never ate there because he always made his own food and it was the same so everything was probably good. He wasn't wrong.

There was a large group of us so Kevin L took the helm and ordered for everyone family style. This means I got to sample lots and lots of options. I sampled so many options my tummy started to hurt a little from being full and I couldn't stop sampling still. This is some seriously delicious Indian food.

More props to the BYOB here. Just dash across the street and pick up some beer or wine to complete your meal and you can leave as one happy camper.
author: Tiffany N.

description: The best Indian restaurant in SF so far. Get the lamb vindaloo, garlic naan, and butter chicken! I like that they spent 20+ minutes to make my food - signs of quality and freshness!
author: Gina H.

description: We got two dishes to share, naan, and rice. We should have had leftovers to take home because it was so much food, but it was so good we ate it all.
author: Kelso H.

description: Honestly I'm not a great judge of indian food.  Got the garlic naan, lamb vindaloo, and fish curry.  All of the meat was perfectly tender with great flavor.  The spiciness definitely builds.  The flavor was great, but didn't overpower the taste of the meat.  Wanted to try the samosas too, but unfortunately they were sold out.  Maybe another time.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
San Francisco has plenty to choose from if you're looking for any kind of ethnic cuisine.  I'm always game for any of it.  But last week when Kathleen M took control of planning a small CM group dinner, she didn't hesitate in bringing us to Lahore - her favorite Indian/Pakistani place on earth!

If you don't believe me, just ask her... she even named her dog after Lahore's Chicken Tikka Masala!  (Her dog's name is Tikka!)

Anyways, on to the details...  this place is tiny, but they can accommodate a large group - lucky for us, we took over a large table. Kathleen led the way in helping herself to a hot chai tea to start.  I did the same.  Everything on the menu sounded appealing, so we decided to order family style and share... it was great because everyone got to try a little of everything.  Kevin L took charge of the ordering while Kathleen and I threw in our two cents as well.  We had all sorts of dishes from the pakora, tandoori delicacies, chicken tikka masala, korma, prawns, several veggie dishes, biryani, naan, etc... I know it sounds like a lot, but we did have a large group.  

If you're a fan of Indian / Pakistani food, this place is for sure worth a visit... I'm sure I'll return as I know I can always count on Kathleen to be my date!
author: Gabi M.

description:
I really wanted to like this place. I was in San Fran for the weekend & was on the hunt for some great food. I saw Lahore Karahi, and thought wow this place has great reviews we should give it a try. I met up with my best friend during the labor day weekend. It took us awhile to get to this place. I really wanted to impress her, and show her some great eats in San Fran. We got there pretty late, so there wasn't a line. We were seated promptly. It was pretty packed in there. I am pretty sure I only saw 2-3 people that worked in there. 

Anyway, I had ordered the Afghani naan, rice, butter chicken and a mango lassi. I was quite disappointed by everything that I had ordered.
The Afghani naan was definitely not what I expected. It tasted like a Christmas fruit cake packed inside a different tasting kind of naan. The butter chicken was different. Creamy but in a different way, as in not a good way. 

Our meat dishes appeared and we had to wait at least 5 minutes for the rice and the naan. My friend had ordered the tandoori fish, and it was pretty spicy despite asking for it mild. 

To top it off there was a cockroach on the wall. Maybe it was the day.
Restaurants have off days right? Anyway, not sure if I'd go back. I honestly though Naan 'n Curry was 10 times better. Maybe it's what I ordered.
author: Nicole B.

description: This place is awesome, the food is great, the service is nice. I always get goat curry with white rice. Better than Chutney and Shalimar. I recommend it
author: Zulfi B.

description:
I give this place a rating of 3 stars for the following reasons: 

The place is tiny, congested and packed (but not sure why since Shalimar, Pakwan and Chutney in the same block are actually better in my opinion.

I tried a few things here. The Karahi Chicken was great, while the Tandoor Fish was average and the Lamb Seek Kabab was not so good. 

Again, not worth the wait. Oh and they don't take American Express.
author: Faisal L.

description: Yelp reviews helped me find this restaurant during a business trip to San Francisco  I enjoyed the food here so much, that I wanted to take the restaurant back with me to New York. I really dig the do it yourself vibe, getting your own sauces, your drink and ordering at the counter. The best Vegetable Pakoras I have ever had. I couldn't stop eating the Saag Paneer even though I was full. Also this was the cheapest meal I had all week. Good deal, no frills decor, amazing food.
author: Jennifer F.

description: Worst service ever! The guy who takes the order has probably never smiled in his life. Seems like he thinks he is doing us a favor by taking our order and serving it to us. Didn't look up once when we ordered. Threw our plates and food before us. You would hope the food would make up for it. Nope! The chicken was stale and had a foul taste. The rest of the food was pretty tasteless. Not worth even a single star.
author: Ana D.

description:
Yummy Indian food. I wish I hadn't gotten medium spice, because it was a bit spicy, but it was still yummy.

This place gets crowded, so expect to wait for a seat for at least 20 minutes in peak times. 

Also, pretty cheap. We got 3 dishes (lamb korti, ckn tikka masala and a green pea potato and nut dish) and garlic naan for ~$26. 

It's just hard to bring leftovers home from this place because it's in the TL. (Your bound to have someone ask for your food, and I just feel bad if I'm being selfish, and just want to save it for tomorrow's lunch)

I don't know why Indian food takes so long, but a couple who sat after us were smart and ordered while they were waiting before they were sat. I was super jealous, and I'll use that tip next time.
author: Jessica S.

description:
Dreadfully disappointing - like watching a beloved relative waste away into a shell of their former self.

By the number of times I've checked in here, you can see that I used to absolutely adore this place. The quirks and inconsistencies used to be tolerable, even cute, because the service was warm and genuine and the food delectable. I had previously had so many lovely experiences at Lahore Karahi, but that era has sadly ended for this Tenderloin dump. If you click Rating Details next to the business address you'll see the steep decline in recent months that other yelpers have also noted.

Upon each visit, more and more basic elements of a properly run restaurant were taken away - the new 'ordering system' demands that customers grab a pad of paper from the entrance podium and write down their request (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/5zKrxtjKK09F_Dwgs5Kxwg?userid=o03ZwIhEEbKLxffxBmcuUw). No number is assigned nor does anyone take the order once you've written it down, so you're really at the mercy of the organization (read: there is none) of the simultaneously frazzled and disinterested servers, who are grossly understaffed. The staff didn't speak to each other and barely acknowledged customers, which was troubling. Owner Guddhu was in the back cooking as usual but seemed completely uninterested in the debacle unfolding in the dining area. 

70 minute wait for even a morsel of food - an acknowledgement or apology + overall terrible experience = no return visits.
author: Kat F.

description:
So, the only reason this place gets four, not five stars is that the food is really spicy, even when you ask for "very mild". I used to work in an Indian restaurant. I like spicy. But holy moly! 

That being said, the food is flavorful, cheap and they have serve your own chai. Some of the best palak paneer I've ever had.
author: Rachel M.

description:
I got a Chicken Tikka Masala and a naan for take out last night.  It was surprisingly cheap! The chicken tikka masala but was really good! The only thing is the location. It was a little ghetto but it should be fine for a quick walk down the street. 

The service was decent.
author: Ashley T.

description:
This is the best indian food I've had in the city! The chicken karahi is unbelievable, and the garlic naan is no joke either. The dishes are actually spicy which is more than I can say for most other places. I can't wait to come back.

I've heard that they have up to two employees, but right now from what I've seen, this is a one man show, so be prepared to wait--but boy, do good things come to those who wait! It seems like any bad reviews here are focused on dinner taking 45 min or more for the food to come out, which I just expect if I'm getting Lahore Karahi...
author: Mike G.

description:
Playing second child to other establishments of the Tenderloin such as Shalimar is Lahore Karahi.

Although the food is rotund, the place is lacking character. The fewer number of people coming to this establishment could be adding to it.

However, when it comes to flavors of the Sind region they are all there.

The spices/the color of food/the sprinkles of raw ginger/the perfect Garlic naan or the oily curry (needed to blend the spice and bring out the flavor) are there in the right amounts and hit the right tone with the customer.

I would like to call out the Sheek kebab to mention that is feels more processed compared to the other places and if you are going for a sheek kebab roll, then this is not the place for it.

I must add a note about the new or the old owners, they are always smiling and very receptive.

There is room for improvement in the Lahore Karahi. I am going with a generous 3 stars!
author: Akshay K.

description:
If you have over an hour to waste after you order the food, you found the right restaurant!  

If you want to get your own plates, water, utensils and WRITE DOWN your order to hand it to the server in the front, you found the right restaurant!

You wait and do all the work to get your food here.  It's self seating and gotta go to the counter to pay as well.  I'm surprised they didn't ask me to cook my own dish and clean the bathroom while waiting.  

One chef in a small open kitchen cooking one order at a time, this place just tests your patience.  Their garlic naan and the chicken tikka masala may have brought all the forgiveness from this impatient fatty (didn't like their fish tandoori however).  It was so authentic and tasty.  Garlic naan was fresh, thin but slightly chewy and went so well with their tikka masala's sauce.  Great pricing as well.
author: Jang David K.

description:
Lahore Karahi has fallen off the tallest pedestal.  I have fought the urge to go back to LK since Guddu sold the restaurant some time ago.  Tonight I gave in and really wish I hadn't.  Aside from ordering for delivery using delivery.com and then getting a call that they didnt have  anyone working that could deliver (umm, I literally live across the street) I found the food no short of disgusting.  No joke.  How can food be bland and spicy at the same time?  Well, it can be.  The butter chicken was in a sauce that looked radio-active and was watery.  The roti was the consistency of naan, the rice was plain white rice with a few slivers of carrot and minimal spice, and the Aloo ghobi had no sauce whatsoever.  And there was no one in the restaurant at 7:30 pm.  There ya go.  What a huge (yet predictable) disappointment.  

The major silver lining to this dark cloud is that thanks to yelp reviewers I now see that Guddu is back in SF and has a new restaurant!  While it's apparently in the middle of nowhere (outer sunset) I will be able to enjoy Guddu's artistry again very soon.  I can almost smell the love of his cooking already!

Steer clear of LK.
author: Lishdish R.

description:
So, they got my order wrong and it took forever to get our food.

My recommendation?

Phone in your order and be open minded about what you get because...

Good god, you will love it.

There was ONE dude back there churning out this EPIC grub and he seemed just giddy to be doing it! It was awesome. Pure passion. It's the Tartine Bakery of Pakistani food.

THE best naan in the city. Trust me.
author: Robert M.

description: Extreamly rude service. Ignores customers and doesn't even speak to them properly. Good food but really bad service.
author: Pasan R.

description:
This place definitely has good food but it is NOT the place to come for a quick lunch. I made the mistake of coming here before a nearby appointment and only giving myself an hour. An hour was not enough. Although there was hardly anyone else in the restaurant, I waited for a very long time to get my meal of rice, naan and chicken tikka masala. 

Again, the food was good, but I only had the chance to eat part of it very quickly before having to get the rest to go -- and I had already pushed back my appointment by 15 minutes. I also found the service a bit awkward and uncomfortable.

There are other good Indian restaurants in the area, so I just didn't think this experience was worth it. I probably won't return. But if you find yourself here you will most likely enjoy your meal! Prices are low, too.
author: Fanny S.

description:
Ok this where the philosophy of "Cheap and Good" comes into play.  It's definitely not for the ambiance or location and service can be a little awkward but they were sincerely welcoming.  

The naan and kulcha was a little dense for my tastes but the quality of the ingredients into all their other dishes, Lamb khorma, chicken vindaloo, kheer and homemade ice cream (off menu) was truly impressive for the price.

Did I mention how nice everyone was?  For the Tenderloin, it's a gem in the rough!
author: Gina K.

description: Lahore Karahi is scheduled to open it's doors again this Thursday! Let us have a warm welcome back for our favorite neighborhood chef!  I can't wait!
author: Mal S.

description:
So good- been in the hood for about 6-7 months now, stumbled upon this place and haven't gone anywhere else for Indian since!! Great food- cheap prices- 
Love it
author: ryan H.

description:
I went with my family last night and we were very much disappointed. 
We had ordered 
Chicken tikka - very dry and no flavor, breast pieces used
Butter chicken - tasted like it was missing something, very bland, breast pieces used
Chicken biryani - good and flavorful, breast pieces used
Reg. naan - it was reg naan
All of my dishes were made with chicken breast.....was not mentioned on the menu!
I asked for it to be spicy...it was not!
We were really hoping for good paki food but instead we got crappy food. 
Service was ok. 
It was my first and last time going there. 
I wish I had read some of recent reviews before going there....
author: Monty D.

description: This is one of the best Indian/Pakistani restaurants in the City and one of the few with a health score above 80. Best for take-out as the place gets jammed and noisy.
author: Albert S.

description:
Still above & beyond the typical indian/pakistani eatery.  Yes, I'm a lil biased. But if you have taste-buds Guddu will surely satisfy them ALL!  Yes, you may have to do self-serve for refills or napkins, but it all balances out once you chow down.

Just stand outside and take in the aromas.  Many props for staying True to the game!!
author: McCracken C.

description:
5 stars for the food, some of the best Pakistani/Northern Indian food I've had in the Bay Area!

I ordered the chicken biryani and saag paneer (both spicy) - one bite of the saag paneer, and I knew I was in for a treat! The food tastes like the chef spent hours preparing it, and I know I'll be coming back next time I crave legit northern Indian food!   

This place has that small, family-owned restaurant charm - friendly service, and the owner seems to be the main chef and cashier. The place seats about 25-30, and offers good serve-yourself chai.
author: Steve L.

description:
I'm loath to give Lahore such a bad rating, but our experience here was just so bad! 

Their system is self-service, so when you walk in, you decide what you want to eat, and then you write your order down yourself and hand it to the cook/waiter. I'm not sure if you're supposed to pay at this point, but we didn't because no one really paid attention to us. I felt lost and ignored, and even the owner didn't bother trying to alleviate our unease because he was so busy filling orders.

The seating is self-seating, too, so we had to wait around for a seat to let up. We went during a super busy time, but they still only had 3 people on staff: two cooks and one waiter/busboy. There were a ton of tables that weren't cleared. When seats finally became available, we bused the dishes of the customers before us ourselves. The water is self-serve, too, but there was chronically no water because the poor busboy didn't have time to refill it. 

We waited an hour for our food. Some of ours came earlier, and by the time they were done, the rest of our food hadn't even come yet. The food itself was very good, but not so good that it balanced out the terrible service.

The entire experience was so stressful. I wish they would just employ and extra person to help out with waiting and busing tables. Maybe I went into it with too high expectations because this was rated so well on Yelp. I won't mind going back again, though, and hopefully my next experience will be better.
author: Jamie C.

description: Small and cozy...and not fancy but delicious. It's all about the food and the food is delicious. Tandoori fish is their specialty and a must with a more than ample portion - get the garlic naan on the side.
author: K S.

description: Finger licking BBQ and a large variety of naan which makes you eat more of it.
author: Marry M.

description:
In an area of San Francisco chock-full of Indian and Pakistani restaurants, this one stands out as my favorite thus far.

I've enjoyed all of the curries I've tried here, from the aloo gobhi to the chicken tikka masala (my personal favorite from here) and the butter chicken curry.  The naan is also top notch -- soft, fluffy and crispy all at the same time -- very delicious and addicting, you'd better make sure you get at least two orders.  The uber popular tandoori fish is pretty tasty as well.
author: Erich D.

description: Do not go here if they are busy! Over 40 minute wait and the food quality will be worse. I got sick and I have a stomach of steel. They do have tasty food though, which is why they are 2 stars rather than 1
author: Ali H.

description: Nice little place and friendly staff. While a lot of people raved about it, I found the food a little bland. The vindaloo wasn't spicy and had no vinegar/sourness to it. The saag paneer was bland; no ginger flavor and needed salt. The price is right but having had food from California and Devon (Chicago's Indian Town) and some of the Indian food in London, I think you can find better in SF.
author: Adrian G.

description:
It took 45 minutes to get our food. It was pretty much the most ridiculous wait I've ever experienced at a restaurant of this format. I can only imagine they were butchering our meat before serving it.

The food wasn't spicy, at all. (yes we asked for it extra, extra spicy) and it came out mild. There is no Lamb on the menu, what's up with that!

The Raita was wronga. 

You'd think the Tandoori chicken would have been good, since it's one of their signature menu sections but you'd be wrong. The chicken had zero flavor and was not served with lemon either.

Maybe we came on a bad day....but it was a really bad day
author: H B.

description:
Everything was fine, food was good until the end of our meal.

One of the restaurant's staff walks in from the street with 4 cans of roach killer.

The other staff proceed to gather around the guy laughing while one of them starts playing around with the roach killer cans, all of this in full view of the patrons! He wasn't spraying, just tossing it around in his hands.

Granted roaches and vermin are inseparable from commercial kitchens, but can one be any less conspicuous?

Then we notice one of the workers adjusting his junk while standing in the kitchen. (Yes he was fully clothed, nothing sexual but entirely inappropriate while serving food!)
author: Ross P.

description:
Came here after the "new owner" conversation so I really didnt know the difference between old and new. Came on a sunday afternoon and found parking right away across the st!

It was 2pm, hardly anyone in there but the place was clean and neat and orderly. There were 2 cooks behind the counter who greeted us upon coming in. From the reviews i expected a REAL hole in the wall bu was surprised to find there were actual tables and chairs and even table side service now.

You still order at the counter but they bring you your food and everything is cooked to order.
The garlic naan came out hot n toasty- just how I like it. I could eat this all day with their curries!

We also had the chicken vindaloo- which is pretty standard and it was really good, + a lamb dish- tasty and the vegetarian dish with the tofu inside (I forgot the name) + basmati rice.

Everything was super delicious, and hot and spicy.

The portions could be bigger for $9 a plate but its perfect for two to get a few dishes to share.

While we were eating, we saw a indian couple pull up in a SL that ran in to get their take out. Hey, if its good for them, then its good for us!

A new indian fav for me in the hood!
author: Petri Y.

description:
Have you ever eaten so much you find it hard to breathe? Okay, maybe you aren't an over eating ogre like me, but yeah, I occasionally do that. Lahore Karahi made me do that. I seriously COULDN'T stop eating. It was sooooo good. After checking out suggestions for good Indian food on Yelp, Lahore seemed like a highly rated place. I made a date with a friend and walked over here with a 6 pack of Stella. Lahore is not in pretty neighborhood but don't let that deter you.

Everything we ate was amazing. I chose two of the items I ordered because there were so many rave reviews on them. I ordered the Tandoori Fish and the Butter Chicken. Both were insanely delicious. The tandoori fish was a little too spicy for me, but I will have you know that I am the biggest wuss in the world when it comes to spice. It was so freakin good I kept eating it though. Maybe next time I will ask if they can make it non spicy. I wanted to swim in the butter chicken sauce. It was that good. Of course, we ordered naan. Mmm, dip your naan in the sauce. Ignore anyone who glares at you for eating with your hands. 

The waiter recommended the saag paneer, which is spinach and cheese. It was off the hook. Seriously. Dip your naan in that too. Oh man, that's what made it hard for me to breathe. I couldn't stop dipping my naan in it. We also got a side of rice. Yeah, that sounds like a lot of food for two girls, but whatever. Lane Bryant here I come.

So, the food is 5 stars fer sher. And at SUCH a great price too!!!! AND you can bring your own beer, wine, etc. Now, I know most everyone else who reviewed this placed warned of a wait for a seat and a wait for your food. It was a Thursday night at about 7:30 and the place was pretty crowded. Honestly, maybe I got really lucky, but I didn't wait at all for a seat and I felt that our food came out at an appropriate pace.  And the waiter was very nice. So 5 stars from me.
author: Liz M.

description: A Pakistani restaurant that acts French.  It took well over an hour for our food to be ready on a Sunday night.  Ridiculous.  But the food was equally ridiculously good.  Oh well.
author: Kristen S.

description:
Big bold flavors, fantastic bread thingies (nan ish)

But Please......none of you noticed the place is disgustingly filthy?

I mean horrible.  Hairs in the menus, counters have food scraps that look to have been there for months, under the side station had not been swept , like EVER.  

Nice guy, tasty food...  if I ever go again I will bring a sponge and a broom.

last health dept. score was 78 with a high risk violation:
014 (CFR) Rodents/Roaches/Flies/Other Animals
author: Christopher F.

description:
Walked up to the door and was greeted by wonderful curry aromas... The menu has all the usual suspects with a good selection of seafood and vegetarian dishes. 
I had the chicken korma (apparently mild) which was quite spicy, huge chunks of chicken, which were a little dry.
My friend had the goat curry, it was delicious and the meat was falling off the bones - there were quite a few bones.
 The naan bread was ok, a little crispy, the meals dont come with rice, so make sure you order it if you want it. Not the kind of place to come for a date! But a good place to satisfy your curry cravings!
author: Wendy C.

description:
Hands down one of the best Indo-Pak joints in the city.  The owner, Guddu Bhai, is a phenomenal chef and host.  He is OCD about the quality of his food and has a militant ownership of the cooking responsibilities.  I can respect that.

While all the dishes are amazing my favorite is the Tandoori Fish.  I've never had anything like it except at home.  It is unique to the sea of south asian restaurants and really makes LK stand out.   

The lamb biryani, tandoori chicken, and other standard items are also far and beyond other places in the area.  The food is meticulously seasoned and not too greasy.  

As the other reviewers have noted, this place is packed and takes some time (he cooks your food fresh) - but is well worth it.
author: Aasim K.

description:
Downsides first: this placed is always packed, and it takes quite a bit of time to order (took about twenty minutes yesterday, then another twenty to be served). That said, every food critic and their mothers have given this place glowing reviews, and I can see why. 

First, the owner/chef is tremendously friendly, and while I'll usually just assume have terrible service if the food is dynamite, the food is great on top of the service. So bonus points there.

Secondly, as mentioned a second ago, the food is awesome. The naan is made fresh right there in front of you, and while there other Pakistani/Indian places nearby with great naan as well, this tastes much more authentic and less greasy. Plus, most of the other restaurants use pre-made naan and just heat it up. Boo on them.

The lamb korma and tikka masala are wicked good - and spicy! The owner asks up front how hot you like your food, so if you tend to wake up in a cold sweat from nightmares of chili peppers, not to fear.

The rice has a great blend of spices too, where usually similar restaurants make it plain, and everything is bundled up nicely if you decide to eat on the go.

Side note: we were the last customers in the restaurant to order yesterday, and the owner insisted that I try one of the (delicious) Indian pilsners, on the house. I insisted on paying back, and he doubled-down on the insisting-niceness poker game. Good beer, better because of the service.

Anyways, I could say more, but if you're reading this far into my review, it's a safe bet that your either thoroughly bored with nothing to do and ready and willing to try it out yourself. If you do, you're in for a treat.
author: Drew V.

description: I definitely come here for their Seekh Kabab, which comes in ground lamb mixed with herbs and spices and is grilled and placed on skewers. Prices here are very affordable, and is worth the taste and flavors with every bite.
author: Krystal S.

description:
If you claim to be an Indian/Pakistani restaurant then it is is imperative to get the biryani right, period. 
The biryani served here is pakki biryani (as opposed to kachi). It takes considerable amount of expertise to get kachi biryani right. The first spoonful of the biryani had a strong taste of unwashed rice. It is good not to wash the rice to retain the nutrients but this left a strong unpleasant taste. Also, the best chicken biryani is made with all parts of chicken, the dark meat tastes the best. The version here was just made with breast meat. Biryani typically has multiple layers of flavors but they used an overdose of green chillies rendering the dish singular flavored and extremely spicy.

Barring the biryani, the other dishes we ordered-chicken karahi, kheema naan, garlic naan were pretty reasonable.
author: Minu M.

description:
Reviewing Lahore is hard... What can I say that hasn't been said before? Well, this place is tied with its around-the-corner neighbor Shalimar for the #1 Indian/Pakistani food in the Tenderloin. As has been said (many, many times), the place is tiny and the service is about what you'd expect from one server and a ton of people packed into a tiny room.  But it's all worth it for the food.

The food, man, the food. Don't come to Lahore for curries; come to Lahore for their Tandoor. The Lamb Boti here may be my favorite preparation of meat anywhere. It's succulent; well-cooked without being dry, just perfect. I try to always come here with at least one other person so that we can get a bunch of stuff to maximize the variety in my supper, because pretty much everything on the menu is amazing. If you really feel hungry, grab some Samosas as an appetizer, because they're awesome.

If it weren't for the tiny dining room, insufficient number of servers, and slightly sketchy neighborhood at night, this would be a 5. As it stands, consider this on the high end of a 4.

Mmm!
author: James B.

description:
Great place. We went a while back, and would go again.
But be prepared for a wait.
The place is small and the owner cooks all the food himself and had
one person helping him - on a Saturday night. 
Shalimar is better at most dishes, but the karhai here is better, and the tandoori fish is the best I have had.
author: Basil M.

description:
Spicy flavor-packed deliciousness! Lamb vindaloo, butter chicken, veggie biryani, 2 orders of naan, 2 orders of mango lassi, free chai tea and water...all of this for three people for $30! It would have been more had they not forgotten the fish tandoori -- we were disappointed in that since it's their specialty and neither of us had tried it before. Oh well...we'll save it for the next visit! 

We experienced all the negatives that previous reviewers had mentioned from the long wait(s), slow service, and being dive bombed by roaches - literally...apart from the ones crawling on the walls, one dropped down on my arm from above. The food truly trumps every fault you can find with this place. It's so good. And the long wait/slow service can be forgiven considering that the owner is the sole cook, and he was only being helped by one waiter. The two of them were simultaneously taking orders (both dining in and take out), and prepping stuff in the kitchen. Amazing, really.

Bring the people here whose company you most enjoy cause you'll have plenty of talk time!
author: Elaine W.

description:
Christ!! Absolutely the best Pakistani/Indian food I've EVER HAD!

The garlic naan is delicious and it's made from scratch. I also had the tikka masala which was also gloriously tasty and spicy. The chef/owner is very generous with the portions and friendly.

But friends, the tandoori fish was off the fucking chain, yo! Maybe it's because I was drunk when I first walked in, but this place was unlike any I have ever been before. 

I highly recommend it just for the fish.
author: Charlie A.

description: If you love the taste of heavy cream, you'll love Lahore Karahi.
author: Josie C.

description:
This place is the definition of a hole in the wall which is my fav type of restaurant.  Screw foo-foo, forget about chains, it's all about these under the radar joints.

Lahore Karahi is in the TL so a few things that probably suck is finding parking on the street, walking passed a dirty ass hooker, crackheads talking to themselves, and the hustlers at the corner of the block.  All good though.  You mind your own business, they do the same.  It's all about respect in this neighborhood.

The restaurant has changed in that they don't have a waiter taking your order.  You get to be host/waiter/waitress by writing down your order and finding the next available table.  Oh yeah, it's BYOB so don't forget to bring your favorite drink.  They have pitchers of water for those that need it.

I gotta give it up to the owner/chef.  He's a one man cooking machine!  Homeboy is the only one cooking food so you can't be mad if you're waiting a while for the food.  The other two assistants are there to cook anything in the tandoori oven and serve up the customers.

I have never been disappointed with the food here.  Everything is awesome and each dish has a unique taste with different levels of flavor which stimulate all the taste buds in your mouth.  The prawn vindaloo is delicious.  Prawns are juicy, the sauce is a bit sour and has some aromatics in there that just makes it the perfect combination of flavors.  You can't go wrong with the curries such as the Chicken Tiki Masala or Butter Chicken.  All of them are a bit thick, slightly sweet and the curry is perfect for dipping the Garlic Naans.

I'll stop yapping now.  You get the point.  This place is good...
author: Suzi K.

description:
Not sure what the big deal is but most of the food that I try here isn't that great. I really want to like this place because I haven't found my favorite Indian place in the city yet.

The lamb biryani is really dry. I need to keep drinking water while eating it. The chicken karahi is not bad, but a bit too salty. The garlic naan is thin and too crispy. Omg, I think Trader Joes' garlic naan tastes better.

The tandoori chicken however tastes really good, as most people point out. I haven't tried the tandoori fish yet, maybe I'll come back some other time just to try that one dish.
author: Novalina N.

description:
A new place to grab some great Indian food! My brother wanted to try this place out so him, my sis and I came here for lunch today before I had to go work. The place was really empty and the gate was still half closed so we thought it was not open. But then the owner came out and it was open. He apparently was the only person working so the food took a little longer then expected.

Free Chai! YAY! Love it. So we ordered our usual food. 
Vegetable Pakora : Mixed vegetable fritters
Chicken tikka masala : Chicken in mild & creamy tomato curry sauce
Buttered chicken : Chicken cooked in creamy tomato sauce
chicken biryani : Saffron basmatic rice w/ chicken & nuts
Plain nann, garlic nann, potato nann

Wayy too much food for 3. I have no clue why we order chicken tikka and butter chicken when they're both the same thing. He warned us but we went for it anyways. Oh wells. The chicken tikka masal had pistachios on top! First time seeing it served like that but it went well with the dish. Tasted delish. Both the chicken tikka masala and buttered chicken tasted the same but we still enjoyed it. I like how it's not like Naan and Curry's sauce. Naan and Curry seem to have more heavy cream in their recipe and this one is more Authentic like. The vegetable pakora was good too but wayy oily... It is fried so yea. Chicken biryani? Good but spicy. I'm becoming so slow with food terms, I didn't even know med is spicier then mild. How lame. So I had to drink tons of water after each bite of food!

The owner/chef was super nice and made sure everything was good and that we enjoyed it. He even offered dessert but I was too full to actually except it..

Cheap good authenic Indian food is the best!!! Oh, and I didn't smell like spices coming out of the restaurant!
author: Juliane N.

description: i'm torn about this place - some of the items we ordered were delicious (lamb boti kebob), others were barely mediocre (chicken karahi, CTM, garlic naan)...my friend and i paid about $45 for everything, which was quite a bit more than we realized since the place is one of those whole-in-the-wall-probably-known-because-its-open-late places. anyway, i've def had better south asian food in the city and will probably not be back.
author: Asmita J.

description: Wouldn't repeat. Not that the food and service weren't good.  There are better indian restaurants in SF.
author: Ali B.

description:
Lahore Karahi is my coworkers & my favorite lunch spot for Indian cuisine in the Tenerloin / Civic Center area.  Most of the dishes range between $4-$7 & it's best ordered family style. There's one cook and one helper so service is a bit slow.  It takes roughly 30 min for the food to be served .  Our order today: 

-(*)Vegetable Pakora
-(*)Chicken Tiki Masala
-Lamb Korma
-Butter Chicken
-Curried Beef
-Plain Naan
-Onion Naan
-(*)Garlic Naan
-(*)Mango Lassi

(*) = Favorites (You really can't go wrong with any of their dishes)

Self service: water, utensils, dishes, tea, to-go boxes
author: Stacey L.

description:
Absolutely the best Indian food, one of the best place for food.

After one hour of wait, we finally got our "Chicken Tiki Masala".  First bite draws the blood, this is the best Indian food I have tasted in the entire country.'

I hate this restaurant sometimes, it has set the bar so high that every time I eat at other Indian restaurant I feel there are something missing.  This place reminds of that episode "Soup Nazi" from Seinfield show :)
author: Peter M.

description: do not eat here! bugs and rats invested! disgusting restaurant saw cock roaches crawling all over the kitchen and the services tables. i do not recommend this place to my worst enemy! its a health hazard! if your waiting on food poisoning you came to the right place!
author: Victoria S.

description:
I don't remember what those dishes were called, and I'm not going to bother trying. They were all good. All of them. If I were to recommend something, I would say chicken tikka masala and garlic naan. But there were lots more, rather, all of them more. Please ask someone who is good at describing Pakistani food because all I can say is, "yes, and again." The wait is annoying, but worth it, and for some reason, I don't feel the after-indian-food urges, which is a great sign.

Go again? Why yes!
author: Ellenor L.

description:
BYOB and write up your own order! My friend decided on Lahore and Karahi and opted to even bring the wine and beer. Grabbing a free table, hellos were exchanged and foolishly we didn't realize we had to write out own menu, good thing we caught it early on and the person with the most legible handwriting wrote up the menu. 

Wait time for our food was longer than expected, but we did read how there is one chef making everyone's order so good conversation mixed with alcohol helped pass the time.

Samosas were a good bite but wasn't as crispy as I wanted them to be.

Garlic naan took awhile to get to our table, and luckily we got them in two separate intervals so the second batch was fresh and warm...yumm...

Butter Chicken - Tandoori chicken pieces cooked in a creamy/buttery sauce was just perfect to scoop up with the garlic naan. 

Lamb looked and smelled amazing, but I couldn't have any at the time, but the general comment was it had a nice strong spicy kick to it. 

Eggplant was a nice change of pace to our palates, by means of nonmeat, but it was good and spicy as well, so I found myself sucking down on water by the end of the night. 

Parking can be atrocious in the Tenderloin if you opt to find a free meter after hours. Décor was nothing special, and felt cramp most times, but for the food we received and the experience we got, I'll gladly suffer anytime. Food overall had a nice spicy taste so be warned for those who don't like spicy food, but the flavor hits the mark and that's all I could ever hope for. Make sure to grab a free table or prepare to wait, write your own menu, and grab a bottle to help lighten the mood. Yes, prepare to wait if you don't see a free table, and the food will come out relatively slow if there is a packed house.
author: Casey L.

description:
How convenient that one of the best Indian/Pakastani eateries is named "The Whore" and its located in the Tenderloin... lol

I also don't understand how India and Pakistan hate each other, yet it seems like every Indian restaurant in SF also highlights their Pakistani cuisine... Interesting....

Enough of the international political mumbo jumbo...

This is one of the few places I've gone that serves Indian food the way it was meant to be served-spicy and grease free. 

I can't tell you what to order simply because I can't pronounce 99% of the items on the menu. So all you need to know is just order a chicken dish; a veggie dish; some naan bread (garlic i would recommend) and a rice dish and you'll be fine. And be sure to grab some nice pipping hot Indian milk tea to wash it all down...after you poured about 20 packs of sugar into it.

One word of warning: This place gets packed real quick. Especially at lunch and during certain evenings.

And, as usual, due to the smokey nature of the naan bread making process, the "smell of India" will follow you after you leave... lol
author: Black K.

description: By far one of my favourite Indian-Pakistan restaurants in San Francisco. Even though this place uses lots of food coloring, the taste is on point! Gotta try the Chicken Tikka Masala and Mango Lassi!
author: Brandon T. L.

description:
We really loved the flavors of everything but of the four dishes we ordered, two were wrong and it may be because we were there late last night, after 10 p.m. And he ran out of BENGAN BHARTIIA - And pawned the plain daal on us.  We think our garlic naan went to wrong table so we got the sesame naan towards end of meal

The lamb boti was very good, but take it off the sizzling plate as soon as it arrives at your table because it quickly over cooks and inedible (took remainder home to our dogs)

Our favorite was the saag panner.  The mango lassi was weird.

I don't know if we will ever go back because the whole process of writing your order and getting all the plates and drinks in a cramped smoky setting was not worth it to us.  Even though the other diners were fun and friendly and asking about what we ordered.

It is the best of all the Pakistani restaurants in the area, we usually alternate among all of them

  But trying to sneak wrong dishes leaves a bad vibe.......
author: Foodlover B.

description:
I get it.

Ah....so every Indian/Pakistani restaurant I went to before  - didn't really matter? Not one bit?!

Not once you've found the one.

When you've found the Indian restaurant that can bring out 6 different meals, each one tasting distinctively different. Distinctively tasty. Distinctively divine.

That is true Lahore Love.

When you can go with a group of people, and order so many things that you can barely make out the outline of the table. From fish, to buttered chicken, to saag panner, to tikka masala, to chicken korma....

That is true Lahore Love.

When you can't even take another bite. Can't even look at any more food, and your hanes are having a hard time keeping in all of the Lahore-ness bulging over your pants.

That is true Lahore Love.

When the bill finally comes, and you're getting nervous just trying to imagine how much, as you scan the food covered table. And it's no more than 12 dollars each. And apparently that's expensive for Lahore.

That is true Lahore Love.

When you're wheezing in your bed, Feeling faint. Feeling feverish, and you reheat your Lahore leftovers and are reminded of the spicy, wondrous meal a week earlier.

That is true Lahore Love.

If you're ready to take the plunge and ready to part ways with all of the other naans, the other tiki masalas....journey to the tenderloin.

Keep your taste-buds and stomach open for some...

True Lahore Love.
author: Jessica T.

description:
This used to be a 5-star restaurant when chef/owner "Guddu" was around.  Guddu's magic touch left with him.  Now its just another ordinary Indo-Pak place.
I went in not knowing that Guddu had sold the restaurant - but at the end of my first bite of food I knew!  When asked, the cashier pretended that he didn't know of any ownership change in the restaurant.  I googled and found out immediately!
author: Prabs P.

description:
On Sunday night 10 of us stuffed ourselves silly with tandori fish, chicken tikka masala, vegetable pakora, aloo keema, vegetable biryani, chicken kabab and naan. I worked the menu out directly with Guddu at the counter. My only regret? Forgetting to order the aloo tikki!

All told (with tax and a 25% tip) the meal cost us $127. Holy bargain!

Lahore's BYOB and yes we did! Tip: Anchor Steam beer pairs well with this food and is available at the bodega across the street.
author: Miriam W.

description:
What a great little find - sketchy neighborhood, but once inside you forget all about that and just enjoy the hussle and bustle of the restaurant.  Self service really means self service - you write up your own order ticket then wait for a table.

Once you finally get a table you can relax and wait for your order.  The food is flavorful - good value at a reasonable price. Not super hot temperature wise but still good.

This is a great place to meet friends if you want a casual, inexpensive meal, and your are not in a hurry.  Definitely an enjoyable experience.

Oh, the free chai tea while you wait is a nice added touch.  And the owner/cook is very friendly, seems to really enjoy what he's doing and takes the time to say hi to the customers.
author: Gina C.

description:
Best in the TL.

Yes I said it.  Just when I finished my review of Chutney and having dissed on Pakwan, I'm proclaiming Lahore the designated favorite of the TL.  However....the only thing is that I didn't notice a lot of people BYOB, so I'm still puzzled to whether its allowed or not....

We had the following:
-Garlic naan - so much buttery garlic goodness.  It's like garlic noodles but with naan
-Potato naan - pretty good
-Serree Paneer - Good flavor
-Tiki masala - if you looked at our plate you wouldn't kno what we had since every last drop was scooped up 
-Prawn Biryani - great flavor n spice with the rice
author: Vincent K.

description:
And I thought Shalimar was unbeatable...
Was I wrong...
It was truly a phenomenal experience, from the naans to the tandoor fish and the intriguing complexity of the biryani. Nothing greasy, everything packed with intense perfumes and flavors. 
You guys have a new regular.
author: Dario B.

description:
http://blogs.kqed.org/checkplease/2010/05/20/lahore-karahi-restaurant-info/

WATCH this man and MEMORIZE his face!  Do NOT eat here if this dude isn't cooking your food!
If he is, you're in awesome hands :)
If not, prepare for the shits.  For realz yo.
author: Meh M.

description:
If you haven't packed enough clothes for your 10 day trip in SF and plan on repeating outfits this probably isn't the restaurant for you.  My clothes from last night's dinner at Lahore Karahi absolutely reek of Indian food...guess I won't be wearing those again on this trip!

Lahore Karahi was worth the smelly clothes!  By far the best Indian food I've enjoyed in a long time (or perhaps ever!).  Miriam W did the honor of ordering for our party of 10 so I had no idea what was coming out to our table.  I had a bit of everything and it was all fabulous (well besides the tandori fish...didn't like that one!). Some favorites included a ground beef dish, garlic naan, and the sesame naan. Can you tell I love my naan?

Oh, and BYOB too- an added bonus to make up for the smelly clothes!
author: Andrea R.

description: Roaches!!! The food, while decent, is clearly hurt by the roaches that crawl around the windows and onto the tables. The waiter thought it reasonable to kill the roach with a napkin after we left the table b/c of the roach,  thinking we wouldn't notice. After seeing our disgust with the process and restaurant itself, he then proceeded to take $7 off out $27 meal. $7. Note: the water is undrinkable, similar to tap water in Karachi and Lahore. Oh, and the waiter had some sort of bag end wrapped around his finger, I guess due to a cut. Anyways, sanitary nightmare.
author: Michael F.

description:
This place is somewhere that is all about the food. If your in search of ambiance, and great service (if at all) then don't expect to find it at Lahore Karahi. The owner/chef is full of smiles and is eager to engage his customers in friendly conversation. Everything made here is all home made from what I can tell, and the food is outstanding, and very reasonably priced:

Vegetable Samosas... 2 Large, flaky, aromatic boys for $3
Tikka Masala... Not your run of the mill same old shit, traditional and un-real! $ 7.50
Lamb Korma... Succulent and tender pieces of lamb in a zesty curry only $7.50
Saag Paneer... So far the best spinach and cheese ive ever had. $7
Garlic Naan... He was kneading fresh balls of dough as he made ours fresh... $2.50
Basmati Rice... Somehow this rice stood out all on its own among great dishes... $2

Bottom line... $30 for a meal that would probably cost at least double this much at any other of the so called "traditional" indian joints here in the city. Expect to find good food at a great price with a very casual and laid back atmosphere at Lahore.
author: Kevin D.

description: OMG!! we sat there and ordered our food and all of a sudden we see a big ass cockroach walking all over the table and menus! It was disgusting and we just left!! I can't believe this happened! They need to take care of this ASAP!!
author: Zuhra L.

description:
I was so glad when I got the e-mail from Megan L. that she was 

a) in town for once (despite her jet-setter/globe trotting lifestyle) 
b) available for dinner that night. 

This was quite an occasion. We knew we wanted something earthy, good and rich. Not that we don't like American/Californian, we do, but not tonight. Tonight calls for something special. Something more comforting and hearty. Finally it's settled w/ a coupon and we go to Lahore Karahi in the Tenderloin. 

The first thing I notice is how packed the place is on a Wednesday. Eclectic crowd of hipsters, business men/women, first/last dates. I'm confident that this place has earned it's reputation. 

I completely forget the decor except for the awards/accalades wallpapering the place; "The best of....", "People Love us on....", "Must have the.......". I get excited as I read the menu and wait. 

The menu...oh the menu! Unbelievably cheap. Most of the entrees for less than 8 bucks and each comes is a shareable portion. Or someone could "splurge" and get a $12 seafood special (amazing). Quick tip: come here for take out and go home to portion it out to at least 2 meals (I would eat them in 4 meals). They take card, but the minimum is $15. Food was made to order. We had the chicken tikka and lamb vindaloo. Everything was tender and juicy w/ the right amount of spice. We left stuffed and happy. 

I will definitely come back for another healthy serving of Indian goodness. Hopefully w/ a larger group to share more plates.
author: Angelo F.

description:
Two months from my first review, these jerks are STILL selling gift certificates they won't honor on Restaurant.com.

Suck a cockroach.
author: Whitney W.

description:
DIRTY!
Should have walked back as soon as i got out of car and saw the locality. Not a good place to have a restaurant. The food was really OK, you can definitely find lot lot better Indian restaurant in SFO. Have a plain burger or pizza but don't find any excuse to visit this place. There are lot other Indian restaurants in SFO with great food, friendly people and CLEANER cutlery.

PLEASE GO ELSEWHERE!!!
author: Prasen P.

description:
Great food. Love the flavors. Best garlic roti. My fingers smell like garlic. Worth it. 

The free chai was a nice surprise. I will be coming back.
author: Raj L.

description:
You come here and this place just looks hectic. You got people all over  cramped up on the tables. You got waiters running around with sizzling plates of Indian/Pakistani food infusing the air and also your clothes. The   smell and smoke makes me feel like I am in an Indian bazaar and somewhat at place with the hectic nature of this place.

The food is great. Like you would expect, the food is very aromatic and flavors pack a punch. In addition to the typical Naan and curry they also have other more unique dishes. All the food taste really authentic and differentiated from other restaurants. The only suggestion I would make is throw some more meat on to the plates which look more like soups with all the sauce. Other than that, keep "hot boxing" the joint with flavors of the sub-continent.
author: Ed L.

description:
Fascinating place. Super nice staff. Super delicious food. Long ass wait. 

Worth it. 

Also, cheap. :)
author: Alex T.

description:
Honestly... it's just not the same when Miriam's not at the helm with ordering.  Even if I can execute flawless decisions on what to order (and let's be honest, could one go wrong here?), Guddu will never love me the way that he loves Ms. W.

Still, I'm like a moth drawn to the flame when it comes to visiting San Francisco and our hotel's proximity to Lahore Karahi.  As much as I know it's going to be a long wait, a gritty dive, a walk through a sketchy neighborhood with countless addicts and panhandlers, and an achingly full belly... I can't avoid it.  It's like a siren song to my inner sailor.

If you know nothing else, know this: the tandoori fish will be the most delicious, flaky, sizzling thing you are likely to ever have in your mouth.  Ever.
