Oh... and if you're looking for raita, you may have to beg, plead, and offer up your first-born.  And it'll be completely worth every last itty-bitty finger and toe.

NB: Apparently Lahore -still- doesn't have its BYO goodness back.  We -were-, however, politely offered their nice sidewalk outside to imbibe an adult beverage, as long as we didn't bring it indoors.  As kla$$y as that may have been, we politely declined.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Truly one of the best Lahori cuisine in Sf!  Coming from San Jose This has been our 4th times eating here. And in every visit, we always come to appreciate this place as having the authenticity of Pakistani cuisine.

Seekh kebab - succulent and complex mixed of spices 
fish tandoori - chef's specialty - spicy, flavorful, and scrumptious (quite rare in pakistani cuisine)
lamb biryani - complex, nutty, tangy, smokey 
butter chicken - rich, nutty, creamy
Lahore rice - nice blend of flavored rice cooked on karahi
Tandoori roti - simple all purpose traditional unleavened bread 
garlic naan - crispy, smokey and garlicky simplicity 

This place is a treasure!
author: Daidan J.

description:
Excellent Indian food and the bill won't leave a dent in your wallet!  The Chicken Tikka Masala (classic English dish, haha) was full of buttery goodness, Lamb Korma had a nice kick.  The daal was tasty, and the Saag Paneer was good but wished there was a bit more cheese.  The mango lassi was yum.  The service was very friendly, great local atmosphere considering you're smack in the heart of the Tenderloin.
Luckily the car was still intact after the meal.
author: Don S.

description: Followed the advice of some other Yelpers and had the Chicken Tikka Masala and garlic naan. It will haunt my dreams.
author: Garet M.

description:
Felt kind of stupid when my friends and I came here. We ordered a few plates and only a couple naan thinking that our plates included rice. We later had to just add more and more stuff as we ate. 

We didn't order that Tandori fish as everyone said we should. We ended up getting a couple of the spicy lamb plates with an amazing butter chicken. The foods are real authentic and prices are not bad, no wonder there are lines on Fridays and Saturdays.

For those who bought the Restaurant.com coupon, don't. They don't accept them. Waste of your time and your money.
author: M C.

description: perfect and amazing and hassle free
author: Ariel R.

description:
My Chicken Tikki Masala was.... chunky??? And my eggplant veggie dish tasted like... overdone stew???

I was very sad. I wanted to like this place and I had high hopes given all the great reviews, but this place just didn't cut it for me or my friends. All the dishes were just kind of bland... the best things were the naan and the rice. But even then I prefer my rice more flavorful and my naan more fluffy (they had crispier naan). Service was not very attentive either. We tried to get the server's attention for water for a bit, until we finally gave up and dragged our feet over to the fridge to get our own pitcher. Won't be coming back here...
author: Joanne Y.

description:
Somehow despite my addiction to Yelp, it escaped my notice that (a) this restaurant is basically a one-man operation, not counting a couple of guys who help prep and clean up, and (b) they currently don't have a server and supposedly only offer food to go. Sorry if I'm repeating things other people have said, but this was a surprise to me. (Slap to my forehead.)

That said, almost everyone who came in still sat down for their meal, and the owner/chef was indeed as charismatic and gifted as everyone has said. We walked in at 5:30pm on Sat and were literally the only ones in the restaurant, but were glad to have gotten our food before the throngs arrived. The wait for food seemed to get longer and longer the later people arrived. It was indeed all very tasty and fresh, and we left happy.
author: Jen Y.

description: excellent. as good as any in the South Bay.  perfect CTM. not too oily and still creamy.  naan fresh and delicious.  aloo palak tasty. tilapia fish grilled in the tandoori oven, soft and perfectly seasoned.  the chicken leg was slightly lighter seasoning than I had at other places
author: Rob C.

description: I live across the street, and have come to Lahore Karahi often through the years. I'm sorry to say that the cooks who seem to have taken over the place have turned it into a real disappointment. Without fail, every take-out order I have placed in the past month and a half has either contained a substitution for something I've ordered (without prior notification of the need to substitute) or be completely missing an item. Absolutely unacceptable! I can't ever go back.
author: N. L.

description:
HOPELESSLY HOPELESS. Thats what comes to my mind when I think of this restaurant. 
We went twice, and both the times the food served was horrible. I am an indian and I know how the indian / Pakistani food should taste, but what they served was far away from rich indian / pakistan flavor.
Once upon a time, it used to be one of the best indian restaurant in SFO ,when previous owner who was from Pakistan ran it. Ever since he left  this establishment,  its food  only deteriorated  with time. 

We ordered for extra spicy, it was served spiceless, naan was half burnt , paneer had only water and red colour and all this is after waiting for half an hour.

I will not recommend this to anyone who enjoys or wants to try India/ Pakistani cuisine. It will take you quite far away from what exactly the cuisine tastes.

The one and only thing eatable was Mixed Veg Pakodas (Indian Fritters) and thats why I have given them 1 star else its a zero star establishment.
author: Neha S.

description: Bread and rice were good   fresh. But the lamb and okra was very dry    feel like it could have been in a little sauce.  Flavor was cool.  Maybe I ordered wrong thing
author: Joe G.

description:
Delicious food in perfect portions, wonderful owner, inexpensive, no frills interior, decent bathrooms, well lit, and small. Diamond in the TL.
Minuses: the wait, which in my experience can be from 10-30 mins. In the end, a small price to pay.
author: Rose H.

description:
I had high expectations for this place, considering it had 730 reviews and a solid 4 stars at the time I went.

I will never go back.

The cockroaches in the bathroom were disgusting.
The waiter forgot my order.
I had to ask him about it at least five times before he said he would "go tell the cook."
I finally got my order as everyone else at my table was getting ready to leave.
The waiter walked by our table every two minutes for half an hour but didn't take our bill.  We had to finally flag him down, which was surprisingly difficult.  (Was he trying to ignore us?)

It was the worst service I've ever had.

The food was decent, but no better than something like Naan and Curry, and at Naan and Curry it's clean and they don't make you wait for more than an hour because of their own incompetence.
author: Allison B.

description:
I know nearly 700 other reviews beg to differ, but I felt compelled to write this review because it baffles the hell out of me why this place would have such great reviews! You might think, "Oh, she's just one of those bitter, angry Yelpers" or "She just wants to play the devil's advocate," but neither of those are true. Check out my other reviews. I love to LOVE places. I wanted to love Lahore Karahi, but I just couldn't. 

When we arrived, every table was covered in the remnants of what other people had finished eating. They did not seat us right away - in fact I got so confused I had to go up and ask the guy working there if we should just seat ourselves. He told us yes, so we seated ourselves at a dirty table piled with dishes, which he cleaned up as we sat down. The food itself was way too salty, and to top it off, lackluster. The fish was an oily salty mess that made our stomachs hurt for hours, and the vegetarian curry tasted like a brown bowl of salt. 

I don't understand why people like this place so much. Now I'm not trying to be a hater, but there was a dying cockroach wiggling around on the edge of the table as we tried (and failed) to enjoy our meal. I won't be back.
author: Michelle G.

description:
Shatangi has been meaning to try this place for over two years. I live right across the street but had not ventured inside. Inspired by Marsha Z's review. I got take out last night. The ordering process was easy. The food was ready when I got there and I was greeted three times by a very kind and enthusiastic staff including the owner (very rare in my hood). For $12 I left with way more food than I had expected. My lamb vindaloo had a weird tangy, tamarind like flavor that was good albeit a bit strange. The spiciness was perfect and the meat and taters cooked perfectly. The rice was great and onion kulcha was pretty darn good with it's subtle onion stuffing. I plan to try again this weekend. Sincere service and good food alway keep me coming back.

Update 04/25/06 OMTS!! I just had lunch there for the first time. Took my contractor out to discuss a project. The owner was as friendly as ever and convinced my contractor to try the tandoori fish. What a hit!!
 
Shatangi told you
author: Njon W.

description:
I would give this place more stars if I could---it's THAT good.

Everything I have ever ordered here has been solid, and more. And when i mean more, I mean the dishes are aggressive with spice. Definitely not for those with zero tolerance for heat, and definitely for those who want a little challenge with their tastebuds. 

I usually order the butter chicken EXTRA spicy--it's absolutely amazing. You can see the whole kernels of spices wading in the thick, rich curry sauce and the chicken is always plump, juicy, and abundant. Pair that with the pillowy, naan that's usually basted with oil and can you say SENSORY overload? lol. No, really, another religious experience is had to be found here. 

Other no-nonsense delicious picks: tandoori lamb chops, saag paneer, tikka masala, matter paneer....but I'm sure everything will be a hit. I heard through the grapevine that the fish tandoori is to die for.

And I love the food so much that even gripes in servicing cant lower my rating. Check this: I made the trip over to Lahore last night at about 9:30. Apparently the usual server (who is a spritely and awesome young man, i might add) couldn't make it and they had a server/busser working on the fly. it took about 45 minutes to get my order in and another 30 to get my food. I might have calculated the whole ordeal to be a 2 hour meal, but I definitely utilized the BYOB rule and enjoyed the waiting game nonetheless.

GO HERE NOW!
author: Katie O.

description:
Better than Shalimar? Nah I don't think so. 
Don't come here if you're in a hurry or if you're starving because the food takes forever. I thought it was because there's only one chef in the kitchen but when you're the only table being served you have to wonder why it's taking SOOOOOO long?

The good news is that the food is very tasty and the ingredients are fresh. I especially like the Chicken Karahi dish -- a great blend of tomatoes, bell peppers, spices and pieces of chicken breast (my favorite)! I also recommend the Chikkar Cholay (puree of garbanzo beans). It reminds me of haleem minus the meat.

Overall solid 3.5 stars!
author: Helen Y.

description:
Was being driven by a taxi to my hotel andnoticed that this placed was packed for dinner.  My friend and I visited during lunch the next day.  We shared the chicken boti lamb boti and an eggplant-pea dish.  For $2 you get a large pile of rice that could easily feed 3.  The meat was succulent but the eggplant dish was total crack.  I am not a veggie type but that eggplant, I could eat at least once a week.

In spite of prior reviews I found their service fine.  You go up to the counter after reviewing the menu at a table.  They bring you the food.  When done, go back to the counter and ask for the check then pay.
author: A A.

description:
Happy to report, Lahore Karahi is back up to 5 stars... Went here last night for the first time in too long of a while, and was reminded why I fell in love with it. Although sad to learn that they no longer allow you to BYOB, Lahore Karahi's food is as good, if not better, than ever.

A few tips:

1) There may be a wait. It's worth it.

2) Order some tandoori something. Might want to bring a ventilator though. This is a small restaurant and it gets very smoky. We were cracking up at the round of coughs every time a dish came out of the tandoor. Again, it's worth it.

3) Be prepared to have your order screwed up. The service here, though amiable, is a bit clumsy. Expect to have your rice arrive about 10 minutes after your curry. Expect at least one thing to be forgotten. Be prepared to gently remind your server about that raita you ordered, at least 2x. It's all part of the experience, and yes, it's worth it.
author: Brian H.

description:
Insanely delicious food. The sauces are so flavorful and fresh tasting, the meat is fall-apart tender and the biryani perfectly spiced. But I just can't ignore the 3 cockroaches we saw crawling on the wall right by our table at dinner the other night. The owners are super nice, but the service is also terribly slow. 

Delicious food, marred by slow service and cockroaches.
author: Julia G.

description: The 3 of us got there around 6:20, so no problem parking right in front & not real busy. We ordered garlic naan, lamb curry, lamb chops, & tandoori chicken. The food took a while, but the guy who took our order did say it would take 15 min, more like 30! But that was ok, they allow you to have free chai tea. Anyways, the 2 lamb dishes were very tasty, the chicken a little dry, the basmati rice yummy, & the naan a generous portion. If we go back, but I won't order the tandoori chicken again. Tip included, I paid $63! Kinda a lot for a whole in the wall, and don't lean on the walls!! Saw a roach crawling on it!! Saw Tycoon Thai right next door...looked much cleaner!
author: susan w.

description: I've had a range of experiences here - the food is TERRIFIC, but over the years the service has been up and down.  When it's super busy, the wait can be crazy long (I've waited 2 hours before which was really too long, but that was a few years ago).  Nowadays seems like the service is much improved and the food is still good. I'm not sure if they changed management a few years ago - the prices are more than they were before, but it's good food so that's ok with me.
author: Y L.

description:
Done lunch, dinner, takeout. This place is really good and the people who work here are nice and friendly. Service is fast too. While you're waiting there is plenty of tea to sip on. 

Background music, good ambiance, happy days.
author: Dilip R.

description:
Won't call this the hands-down best indian food in the city anymore.
The new owner seems nice, and he will probably figure things out in due time, but the food is no longer as amazing as it was in guddu's time.
Now this is just another indian restaurant in the city.. I might eat here if I am in the vicinity, but probably won't go out of my way to come here or bring friends over here.
The menu seems slightly altered (no more aloo matter), the to-go containers and portion-sizes seem to have changed..
The new owner should either try to be an exact copy of the old lahore karahi, and do his best to deliver the exact same experience, food quality, etc or he should go do his own thing and have a completely different menu full of interesting sounding new dishes and stuff.. having a similar menu to the old restaurant naturally invites comparison with it which the new karahi doesn't currently fare too well in.
author: Aditya M.

description: This place is not good at all. We had the Lamb Vindaloo and the Alook Paneer. The paneer did not have cheese like in the picture and was about half oil and half over cooked spinach. The lamb vindaloo had three pieces of lamb for $11. Absolutely overpriced and tasted terrible. If you want good Indian food, save yourself time and disappointment. Go to Shalimar down the street.
author: Savi E.

description: Jennifer "Ab-Fab" P. corrected me...it was mango ice cream, not pumpkin. LOL, I know, not even close. Well, they're both orangish.
author: Helen L.

description:
**********PLEASE READ THIS**********
I don't know where to start to tell you how disappointed I am. This is a personal tragedy for me and it has forced me to finally sign up for yelp and share my heartbreak here. It's very sad that I didn't review this place before, mostly because I never expected Guddu to sell it and leave.The 'old' Lahore Karahi would easily be 10 out of 10 stars for me.

I have been a ferociously avid Lahore Karahi fan for over 2 years. I'm there pretty much once every week to taste the most authentic and gloriously 'different' Indo-Pak food over n over. The word 'different' is in quotes and is extremely important  because the taste of each n every dish all across the menu is 'different' in the most tastiest way possible than most if not all Indian/Pakistani restaurant all over Bay Area. I have tasted nearly 100% of the menu over 2 years, and being a South Asian I can pretty much bet my life on the fact that the food Guddu(previous owner) cooked cant be replicated by anyone maybe even back home(well at most places!) Being in the States for over 5 years I have tried out this cuisine in over 100 restaurants here. Its pretty much the same ol' tasting staple dishes at 99 of them but Lahore Karahi was the most different,most authentic and the absolute tastiest amongst them all. 

For those of you who don't know, Guddu has sold this place and it is under a new ownership now since past couple of weeks. And from what i have read and seen, the new owner's prime focus is not on the food but on ways to milk most money from different avenues. So it is pretty much safe to say Lahore Karahi is dead, it's history. But again without Guddu the new owner can never achieve that level of taste but he could have at least tried to get closer if his focus was on THE FOOD (damn it! that's what we care for at such hole in the walls , not your fancy lamps and liquor license...BYOB rules!).
Also, I totally support the other guy on yelp who said that Yelp needs to be notified so that Ratings and Reviews of Lahore Karahi is nullified and should start from scratch. Otherwise many would question the credibility of Yelp once they go to eat there after checking the current rating of this establishment. Or the owner should just change the name. Also, the new owner better take down the shitload of Awards and Recognitions by leading food reviewers and critics hung on the wall, which Guddu received over the years.

Finally, a shout out to Guddu..Dude I'm not sure why you did what you did but I'm sure you have major reasons. But if you read this someday I would request you to kindly reconsider and open some kind of no-frills food establishment SOON. 
I mean it in the most humblest and grateful of ways- God's purpose for you was to cook your extraordinary food for the ordinary people.  R.I.P. Lahore Karahi!
author: DJ R.

description:
I have to remember to not show up already starving on a Friday or Saturday night... depending on when you show up on those nights you may have a bit of a wait (I've waited as long as half an hour for a party of two). On my most recent visit this weekend, we waited 20 minutes for two.

But with the delicious food and cheap prices, the wait is definitely worth it.  I eat a lot of Indian and Pakistani food and I have to say that I think their garlic naan may be the best naan I've ever had anywhere.

I usually order the Chicken Vindaloo and their version is perfectly spicy with plenty of pieces of chicken and potatoes.

One of these days I will remember the BYOB and stop at the liquor store on my way here...
author: Dani D.

description: I found the creamy yogurt sauces to be far too sweet and not at all spicy (maybe there was some kind of misunderstanding in the ordering?). I found the fish tandoori to be overly spiced - not too spicy, just coated with too much salt and spice. The chicken tandoori was overly charred for my taste.
author: Lisa K.

description: Food was tasty a little overpriced, considering it's a self help style restaurant, with zero customer service. However, very dirty and messy inside. I would not go back to this joint.
author: Homayun Q.

description: Really delicious. Some of my favorite curry and naan I've ever had. We got the lamb curry and ground lamb with potatoes which was a special that day. That being said, service could use a lot of improvement. We Waited a long time which was fine because there was a large group ahead of us. But then a group who came in after us was served, after which they came over and told us that they were out of the goat that we originally ordered. Okay. So they not only served people who came in after us but they hadn't even started ours yet. Fifteen or so minutes later we get our food along with the table next to us who came in waaay after. 5 star food, 2 star service.
author: Gina G.

description: Lahore Karahi really embodies a hidden gem hole-in-the-wall restaurant.  My group ordered the Chana Saag, Chicken Tikka Masala, and Tandoori Fish with sides of naan and rice.  I thought the food was really, really good.  The food took a long time to come out (-1 star), but the great flavor and super low prices totally made up for it.  I'll be back for sure.
author: Pam S.

description:
Sadly, this place has completely fallen off. Once the owner left the dishes are not just different - but bad! Two experiences in the last week:

1) Chicken Tikka + Garlic Naan. The Chicken TIkka curry had the consistency of water (no exaggeration, it was colored, flavorless water). The chicken was bone dry and completely flavorless.

I thought it was an off night...

2) Bhuna Gosht and Naan - naan was fine, but the BG was bland and drab; I even ordered it spicy and it was just not there.

Burn me once? Shame on thee. Burn me twice? Shame on me.

This is really sad because under the old owner this place was by far the best and most reliable Indian / Pakistani place in SF. Someone get out the black arm band...
author: Jerry T.

description:
Lahore Karahi is so delicious that I can't stop going back. I guess only the owner ever cooks, it's always the same guy, and he must be some kind of genius. I love the chicken tikka masala, butter chicken, karahi chicken, and I'm trying to branch out through the rest of the menu. I try to go every week. It's the best Indian food I've ever had, and it seems to somehow be cheaper than the other Indian restaurants in this neighborhood (there are at least 4 more around here).

This is a very casual environment, partially self-service. You read the menu at the counter and write your order on one of the pads yourself, then get water and seat yourself. You do not help yourself to beer etc. from the fridge; order that from the waiter, who will eventually stop by your table. When you are done eating your incredibly delicious food, you pay at the counter on the way out. Often it's crowded. It may take a while to get your food if it's busy, and you'll likely have to wait a bit at the counter to pay after eating, but it's well worth it.
author: David M.

description:
TL;DR: For now, as long as Zulfiqar is manning the stove, my go to place for solid Punjabi food in the Bay Area. 


It might seem that I have universal contempt for veg fare, though that's not really true. The fact of the matter is that, more often than not, veg dishes at many Punjabi joints here well... suck. That the non-veg dishes never quite measure up to my expectations either--well I figure, better to just cut my losses. 

What's missing exactly? Some kind of weltanschauung--a totality of experience--encompassing the things we love and the art to express it? 

Difficult to imagine in a status obsessed, foodie-ville like SF, but opulence and cost have nothing to do with it. Some of my most memorable meals in the subcontinent were for less than a dollar... 

For example, in Old Delhi, Ustad Moinuddin's seekh kababs, made at a tiny street-side charcoal brazier on a congested side lane down from the old haveli of the great Urdu poet Ghalib, are probably the best I've ever had (or will have). While President Clinton can shell out 25 USD for a plate at Bukhara, I'm happy to know that a cycle-rickshaw-wallah can get equal (or better) ones at 4 Rs (10 cents) a pop (this was after a 1 Rs price hike a few years ago). Ustad Moinuddin-ji could easily charge double or triple, but I think that it's not just about money, but about art, along with an obstinate refusal to compromise. 

***



THE REVIEW:

For now Lahore Karahi will be my go to place for Punjabi khanna. This is the first place I've been to in the Bay Area where both the non-veg and veg items were done equally well. The food is honest, straightforward--reflecting something of the cook's dedication and skill. Definitely not trying to ingratiate itself to local tastes. While inexpensive, (like nita m. said below) if you choose well, you can get some amazing food.

The dishes:

* Butter Chicken
* Palak Paneer
* Dal Makhani
* Aloo Paratha
* Garlic Naan
* Tandoori Roti
* Raita

My measure of a good Punjabi restaurant is how well they make their dal and tandoori rotis. While a North Indian staple, for most restaurants here they are an afterthought. What's more telling about a place is not the specials, but their approach to the basics. To me a flavorless dal, or mediocre tandoori roti reflects a basic lack of skill or respect for the food.  And a shame really, because a good plate of dal accompanied by chawal (rice) or a simple tandoori roti, is to me, basic comfort food.

Zulfiqar, the chef and owner in the kitchen, has a touch. The food actually has personality. The tandoori roti was decent, not some kind of dry cracker, and the dal? Flavorful.

Butter chicken is really what CTM aspires to be. The latter being merely its pale, poultry shadow. LK's version was a little heavy on the fenugreek and onion for my tastes and lacked a hint of sweetness, but was decent. But what really stood out was the palak paneer. 

Compared to other places the flavors were distinct and had depth. The paneer was fried to a golden color with brown edges, giving it a nice firm texture. 

As far as the bread goes, it's okay. The aloo paratha was decent, better than the one that I had at Kabana. The sprinkle of sesame seeds on the garlic naan is a nice touch. Though personally, I prefer my naan to be a little thicker, more pillowy (can't say I've found good naan outside of Old Delhi, honestly). And the fact that they can make tandoori roti already speaks volumes. 

The only thing that kind of sucked was the raita. While they may make their own yogurt at the restaurant--which is great--the raita was way too tart, with a bit of a 'carbonated' taste from being overly fermented.

Sans hipsters, all-in-all, LK could be a neighborhood joint in Delhi or Lahore. Like some other reviewers said, if you're missing real Punjabi food, I recommend this place.


Service was friendly, prompt and good. 

Cleanliness-wise: during our wait for a table, a roach did double duty as a greeter on a stack of Urdu newspapers by the entrance. Though I'm not really all that squeamish and don't care that much, it does detract from the overall experience.
author: Tak N.

description:
Definite benefits in having a big group come to Lahore.  That way, you get to try everything, and you're not the only one walking down the street smelling like Indian food.

+ byob.  $10 for a 6-pack at the corner liquor store.  makes all the difference.
+ butter chicken
+ chicken tikka masala
+ chicken vandaloo
+ lamb biryani
+ aloo bengan
+ saag paneer
+ naan
+ onion kulcha
+ garlic naan

Maybe I'm not too good at distinguishing all the different flavors of the dishes, but after 10 minutes, everything started to taste the same to me.

At least I walked out full and happy.
author: Jenny L.

description:
I am heart-sick that Guddu lelt.....his food was out of this world + he welcomed all as 'family'.

I did try the new owner's food, once I got over the shock of the change in ownership.  Unfortunately, the quality of the food and the spices were definitely inferior.  To add to this, there was a vast difference in the quantity of food.

Still lamanting....

Yet I am sure Guddu is happy.  But I do not think he can be gone too long as this / cooking was/is his gift to the world.  Hurry back :)
author: Candace S.

description:
Lamb Korma, $7.00, very good.
Bengan Bharta, $6.50, Delicious!
Lahore Karahi Rice, $2.00, very good. 
Garlic Naan, $2.50, very good. 
Total price: $18.00, and I had plenty for lunch the next day. 

I was skeptical, given the reviews, however, I arrived on Sunday at 6:05pm, and was able to order right away. Dining room was only 2/3 full.  20 minutes later, I had my entire order, no problem.  Right after I ate, I paid for an extra order of rice, and got it right away. In all, I was there less than 50 minutes.  

Perhaps arriving when they're busy would be a different experience.  But coming when it's slow was perfectly fine.  The tables could have been cleaner, but that's my only complaint.
author: Dan C.

description:
What a difference! I'd been waiting to get back to San Francisco for a Lahore fix for months. Finally got there last night. Slow..... finally my butter chicken arrived with side of rice. No plates for nearly 5 minutes. Then another 3 or 4 minutes for the naan to arrive. Meanwhile, there were only 4 bite-sized pieces of chicken in my dish of butter chicken. And how did they manage to make basmati rice sticky?
Guddu, please open another place anywhere. I'll come find you!
Yelp, can you re-start Lahore Karahi's reviews to coincide with the change in ownership? It's too deceiving to people when they think they're getting the same old Lahore.
author: Katie A.

description:
I had been craving Indian food so I thought just as long as I had butter chicken or chicken tikka masala, I'd be good.  Sadly I left this place feeling unsatisfied and a bit annoyed.

It's a small place and always crowded, so be prepared to wait.  You're not going to just be waiting for a seat, but you're going to be waiting for your food also.  My friends and I came super hungry and it took an hour to get our food.  Not sure if it's because they didn't put in our order, but the fact that they only have one cook (and one guy making the naan) probably didn't help matters.  They also got our order wrong but since we were so hungry, we didn't care and just took whatever dish they made us.

The butter chicken was easily the favorite dish amongst our table.  Garlic Naan was pretty tasty.  I think the other two dishes we got were vegetarian, the Galoo Gobhi (cauliflower and potato) and Aloo Bengan (eggplant and potato).  They were both bleh to me.  Might be because I'm a carnivore and I'm not happy unless there's meat.  Everything was spicy too.  Two of my friends were dying.

In the end, I wasn't very impressed.  There's better Indian food around where you don't have to wait around forever for everything.
author: Jane N.

description:
This place is a good enough reason for winding up in the Tenderloin. If you can manage to deal with people walking up to you offering you crack every so often, find your way over here. Granted, you may get side-tracked by another deliciously-smelling Indian restaurant on the way (they seem to be all over the TL), but when you get here, holding off at the other places will be worth it!

I came here for lunch with 4 of my coworkers yesterday, and thankfully, it was not busy at all. We had no problem getting served quickly too.

We ordered:
Aloo Keema
- ground up lamb with potatoes... this was delicious! If you thought you didn't like lamb, don't turn your attention away from this dish. I was skeptical at first because I'm very particular about how where I order lamb, but gosh, this was WORTH it! Deliciously spicy too!

Chicken Biryani
- good and flavorful

Tandoori Fish
- we were told that we should order this dish because it's the signature dish! It comes served to you on a sizzling dish, with onions and spices on it. Definitely a good idea that we read yelp reviews saying to order this! And the fish just comes apart in your mouth!

Prawn Vindaloo
- I'm such a vindaloo fan, so this dish was my pick for the meal. The prawn was soft enough to eat. I hate when I order something with prawn or shrimp and it comes out tough. That's gotta be the worst ever. The sauce was a very good kind of spicy. Mmmm, I'm salivating just thinking about it now...

Garlic and Sesame Naan
- WHOA! The garlic really jumps out at you! I'm glad we ordered 4 of these.

Vegetable Pakora
- delicious mixed vegetable fritters. I think I like samosas more, but this was a nice change. Definitely try it if you haven't yet.

When we first saw the plates, I thought the portions were a little small. But as we ate, we soon realized that we were getting stuffed and still had lots of extra food there! Four plates is defitely a good amount for 5 people.

I can't wait to go back... Only thing that I hated was that I smelled like a curry restaurant for the rest of the afternoon at work. But we all have to make sacrifices, right?
author: Melissa D.

description:
I grew up with Indian food, I know Indian food and I love Indian food . 
When living in Paris I use to do daily round trips to London just to go eat Indian food in there ( Round trip tickets to Bombay were a little too expensive :-) 

Therefor, I am a bitch about Indian Food : One day a co worker took me to naan-and-curry and had the audacity of telling me it was really good. Needless to say I never take recommendations from that person anymore ... I don't even think I talk to her anymore ! 

But Lahore Karahi is different. It's absolutely not pretentious. The atmosphere is very casual but the food is amazing. 

They are pretty basic with the menu ( Tandoori , Tikka masala , naan ... ), there's no item that seems unfamiliar but everything is mastered the way only a true Indian who's been cooking for the family for the last 60 years could !
author: Clara T.

description:
Talk about value! Best Pakistani food I've had at a eatery that doesn't burn a hole in your pocket....
Favs: 
Tandoori Mixed Grill- probably the most expensive dish on the menu at a whooping $11, awesome :), came with a mix of marinated chicken & lamb on a sizzling platter...wrap these in there fresh garlic naan, yummm...
Chicken Tikka Masala- chicken breast in creamy tomato sauce, delish...
Don't forget to order extra garlic naan, the meal is not complete without it!! Also if sensitive on spiciness make sure to ask for medium spice level, seems to be spicier than some other Pakistani spots I've been to...definitely cleared my sinuses haha 
Warning: refrain from planning any dates/meetings/social interaction after leaving this place without leaving time for multiple showers and a change of clothing, you will smell like a walking bowl of curry!
author: Mahsa K.

description: Chicken kofta + naaaaaan
author: Blake N.

description: Located in the Tenderloin, it took a while before I venture to the spot.(Pretty easy and safe to get to during the day) That being said, the food is wonder and very flavorful. Definitely worth the trip. Ordered Lamb Biryani and really surprised how good it is. Will definitely visit again and recommend anyone to try it out! Looking forward to try the rest of the menu.
author: J Y.

description:
This is my go-to spot to eat dinner prior to grabbing drinks at B&B.  I know, I know...where's the relation?  The only relation I have to tell you is purely how close they are to each other and how great the food is at Lahore.

The staple dishes I like to order are:  Seekh Kabob, Butter Chicken, Saag Paneer, Lahore Rice, and Naan.  The portions are hefty compared to other places like Naan and Curry and the amount of actual meat you get is worth what you're paying for.  There's normally only one server, so you can't really complain about service being slow unless if you want another $ dollar added to the menu prices.  

During my last visit, I saw the owner being visited by a mother and her 2 year old son dropping off a X-mas present to Zulfiqar.  It was really nice to see how the restaurant is supported by its neighbors and the interaction of the chef to his patrons.  Go here if you want well made Pakistani/Indian food and decent prices to follow on your bill.  If I'm on a tight budget, you'll find me here!
author: Char C. B.

description:
MY FELLOW INDIAN FRIENDS, IF YOU WANT A TRADITIONAL, QUALITY INDIAN FOOD, AVOID THIS PLACE!!!!!

To set the scene:
My wife and I had been hiking and decided on our way home to stop off at an Indian restaurant as felt the need for some traditional home cooked Indian food without paying over $100 for it!!!! We decided on Lahore based on the reviews and that it seems reasonably populated with customers each time we have driven by.

AMBIANCE:
Very basic which is not a problem at all, but I would say that staff were not too friendly; it was quite cold in the restaurant and a lot of people seemed to have been waiting a VERY long time for their food. The tables seemed clean, except the wash rooms were not particularly pleasant. THAT SHOULD HAVE BEEN WARNING NUMBER 1.

FOOD:
We were very excited by the menu and we ordered veggie samosas, (which were average and filled with flour versus actual veggies); lamb chops, karahi chicken bhengan parthaa and some naans.
The lamp chops were scarred and burnt, which probably meant that they were out of date, they also had very little meat on them. I decided to return them, only to some attitude from a staff member.... UGH HELLO, we are Indians, do not try and fool us and treat us like tourists who don't know any better. The dish was also $14 which for what we got was a rip off.
The chicken dish was OK and the paartha looked yellow and quite hideous, so we decided to leave that alone as well.

SERVICE:
The reaction from returning the lamb chops said it all, you would have had to be blind to not see that the chops were charred and over done, not sure why... .HMMM

OVERALL:
This was a great shame, OK the bar is set high, I am from the UK where Indian food is the #1 dish and my wife is from NY and born in India, so we both "get it" when it comes to a traditional Indian affair.

This most definitely is not one of them. PASS.
author: King O.

description:
Holy crap was this place good!  My friend and I shared:  bainghan bhartha, aloo gobi, 1 order of naan and 1 order of rice.  All our dishes were delicious and had a little something different that resulted in a nice variation from all the cookie cutter Indian restaurants in SF.  For example, I'm guessing the bainghan bhartha had a little yogurt in it, which resulted in a creamy, tangy taste.

Pros:  Delicious food, amazing price (total was $17.95!), chill ambiance (I like the cafeteria-style quality.  I mean, it's the 'Loin.  A pretentious atmosphere makes no sense here), super friendly wait staff.

Cons:  Service was very slow (we went at 9:45 - not smack dab in the middle of dinner time).  Tables weren't super clean and I don't really want to know how clean the kitchen is.  Also, lots of people order sizzling kebabs, which means your hair and clothes will smell a little after you leave.

PS - Def get the rice with your dish.  It is beautifully seasoned with cardamom and cumin.   I liked it more than the naan, which is unheard of in my gluten-obsessed diet!
author: Rani V.

description:
Oh Lahore Karahi...you definitely have become my special little *hore. My first time with you was indescribable. It was everything one would expect it to be for a night with a *hore. Your service was amazing, you were friendly beyond belief, and you made me feel good about myself in ways others could not. 

Your Chicken Korma brought me to euphoria. I couldn't believe that in my many years of eating Indian food, I had never been introduced to this spicy deliciousness. 

You were so good to me, I could not wait till my next rendezvous with you. This time, I couldn't make it earlier and was forced to meet you at around 9pm only to force myself to watch you *hore yourself out to all your other customers. It was painful to my eyes, but I knew it would be worth the wait and torture. 

Sadly so, I was a tid bit disappointed the second time around. I guess I held the bar too high on a busy Saturday night when all the creeps were out lurking for a good night. It wasn't your fault, you were overwhelmed with all your clients from inside the restaurant and the ones waiting around for a piece of the your Karahi. Once again, your service and sympathy for making me wait endeared me even more so than the first time. Sadly so, your Korma did not please me as much as my first time. I think you were trying to overcompensate yourself for making me wait, but maybe, just maybe you put a little too much cinnamon in my curry. However, your Tandoori Fish made my wait all the worthwhile.

I must admit, my first evening with you was one to write home about. I couldn't wait to share my amazing night out with a *hore like you to all my friends. Your first impression keeps me coming back for more.
author: Lisa T.

description:
My only question, "Why didn't I know about this place years ago???"

My boyfriend and I have been coming here for the last two years, and we have NEVER been disappointed. 

Reasons: 
Tasty food. friendly staff. Clean environment. and the food comes reasonably quick. 
They also make it fresh right after you order! 
The seating is a little small, but I find it cozy!

Basically, we travel from castro valley all the way here JUST to eat this delicious food. How could it not get 5 stars?

Our favorite meal:  chicken tikka massala, safron rice and garlic naan. 
mmm mmm good
author: Jeanine M.

description: Actually, unfortunately while the food is good, the management insists on increasing the income by adding an amount to your charge after you have signed the credit card voucher.  It's happened to me three times now, so if I ever go back, I will pay in cash.  What a jerk.  And you should scroll around to other reviews....  Others have said the same thing about the extra charges.....
author: Gary R.

description:
I decided to try this indian restaurant because i heard their food was good, but after trying it i would never recommend this place to anyone.  

Reasons why:
-Terrible service
-Forgot two of the dishes we ordered
-Water tasted like it was left in the refrigerator with bad food
-The food itself was not that great after all that

I will not go back again!
author: Alisha R.

description:
When I first heard the name of this restaurant I snickered to myself because I am five.

Had two types of bread - garlic naan and onion kulcha - which were VERY GOOD, definitely freshly made - warm and chewy and generously studded with garlic and onion and cilantro.  The two curries, chicken tikka masala and matar paneer (peas and cheese) were a bit on the creamy, buttery side, but well balanced salt and spice-wise.

Really rich and filling meal, but it hit the Indian comfort food spot. Service was a bit slow, but the waiters were friendly and sweet, so whatever. I don't expect to be waited on hand and foot at a hole in the wall place in the tenderloin.

Bill was under $30 for the two curries and two naans (naan? Can it be plural?).
author: cecilia y.

description:
Very slow service. Food came after about 45 minutes of ordering, and no it was not freshly cooked. We were the only Pakistani Indian family eating there, this means the people who were eating could not verify the authenticity of the taste. Chicken Karahi was anything but Karahi...
There are far better eateries out there than this average one.  They are expensive tangibly, but, intangibly the prices are off the charts because taste of the food does not justify the cost :( only thing that was at par in taste was naan or bread.

To reiterate, this place does not have authentic Pakistani Indian cuisine,
author: Muhammad D.

description:
Recently i visited SF and i was looking for authentic Pakistani/Indian food.. i finally i found this amazing place called Lahore karahi. Food is really delicious..i ordered Nehari(Beef Curry), Chicken Tikka Masala and Daal. all are very tasty speciall Beef curry(Nehari) so tender and mosit.. This restuarant is under new mangement.and renovated. The new owner Mr.Iqbal is super nice..amazing customer service..
I highly recommend this place...
author: Basit A.

description:
Spices that pop, would sum up Lahore Karahi in a nutshell. Indian food requires plenty of spices but what gives this place the edge is the freshness of their flavors. 

Don't miss the tandoori fish and lamb curries. Ask for some of their housemade ice cream for dessert.
author: Derrick V.

description:
I would never be so bold as to say I am an Indian flavor connoisseur.  But I would be so bold as to say that I. Love. Lahore. Karahi.  Reasons why:

1. Dirt cheap
2. Amazing, fresh flavors
3. Friendly staff
4. Bollywood movies on the television that the owners probably purchased in 1989.

Reasons why they didn't get the fifth star:
1. Currently, no liquor license.  I have been told that they used to have a BYOB rule, which would have rocked.  But apparently they are working on the license.
2. If you are going out afterward to anywhere other than an open air concert, go home and take a shower and change your clothes.  On a busy night with the grills going, you'll come out smelling like your dinner.
3.  I wish it was a tinnnnny bit bigger.  Often it can get very very crowded on a Friday or Saturday night.
author: Ashley W.

description:
I agree with everyone who's feelin the tandoori fish. I've never tasted fish like this before I ate here and I haven't since.

Don't know the owner's name but he's really friendly and every time I've been by he's behind the stove cookin up a storm. There's really something to be said for any restaurant owner that takes that much pride in their food. Another place like that off the top of my head is Brenda's and most people know how good that place is.

I also like the fact that the prices are super reasonable. 

Writing this review makes me question why I don't stop by this place more. It's right across the street from me. I need to get on that shite...
author: Tommy P.

description: Good stuff :) better than more famous ones in downtown! Free tea is awesome! Chicken, lamb,, whatever u choose u will be happy!good service too
author: Sojin K.

description:
Very very cheap, and tasted very fresh. We had a large variety of dishes, and 7 of us ate for $44.00! Also, it's BYOB so we brought a 12-pack of beer. 

Definitely the best value Indian eating experience I've had since getting to the city. The location is not so bad, even though it is Tenderloinish. You might have to share tables depending on how many your party is, but we went on a Friday night and enjoyed a good meal.

Ironically the 3 Indian people with us didn't dig the food that much, but all the rest of us loved it.
author: Jordan C.

description:
Went here for my first time last night. In-credible. 

Had the samosa's to start, then the mixed grill plate, kabobs, and saag paneer. The samosas were a bit different than i'm used to, but still good. Mixed grill was great, but my favorite  was the saag paneer. 

My fav. indian places are Shalimar, Chutney, and now, Lahore (all conveniently located next to each other. 
I go to shalimar if I'm looking to bring in some beer. 

This place had a more 'home cookin'' style - to me anyways. I'd def go back here again.
author: David N.

description: Happened to just stop at this place while strolling by. The place looks very tiny and the ambiance is less than 4 star but the "superhero" here is the food!! I ordered tandoori fish, chicken biryani and some dessert. Everything tasted just awesome!! Great place for Indian/Pakistani food.
author: Sweta R.

description:
I love this place! Great food for a good price. You can order customize the amount of heat in the dish, so to speak, so your spice loving friend can get his fix and your white bread friend can avoid tearing up. Friendly service, clean, and they show Bollywood music videos most days. 

Cons: The place is small and has limited tables. Sometimes you have to remind the waiter about small things like a drink or an extra order of naan. 

Enjoy!
author: Haley R.

description:
this place is legit and delish; my wife dislikes Indian food and loved her grub too

only 4 starts b/c the food does take a while; but call ahead/order to go and you'll be super-stoked

best samosas ever

awesome veggie and fish selections - not just typical lamb chicken dishes 

If you want a GIANT serving, order a birayni - you wont be able to finish it; other dishes are reasonably sized
author: Mark B.

description:
Sick with a cold and hungover to boot, I decided to throw my slimfast and coffee diet to the wind and indulge a little this morning. With Indian on the brain, I resolved to try something new. Lahore has been on my to-do list for a while so I called in my order and enlisted Boy Delivery Service to bring it to my door. FanTAStic idea. 

This place is cheap, cheap, cheap. Think $7 tikka masala and $6 saag paneer. The giant pakoras ($3) are outrageously good, the naan ($1) is delightfully fluffy, and the rice ($2) kicks ass. The Tikka Masala is smoky and spicy and incredibly smooth. I'm not as big a fan of the saag paneer- too sweet, but my dining companion thought it was swell. 

The depth of flavor is a vast improvement over the standard greasy takeaway. It was more like eating great, home-cooked fare than it was like eating heavy Indian food. I'm sincerely considering leveraging this coldover (cold + hangover) for all it's worth and  ordering dinner from them just so I can try the veggie korma I've heard so much about. I have a feeling Lahore Karahi is going to be derailing my power diets on a regular basis.
author: Autumn K.

description: I thought the food was quite good, especially for the price. I docked 1 star because I found a small piece of aluminum foil in my food.
author: Ben H.

description: On a Friday night the place was crowded but tables still opened up regularly. We had sag paneer, lamb boti and garlic naan which were excellent, and the prices were too. Another plus - it's BYOA and you can make your purchases from any of the nearby corner shops. Several tables had brought wine. The host was happy to lend us a bottle opener, too! I wish they didn't have TVs on but they're easy to ignore. I'll definitely be back when I need my Pakistani/Indian food fix again!
author: Sean C.

description:
By far one of THE BEST customer service I have ever had. Not to mention the food quality was equally amazing. Lahore Karahi is one of the smallest restaurants I've ever been in. It fits about 5 or 6 tables that fit 2-4 people each. But it didn't feel cramped. There was complimentary tea by the utensils. It made it homey & I felt welcomed.

I ordered the butter chicken while my friend ordered the chicken tikka masala. She warned me about the spice levels being higher than the usual. So I opted to get mine in a medium instead of hot like she did. My medium butter chicken was SOOO spicy. It was delicious but I must admit, I think I would've enjoyed my meal better with less heat. I was literally sweating I had to take my sweater off. One of the waiters saw & gave us complimentary yogurt to help soften the dish. It really did help! The same waiter also brought us complimentary dessert because he felt bad that I couldn't fully eat my chicken. He really didn't have to because I more than enjoyed my meal!

With the service being more than helpful, the dishes extremely flavorful, the complimentary treats tasty & delightful, I can honestly say that Lahore Karahi is one of my favorite restaurants!
author: Kris B.

description:
Food: 
-Tastes delicious (give the Fish Tandoori a try)
-Unlimited self-serve hot chai on the side table :D
-Portion is good

Service:
-Friendly
-Dishes served relatively quick

Others:
-Limited seating, so you may have to wait if you go during popular dining hours
-Been there 3 times and haven't seen any cockroaches other reviews have mentioned (thank goodness)

& last but not least--you're guaranteed to smell like food after dining in. Enjoy :)
author: Jolinda T.

description:
Yum!  This place is divine!  A friend and I were in the mood for meat and we ordered Chicken Tikka Masala and Saag Gosht.  Both were flavorful and delicious.  The garlic naan is wonderful.  I was wired from the complimentary chai all day, so be forewarned: one cup is enough.  

Great prices and friendly, helpful service.  I'll definitely be back.
author: Margaret C.

description: Went on a Saturday night, around 9ish... had to wait in line and then waited forever for our food. The place was packed and the lineup never ended and was out the door the whole time we were there. Got the Chicken Curry, Lamb Vindaloo, Potato Naan, two orders of Garlic Naan, and Fish Tandoori. They forgot one of our garlic naan orders. The food was good but not as awesome as it should be for the long wait and long line up. Overall the whole restaurant was a little dirty.
author: K S.

description: Better than most of the Indian food in LA, but nothing on the restaurants in London. Still, not bad for a quick fix.
author: Yannick L.

description:
Been wanting to come here for about a year and this place lived up to the praise my Indian friends lauded on this spot.

The food is nicely spiced. If you like it spicy, they certainly can accommodate that request. 

Service is competent.  They took the order and delivered it.  Nothing more. Don't expect witty banter.  
 
Decor is reflective of the neighborhood.  Unfortunately there is little to no circulation so it gets warm in here.  So I suggest wearing short sleeve.  Another drawback to the circulation issue is that there's a good chance you are gonna smell of Indian food when you leave.  Just a warning if that's an issue for you.
 
Good bang for your buck here, as value is a big factor in this neighborhood.
author: Roger H.

description:
Lahore Karahi was my fav pakistani restaurant in the city -- and that's holding pretty high standards because I know what Pakistani food is supposed to taste like. The chicken karahi and fish tandoori were my favs, always fresh and yummy.

Recently, I learned that Lahore Karahi had new owners and Guddu was no longer the chef. It was the only Pakistani restaurant I fully endorsed and somehow I was sure the new owners just wouldn't be able to cut it. Lahore Karahi would now be added to the list of other mediocre Pakistani restaurants in the City.

Well, since I was already there when I learned of this change, I figured I might as well give them a chance and eat something. I expected the worst...no one I knew had eaten here since the new owners and yelp reviews weren't updated yet. I ordered the chef's special Nihari, one of my fav dishes but one that was never on the previous LK menu, as well as the chicken karahi, my LK fav. 

The cons to the new owners are that they're still finding their groove. They don't have service down just yet, they didn't bring us plates or drinks or anything to begin with. The food took a bit longer than expected, especially since most of the tables in the restaurant had already been served, but we could see that they were still trying to move quickly. The food arrived and my primary disappointment was the portion sizes -- smaller than most restaurants. If the owners are reading this, take my word of advice on the service and portions -- you'll need to step it up to restaurant standard, this isn't your dining room at home. My second disappointment was that although the main entrees arrived, there was no naan in sight. We silently waiting a few mins but our food was getting cold and we still had no naan. We politely asked the owner and he rushed an order and sent over naan one by one as soon as he could and we began eating.

Now you must wonder, if I have so many suggestions and disappointments thusfar, then why the 4 stars? Well, because to my dismay and against all expectations, the food was still good. They obviously can't have exactly the same taste as Guddu, every chef has their own way of making food, but the nihari was better than i expected and the chicken karahi flavorful. You've gotta remember, i walked in to this expecting it to be terrible, but I'm still giving them four stars because it's hard learning to run a restaurant and they were clearly trying. Yes, the service could be better, the food could come faster, and the naan could actually make it on time, but I truly think they'll get to that point very soon. They're just experiencing a couple of the pains of working a new business, especially one where everyone has such high expectations.

I know it's hard for a lot of people to look passed the fact that Guddu is gone, but give them a chance. And if you're into beef stew, try the nihari, It was pretty yummy and I think they may just have a couple tricks up their sleeves. Fingers crossed that they work out the kinks.
author: Shafaq C.

description:
Hole-in-the-wall place with fabulous food.
Yeah, I just said fabulous.

The food is Pakistani/Indian, which probably means some specific things if you're from that area, or more familiar with the regional cuisines.  To me, it just translates as Yummy!

Anyway.  Know: there's often a line, and it's pretty slow moving.  There's really only 1 chef, so don't expect to be in & out in 30 minutes.
Know also: the food is delicious, incredibly rich & flavorful, remarkably inexpensive, and often spicy.  I like spice (I think a burrito is a vehicle for consuming salsa, for example), and I was quite content with medium spicy.

The Saag Gosht was unlike any saag dish I've ever had.  There was much more than just spinach involved, and the complexity of flavor and texture in the sauce was remarkable.  Even better, there was no detectable oil or ghee in it!
Rice is tastily spiced.
Naan had a consistency and even flavor similar to pizza dough.  Uniquely different, but good.
Chicken Koorma was tasty (though the chicken was just a tad dry), but WOW was that some ghee-liciousness.  Seriously - imagine a ghee lake, with some chicken and sauce mixed into it.  So if you're anti-ghee or anti-oil, you might want to ask the friendly servers what they recommend to avoid it.

Sure, the place looks like it hasn't been updated since the '70s, but who cares when it's that good?

Oh - and lest I forget, it's BYOB!
author: Don H.

description:
Not the same Lahore. 

It closed down, upgraded the kitchen, cleaned-up the paint job, and reopened. Unfortunately, the food didn't make the upgrade. 

Naan was excellent, but everything else was subpar. The chicken tikka masala's sauce was thin and the meat chewy. The saag paneer seemed like they'd dumped frozen spinach into an oily broth.  Even the mint chutney was runny and bland.  Pakoras were fine. 

Maybe they need a little grime back on the walls to bring back the flavor. Until then, I'll be going elsewhere.
author: Floyd L.

description: This place was a pleasant surprise.  My husband and I were on our way to Little Delhi for dinner and the orange walls, Christmas lights in the windows, and packed tables beckoned us, so we entered.  It was a delicious taste treat.  The chili naan was delicious and we each had super tasty kormas.  The prices were so cheap and the service was friendly.  I will definitely be back to this Tenderloin treasure again.  My stomach is so happy right now.
author: Megna M.

description:
This is my go-to place for good, cheap food. Everything is delicious, but my favorite dish is the Shahi Paneer. Be sure to get plenty of rice! The mango lassie is delicious and a great compliment to anything spicy. 

Some warnings:
Do NOT go into the bathroom. DON'T. Seriously. In the girl's room the toilet is literally a foot off of the floor. The floor is dirty and there were bugs that I think were bedbugs crawling on the floor and walls. 
The service is regularly poor; sometimes you get the entrees before the apps and the drinks much later. No one will refill your water glass, so you have to do it yourself which feels awkward.

Yet even after these things I give this place 4 stars. The food really is that good. It's definitely worth being patient for/making the walk through the Tenderloin for!
author: Jen M.

description:
Mmmmm. Spicy

Make sure you prepare yourself for the day after...in the toilet. hehe
author: Moko R.

description:
I went to this place 3 times in the last couple of weeks. It is a great place to go but it's easy to arrive at the time when there's a whole pack of people trying to get in as well. The place is small, the service is not that fast (I'm from NY). So if you're going for a late dinner, be prepared to wait in line in the tiny doorway for a while.

While the food is good, i have to say - it's far from the best. Based on the other reviews here i would even say it's overrated! I just went to the enarby Shalimar last night and i have to say the food was better there. 

Would i come back? sure, its a neat place, with good food, and cool "hole in a wall" ambiance. But the next time I might just go for Shalimar two blocks over again instead.
author: Maciej K.

description:
This is my favorite Indian restaurant!
Their tandoori fish, ghosht curry, chicken tikka masala, karahi chicken, veg biriyani and karahi paneer is awesome! Customer service is fabulous too! The only thing I did not like was their butter chicken.
author: Mrinalini K.

description:
i was greeted by not one, but TWO cockroaches last night. Although i wasn't surprised--what else can you expect from a hole-in-the-wall in the tenderloin? The waiter kindly took care of the cockroaches for us, but there was no discount on the bill? 
if you are squeamish do not go here. I will not dine in here again. I would recommend takeout if you really want to try the food. 
ick!
author: Ani L.

description:
My rating might be bias because my knees gets weak even from the smell of Pakistani/Indian cuisine. Walked in to a little tiny restaurant, pretty packed. People were waiting to be seated but the wait was less than 10 minutes. It get's super smoky inside, cleaniness? not so much. 

Sat down to a dirty table but the waiter came right away to clean it. Served us water and gave us our menus. We ordered the Chicken tikka masala, an eggplant curry, a lamb curry and 4 naan's (3 regular and a garlic).

Chicken Tikka masala came out with the naan's and then the eggplant. I love chicken tikka masala and this one was pretty good. There were sprinkles of pistachios on top which made it look pretty and if you bite into a bigger chunk you get that bit of pistachio flavor which is nice because I like pistachios. Chicken was pretty tender, not dried. Very flavorful, we ordered mild so it was not overly spicy.

Eggplant curry was ok, the flavor didn't stood out in any particular way. Lamb curry, my friend said it was pretty good. I didn't really eat too much of the lamb because of the game-y taste.

Garlic naan was really good, came out nice fresh and hot! Tons of garlic on top. 

Food was good, waiting time for our food was a bit long...price is decent.
author: Amy L.

description:
Food: 5 stars - I was told to come here for authenticity and spiciness, and Lahore Karahi delivered. I had the tandoori chicken, garlic naan (perfect complement to the curries here...), aloo tikki, and lamb vindaloo, and couldn't find a fault with anything I ordered.

Service: 3 stars - This place is understaffed, and service times reflect that.

Price: 5 stars - Food good enough to be fat for the stomach, cheap enough to be lean on the wallet. Win.
author: Joshua L.

description:
delectable Indian food in sf!! 

Must eats: 
-chicken marsala curry!! must must must!! whenever I go ... I ALWAYS get chicken marsala. watch out! it is a bit spicy so choose your spice level accordingly!
-rice... the plain rice is deliecious with every bit of curry and NAN!!
-plaine nan... i've tried all the flavors... but the plain nan... is absolutely delicious!

Décor:
-a total hole in the wall... the dining area seats no more than 30 people, so make sure to go early if you have a large group! 
-they always have Indian movies on... love it!

Service: 
-never had bad service the few times I've gone there.
-they have unlimited free tea, you have to just get it yourself

Cost:
-soooOoOoOo affordable! 
-chicken marsala $7.50 (can feed 2 people... or 3 small appetites)
-plate of rice $2.00
-nan: $1.00 (large ... usually people have 1 or 2)

Overall: I love this place! I always make sure to stop by when I'm in SF! Eventhough the resturant isn't elaborately decorated... it doesn't need to be! That's how delicious I think this place is. I've met and seen the owners everytime I go by... so friendly! That's always a plus!
author: Sarah Kouoon Y.

description:
I came here following the recommendation of a friend, and after I read about all the food-poisoning incidents at Chutney (I really didn't want to risk it while I was on vacation).  The restaurant is in the "'loin" so careful!  We had to park on the street and walk for a few blocks -- a little pre-dinner exercise.

We started the meal with some poppers and then shared the butter chicken and saag paneer with garlic and regular naan.   I really liked the saag paneer -- the cheese was tofu-like and remarkably light, nothing gooey about it.  The butter chicken was a tad spicy, but with some water, a non-spice eater, such as myself, was able to down it.  

This restaurant could have easily gotten 5 stars from me but the sluggish service holds me back.  And it wasn't only the food that was slow to arrive, the check required two reminders and eventually, we went up to pay.
author: Jun H.

description: Absolutely disgusting service. Walked in to the empty restaurant and find every table filled with dirty plates and flies buzzing around - apart for one table. We asked the manager if he could wipe ours, but he proceeded to clean every table apart from ours. It was almost comical. After asking him again, he just ignored us. So we started to leave and said "you should be more welcoming to your customers" to which he replied "well there are plenty of other restaurants in SF for you". What a joke! Be warned. These people don't seem to appreciate their customers.
author: Rezwan I.

description:
LORD-A-MERCY!

Outstandingly fresh Pakistani food + excellent service = random reggae dance hall terms. Booyah!
author: Mennlay A.

description:
Packed with every other ethinic group other than indians. Place is small and run down. Accidentally stepped in the restroom. Most people think this place is cheap, but it is not. The dishes are priced to $9.99 to stay within $ range. I found Mehfil restaurant as comparable and with full service you will end up paying the same amount. The only thing you save is 18% tip.

Everyone (cook,waiter,dishwasher) are all latin people. No Indian chef/owner.... other than the name of the restaurant.
author: sam v.

description: Loved the food here so much we ended up ordering extra to carry away for the next day. Cozy bright orange dining room was a little shabby but charming. Very vegetarian friendly.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
After reading the yelp reviews, I had to try this place.  The food was very flavorful and well seasoned.  The chicken biryani was good. The sea bass was not too impressive.  The mango lassi was yummy too.  Very friendly service. 
    The only drawback is the "pets" that were crawling along the wall--cockroaches (small and medium sized).  I would suggest ordering take out or not not sit at the tables along the walls, unless don't mind the cockroaches.  I would highly suggest that the owners of the restaurant hire a pest control company to contain the pets if they do have one already.
author: L Y.

description:
Simply the best in its category in San Francisco.  

Every dish was cooked to perfection and authentic (per my two Indian friends who took me there).  The dahl was not a runny soup as one gets a few blocks away.  Even the vindaloo, which is not local dish of Lahore, was cooked as well as one might find anywhere in Goa. 

Don't patronize this restaurant if  you are interested in ambiance, table settings, art, or quiet conversation over a meal.  Come hungry  and bring your sophisticated pallet for  Indian/Pakistani cuisine.
author: Matt B.

description:
Very good Indian food cooked just like homestyle. Not greasy like the other indian restaurants in the city. 

Try the kheer for desert. its one of my favorites there.
author: Rahul P.

description:
The short answer is that it is cheap and very good and my stomach does not hurt. wow. 

Worth getting are the giant, lightly seasoned pakoras, and the chicken tikka masala, which is tender and a little bit smokier and more savory than the nuclear orange stuff you'll get at most other indian joints.

the jury is still out on the saag paneer; it's different, that's for sure, but I certainly tasted the love.

They use an actual tandoor; not a clay hole in the ground, but a commercial grade hole in a steel countertop. you can taste the difference. also the love.
author: matthew r.

description: I just saw a cockroach during my lunch there. it was on the wall very close to my shoulders. They still charged me for the meal though. $18 lunch with cockroach, what else can i say?!
author: Alta B.

description:
Close to the worst Indian/Pakistani Food I have ever had in the US over the last 2 years. 

For starters, we ordered Vegetable Pakoras, most of them were over-fried. For main course, we ordered Vegetable Korma, Bhindi Masala, Roti and Garlic Naan. The Garlic Naan was good, the Roti was fine, the Bhindi Masala was barely palatable, and the Vegetable Korma was simply un-eatable. On top of food being absolutely tasteless, there was an overwhelming amount of oil in the entres. 

Apart from the food, the ambience was pretty bad too, and the place could seriously use better cleaning of utensils (yes!!!), and tables.

I would not revisit this place.
author: Saurabh G.

description:
Crazy yummy.  Ordered a couple vegetarian dishes and was very pleased.  I felt like I got white-boy treatment with regard to how spicy it was, but it was still decently spicy.  Not much to say, to be honest -- the food was just really tasty, and hit the spot after a long day.

Don't expect to get in and out quickly, though: there was only one guy waiting tables, and the food appeared to take a while (not just us, other tables seemed to be without food for some time).  I think we waited a good 15-20 minutes after we arrived before our order was taken, and another 20 before the food arrived.  Waiter was super friendly and helpful, though.

Hilariously bad Bollywood movie on the TV (well, at least the English subtitles made it seem even cheesier than I'd expect), which helped pass the time.
author: Brian T.

description:
Um. The food was OK. I ordered the butter chicken but shared a whole host of other dishes with a group of people including a few varieties of naan and tandoori chicken. The problem I had with this place was the wait time.

This place is tiny but I think what makes it worse is that there are only two guys working the place, at least there were when I ate there for lunch on a weekday. My party ended up waiting 45 minutes for a table and then about 20 more for our dishes. One of us didn't get his tandoori until we had finished all of the other dishes. 

I'm not familiar with Indian food, having only eaten it a handful of times in my life, but it was actually OK, especially the curries. But the tandoori chicken was only OK, probably because it was rushed (I think the super-busy cook forgot until the last minute). 

And yes, the bathroom is scary. Didn't see any roaches but was freaked by the dirty broom stowed away alongside the toilet and the lack of proper toilet paper (they only had a large roll of crisp, paper towels). 

If it weren't for the fact that someone else paid for my meal, I wouldn't have gone here. And what's more, I went here as part of a 'welcome' meal-- couldn't have been less welcoming but I knew it wasn't the fault or the intention of the people who took me out. I wanted Indian food but wasn't familiar with the restaurants in the area so I left it up to someone else to pick (and yes, I realize Pakistani food is different but I specifically said I wanted to eat Indian and this is where I was brought-- I'm not implying that Pakistani and Indian are "all the same"). Throughout the wait and after the meal (wait time+actual eating=2 and a half hours!), a few people in my group asked me if I had chosen the place. I only realized later that they must have been like 'Who was the nut who chose this place???'  If I had to pay, I would not go back here.
author: Jasmine S.

description:
Wait this place has a website? 

Anywho..this place was okay. I'm not a big fan of Indian food but my girl wanted to try something new. So we went for lunch one day and it was pretty packed..packed and tiny.  The garlic naan was pretty amazing. The lamb was too spicy for me and a bit chewy. The tikka masal was good as well. Overall pretty good meals. However I did order rice and never saw it and the place isn't the cleaniest. But it is cheap so I guess you really do get what you pay for. When I went there was one guy serving the whole restaurant but we got our food pretty fast, just towards the middle of the meal I was getting our own pitcher of water, so don't be surprised if there's moments of self service going on...lol.

Again, I'm not a fan of Indian food but if you are you will probably dig this place.
author: Natalie F.

description:
I really like this restaurant.  They are very friendly and food is good.
Dishes I liked;
- Paneer Pakora (Fried Cheese) - I don't  like American cheese stick with tons of melted cheese.  This one had solid white cheese lightly battered and fried - very good $4.50
- Chicken Korma (Orange colored Curry) - Very nice mixtures of spices and flavor.  Big boneless chicken chunks. $5
- Rice (Basmati rice with spices - very flavorful but not overwhelmingly spicy. $1.25
- Lamb Biryani (Saffron flavored Basmati Rice with Lamb) - the lamb was very tender and tasty. BUT had a lot of cilantro (which I hate) in it...
$8.95

Oh, one thing... they have no liquor license and I NEED to have beer when I have Indian food, so I called the restaurant prior to going there and asked ,

Me- Can I bring beer to your restaurant?
A guy at Lahore Karahi (LK) - No beer but wine OK
Me-why no beer why wine OK?
LK-wine OK no underage!
Me-??????? Can I please bring beer
LK-No sorry hahaha

I don't understand why wine is ok and beer is not ok....


Me .
author: Chie J.

description:
The great thing about this place is that you feel like you're in Uncle Guddu's kitchen... The not so great thing is that come out smelling like you've been in Uncle Guddu's kitchen! LOL... 

A couple of my friends and I checked this place out last night and it was a pretty good overall experience, waited only about five to ten minutes for a table and seated right away. From the first look of the place I thought is small, but when we sat down we didn't feel cramp at all. The place isn't the cleanest, but you get the value you pay for and tastier! 

The great thing is that appetizer are price accordingly, they're lower priced than the main dishes; it kind of bugs me that appetizers are priced the same as main dishes at a lot of restaurants nowadays. The same value system goes for the vegetarian dishes, they're slightly cheaper than meat dishes as they should be! : -) 

Food: 
* Vegetable Fritters - crispy and tasty! 
* Regular Naan - Not greasy and not doughy thick like Naan-N-Curry! That's good thing! 
* Garlic Naan - Tasty, but you only get one with an order... hmmm 
* Chicken Tikka Marsala - YUM, I always get this at Indian restaurants! Though I did notice that the curry had a sweet onion like taste, than the more common tomato curry base in other Indian places. Still tasty! 
* Lamb Saag - This was goood! The lamb was all meat w/o bones and tender 
* Fish Tandoori - YUMMY! My friend said it was a bit dry. I just thought it could have slightly less cooked, but not dry.... You get like six chucks of fish! A good value compared to other places. 

Drinks: 
* Mango Lassi - I think they use fresh mango (not frozen) which is a good thing, but the mango tasted too ripe. So that was bit of a let down. 

Service: 
Considering that there's only one cook, one guy making the naan by orders, and one waiter to take orders and serve the food, the service was fast! There is a guy who process the bills and another guy who wash dishes (?). Great friendly service! 

Go check this place out! Not the cleanest, but we didn't see and bugs that goodness....Lol
author: Fried Rice B.

description:
Amazing Pakistani... you can't beat the food for the price...

I would give it 5 stars but it's a bit dirty and if your a clean freak I wouldn't suggest it.  That Said it's part of the charm... and you can walk away completely full for under $12 a person.
author: Allen P.

description:
Go. Go. Go.

Saw the restaurant on KQED's Check Please Bay Area...and it was exactly as described...amazing food (Seafood Tandori, Shrimp Curry, and Nan). Get your own water. Order at the counter. Don't be in a rush...inexpensive, amazing flavors/spices - real(!) eating.

WARNING - If you want clean and pretty and to be waited on, don't go!!!

If you want good food that is local and prepared and served by someone who makes great food, go now!
author: Mark M.

description:
5 stars for the food
3 stars for the speed and service

I finally went here last night with my girlfriend after she told me about it somewhere around 100 times.  We ordered samosas, chicken tikka masala, and vindaloo with two orders of garlic naan.

The food did take forever to get there which is kind of ridiculous considering some people who had to go orders who arrived after us got served first.  

But the food!  The vindaloo is the best, most flavorful, and full of the right kind of spice.  Amazing.  The chicken tikka masala was decent.  Well, I guess just different than the Americanized versions I am used to.  It is not at tomato based as the usual.  I think there was a yogurt base in there.  Not bad, just different.  Let me say this, you have not had garlic naan until you have been to Lahore Kahari.  Best. Naan. Ever.

All in all, a good meal, decent prices, decent service.  Highly reccomended.
author: David G.

description: For me they have the best naan in the city (: && the new owners are super nice and friendly the women who cooks is super friendly & hardworking ! Plus they have remodeled the place it looks better now than it did before well my favorite dish they Serve is Fish Biriyani it really tasty and this biriyani has the most flavor in it !! Also there butter chicken is creamy thick and delicious ! They have good portion and the price is pretty affordable ! Although they do get busy ALOt of the times but if you comd in at 5 it's actully a good time !! OVERALL I think this place is good for family && they also give FREE CHAI(tea) & you can bring your OWN Alcohol bottle ! SO IF YOUR IN THE TENDERLOIN AND STARVING THIS IS THE PLACE TO GO !!!
