author: Mahnoor S.

description:
Lahore Karahi serves some amazing Indian food with great value. By choosing your dishes carefully you can have a five star meal here. You MUST get the palak paneer & garlic naan, and the mango kulfi if you want dessert. The place is a hole in the wall in an unspectacular neighborhood of San Francisco, but is full of well to-do professionals. By hole in the wall I mean I didn't drink out of the water glass. I think it's only the chef & one waiter, so service can be kind of slow but they are very kind. We had: 

- Palak Paneer: Probably the best palak paneer I've ever had, my mom has ever had, and my dad has ever had (and between the three of us, that is a lot of palak paneer). This stuff is so fresh! The flavor is amazing, the texture is perfect, and it's a must (order two). 
- Lahore Channa: Their channa masala was ok. It's not the best I've ever had, but rounded out our meal nicely. It's a bit more sweet than most, darker in color, and more 'soft' (the garbanzo beans are more mushed up). Also I thought it tasted a little peanut buttery, which is not a flavor commonly found in channas. 
- Aloo Gobhi: This is a dish I would recommend avoiding. It's really oily & doesn't have very good flavor. 
- Garlic Naan: Lahore puts garlic and a spice rub on their garlic naan, and it's amazing. I saw the cook pat out the dough & stick it into the tandoor fresh to order, so the bread came out super soft and warm. 
- Mango Kulfi: Wow. They make their own homemade, which is amazing on it's own, and it turns out really really good. The flavors of mango, cream, saffron, pistachio, and a little cardamom come together beautifully. 
- Chai Tea: How nice that it's complimentary. It was a nice end to our meal, and way better than Starbucks.
author: Jasmine A.

description:
My folks are in town from the old country.  I raved to them about the Tandoori Fish at Lahore Karahi.  It's Amritsari style!  Somehow, the fact that they live in the same state as the actual source of this amazing fish style didn't deter them from buying into my suggestion.  And yes, the wanted to try it in San Francisco.  

 We were beaten to the entrance by four women who then tragically took the one empty table while we waited. I walked to the nearest liquor store to pick up some beer and upon returning we opened one of the Pilsner's.  

Quickly, there were gasps. The waiter pointed and said "Nooooo" as if  I had just stolen his first born child.  I walked over the counter to talk to Gudoo.  I told him I had brought beer from the nearby liquor store several times before and had then drunk it in open view at his fine establishment. I also mentioned how I had specially bought the folks from the old country to try his special fish.  I was confused when he, at first, insisted that I could never have possibly done so but then said he hadn't allowed BYOB for the last three months.  I tried to reason that I didn't know things had changed but he would not let us drink the beer.  We left - sadly - no fish eaten and headed to Pakwan which saved the night with their achar ghost, biryani and beer permissive attitude.   

I still love the fish Gudoo but without a nice beer to wash it down, I must take away a star.  Hope you get that license soon!
author: Abhi S.

description:
I never went to lahori karahe before because of its uncooked Naan I was never happy there I always went to Berkely as I am living in East Bay. But since I went to San Francisco I thought why not to eat here just to avoid  friday traffic. I Love there food and I just got to know they have change Ownership I noticed the woman who cooked food is really hardwork, she cooked amazing food which reminds me food from pakistan and India.

Fav dishes: All 

If you want to eat real Desi food go there and Enjoy!!!!!!!!!!
author: Rose S.

description: Gaddu (the former owner) is back in San Francisco with a new restaurant, Guddu de Karahi in the Outer Sunset (http://www.yelp.com/biz/guddu-de-karahi-san-francisco).  If you want great Pakistani/Indian food, you will want to go to his new place instead of Lahore Karahi..
author: Robert R.

description: Just went here last night and a cockroach crawled up on the table. The owners didn't seem to care at all.
author: Michael L.

description:
Yes it's in a sketchy neighbor but that' okay because it's worth it. It's not completely a hole in the wall restaurant but it's definitely not fancy or anything either so don't be surprised. Gets very crowded on the weekends and they don't take reservations. 

We went there based off of a review in a magazine. My fiancé and brother in law loves, loves, loves hot food and the review they read said this place had it. Super hot that they wouldn't be able to eat. So we made a trip into the city last weekend. 

Our order: 
*Vegetable Samosa-It was pretty good, but maybe because we were starving. 
*Naan-It was hot, toasty and yummy...especially dipped in the curry 
*Lahore Karahi Rice-you will definitely need to order this if you're ordering curry 
*Tandoori fish-My fiancé ordered this because he saw them make it on Iron Chef and we all must admit, it was a good choice. Probably our favorite dish there. Seasoned just perfectly to give you that nice flavored taste 
*Chicken curry & lamb curry-Flavorable and had a bite to it 
*Mango Lassi drink-Very interesting. They ran out of it but gave us half a glass to try and it was good. Very thick and I don't think I could have finished a full glass 

What was disappointing was that we had asked for the curry to be extra, super, I can't eat it spicy and it barely even had a bite. We figured they were so busy that they forgot to add some spices to the food. 

It was really crowded and the place isn't big. There was only one waiter and he was running from table to table but he was very apologetic that it was busy so we didn't mind at all. Overall I think I'll be back to try other things on the menu.
author: Betty D.

description: The paneer was okay. Everything was just okay. The environment was terrible. The service was below average. And the rice was skimpy and caked together. I've never been to an Indian restaurant that didn't know how to make nice basmati rice!  Given all the hype, this place was a real disappointment.
author: Mark S.

description: Quite authentic food. Very casual atmosphere and infact it gets little unorganized while seating. But who cares compared to the good food. I ate here chicken jalfrazi with naan. It was delicious. Inexpensive and yet original and authentic.
author: Alien T.

description: Best Indian food ever! Loved the chicken tikka masala and garlic naan.
author: Winston S.

description:
I had heard some twitterings about Lahore's greatness even before I moved around the corner from it. The very first weekend I moved in I took my mom and brothers here to see if it lived up to it's hype. 

In some ways it certainly did. This is definitely some of the better Indian food I've had. It's a bit of a hole in the wall and you can see all the guys making everything from scratch. If you're in to spice, they put A LOT on. I've had some more mild stuff and this was nowhere near mild. 

The nan was my FAV. I'm a sucker for seasoned bread and theirs is bomb. I also enjoyed the chicken korma and eggplant and potatoes. All good stuff. 

If you're looking for fast, efficient and thoughtful service, this is not the place to come. It was chaos and nobody really seemed to know what they were doing aside from the chef's themselves. The server would come with plates of food, hover over us like he wasn't sure if it was ours and then would actually ask if it was ours. "umm, how would we know? What is it?" He didn't know what it was. We also had to wait quite a while for the bill. He kept telling us to go up to the cashier but we wanted to see the bill so we knew what to leave for a tip. We never got it so we just left some $$, went up to the front and waited some more until a chef finally came over to cash us out. We had left entirely too much tip and by then the money had already been taken from the table. 

The poor service won't deter me from coming again bc I know that's not what this place is about. I'm only mentioning it because 1) I believe in fair reviews and 2) People should know that if they're in a huge hurry that this isn't the spot to go. 

Another thing to note is that they don't serve alcohol. I saw a lot of people bringing in their own beer. There's no charge for it either so stalk up before you come!
author: Julia N.

description: I had the pleasure of eating here with a group of co-workers and friends. Our entire group loved all the dishes we ordered. The garlic naan, tandoori fish and butter chicken were standouts. At the time, the restaurant was BYOB (I'm not sure if it still is) and that was/is an awesome perk! The new owners were very kind and accommodating! The new LK is a great idea for groups or even a party of 1. The bill for our group was very reasonable and the food was outright delicious! Thank-you, Mr. & Mrs. Sheikh! Also, don't miss the rice pudding; amazing!
author: Baroness M.

description: The food is good here, but not amazing. I liked the cutesy small SF restaurant atmosphere feel. Self service (you even write your own order), but they take credit card. I had the roasted eggplant curry dish. It was good, but a little spicy. Also had the garlic naan and it was ok. Saw two other groups of people who had brought their own drinks (six pack of beer) w/ them. Service was kind of fast, waited about 10 mins for our food and getting a seat wasn't too bad. Stopped in here on a Thur evening, probably would try other places before I come back here.
author: Irene L.

description: I have been eating here for over 5 years now and this place just gets better each time I go. This place just got new ownership, as Guddu has sold this place and I am amazed by how better the place looks, feels and treats their customers. The Nans are perfect, served hot and the food is delicious. Just about spicy enough for my likeness. I would suggest each of the 1 2 or 3 star people to go again and I assure you, you will change your review and get to meet the new owner, Shan, just as nice as Guddu. I guess Indians/Pakistanis are just raised that way.
author: Sajjad S.

description: Their garlic naan is the best I've ever had!  Some of their other dishes were slightly powerful in spices but overall, the food was steaming and tasty.
author: Brenda L.

description:
The old Lahore Karahi was easily 4 if not 5 stars. It rivaled the Pakwan near 16th and Mission and was better than Shalimar. I'm sorry to say, but the new owners have really ruined the place. The food is not nearly as good as it used to be! Most of the dishes are more bland. The curries are watered down. I order the lamb boti tandoori plate and there was about half as much meat as I would expect and received in the past. The new owners and cooks seems like total weirdos. The previous owner was much friendlier and service was much, much better before. 

Overall, it isn't awful, but I wouldn't go here unless you're Oscar Pistorius but missing your prosthetic legs. If you have legs or means, you need to go to Pakwan (16th and Mission or in tenderloin) or Shalimar.
author: Amar M.

description:
One of my favorite Indian dishes, hands down is chicken tikka masala. The chicken tikka masala here is delicious, although, a bit sweeter than I would have liked. The chicken was tender and it was served pipping hot!! :) yay.. Oh and the rice was delicious as well, it was all spiced out with a cinnamon stick in the middle. I could tell, it was made with love.

The owner, Zulfiqar was very welcoming. As it was my first time eating here, he introduced me to some mango-spiced ice cream. Although it was not pleasing to my palette, the gesture alone deserves many stars.

This joint is truly a diamond in the rough.
author: Nance H.

description:
Another great hole-in-the-wall find! 

First they gave us papadams on the house and I heart papadams!!

Fish Tikka Masala had a really good amount of fish pieces in it with just the perfect amount of spice. But you can order anything to your spice liking.

Saag Paneer, spinach cooked with cheese and herbs was really rustic tasting because they make the cheese themselves and not at all oily like many of the other Indian/Pakistani restaurants out there.

We also had the plain naan and a garlic naan. Garlic naan was my fave out of these two. Tons of spice and really tasty. They gave us the plain one first and about 10 mins later, the garlic one which was great because who doesn't like "just out of the oven " naan?!

Everything was so good, we ate every last drop and were so full.Can't wait to come back and try their other dishes! One thing, put the fancy clothes away because you'll go home smelling like what you ordered!
author: Heidi L.

description: Hands down the best chicken tikka masala in the city. You would never know it by the looks of it, or the neighborhood that it's in, but this is the best place to get take-out for sure. YUM.
author: Suzie P.

description:
Well.  The food here MUST be good. Every table was filled, the kitchen was super busy and there was a line out the door!  Too bad I didn't get to try it.   :*(

Let me paste out the scenario.  It's Saturday night, 12/3 (not really a super special day or holiday) my friend and I came out to the city for dinner prior to a long night of my pre bday celebration with friends.  We were feeling like Indian food so I suggested this place since Yelp was giving it 4 whole stars!  So we are the last people in line when we arrive and I look around... it's a pretty small venue and all the tables were filled.  At that moment I felt a little worried because if all the tables were still filled by the time we ordered - where were we going to eat?  But I quenched that worrying voice in my head and told myself it should be fine.  The couple in front of us handed us a couple of menus (cool - they were really nice).  So we picked out what we were going to order.  About 10 minutes later, we only moved about a foot forward and I'm starting to notice a few things: 1) No one was at the counter taking orders, 2) some of the filled tables had bottles of beer or wine with paper cups.... 3) there was a very long line of receipts on order hanging in front of one of the kitchen workers.  I started to worry a little more.  I didn't want to spend two hours here and completely miss out on my night in the bar with friends.  Still, the glorious smell coming from the kitchen and the authentic looking dishes that were going out made us wait just a little while longer.  Except.....

Another 10-15 minutes later the couple behind us left, we're still standing in the same spot behind the nice couple who gave us menus and I realize that orders were leaving the kitchen and receipts were getting removed from the hanging line........ but then I notice there's a huge stack of receipts taking place of the ones that were removed!!!!  Holy crap - the realization hits me - about 75% of the people sitting at the tables were STILL waiting for their food!  AND I overheard someone saying that they were allowed to bring in their own wine or beer as they waited.  That explained the wine/beer bottles, paper cups and absence of food!  

This was the point where I really did start to worry because we now only had an hour to eat before my friends would be at the bar waiting for me.  So I look at my companion, he agrees that we would probably have a very long wait if we stayed and we, with extremely disappointed taste buds, decided to book it outta there.

It was such a shame we wasted so much time waiting in a line that wasn't moving.  It would have been nice if someone had actually come up to us to let us know there would be an insane long period of wait time.  Maybe one day we'll come back to actually try out the food because there's Got to be a reason why so many people waited a long time for their food to come out!
author: Mercy D.

description:
Thumbs up:

Chicken kabab
Mattar paneer
Rice

The food was brilliant.  Simple and delicious at a great price.  Service was excellent as well.  Came in while it was really busy without calling before hand.  That was my bad.  Was offered a table as I waited and was also offered water.  I'm not hard to please.  Simple acts of courtesy and excellent food is no question worthy of 5 stars.
author: A C.

description:
I was debating on whether to give this place 4 or 5 stars.

5 stars for the food.  The mere thought of eating there is making my mouth water right now.  Their dishes might be a little too spicy for some who are not used to it, but that's just how I like it.  Mm-hmm!  The lamb vindaloo is a favorite, as well as the tandoori fish, the prawn biryani, and the garlic naan.  Again, I'm not too fond of seafood, but the fish is one of the highlights of the meal when some friends and I ate there.  The chicken tikka masala was a bit sweeter than the tikka masalas I have tried in other restaurants.  It's interesting...

I don't know what to make of the Afghani naan.  On one hand, I liked it because it's fruity and sweet.  On the other hand, I think it's a stand-alone that's more for dessert than for dipping in curry.  I also LOVED the pistachio (?) ice cream they gave us in the end.  I'm not sure what it's called though.

Minus 1 star because of the service, the location, and the ambiance.  It's in the Tenderloin--what more can I say?  It's hard to get a table.  And for the busy-ness of the place, I think they are understaffed even if they really try to cater to every customer.  They were pretty fast when it comes to take-outs though.

All in all, I say, don't be fooled by the interior/exterior of this restaurant.  It's one of the best Indian/ Pakistani restaurants I have been to--if only for the food!
author: Samantha A.

description:
The other reviews say it all. The best Indian food in town. And inexpensive. 

I usually get the garlic naan, biryani, and palak paneer. They have the most amazing piping-hot samosas I've had outside of India!
author: Anubhav J.

description:
Heads up; you cannot be shy here, you grab a table/seat where ever you can find for your party, then grab a menu from the counter and fill out your own order slip and hand it over to whomever will grab it.
Next, get your plates/cutlery/napkins.
Finally, wait. It's worth it.
We walked by this place years ago and the smell was freaking amazing. We didn't go in because we were there to take a friend to a certain restaurant (#fail), we finally made it back and will continue to frequent. 
Nomnoms:
We inhaled the veggie samosas, daal makhani, butter chicken, and garlic/regular naan.
Also, on the way, our cabbie asked us where exactly we were going, once we told him, he started raving about the place and said he'd just found it the night before... He also ran inside with us, placed his order, and said see us in a bit when he comes back to pick it up :)
Summing it up, this place teeters on my list of possibly the best Indian/Pakistani food I've ever eaten. I would say 'locals only' but then it would make the tourists flock here. My boyfriend says I'm not allowed to tell the tourists that they'll be mugged if they go here.
author: Paula S.

description:
What can I say that 719 others haven't said?

*Absolutely delectable chicken vindaloo, so fresh tasting and fragrant with oregano and cumin flavors in the thick sauce. For about $7 you easily get plenty to share with a friend, and you get  decent 50/50 mix of chicken chunks with the potatoes.

*Naan that was fresh and pleasantly thick and sopped up every bit of the sauce. For a buck! Come on! Bring on some more!

*Samosas were not heavy and rock-like, which some places can ruin. These were also perfectly seasoned and I think it matters a lot that they're made just moments before and not hanging around on a counter for the entire afternoon.

*Basmati rice that was almost too much to eat. Also fresh and light, not clumpy and thick. It married well with all of the vindaloo.

*Attentive, kind service by my server. I also liked the fact that it wasn't busy at all and I could hold a conversation in the middle of a Tuesday afternoon. Shalimar is never this quiet.

*Next time I have to try the sizzling chicken tandoori, which arrives on a hot platter with a mountain of cabbage.
author: Alfonso L.

description:
I went here on a suggestion from a friend, surprisingly it was only 2 blocks from my house, and I never noticed it. Anyway, it was pretty good for Indian food, which I'm not a huge fan of.

This was probably the only Indian restaurant in the city where the Naan didn't taste burnt, haha. But yeah, I ordered the Garlic naan, and when he brought it to my table, I was intoxicated by the amount of garlic in it. :) Loved it!

I also ordered the Prawn Curry, and it wasn't bad. It was spicy but not overly so. I didn't finish it though, because like I said, not a huge fan of Indian food.

The total was $15 so not too expensive but not too cheap, but now that I think about it, my meal could have fed two people, so then $7.50 isn't a bad deal.

The service itself was kind of 3 starsish...My waiter didn't know how to use the credit card machine so I had to wait until the owner came back. Kind of weird...

**Oh uber uber bonus for having free chai. Luckily my friend told me about it, or I would never had noticed it. It's not on the menu, but you have to go up for self service chai, and I think self service water, bc my waiter never filled my glass back up. But yeah, the chai was pretty tasty, with sugar, without sugar it tasted pretty awful. Not too sure why that is. Maybe it's super healthy? But yeah the main reason this place is 4 stars instead of 3 is for the free chai. :)
author: Xavier G.

description:
I can't believe I lived across the street from this place for a year and then in the area for another year and a half and just tried it out now.  Seriously!  The food was really good.  We had butter chicken (fyi, when you order it hot, it will be HOT!) and chicken saag with naan and pappadam.  Everything was delicious, and the place is casual and homey.  I will certainly be coming back.

If you are looking to use your airline miles through restaurant.com (which is how I ended up trying Lahore Karahi out, they do accept the certificates!
author: Elli F.

description:
Food was delicious.  Price was also as pleasing.  

My wife and I went here for dinner before a symphony at Davies.  Not a great idea, unless you like smelling like bbq smoke.  Fortunately, that is my preferred odor prior to a fancy engagement.  Some guys wear Polo cologne.  I wear tandoori.  And, as such, I ordered the tandoori fish.  So good.  My wife had the saag. Man, that was delicious, too.  

Bottom line:  Great food, will definitely return.
author: Chris S.

description:
I got the Butter Chickenw ith rice and a naan. It was just alright. Good portion tho for a little over $10.
The tandoori meats looked really good tho. Maybe I'll give the place another try for its tandoori but I don't recommend the butter chicken there.
author: Christian P.

description: Visiting the Bay Area for work and wanted some simple south Asian take out.. This place fit the bill perfectly.. the neighbourhood is quite seedy.. However the food is awesome! I like to see my food being cooked- and the food here is cooked pretty much In front of you..the lamb samosas were really good not super greasy and the lab biryani was excellent! More than enough for two meals.. No frills - basic - authentic dive
author: Joel M.

description: Lamb vindaloo, tandoori fish are decent. Garlic naan is delic!
author: Romita J.

description:
In a word Yumm!  This place has really good Indian food.  We went the safe route and ordered Tikka Masala and the Vindaloo and we asked for both to be spicy.  We also ordered some garlic naan, rice and some chicken & lamb kebobs.  All of the food tasted great, super fresh and super tasty!

The resto is located only a few blocks from Union Square, albeit a few shady blocks but it's worth the walk (and the risk;-).  I could see the casual visitor being dissuaded from dining here since it's not the cleanest of establishments.  In any case if you've done your homework you know what this place is all about.

The prices were really affordable, I'm not sure how this guy stays in business...   It cost us $50 for a party of three.  Easily the most affordable meal that we've had while we've been in San Francisco.

One last thing, the owner \ cook reminds me of Babu from Seinfeld...  "You very bad man!"  :-)
author: Timothy W.

description: CHANGE IN OWNERSHIP AND FOOD IS HORRIBLE NOW...Many other friends had similar experience. I absolutely loved the food with the past owners..What a shame now..
author: A S.

description:
Do I love me some Indian food....

This by far is my favorite in the city (so far) since Im on a mission to eat at every single reputable place in the greater bay area. LOL. Anyway, been here twice and both times I was not disappointed.  Always order some kind of appetizer such as the vegetable somosa's and etc.  The chicken tikki masala is to die for and the chicken birayani is great.

Not the best decor, definately a hole in the wall, kinda ghetto neighborhood....but I'm down to make a trip down this way to fulfill any Indian food itch I have.  The service is so so depending on how busy it is.  First time I went service was awesome because it was a random weeknight and nobody was there..next time was dinner and we had to light a flare in order to get their attention.  

The food is authentic and not the fast chain food crap, also very reasonably priced.
author: roe n.

description:
WOW THE FISH TIKKA MASALA  at Lahore Karahi lets the spiciness sneak up on you rather quickly and unassumingly... it's a different kind of spice than I'm used to (grew up on jalapenos and wasabi), and it really packed a gastro-intestinal wallop.  My Chinese acupuncturist/herbalist probably would have been upset with me but fortunately for both of us I didn't tell her and instead endured the after-effects, left on my own devices.

Spicy, but extremely good, especially with the regular naan (the other naan varieties seem to have a bit too much going on in the flavor department and, to me, detract from the herbal complexity of the tikka masala flavor).

Similar to my experience at Shalimar, at first I wondered if this restaurant was smoking or non-smoking because of the sheer and visible amount of smoke (which I subsequently realized was coming from the cooking apparatus and food, not from a cig).

Advice: Expect your clothing to smell strongly of curry for at least 48 hours after your dining experience here, depending on the ventilation in your residence.
author: Peter L.

description:
New management- Stingy 
Quality- tasteless, curries r very dry
Quantity- very less curry
Pricy for the quality of food
Goat Biriyani- 2 small piece in the entire Biriyani, no gravy
The only good thing was their garlic Nan's . Rest all sucks
author: Nifty G.

description:
I don't understand the hype about this place.  I was excited to try it after reading all the good Yelp reviews, and was sadly disappointed.

First off, we tried to order some appetizers for a table of 5.  Vegetable samosas?  "Sorry, we are out."   Aloo Tikki?  "Sorry".  OK, then just some vegetable Pakoras, and some Aloo Paratha.  Papadams?  "No need to order, they are on the house".

- There were no discernible vegetables in the pakoras. They were heavy and  without good flavor. The "chutneys" accompanying them were watered down sauces with flat flavors.
- The papadams never arrived; we had to ask twice and they finally showed up with the entrees
- The paratha never showed up
- "Out" of samosas, probably the most popular Indian appetizer, early on a Saturday evening?  What, they ran out of flour and potatoes?

Main courses:  

- having read so many raves about the tandoori fish, I had to try it.  The flavor, spice and burn were all good, but something must have been unbalanced since I found myself burping tandoori for the next 6 hours.

My companions had:
- saag gosht - fair
- chicken saag - barely touched
- butter chicken - adequate
- chicken biryani - barely touched

Breads:
- Onion kulcha was soggy and needed salt
- Naan was OK but buried under the kulcha in layers, became soggy.

Summary:
Service: slow, missed items
Atmosphere: dank
Food: sub-par
author: Martha M.

description:
I tried this restaurant years ago and i liked it.
Today, they made us wait for hours to get the food (service was bad). 
Meat was very dried and burnt. Lamb Korma tasted like pork, not like lamb. Kebabs were burnt and tasted horrible.

In the end these people overcharged us $17.They appologized, but i was really upset. It felt like they ruined my evening.
I would not recommend this place to anybody. I felt horrible that i brought my family there.
author: Ilyah L.

description: I've been to a good number of Indian restaurants, mostly in Berkeley and San Francisco. I generally don't identify a MAJOR difference in quality between them. This place is head-and-shoulders above the rest. Everything comes to you prepared fresh (rather than out of a big pot being kept warm somewhere). Naan is $1 - this place is about 20% cheaper than the competition. The best way to describe the food is that it is more complex than your standard Indian fare. I can't recommend this place enough.
author: Eric R.

description:
tasty indian/pakistani treats!

favorite dishes: 
- chicken karahi
- palak paneer
- tandoori fish
- garlic naan
- plain rice (cooked with cinnamon and cloves -- mmm!)

it's a super tasty dive restaurant (a bit smoky inside; place-settings, water, and chai are self-service; somewhat dated interior design), very casual. go there for the food, you will not be disappointed!
author: Greg D.

description: Not sure why this place has 4 star rating cause everything about this place sucked. From service to food. It took 35 mins to get our meal. We ordered: chicken tikka masala (there's no flavor whatsoever), chicken biryani (um I don't think you're suppose to add food color to biryani. The color comes from the spices duh which were not in this biryani. Actually, it should be called fried rice not biryani). We also got papadam which you can't really fuck up so won't comment on that but we did ask for some chutney that is suppose to go with the papadam and the server said sure let me get it and he never came back lol We also got some naan. I will say this their naan is freshly made and it was piping hot and delicious. So if you plan on going here just get the naan LOL oh and I also asked for samosa and the dude was like we have no samosa's WHAT NO SAMOSA's ok big tip here DO NO EAT AT AN INDIAN PLACE THAT HAS NO SAMOSA's ITS A SIGN FOR BAD THINGS TO COME
author: Sid B.

description:
My Indian friend has recommended us to visit Lahore. I went with my gf with high expectations because of the high ratings by the reviewers.  The shop was so crowded that we had to wait for about an hour to actually start eating. But the waiter was friendly and we didn't bother to wait. 

And it was worth waiting. We ordered KARAHI CHICKEN(ordered spicy) and SAAG GOSHT for the curry and sesame naan and onion kulcha. The kulcha was so tasteful. the onion inside it was sweet and it goes well with both curries.Sesame was fine but the onion kulcha had more impact to us.

Both curries were certainly delicious and well-spiced. We both love the saag gosht better. The lamb in the curry were so soft and well-flavored. And Karahi Chicken had so much chicken inside it that we were bit surprised of the amount. 

The one thing that we would have hope was that (spice) was not so "spicy" enough for us. Maybe they can arrange that for us if we ask.

Overall we were totally satisfied with the orders and would certainly go back there once more. 

The shop closes on Monday so try to avoid those days.
author: Kousuke I.

description:
The best, cheapest Indian food restaurant in San Francisco, by far. I'm addicted to the Chicken Tikka Masala, and I'm not ashamed to say I can eat an entire plate all by myself while fighting off my husband at the same time. In fact, this is the only negative I can say about Lahore. This restaurant encourages selfish, pig-like behavior.


 Oh, and the location may be a tad colorful for tourists not familiar with the Tenderloin. Just be on the lookout and you'll be fine. This place is worth the risk of being hit up for change every now and again.
author: sfKristina

description:
The food is still excellent; but I can't ignore the declining service anymore.
I'm not expecting fine dining here: I know that it's mostly self-serve, the wait can be long, etc.

But I'm confused and annoyed at:
1. Why do some tables get the free crispy cracker bread before dinner and we do not (anymore)?
2. How come the group that was sat before us get their food before ours?
3. How come I had to remind the waiter about our mango lassis before even getting them?  I mean, they're pre-made already...
4. How come the other tables' mango lassi is filled to the brim, but ours is only filled 65% full?

Sorry Lahore, your food is still tops, but your service (though friendly), leaves a lot to be desired.
author: Mercutio k.

description:
Lahore Karahi is as delicious as ever! And, as it seems to be with every delicious downtown eatery, less accessible than ever! Hungry diners, be warned. If you plan on popping in during SF-dinner-rush-hour, (6-8pm) hoping to order-and-eat in a span of two, even three hours... well... lol. Just, lol. 

The problem, my group realized, during our two-plus-hour dining experience, is that there is only one, max two chefs, cooking each order, lovingly, one at a time, be it rush hour or not. So the creamy, stewy daal makhany you ordered? Yeah, it's going to take at least 20 minutes on top of the time it takes Chef Guddu to make everything else. 

Not realizing this, my group of four crowded in at 7:30, wrote down our order via the new-fangled self-service process, watched the tab slip into Guddu's pocket, and sat down to wait. And wait. And wait. And then wait some more. When, 45 minutes later, the single waiter hurried out with an urn of hot chai, everyone made a mad beeline for it, hoping to refuel their starved bodies with the sticky, hot concoction of caffeine, milk and sugar. It was gone within 10 minutes, and would not be replenished.

An hour and 15 minutes later, we went to check on our meal ticket, which was still lying, crinkled and forgotten, in Guddu's pocket. Realizing this, he pulled it out, chuckling apologetically, and placed it in front of all the other meal tickets, which were being arbitrarily assembled and sent out. 30 minutes after that, we flagged down the harried waiter, who asked if we wanted some naan in the meanwhile. We did, and it came out buttery and hot, within five minutes. Having made this awesome discovery (that naan is the only thing that will come out in under five minutes) we called for more, and when we were finally satiated with the puffy rounds of bread, the dishes started coming out, (at this point, past the two hour mark) staggered, one by one. 

The food wafted up to our noses in fragrant curls of steam, and every bite of my chicken tikka masala was tender, silken and spicy. I enjoyed it greatly, despite the fact that I didn't order chicken tikka masala-- I ordered butter chicken, but whatever-- I really didn't want to wait another hour for that to come around. The kabobs were deliciously smoky, and the aloo paratha yielded comforting, giant mouthfuls of spiced potato and fresh cilantro. 

At 9pm, the atmosphere crackled with the polar swing of ravenous irritation and silent content. Merry beer drinkers gave way into irascible finger-tappers. A displeased Indian family dissolved into smiles when their tandoori fish finally made it to their corner table. 

All said, it would probably be easier to know a Pakistani mama who can make similarly delicious food for you, but if that isn't obtainable... Come full so that you can digest your food during the two-hour wait and then be hungry enough to eat again, or just come really late. 9:45pm should do the trick. You'd have to be a real trooper to eat here regularly.

Happy eating!

Bottom Line: Epitome of the ridiculous foodie experience.
author: Tianyi S.

description: Came in here for a quick lunch with a friend. We came at opening time which is noon. So at that time it was dead quiet. However 10-15 minutes into the lunch service the restaurant became more packed and active. Since my friend and I were in a hurry we ordered four dishes: 2 Naans, Chicken Tikka Masala, Tandoori Chicken, and my personal favorite Lamb Biryani. The naan was soft and buttery and never went hard (Usually after 5-10 minutes Naan becomes crisp and hard as a rock.) Lahore Karahi does a good job from keeping their Naans soft and tasty until the very end. The Chicken Tikka Masla was spicy, tangy and rich. They also gave generous portions of meat (always a plus in my book because some Indian restaurants only give you tiny chunks and more curry sauce). Here it's balanced. The Tandoori Chicken was tasty, juicy, and had a perfect balance of spice (reminded me of my uncle's cooking)! Last but not the lamb biryani. Juicy lamb with the perfect blend  of pure spices. Not too spicy and not too bland. Also this place serves free chai (tea). A perfect drink to have when having Indian food. I'll be coming back soon with other friends that are familiar with Indian food and those that aren't like my friend who I brought.
author: Krishan S.

description:
I've eated at a ton of Indian restaurants (and Indian/Pakistani hybrids for that matter) and this is the best ever!  The tandoori fish is out of this world.  The garlic naan was really good, but twice the price of the regular naan.  And don't miss out on the Saag Paneer (spinach cooked with homemade cheese and herbs)!  The Chicken Tikka Masala is above average, but I've had better.

The food here is about the same quality or better than Amber India, but waaaay cheaper.  The neighborhood is a little seedy, but so what!  Be prepared to wait at least thirty minutes for a table.  And you will smell like food.  It seems the kitchen doesn't have vents, but again, who cares?!!
author: Adrian G.

description:
self service...wasnt crowded , still took lot of time to deliver the order.
pros: nice appetizers ,tea . garlic naan was good. especially the boti kabab chicken .

cons : Chicken curry wasnt spciy enough , had less salt . 
rotis were too hard.  

Will probably give it one more try.
author: Neero D.

description:
They have failed entire Punjab/Lahore
1. The aaloo qeema was stale and microwaved
2.staff was rude and took us an hour to get seated
3. Food was bland and tasteless 
4. Bohat ganda khana thaa. Inhoon nay Ghanta humain bithaya hi. Yeh Malik Pakistan may choora marasi thaa

With better options available nearby why waste money
author: Asif K.

description:
As a curry addict i've been all over the city enjoying indian/pakistan food. I am a regular patron of Shalimar (Jones St), I wanted to see if there was another Indian/Pakistan restaurant on par w/the potato nan, lamb, ginger goat curry, and chix tiki masala i've come to love.

After countless reviewing of reviews, Lahore Karahi seemed to stand out as a victor in this area of expertise with people often compairing the 2 establishments. I thought i had found the one!  Unfortunately, my expectations were far under exceeded. 

Myself and 3 of my fellow indian/pakistan loving friends patrooned Lahore Karah on a Thursday night in hopes that it would be just as mind blowing as our beloved.

General table consensus
- most currys had a strong vinegary aftertaste 
- Chicken was overcooked and chewy
- tiki masala curry tasted burnt
- nan was served luke warm and lifeless
- they didn't server goat and didn't allow beer

Underwhelmed and over hyped?!? I haven't been back since.
author: Maggie L.

description: Absolutely delicious.  Unpretentious ambience with earthly servers make this spot a great find for casual dining.  Just grab some some beers or wine from across the street (avoid the shady shop right next door) to complete the meal.  Chicken korma was great but also do check out their specials too.  Go eat it!
author: Sony P.

description: bomb.com when a friend asked where I ate really good indian food, i could not recall this place for the LIFE of me.  I had to search which auto body my car was towed to (original reason for our trip to SF), then where the theater was (we watched a movie after dinner).  and now i remember why i couldn't remember the name, it wasn't easy to remember.  it was too long since I ate it to remember why I liked it but let me tell you, it's AMAZE BALLS.  I would make it the only meal I eat in SF if I go up there again which is rare).
author: Phebe T.

description:
Wow Tandoori Fish!
We were not mugged, got a parking space close to the restaurant.
Perfect night.
Everything we had was delicious, the naan, chicken tikka, vindaloo
Yum!
author: Pug P.

description:
We have been here twice. The food has been amazing both times. I think the price is great. For the quality of food that you get, the price is very outstanding. Both times we came, the waiter messed up our order. The second time there, we brought our two friends and unfortunately we had to witness a cockroach crawling on the wall. 

2 STARS for the restaurant itself - it is small, old, and smokey because the kitchen is pretty much part of the dining area

41/2 STARS for the food 

I love the butter chicken here and my boyfriend loves the lamb korma!!
author: Cnn F.

description: Food here is amazing. Chicken Tikka Masala was perfect, and the garlic naan was the best I've ever had. Staff isn't the friendliest but the food was so good that I don't even care.
author: Kimberly C.

description:
Amazing!  Thus far, the best Indian I've had in the city.  I had the chicken korma - tender, white meat chicken in a spicy ginger/coriander sauce.  Delicious!  My only complaint would be the amount of clarified butter in the sauce (it was not an insignificant amount by any strentch).  My bf had the Saag Gosht, a lamb saag with spinach & lentils, which was also fabulous (& had considerably less clarified butter in it).  The Saag Gosht had a wonderful smoky, chocolatey, almost mole-like character to it, and the meat was tender & flavorful.  The rice was tasty, and the naan had almost a pizza crust texture to it (which, authentic or not, I really enjoyed).

Service was excellent, and the prices are more than reasonable ($23 for both entrees, rice, & two naan plus tax & tip).  One word of warning - the place is small, turnover is not quick, and the line can be long (there were four parties ahead of us & we waited 50 minutes to be seated - then again, this was at about 8:15 pm on Saturday night).  On the other hand, the food came out faster than I expected, considering that there's one guy doing all the cooking.  Still, the food was fabulous enough that we'll DEFINITELY be back for late-night take out during the week.
author: Angela B.

description:
Something keeps me coming back here, but I've realized it isn't the food.  It's an ever-fading memory of an experience that was amazing at a time when I didn't really know what I was talking about.  A time when Yelpularity + journey from the East Bay + cool anecdote for me to tell in a review =(ed) five-star experience.  Plenty of return visits to Lahore Karahi, but more importantly plenty of visits to the neighborhood's several other palaces of fluorescent light, helped open my eyes. 

The food here is definitely still homey, and it is still made with much care and much passion.  What is unfortunate is that it is not made with all that much talent or taste.  My grandmother makes food with love, but she does not run a foodservice establishment in San Francisco.  I would be shocked to hear the cooks here say they think everything they serve tastes perfect; I don't know any South Asians who like sugar in their curries or dry kabobs.  Everything just ends up tasting like caramelized onions with hot chile powder.  And y'all are reinforcing their misbehavior with your five-star reviews.  

I'm sorry to lash back so hard, LK, but I'm hoping it ends up being for your own good.  I'm hoping that just maybe you'll notice this lonely unappreciative review and then do your best to tone down the candy masala and seekh jerky... that just maybe you'll try to win back some of the hefty lunch money I've been spending at Pakwan and Shalimar.
author: Daniel A.

description:
I'm only NOT giving them a perfect score because of some nitpicky things. Our Tandori fish came out late and cold, then the refire on it was still a bit unsatisfactory, but that is really the biggest negative of the experience at Lahore Karahi and possibly some lack of service here and there.

Me and 3 friends showed up on a Sunday evening around 7pm. We were seated in a couple minutes. 

We ordered:
Vegetable Pakora - Crispy, Tasty and Amazing.
Garlic Naan - VERY GOOD
Chicken Kabab - This was pretty spicy, but tasty, please note it's GROUND chicken, so it's a bit of a shaped kabob, but good if you can handle the heat.
Chicken Vindaloo - Amazing.
Vegetable Biryani - Perfect to mix everything with and wrap up in a piece of Naan.
Tandori Fish - Was good, but ours was cold and refired and not as fresh tasting. Would try this again to see if I missed out on the magic or not.

I saw this restaurant on Check Please Bay Area and I'm so thankful I did. I'm not one to just guess about getting indian/pakistani food. So Yelp and that show gave me the shove I needed to try it out. 

It is now one of my favorite places to eat in SF. 

My belly is smiling.
author: Mack L.

description:
Ohhhh baby, Indian/Pakistani food - one of my faves!

We had a mini feast and everything we tried was amazing!  The tandoori chicken, the paneer palak, and the fish were all impressive dishes.  I would definitely eat here again.  Don't let the hole in the wall atmosphere deter you!
author: Amber S.

description:
Pretty affordable
Quick take-out.
Man that tandoori fish was SPICY! 

Eat in is probably better than take out... Naan was soggy
Chicken Tikka Masala actually had a lot more garlic in it than I've had before at other places.  

Long wait, small restaurant. 

I totally heard "Check Please" (PBS show) on NPR this weekend without knowing which restaurant they were talking about and I could tell they were talking about Lahore Karahi.
author: Alias A.

description: All I will say is - I have not returned to this restaurat since the previous owner left this restaurant. Well, correction - I did return once just to see how the new restaurant owner runs this place. Not even close. All that mattered at this palce was its food and now, the magic is gone. I am still secretly hoping that the previous owner will come back some day and I will get to eat the best Chicken tikka masala and tandoory fish I have ever tasted.
author: N P.

description:
6/9/12 - Uh oh. The main guy is on sabbatical? Food nowhere near as good, made differently, served differently. Yikes, is this the end of Lahore??
-----------------
Best Indian food I've ever had. Total dump but who cares. You may wait awhile but it's so worth it. The Saag Paneer has a depth of flavor I've never experienced anywhere else. The Daal Masala as well. Wonderful naan (only $1), cinnamon scented rice. Thats my usual order. Occasionally stray but always come back to those 5 things. Not sure theres even waiter service any longer, seems people order when they walk in and then find a table. We usually call for pickup and eat at home. (PS - anyone who would rate a restaurant 1 star without ever eating there should be banned from this site.)
author: Josh B.

description: Lahore Karahi... why do I love you so?  no, really why?   Self service restaurant in the Tenderlion. Inconsistent food.  But I do love this place.  It's cozy yet dodgy and the food can be hit or miss at times but I keep going back.  Today I had the vegetarian korma and bhindi masala.    The korma was excellent.  I had a wonderful sauce and a perfect mix of vegies.   The garlic naan was hot and fresh and rice was tasty.   The bhindi masala was ok.  The okra was a little hard and chewy and overall the dish was oily.   I'm going to say that bhindi masala just isn't something I will ever like so I'm going easy on it.  I was just trying something new with that one.
author: Chuck W.

description: I went here on the recommendation of a friend before moving to the bay area. The place is small, the serving staff is responsive and helpful, and the food is great! It's one of my favorite places to eat. Great atmosphere, sometimes very busy. Definitely recommended!
author: N D.

description:
This place is worth fighting off bums and dodging human excrement on the street to get here.  The food is delicious and I am always greeted with a smile when I walk in.  The man that owns this place is an amazing chef, but he really needs to hire more people!  I've been there during lunch when he is the only one cooking, taking orders, and busing the tables.  It makes for incredibly slow service, but good things are worth waiting for.

Order any of their lamb dishes, or their paneer dishes and you will not be disappointed.  The food is perfectly spicy, savory, and oh-so-good.

My only disappointment is the rice pudding.  When I ordered it, I was expecting the soupy, cinnamony, yumminess that normally comes at the end of Indian meals.  Unfortunately, they served thick, bland rice pudding that was nothing close to what I'm used to.
author: Carmen L.

description:
Tasty food and a nice atmosphere. I especially liked that everything was cooked pretty much from scratch after we ordered it. However, Lahore didn't knock Shalimar off my #1 spot. The chicken tikka masala is way more flavorful at Shalimar. At Lahore it was really sweet in the beginning with a spiciness at the end and not a lot of flavor in between. Very good but not fantastic.

Everything was spicy enough. The food just lacked that explosion of flavor that I expect from a top-notch Pakistani restaurant. I did think the samosas were excellent and worth the trip alone. I'd definitely come back here but if I want the best chicken tikka masala in SF I'll be heading to Shalimar.
author: Aaron V.

description: This place is great. I can't wait to go back! Tried the lamb vindaloo (just a baseline comparison dish I try in virtually all new Indian restaurants) and a ground lamb and potato special. The dishes are cooked fresh and served hot. I thought the portion size was good and in line with the prices. The restaurant is small, sparsely furnished, and the semi-counter service is a bit of a put-off. As I said, the food is cooked to order and the kitchen can be a bit slow, so this isn't the place to dash in and get a quick meal. But all said and done, this place is a true find.
author: Jayson H.

description:
I went here for the first time last night, and I must say I was not expecting it to be that effing amazing, and well they totally proved me wrong...With a bag filled with stella artois we were definitely set. We got the paneer pekora (I'm sure the vegetable one was much better- these were glorified cheese sticks but hey I love me some cheese)...then the chicken tikka masala and the lamb korma. The chicken tikka masala was by far the best I've had so far in the city, and the lamb was just so so in comparison. The garlic naan was perfect and tasty. 

The girl sitting behind my friend was rubbing her date's beard. Creepy.  That was the only thing that bothered me while I was there. 

Seriously, this is as good as it gets.
Real talk.
author: Lauren S.

description:
We love good Indian/Pakistani food...there are far too many eateries out there with substandard dishes (especially the cheap buffets!!!)  We don't like to waste our time, so we rely on reading reviews here to help us when eating out of town.  We liked the reviews we read and decided to take a chance at Lahore Karahi.

We were not disappointed!!!  There were 6 of us, including a 4 year old who thought everything was too spicy except for the Naan... the rest of us enjoyed everything from the Butter Chicken (the best I've ever had...just the right blend of spices and texture-I ordered mild but the 4 year old still thought it was too spicy,  to the grilled plates, tandoori fish, kabobs and saag paneer for our vegetarian daughter).

My husband liked the kabob a lot!!!  He is very picky about his Kabobs since he is from Iran and eating good Kabobs is very important to him. 

I must say, the highlight of the evening was eating the tasty fresh out of the the tanoor, Naans.  We ordered all kinds... even ones not on the menu (Keema Naan).  Everything was reasonably priced except for the soda cans!!!  (If you can avoid ordering the overpriced drinks... then you won't be angry about having to pay $3 for a can of Sprite/Pepsi when a fresh homemade Naan straight from the oven is only $1.  (But I could be wrong about the price of the drinks since I didn't actually look at the bill personally and just going by what one member of our party was saying... which is why I didn't take a star away from my ratings.)  

Anyway, our server, a young boy (probably owner's son) was very polite and pleasant, but distracted probably because many people do go through.  We were lucky to be there when it wasn't quite so busy just yet.

I highly recommend this place... especially for those tired of the same menu and blah taste of the usual Paskistani/Indian food.  This place is small.. a bit of a hole int he wall.. but worth venturing to!  You won't regret it!
author: Kit S.

description:
There's something magical about this place; It's cast it's spell on me.

The tandoori fish was calling out to me, and I could no longer resist the temptation of the flavorfully marinated and grilled ocean dweller.  It tasted even better than I recollected.  It wasn't the typical orangish red that I'm accustomed to from tandoori dishes, but more of a curry colored, chunky marinade.  With each bite, I tasted a different mix of exotic spices so each bite gave way to a flavor explosion.  Taking a closer look at the fish, I saw evidence of cumin seeds and pepper flakes, though I wasn't able to distinguish all the flavors were contributing to the deliciousness.  I'm only able to say it has a medium heat with a slightly citrusy flavor, and a garlicky-gingery bite.

I picked up the tandoori mixed grill, which is an assortment of chicken and lamb and was surprised when I opened the to-go box.  Plenty of chicken from a large kabab, boti, a drumstick and breast and one lonely lamb kebab.  The lamb looked out of place in the large poultry parts assortment, almost as if it had mistakenly rolled in before the box had been closed.  I was disappointed that there was so little of it because I love lamb; that is, until I bit into it.  The lamb was dried out and chewy, and tasted a lot like a huge exotic-tasting beef jerky ball.  The chicken was, by contrast, much moister and tender.  I particularly liked the chicken kebab and grilled breast & thigh.

Since I highly doubt I'll be able to replicate the tandoori fish with any success, I'll definitely be back for more.  Definitely go for the tandoori fish, and try the chicken tikka masala too!

After feasting on the various tandoori dishes, I smell strongly of curry so I highly suspect I'll be flying solo tonight and running outdoors instead of working out at the gym =)
author: Janet L.

description:
For the love of all that is fishy, get the Tandoori Fish.  I've never had tandoori style fish anywhere, but it is delish here. 

Oh and these people do NOT mess around with the spiciness. if you say medium, it is quite spicy. To me it was medium but a lot of people couldn't handle it. They don't mess around like a lot of places. So if you are one of those people that can handle generally spicy food, get medium. The higher spicy level must be REAL spicy, and I never get anything but the highest spicy levels usually, so coming from me it says a lot. Then again, if you come on a different day with a different Chef it might change, so order at your own risk! 

It's a pretty small place so be ready for longer waits during busy times. Family style works well here. The waiter was real cool and knew the friend I went with, so he rewarded us with ice cream on a toothpick at the end. That was some good ice cream...they probably have it on the menu, if so, get it! It's orange.

Great tasting food, VERY good prices (under 8-9 dollars will fill most people up). Go here.

Only caveat is that it's in one of the worst neighborhoods of SF (tenderloin), so don't come here alone or with a group of 2-3 girls late at night..make sure you've got guys or a larger group.
author: Edrees H.

description:
Best Indo/pak food in the bay area. Period. 

Lamb seekh kebabs, garlic naan are my favorite
author: Pranav C.

description:
A crackhead tugs on my sleeve.  "Come here, sweetie," he says, and holds on as I try to continue walking.  He was the crackhead of my dreams, I assure you, and if I hadn't had dinner plans, I totally would have run away with him, but...  "Uh, no," I say, jerk my arm away, and hurry on up Leavenworth to Lahore.

Mmm!  Local flavor!

Sketchy neighborhood aside, this may very well be my new favorite restaurant.  We went on a Sunday night--there was plenty of business, but we didn't have to wait for a table.  It's not a fancy restaurant (although it looked pretty clean and spiffy to me), but the smell of the food knocks you flat and proceeds to permeate your entire being, until you smell like curry and MAGIC.

(I had a date that night after dinner, and made my friends smell me afterwards to see if I smelled more like hugs (another story entirely) or indian food.  Verdict: hugs.)

I requested that my (delicious! and $6.50!) butter chicken be made mild, and that was the perfect amount of heat for me--in no way could it be considered "mild," at least insofar as this whiter-than-white girl is concerned, but it was spicy enough to make me feel warm and fuzzy.  Naan and rice are a must, of course.

Best part: it is incredibly cheap.  With tax and tip, the five of us paid $11 each.  This is after 3 orders of both naan and rice, plus five entrees.  Normally I don't put a price on personal safety, but I think a delicious $11 dinner is a fair trade.  I'll walk though the crackhead microcosm for this!

NOTE: their BYOB policy is no longer in effect, and they took our beers from us.
author: Jennie K.

description: Ordered pickup. Everything tasted like it was 2 days old - the naan was hard and dry, the pakora was so hard it was inedible. After paying $43 the food was so bad it felt like an insult. There are so many good places in the loin that there is no need to waste your money on food that should have been thrown out.
author: Gregorio S.

description: Extremely disappointed. The place came highly recommended and I had high expectations. We ordered butter chicken which was bland. Also we ordered baingan bharta which was so definitely NOT baingan bharta! It was a creamy gravy instead of a dark roasted eggplant in a thick tomato base! And let me not even start about the naan - it was ridiculous. Bottom line - awful place, do not go there!
author: Shruti S.

description:
Best Indian food in SF! Prices are good too.

The restaurant is fairly small and somewhat unimpressive, about what you'd expect to find in/near the Loin. The food more than makes up for it though.
author: John K.

description: extremely non professional staff in all aspects. Too much spicy food and poor service. Will never go there again in my life.
author: Tahira R.

description:
First, a caveat, I didn't get to order the dishes I normally would which usually results in me not liking the meal as much. Sadly, this place was no exception to the rule. The one dish, I will say, that blew me away was the Karahi chicken. Awesome dish and not one that's mentioned much in reviews because most people, myself included, would probably order the chicken tikka and tandoori fish like everyone else. Definitely try this dish. 

The rest of the stuff I ordered I wouldn't try again. That was: The choley, which tasted like a plate of mush. I packed and left it on top of a garbage can for a homeless person to take and I'm pretty sure I got a dirty look from the guy who peeked inside. The assorted meat platter had good kababs but the chicken and lamb had no flavor to them. The sesame naan and roti was ok but didn't live up to their potential. 

In all I'd go back to try the chicken tikka and tandoori fish but sadly find myself lowering my expectations about a place I've heard so much about.
author: Shreya C.

description:
Like my friend said: " If you crave Indian, this is a great place to be." She treated me for dinner and we tried the recommended Tandoori Fish and it was absolutely delicious. 
Service was friendly, but don't be shy to self-serve the Chai Tea and water.
author: Tigre T.

description:
I've been here twice now, and if I was just rating the food, I would give it 5 stars, particularly for value for the money but we went last night and the service was just dreadful. We ended up missing the movie we were supposed to go to because the service was so slow.

Let's start with the food. All of the dishes I've had are richly spiced and really nicely put together, especially for $7 or $8. Even old standbys are extra tasty here, and they aren't greasy which can be the downfall of some cheap South Asian restaurants.

I've had the well loved fish curry, and really liked it, the the potato/cauliflower aloo gobhi (extra interesting here and absolutely delicious with what can be relatively bland ingredients) and the butter chicken. All were delicious.

The first visit I made a month or so ago (7/09) the service was quick and efficient. It's a small room and one person should be able to cover it even when busy.

Last night, 9/12/09,  was just dreadful. The one waiter was scattered and couldn't seem to figure out that bringing more than one dish from the kitchen at a time would be more efficient and less annoying to the patrons. He would go to the kitchen, get one thing, and then go back and get another and take it to the same table. Crazy. 

It took 30 minutes for our food to come which seems very long in a restaurant of this sort. People who sat down after us got their food before us, which is always irritating, moreso when you're trying to go to a movie up the street. The waiter was also packaging to go orders, so it's not entirely his fault, but he clearly had no idea what he was doing. 

When the first dish finally came, we reminded him to bring us the bread, rice and mixed pickle we ordered, which he brought ON THREE SEPARATE TRIPS from the kitchen, even though it's either pre-made (pickle) or sitting there waiting to be dished up (bread and rice).

Just crazy. it would make me hesitate to go back, particularly if I was in a hurry, like last night. I'd also say that for a little more money, travelling up the street to Sultan (behind the Hilton on O'Farrell) will get you as good a food and FAR better service.
author: Mike F.

description:
Wow, what a grease pit!  Everything we ordered was super super greasy and not all that good.  

Contrary to other Yelpers, I found the service to be pretty decent, although every table was occupied.  Since there were four of us, we managed to try several different items.  My chicken tikka masala was OK, but there were only about four pieces of chicken - come on!  I hate stingy portions.  The rice was kind of weird and brownish - not basmati, nor was it brown rice.  Some sort of hybrid, I guess.  We really enjoyed the naan and the samosas, even though they were so damn greasy.

My favorite part of the evening was checking out the amazing apartment building across the street, called the Hamilton.  I might go back to O'Farrell Street, but not for Lahore Karahi.  The guy cooking - the owner, I presume, scowled at us when we left.
author: .Hon H.

description: We had to get our own water out of the refrigerator, so things didn't start off well. You see, I'm a person who likes to be "served" when I'm out paying money for service.  But, the food was great, so I forgave them. I was hoping to put myself in an Olympic worthy food comma - samosas, mango lassi, curry after curry, desert after desert, naan bread, naan bread, naan bread...but it didn't happen. I packed a whole bunch and I just kept eating like a jolly fat man with not a worry in the world.  The food is just THAT good.  It's so good it makes you forgive wrong-doings.
author: Pauline J.

description: I cant really give a specific review on Indian restaurants since it all tastes the same to me.. It all looks like poop, tastes really good and you end up smelling really bad when you go home. =)
author: Kayla G.

description:
Being this is my 1st indian food experience ever since I was very apprehensive about trying it (won't go into details why but I assume you can figure it out) it was quite tasty!!

Went with 2 other friends to hold my hand through the process.

Samosa was pretty good! Rate 3 stars

We got 3 naans. garlic (my friend's favorite but not mines), the potato/cilantro one (it was ok), my personal fave was the onion stuffed one. Rate this a 4!

We also got the chicken curry which I thought was ok. The meal was much much smaller than I thought it would be. and the chicken was kind of dry. The potatoes were a tiny bit undercooked to my liking. I would probably rate this a 2.

We also ordered this eggplant vegetarian dish (vindaloo?). I forget what it was called but it was very good! You need to order it with naan or rice though as it is more of a sauce/dip. Rate this 4 stars!

The service here is pretty slow but understandable since there is only one guy serving everyone in a packed restaurant! Hey tough economy. If I could serve all these people and save thousands of dollars I would do it too.

I felt that the prices were incredibly reasonable. We spent $11 on the entire meal w/ tax and tip.

Honestly though with the ingredients of indian food, I just wouldnt want to spend more than $11. The ingredients are flavorful but just kind of simple (potatoes, chicken, lentils, flour, eggplant, etc) Kind of like I wouldn't feel right paying over $7 for pho noodles.

However this place is good and a must try! I was pleasantly surprised by how much I liked the food. (Didn't love it but I don't think I ever would due to the simple ingredients).

I will have to agree with someone who commented that the place smells like BO and smelly feet but hey you end up acclimating to that in 5 minutes! And jsut make sure you open your car windows when you drive home. LOL
author: Em F.

description:
Pretty tasty food I must say.

Chicken Tikka Masala: Okay, not the finer point of the meal.
Garlic Naan: Awesome!  Tasted great!
Sheesh Kabob: Awesome!  Very Flavorful!

Next time I'm trying the fish...
author: Limzer L.

description:
Boyfriend took the words right out of my mouth with his review- http://www.yelp.com/biz/lahore-karahi-san-francisco#hrid:B17TMN7aRopQ1Xs7TMtq3w This wasn't so much bad curry as good salsa. If you like your curry chunky and minimally cooked, you might like it, but it wasn't for us.

Before I found out the price from his review, I was a little miffed by the portions. The aloo gobi skimped on the cauliflower and there were only two tiny chunks of potato. A large styrofoam take out container turned out to only be 1/3 filled with rice. And speaking of the rice, I know that it's super expensive, but there was NYET saffron. It was as inauthentic as Russian in a review for an Pakistani restaurant. Although, historically speaking, that would actually be pretty authentic. But I digress. Once I found out that it only cost $24 for two "curries", tandoori chicken (too dry), naan, and a large(ish) rice, I was happier about the value. We'll just have to order more when we go back. Which we will, 'cause I have to try that bass that everyone is mentioning. 

And 'cause I like Mexican food.
author: Lauren C.

description:
This might just be my favorite restaurant in San Francisco! 

Lahore is nestled in a very a safe/ un-sketch block in the tandor-loin.  Parking is always easy, prices are right, service is great, and the food is heavenly..

I've tried several Pakistani/Indian places, and this by far exceeds any competition.  Lahore is seriously in a league of its own!  

I typically order the chicken tikka marsala, mango lassi, garlic naan and a few samosos.  My girl friend gets the butter chicken. 

Trust me you can't go wrong!
author: Peter G.

description:
I would wait in a two hour line in the rain to eat here. Luckily I only had to wait about 30 minutes and it was not raining. 

The chicken tikka masala is the best that I have ever tasted. I am sad that I only get to have it when I am in San Francisco, which is a rare occasion. Paneer Pakora and Vegetable Pakora are both great. Garlic Naan is AMAZING and the rice is AMAZING.
author: Mary M.

description:
Great little spot for Lahori cuisine with great prices and friendly staff!  There are a number of restaurants serving Indian/Pakistani food in the area and this one is the best I've found.

Pros:
The owner is so nice and friendly!
Choley!  Daal!  Nice texture and seasonings.
Inexpensive
Great for eat-in or take-out
Brown basmati rice

Cons:
Samosas were not freshly fried
author: Maggie R.

description:
4.5 stars.

I compare all Northern Indian food to Amber India, and it wasn't QUITE as good. Nonetheless, it's still some of the most amazing and complex indian food I've had, and certainly the best for its price point. 

Everything was very intricately seasoned, but none of it was overwhelming.
author: Mark A.

description:
Came here for a second time last night and felt compelled to Yelp it this time.  Probably my favorite BYOB Indian in the city.  The prices are RIDICULOUS-- $7 for lamb/chicken dishes?  $6 for veggie plates?  You can leave this place so stuffed for under $20, its almost a crime.

I've had the famous tandoori fish and I agree, its delicious.  The lamb korma is spicy and the lamb is perfectly tender, although we could have used a touch more salt (we love salt).  Mattar paneer was solid.  

My warning is that medium spicy = pretty freakin' spicy.  I enjoy the spicy, but they're not kidding when they say medium.  I'm not sure if I could handle anything higher than medium.  

My only complaint is that dishes don't all come out at once-- we waited at least 5 minutes for our rice after our dishes had been served, which was kind of agonizing since we were hungry-mungry!  But all was forgiven once our rice arrived and found its way into our mouths :)
author: Kristin P.

description:
Would've given it 5 stars had I written the review when I came here two years ago. Although a bit disappointed by the service and cleanliness when I revisited this time, the food is still delicious without a doubt.

Pros:
- Very authentic - the food is not drenched in butter as most Americanized Indian food is, you can actually taste the various herbs and every dish is extremely flavorful (which means it can also be VERY spicy!) You get a variety of dishes, not just limited to tandoori chicken and chicken tikka masala
- total hole-in-the-wall with cheap cheap food & huge portions, two thumbs up!

Cons:
- Slow service - I guess they are short-staffed after all. There's one chef who is also owner of the restaurant and two waiters...basically waited over 20+ min for our food
- Not exactly the cleanest place (but you won't get stomach problems) our water tasted like curry...my friend even had curry chunks on her cup! 

Recommendations:
- Tandoori fish...it's just as good, if not better than tandoori chicken! 
- Chicken tikka masala - has a combination of various spices with a sweet taste to it, and surprisingly, it's not greasy! 
- Samosa - bursting with herbal scent, a must have!  

Come here early because a line starts forming out the door after busy hours and the turn-around is not very fast because they are really short-staffed (basically 3-4 ppl serving a restaurant of ~30)
author: Melody L.

description:
My favorite Indian place in the bay area/city. It takes a while for stuff to happen at this place, but the food is totally worht the wait. Plus the prices are as down to earth as the food. This is good good food. I especially liked the seekh kabab and the karahi chicken. The aloo keema was also good. 

Overall a fantastic place.
author: Puneet L.

description:
This is a nice place. I'd give the food a 4 and the service a 2. When I went there was just one poor waiter in the crowded restaurant, and he was clearly overwhelmed. 

The best part of the meal was the garlic naan. Other Indian restaurants just add chopped garlic and olive oil to the regular naan (don't get me wrong, I have no problem with that - I'd order a side of chopped garlic if it was on the menu), but at Lahore Karahi it was like a whole different delicious dish. My entree, shrimp curry, was fine but nothing to write home about.
author: Adam B.

description: Whole in the wall south asian place with stellar food! I had the palak paneer with tandoori roti. The palak paneer was off the charts on the flavor dimension and spicy just the way I like it. The tandoori roti was made fresh and the perfect combination of crispy and chewy. My only complaint was the the paneer wasn't as great as it could be.
author: Vrushali P.

description:
This is about as good as Indian food really gets. 

After a first awkward initial experience involving the level of involvement by our overworked server, I figured out what you're allowed to do here: whatever you want.

Yep, you want a pitcher of water? Go and get it. Or wait. It's all up to you. That is not what makes this place good, however.

When you dip your freshly prepared naan into the perfect flavored curry sauce you will realize why this place is so good. I have yet to try a dish that wasn't amazing. What else do you need to know?
author: Ryan V.

description:
Not everything is a winner, but these are 5-star-worthy:

* butter chicken--this one is different than the one at Amber, which is more tomatoey; it's creamy and has a combination of spices I can't ID.
* kheer--mushy like it's supposed to be, not milky which seems to be the norm.
* biryani--better than (Mission) Pakwan. Pakwan biryani is rustic, and here it's tender, spicy, and refined.

Looking back at my list, it looks like an unadventurous order of a Indo/Paki dilettante. All that's missing is the garlic naan, which I also order. But whatev.
author: Mehul P.

description:
I've been wanting to get my 'curry on' over here for years, because it's just a few doors down from the loved ones house. The place is usually packed to the gills, but since I no longer have the temperament to dodge the occasional stray bullet and/ or hooker, we'd always end up elsewhere. And then came the rain...washing all the hoodlums away, and the customers apparently. Lahore Karahi was empty! Jerry, Omar and I feasted on Chicken Vindaloo, Butter Chicken, some other chicken fantastakabobbie thing, garlic naan and mango laasi's. 

The chicken vindaloo was perfectly spiced, although if I had it my way - I would have made it bloodcurdling hot. My fellow diners have weaker constitutions.  The naan was thinner than what I am usually accustomed to...less dense, with a light crisp to it.  More importantly: the garlic was fully-cooked, not thrown on at the end, rendering it too pungent.  The butter chicken was indescribable.  It seemed to be a combination of a light curry, a smattering of sweetness (cinnamon, I assume) with a tub and a half of butter thrown in for good measure.  I wanted to doggy paddle in the freakin' sauce...it was that good.  The mango laasi's were perfectly paired for the dishes as well...not too thick, and not too sweet like some other places I've been to.

And now the pet peeves:  The Bollywood film playing on the television was simply terrible...and yet I could not peel my eyes away from it.  The food was brought out awkwardly...one dish at a time, then the naan.  By the time the raita came - there was nothing left on the table to dip (other than my spoon, and so I ate it like soup).  Also they did not give us enough rice for three people.  Lastly, Jerry bit down on a 

R
O
C
K

(okay, it was a pebble)  But still - WTF.  He sank it in his water glass, cleaned it off and passed it around the table.  Sure enough - it was a rock.  We banged it against the table...scratched the table with it in fact.   And then we scratched our heads.  Maybe it was a spicy rock? A spice rock?  A cinna-pebble? We debated how such a pebble could get into the vindaloo, and then debated some more whether to tell the chef-owner when paying.  Jerry decided he should.  The owner just kinda looked at it for a bit.  Then he picked it up and rolled it between his fingers.  The smile never left his face.  I felt awkward.  US/ Pakistani relations are slightly strained right now, and I thought this might add to the tension, so I went out for a smoke...

Moral of story:  Enjoy the food...order extra rice and avoid rocks and uncomfortable situations.
author: Mc Matty b.

description: I went to eat here with my family yesterday.  The man working at the register was quite rude.  I ordered extra food to go at the end of our meal and he had the audacity to tell me to order earlier next time.  I told him I can wait and he acted as if he didn't want to take my to go order.  He started lecturing me about when to make the order next time and seemed annoyed that I was going to BUY more food!  How ridiculous.  My family and I will decide WHEN we want to make the order not when you tell me to.  Me nor my family will be returning with this sort of customer service.  Does the guy not want extra business from us because we already finished dining in?  Didn't understand.  The food was bland and tasted a lot like yogurt.  Did not taste as good as other Indian restaurants I've been to.  Overall, I did not like the treatment so I won't be returning.
author: Susie A.

description:
This is ABSOLUTELY the WORST experience I've EVER had dining in San Francisco (I normally love hole-in-the-wall places but this place has failed miserably). 
To be fair, the food was good (I wouldn't say great, but above par),  
but the SERVICE was PATHETIC and EXTREMELY POOR. 
And the owner was IRRESPONSIBLE and IMPOTENT. 
I do not want to go back in memory and list all the HORRIFYING mistakes the waiter and the owner made (while blaming each other and shoveling responsibilities to us, which is totally unprofessional and absurd). 
We wasted 2.5 hrs in frustration and anger.
To sum it up, I will certainly not go back there ANYTIME SOON, and will send out an email to warn all my friends to stay away from that place.

Of course, the COCKROACH that crawled over our table, the plate of Naan that was mis-served to us that we unknowingly touched, and was then served to the table next to us didn't help either.
author: Mengqiu W.

description:
Spending the night in San Francisco? Go to Lahore Karahi.
Two hour layover? Go to Lahore Karahi.
Driving somewhere within 3 hours of the SF city limits? Go to Lahore Karahi. 
Week long family vacay? Go to Lahore Karahi...seven times.
