I am forever ruined. Sure, I had heard/read the great things about Lahore and Andrew K. had prepped me for what I was about to eat. But even with the highest of expectations, I was blown away. A transcendental Indian food experience, for sure. 

I was lucky to be there with an elite Lahorian (yeah, even bigger than Yelp Elite) so I didn't even see a menu. Trust me, it doesn't matter: everything here is perfection, right down to the chai. I was eyeing the leftover chicken tikka masala sauce and was relieved when fresh, soft, wonderful hot naan arrived so I wasn't forced to lick it straight from the bowl. 

Unfortunately, all Indian food outside of Lahore now just tastes sad.  And that, in turn, makes me sad. So until we meet again, Lahore, I pine for you.
author: Kathleen M.

description:
So I've been here twice. Didn't order either time. 

I just arrived, sat down, and waited for the parade of naans and curries to be delivered. I ate, my eyes watered with dense satisfaction, my stomach rejoiced (and did not revolt at any other point), I ate more, the fish, the chicken, the curries, vindaloos -- shit, i don't even really know WHAT I was eating. All I knew was that it was perfectly pleasing to the palette and that I love my cousin for repeatedly choosing this place whenever he visits. This is the only Indian place so far in the city that has brought back memories of Indian food in London. And that's legit.

Just wish that BYOB was still in place. But it's cool. You gotta do what you gotta do, Lahore.
author: Chieh T.

description:
this place is great. varied menu, great food, low prices, and BYOB.

it's also a little weird with bright fluorescent lighting, fill out your own order slip, seat yourself and maybe share a table, cash only pay on your way out.

GREAT, CHEAP FOOD + WEIRDNESS = HELL YES.
author: Chris B.

description:
5 stars for the food!!

This place makes DELICIOUS food.  It has a very laidback atmosphere with Indian music/ soap operas and the owner is very charismatic. The portions are good AND you are likely to have food left over once your stomach is stuffed beyond capacity.

I will come here again and again. I recommend the chicken biryani.  Now for the warnings..


*WARNING* 

Eat a little snack before coming here!!!!! The wait is WAAAYY too long and smelling the food cooking while you're starving to death is pure torture..

*Also, the food is VERY spicy but oh-so delicious and (i am practically drooling as I write this) you won't be able to stop yourself from eating it, despite your mouth being freakin on fire.. Luckily there's a pitcher of water ready at each table for your burning mouth. You do get used to the heat once you start eating and you focus on the convo you're having with your friends/significant other.

This place may look like a crappy little hole in the wall nestled in the filthy Tenderloin district (which i love) but it is truly a treasure. It has awards displayed on the wall and even has a Zagat rating.

Support local businesses and check out this gem.
author: Jenna N.

description:
The service was fine.

The saag paneer? The cheese was burnt. And the rest tasted like old coriander sauteed in Dinty Moore beef stew (you know the flavor I'm talking about). Seriously; I think they used coriander instead of spinach/greens/anything good. The naan was okay, but the Tikka down the street has better. Will I go back? If someone else pays, I guess. Everyone else has spoken so highly of it... maybe this was a colossal fluke?

Seriously: that was the most disgusting food I've ever paid for. Bleck.
author: Annelise D.

description: Very good Indian/Pakistani food! This is one of my best finds for tasty Indian food after I moved to the city 3 months back. Both vegetarian and meat options are good and I would definitely recommend this place.
author: Sandeep A.

description:
Lahore Karahi has some hidden aptitude that will reconcile whatever quarrel you have with your hunger . 

Run by an upbeat cook who really perfected the art of multi-tasking, you have to respect the guy. Granted he does have a helpful staff of about 2-3,  but heavy lies the task of keeping that place functional. Expect to wait a bit if there are a lot of people (and there usually are, the place is phenomenal). 

Valentine's Day was hectic in the city but my girlfriend and I braved the trek from the East Bay. Parking is always a joke, come with a few quarters and a lot of good karma. After 6pm though, the meters go into sleep mode which is convenient to know (a bummy dude told us as he disappeared into the night haha).

You get to snack on an interesting wafer that has a taste resembling corn flakes;  it comes with two dipping sauces. Once the wait is over, all that is left is to immerse yourself in whatever you ordered. 

We got the chicken tikka masala with two orders of garlic naan and some balsamic rice! Every friggen' bite sent a jolt flavor and spice that never stopped coming until the last of it went extinct on our plates. The craft and expertise of the cook is matched by no one. Kudos my friend, I WILL be coming back.

All hail Lahore Karahi
author: Matt B.

description:
Makes me re-think my 5 star dedication to any other Indian/Pakistani restaurant in this city.  I give out a lot of 5 stars because well, I thrive on approval, it's a sickness of mine, by the way, did i mention how lovely you look today?  

But for realz, this place is off the mother flipping CHAIN.  Do yourself a favor and put on whatever lame outfit is laying on your floor covered in vomit from last night's happy hour (Do I know you or do i KNOW you?  Actually, don't answer that questions...there is a strong possibility we have KNOWN each other in the past.) and get your ass over here.  

If you are vegan or vegetarian or not a moron, you will order the Sabzi.  It.  is.  AMAZING.  Not oily at all and full of flavor.  The rice is something magical and the roti (with sesame seeds!  delightful touch!) is INSANE.    I mean, that bread will physically get up and knock you over being all, "Bitch, I am delicious!"  

I didn't notice the food taking forever on a Friday night but it might have been the sassy company I kept.  Come here with a group of hot bitches and junk and the time will fly...besides, you won't have time to talk when the food is out because your internal monologue will be all, "FUCK WORDS!  THIS MOUTH IS FOR EATING!"  Honestly, I wanted to bust into song after this meal.  Unfortunately that song was Ludacris' "Area Codes" and that is not a song you want to sing in the Tenderloin for fear of being confused with an actual pimp.
author: Laura B.

description:
Although a San Franciscan native, and growing up just a few blocks from the Tenderloin, I have only recently discovered my love and appreciation of the "Tandoor-loin." This particular little restaurant is pretty darned amazing. Especially once you realize the entire place is run by just two guys - one chef and one server.

Due to the lack of staff, the wait can be pretty long. Remedy? Don't walk in hungry. Come here knowing that you will be hungry soon. Order your favorite Indian/Pakistani fare, grab a few beers from the nearest liquor store, and enjoy the conversations that will ensue amongst your party of friends as you wait.

If you're anything like me, ordering at Indian restaurants is more like throwing darts at a dartboard. Sure, there are the staples like naan and chicken tikka masala, but what are all these other things? And how do you pronounce them? Rest assured that whatever dishes do end up on your table at this place will be top notch tasty. 

It also isn't too bad of a walk to the theaters from here. If only the waiting wasn't so long, this would be my choice for pre-theatre munches. Wait a minute... is curry breath classy?
author: Erk R.

description:
A friend and I recently saw a review of Lahor Karahi on comcast's "on demand" programing. True to the reviewers comments, the service was pretty slow and the potato naan and karahi rice were VERY good. The price was also extremely reasonable. 

The rest of the meal had a lot of potential, but fell a bit short. We decided to share the karahi chicken. Both of us prefer mild, when the 
meal came out and I took a bite I thought my throat may actually be on fire.... The server was very kind and he sent it back (giving us an extra naan) in exchange for a milder version, but even the newly made dish was STILL on the hot side. Very good flavors, but it was hard to taste them through the heat. After seeing what others were getting, I believe that one of the Tandoori dishes would have been preferable. That said, with 3 stars and a plethora of restaurants to choose from, not sure I'll be back.
author: Jamie G.

description:
Updated without a true update because it deserves five stars. I can easily say this is one of my favorite Indian places. Delicious and cheap, just the way I like it. 

I can never remember the full name of this restaurant. I always say something along the lines of "Lahore Blah Blah Blah" or "that Lahore place." Service is slow and strange. Over the fantastic birthday weekend, we had the most bizarre dining experience ever. It was a little stressful, but oh-so-delicious! Twilight zone dinner. Every action taken was first discussed in our committee of three. 

Should we sit down? 

Do we order here, or will he come over here? 

Do we get our own plates? 

Should we grab some water? Silverware, maybe? 

Is this our food? 

Does this come with rice?

Where's our other naan? 

Should we pay our bill from the table or bring it to the register? 

What's going on!?!

Why isn't he bringing our change? Should we have paid with credit card instead? 

The Garlic Naan was like a mini garlic pizza - delicious! The Chicken Tikka Masala was surprisingly not just sauce and a few bits of chicken like at other places. We also ordered two vegetable curries - Benghan Bharta and Aloo Saag. Tasty!

With all the discussions that took place, the dinner lasted quite a long time. So come here if you have the time. Plus, there is just one person cooking the delicious food. Well worth the wait if you've got the time! I'm trying the Tandoori Chicken next time - it's supposedly their signature dish.
author: Tinna H.

description:
My friend brought me here for dinner one night and I have to say it  was so good! I was not sure what to think since it is not in the nicest part of town and it was a hole in the wall place.

We went to dinner on a Friday night and it was very crowded - we had to wait a little bit for a table.

We got:
Garlic Naan
Sesame Naan
Seekn Kabab
Butter Chicken
Lahore Karahi Rice

Everything we order was good. It did take a bit to get the food since there is only one person who works the front of the restaurant but it was well worth the wait. 

When I went it was BYOB - but from what I have heard that has not changed (too bad too).

The dinner is also very inexpensive....
author: Emily W.

description:
So, the decor is about as fabulous as your average crack house or church group rec. center in some depressed backwoods county, but there are some times when atmosphere is important and some times when it's not. (And if you're not flexible on this issue, you probably shouldn't be dining in this neighborhood anyway.) 

Lahore Karahi is about the last place the wallpaper matters, because this food is fucking insane. It's the Dottie's True Blue of the Tandoorloin. Oh wait... no it's not, because Dottie's is... Never mind. Suffice it to say it's the kind of joint where one very talented dude does all the cooking. And dude is amazing. You can imagine it takes a bit longer with only one person manning the kitchen, but if you consider it that way, the wait is negligible. And it was empty when we were there, so it really wasn't a wait at all. 

Anyway, what you need to know is, chicken vindaloo, sesame naan, saag aloo and if you're lucky they'll bring you some raita, and you're stoked. It's going to blow your mind and you'll be back. Bring friends or anyone you want to impress. If they don't like LK, they're nobody you want to know anyway.
author: Megan W.

description:
Wish there was a minus or no stars or report to the health department category.  Lunchtime mealtime the food delivery guys enter stage right (O"Farrell Street).  The owner who is also the primary cook greets the delivery guy warmly, hugs and greets the delivery guy"s dog more warmly including saliva everywhere,.

 I leave it there - straight from dog to food prep and my appetite left the building.
author: John K.

description:
Ok, so... it's not the cleanest, and it's really small, and you'll have to expect a long wait for your food to come out, and you'll have to serve yourself water, and you'll need to oversee that they charge multiple credit cards correctly, and all your clothes will smell like tandoori fish so make sure you are not wearing your favorite dry clean only outfit, and don't expect to actually get all of the things you order type of restaurant. BUT it feels authentic, the guys here are actually really nice and the lone chef cooks wonderfully tasty Indian/Pakistani food. 5 stars because of that!

Our party of 11 left the ordering to Miss Miriam, who ordered a fantastic variety of dishes to please both vegetarians and non, and EXTRA rice and naan for the Asians at the table. The food just kept coming out and we even had leftovers in the end. We were all overly stuffed (and smelled of tandoori fish) and can you guess that our bill came out to only $13 per person? Actually, I think the last time I went, it came out to $7 per person, so we really ordered a lot more food this time. Absolutely one of the best cheap eats in the entire city!
author: Connie C.

description:
December 15, 2006

HBO Corporation
Programming Department
1100 Avenue of the Americas 
New York, NY 10036
Attn: Carrie Bradshaw
Samantha Jones
Charlotte York
Miranda Hobbes

Dear Sex and the City ladies,

RE: Pilot Concept

Although I never voluntarily watched your wildly popular show, I was obliged to watch it on many occasions by my ex-girlfriend, who had a powerful love affair with the show that rivaled - and then outlasted - our very own.  The content and social value of the program totally escaped me each and every time I was mandated to watch, however, a healthy respect for your popularity was not lost on me, and I was always awe-struck by the influence your show possessed over sorority girls, far and wide from coast-to-coast. 

Last night, as I sat with my three little friends Sav B., Celebguru (please please please), and Ed M. at Lahore Karahi nibbling on vegetable biryani, enjoying the intimate conversations that unfold between close friends, I found myself with ample time to think about the striking similarities between the now mythically famous nightly dinners enjoyed by you four girls and our own delightful little dinner interludes at various dives upon San Francisco's skid row.  As the others shoveled cauliflower pakoras and spoke of ungodly things, my creative side was inspired...

My question to you is as follows: would any sort of copyright infringement be involved if my bitches and I were to start our own show, and possibly call it "Sex and the Gulab Jamun" or perhaps "Tasty Bitches on Skid Row", or maybe even something like "Four Little Bitches Nibbling on Vegetable Biryani" or something to that effect?

I have even sketched up a pilot script and a series of potential characters.  For instance, Sav might be a character similar to Samantha's, because they are both slutty Prada scarf-wearing whores; Celebguru could be the Charlotte of our group, with his doofy comments about deep colds and overall lack of comprehension; Ed might very well play a character similar to Miranda because of his thick, lustrous red hair, strong work ethic, and sense of intensity and seriousness.  And, of course, my own character might take on a feel that is quite close to Carrie Bradshaw's character, being the wise voice of reason and the central character in our storyline (its my pilot).

So, in closing, I just wanted to run these preliminary concepts past you and get your thoughts on the legality of my pilot idea.  Please have your agent, or an HBO representative, contact my agent or lawyer at your earliest convenience, so that my bitches can get together with you bitches over one of those dinners, and have an opportunity to discuss this potential goldmine idea in greater detail.  

Thank you for your consideration.  I look forward to a thoughtful response....

Sincerely,


Rick Hirsch
Reluctant Fan
author: Rick H.

description:
Best Pakistani/Indian in the tandoorloin. I'm a big fan of Shalimar but Lahore Karahi eclipses it in many respects: 

(a) They cook everything fresh to order. I don't actually want my order to arrive at my table before I walk over there and sit down. 

(b) The service is kinder. Surliness is only lovable to a point.

(c) Marginally nicer digs. Make no mistake, it's a discount dive, but it's a little cozier and cleaner-feeling, as though they're actually trying to do the best they can with what they have than wearing their diveiness on their sleeve.

(d) Vintage 70s Bollywood movies. Got the wifey singing along.

(e) Most importantly, extremely good food. Two big thumbs up from two big South Asian food enthusiasts.

Bonus: For your after-dinner entertainment, have your car battery die while parked in front of a gaggle of crack fiends. Be sure not to lock your door when this happens, since that would be paranoid, so that the most cracked-out of them all can open the passenger side to "talk to your girl" and "borrow your phone to make a call". Hopefully the guy with the warrant will be among them that evening so that a police cruiser can roll up next to you and commence interrogation and body searches as you patiently sit and wait out the 70 minute ETA for AAA. Good times all around.

UPDATE: Be prepared to wait if they're busy. A long time. It's just one guy in the kitchen.
author: Tom L.

description:
Highlights:
Garlic naan ($2.50)
Butter chicken ($6.50)

The prices were fair, just like the weather.  We also had mill juli sabzi ($5.50) and regular naan ($1).  The dishes were all really good- not too oily.  The chicken in the butter chicken was awesome- definitely marinated in something yummy!  Lahore Karahi is small, cheap, and yummy- infinitely better than Naan n' Curry buffet at 2am that I didn't go to (okay I did, but I regret it!).  I only subtracted a star because the portions were pretty tiny.  My boyfriend and I split the two dishes and two naans and my half was just barely enough food for me.  When we got home, he started eating again.
author: Cersei T.

description:
This place is great, no doubt. If you want a super down-home Indian/Pakistani eating experience though, I would hit up Kabana on University in Berkeley; light green walls, dim fluorescent lights, menz cookin in the kitchen, bollywood bonanza jumpin off on THREE different screens, bathroom that would induce immediate cardiac arrest in one martha stewart and food that will blow your damn mind. Anyways, onto the review at hand:

The Good - Chicken Korma, Chicken Tikka Masala (a lil sweet, but not too much), Garlic Nan, Saag Paneer, Raita (they whipped it up fresh, DAMN! Thank you!!), fresh homemade achar (pickled veggies), and mango chutney.

The Aight - Tandoori Fish; too fishy, not that fresh tasting, but based on all the other rave reviews, maybe just an off night? Mango Lassi; tasted a lot artificial. 

The personal growth/"have a heart you bougi twit!!!" moment - My friends and I were gonna roll out without our leftovers b/c we had flights to catch and the waiter brought us take-out containers anyways and told us to pack it up and give it to someone who needed it - "it's not right to throw this food away in here when someone is hungry out there." word!!

Service was fast on a Sunday night and we were seated immediately.
author: Preet K.

description:
Reason I love living in San Francisco #2,795,034:  Lahore Karahi.

You can go to any number of highly rated, expensive restaurants in any part of the world and be sure of enjoying a great meal, made-to-order, with unique flavors, sophisticated spices, and a variety of ingredients to entertain your palate.

Only in a city such as ours can you do this for under $15 per person and leave full, satisfied, and wanting to go back.

Lahore Karahi is an excellent find.  I never would have known it was there without Yelp, but after reading the many glowing reviews, it had been in my bookmarks for some time.  By sheer luck and timing, I was able to try it tonight with a group of fine folks to accompany me on my maiden voyage.

Naan, Samosas, Saag Paneer, Chicken Tika Masala - all as colorful, fragrant and delicious as any meal that I have had in India.  The tandooris coming out of the kitchen were sizzling and savory, and the special Basmati rice had a toasted flavor that I really enjoyed.  Dessert was a combination of home-made cardamom ice cream "cubes", and Rice Pudding - a great pairing to finish a great meal.

The Mango Lassi is a great example of the authenticity of the food here.  It tasted of yogurt and mango without the over-sweetened taste that I have come to associate with overly creamy Tika Masalas which I can imagine are made to suit a Western palate.

The atmosphere is no-frills casual, yet inviting.  If I lived in the neighborhood, this would be a regular stop for me.  I just ate there and I am already dreaming of my next visit...now that's something.  What time do they open again?
author: Liz S.

description:
Being an INDIAN, I know for real how the real taste of indian/pakistani food should be, and I have had better pakistani food in SF.

I tried lamb vindaloo, chicken achar and samosa. you can get better samosa at  restaurant near 3rd and folsom. I would say lamb vindaloo and chicken achar are just ok, nothing special about them.
author: Abhishek G.

description:
Wow. 

With the number of glowing reviews, I triple checked to ensure this is the same place I went to the other day...  Indeed it is and I'm quite baffled.

My experience:
Samosa = ugh
isn't the filling supposed to be potato based? I swear, the innards of these suckers was mushy overcooked basmati rice. Like I literally saw the grains... and it curiously resembled Chinese porridge.... with a hint of curry.

Chicken Vindaloo = ick
This is basically what happened:
looked down in my curry ---- saw a pool of grease ----  first thought was ew!! ---- but since it got great reviews on Yelp, assumed the grease was part of what made the curry so great ---- took my spoon and stirred the grease in with the roux. Yes, I am a sav. (a savage... not in the literal sense)

After I took my first few bites, I realized the grease would not have helped the core taste of the curry =/ The reason I love Vindaloo so much is for the depth. It's spicy, with a liiiiitle tangy kick (from the vinegar) which blends SO beautifully with the spices from the curry... but not this one. Maybe I got a bad batch....? =/

Garlic na'an = yikes
I love love LOVE garlic na'an.. but not theirs. It's WAY too greasy and WAAAAAAY too bready. And not in the yummm it's so soft and melts in my mouth type good bready.

I would normally be angry at bad food, but this time I was sad since I love Indian and the nice man with the mustache gave me a free piece of garlic na'an.  I actually feel bad for giving a bad review....


*note: second star is for the nice man with the mustache
**note 2: i couldn't finish..well i didn't want to eat the second piece of na'an so i wrapped it up and tried giving it to the homeless man on the corner who told me to F*CK OFF. sheesh. i was just trying to help!
MAAAAN I love SF!
author: Mona N.

description:
Lahore Karahi is the best Indian joint in the tenderloin. The food is simple and delicious and unlike the other similar styled Indian places close by  (pakwan, chutney, shalimar, naan-n-curry etc..) where the food is usually pre-made, the cook/owner cooks every dish from scratch for each order. All dishes there are excellent. I always get the Aloo Gobi though each time I go there. 

If you're in a hurry though, I won't recommend you going there  - almost always a crowd for the tiny place in the evenings and the service is no rush. You can bring your own drinks and they have the wine glasses to use (still trying to figure out though what wine goes good with curry). Many liquor stores just outside on the same block. If you don't BYOB, they do have Free chai.
author: Nilesh D.

description:
What did you do with my adopted Indian mom, Elizabeth?

 Did you kidnap her and have her make your samosas for you? Where is she hiding???? 


Where did you put my maataa? 


After all the times she recommended Shaadi.Com, told me I can marry anybody I want, told me "you're so pretty, you'd make good babies!",chased Akshay Kumar (the wrong Akshay http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Akshay_Kumar) thinking it was the right Akshay who I have a crush on in Bollywood films, all through the entire Singapore Aiport just to get an autograph? One day she had to move and I have not had a good samosa since that day. :( We keep telling each other we will find time and she'd hunt down Akshay for me and feed me more samosas, but alas, that day in Goa, stuffing my face with her samosas is but a dream.

But wait,  after not seeing her for awhile, I think she is here....hiding somewhere in the kitchen of this hole in the wall restaurant with authentic yummy food and Old  1960's Bollywood flicks of Sholay and Khabi Khabi!  After all the stories of her in Bombay making food, and her colorful stories of travel, Lahore Karahi has captured my mum Elizabeth. Good business move. 

The food tastes like my adopted mum's, so don't expect to leave in a hurry. Good food takes time. When it's from scratch, you can consider it homemade. 
So Lahore Karahi is far better, so it can't even be compared to Shalimar. Shalimar becomes Delhi Belly and Lahore Karahi is like being in Elizabeth's Kitchen, while she tells me stories and tells me repeatedly, "You're sooo pretty, you can get any husband you want, You'd make good babies!"
 Doesn't get better than that. Saag Paneer, Butter Chicken, Freshly made Naan and all Halal. OH BOY! 

Hey Aunty Elizabeth,Where's Akshay Khanna (the right Akshay http://8c.img.v4.skyrock.com/8cb/fleurdeglace01/pics/89131440_small.jpg)? I think you need to go to Goa next time to find him for me. He surfs like me! :) Of course, if Lahore Karahi can spare you for a week. I'm sure they could let you go for awhile. But I'm sure they were doing just as well before, but I'm convinced, they have you, Aunty. Return the Samosas to me. ALL OF THEM. :D
author: J A.

description:
Unbeknownst to the savvy local guide (in this case, not Yelp the site but the inimitable Miriam W) we saw menus...well, saw the covers of menus, for all of a few seconds before they were whisked away in the shadow of whatever Bollywood gem that was spinning onscreen above the tables.  

Over the course of the ensuing hour, we watched and gnoshed in wide eyed  amazement (well, at least amusement) as the courses rained down upon us: tandoori fish (*so* flavorful and tender), chicken tikka masala (which satisfied my Indian sauce jones), even the naan had a nominal kick to it, which was a welcome surprise.  When in New Delhi, as the saying goes, and we paired the whole thing with some Anchor Steams that seemed to do the trick.  Thanks for the memories, Miriam, and thanks for the grub, Lahore Karahi.  Can I clone this place?
author: Kevin N.

description:
Four stars for the food alone, but I had to take one off because 1) we found a strand of hair in our food and 2) the waiter asked us to leave right after we paid the bill because a party was waiting. Not cool on both counts.

My friends and I had the Butter Chicken, Lamb Korma, Aloo Gobhi (cauliflower and potato), and side orders of Lahore Karahi Rice and naan. Although I'm not a big fan of Indian food, the chicken seriously made me reconsider this--I loved the flavor of the creamy sauce and butter. Butter definitely makes everything better. The lamb was extremely tender and the curry, well-spiced. It's always interesting to see cinnamon sticks used outside of desserts. I found the cauliflower and potato to be mediocre, but my friends really enjoyed this dish. The rice was incredibly fragrant and the naan, hot and doughy--I'm just in love with everything doughy.

The waiters will serve you water but you have to self-serve Chai tea. I don't understand the logic in this at all. Anyway, I'm actually looking forward to trying more Indian food--or just to get more of that butter chicken. This is definitely one of the better Indian restaurants I've been to in my life.
author: Liz T.

description:
THREE YEARS!!!! - They've been around for THREE flippin' YEARS!!
I have been living in the Yay-Areaaa for 6 years now, and I just find out about this place like, NOW?!?!?!  Heights of unfairness.

Can I just say that the food was nothing short of FREAKIN' amazing?! - I was there with a vegetarian friend, so we didn't touch the meat dishes, but dang they were awesome:

1 Veg Pakoras -- holy-mother.
1 Shahi Paneer (equivalent of Paneer TIkka Masala) -- divine.
1 Daal Makhaney -- just like home.
1 Pala Methi Aloo -- sigh!
2 Garlic Naan -- with butter!
1 Raita - aight.
1 Gulab Jamun -- was disappointed =`(

Grand Sum of All Things Yummy ~ $30.50
(read: $15 per person and we both ate like Maharani's bitches)

Neighbourhood/ Ambiance? -- Sketch-a-licious baby! 
-- There's this raised TV in the back upper right hand corner of the restaurant, which looked like it had once been afflicted with brown packaging tape (supreme fix-it tool of my childhood) -- lets just say I wouldn't wanna sit underneath it -- and no, NOT cos it would threaten to plop on my head at any given moment, but because I wouldn't get to watch the HILAAARIOUS reruns of old-school 90's era Indian Film Awards they play on repeat!! -- I knew all the songs by heart, and was totalmente diggin' it and a-boppin' in mah seat..

The Gulab Jamun was what they lost a star on, for me though -- I have supreme expectations for my belovedly sweet brown balls (ahem), and I had a momentary let-down.  They tasted slightly stale, and the syrup was watered-downy type..Ah well, ya just can't win 'em all!

After a little chit-chattin' with the brothers (one cooks, one serves) I got to hear a few stories of theirs, and when I got back to my table a (freeeeeeeee!) dish of 'Kheer' followed suite... and THAT my friends made me happy ever after in the land of "Desert" (yes, this is how they spell it on their website!=D) -- and made me re-consider "4 stars" to "5"... oh joy!

NB: -- This grub ain't for ye faint hearted -- the dishes are spicy -- so when uncle takes your order, be sure to say "mild" and I can almost guarantee you it'll be just as tantalizing to your taste buds. Oh and: BYOB.

I came.  
I ate.  
I drank 2 Peach-Hefeweizens.  
I went home.
& Passed Le Fuck Out.
author: Anjali V.

description:
Ahh yes! An experience to restore my faith in the Yelp hype! From reading some of the reviews, I would have thought that there would be swarms of flies, grimy walls, and greasy table tops. Yeah, it's kinda divey and there are probably people doing crack across the street, but the little restaurant itself isn't THAT bad. Luckily, the Pakistani-Indian food lived up to the rave reviews!

We split the Bengan Bhartha (roasted eggplant w/ onions, tomatoes & cream) and the Saag Paneer (one of my faaaavorites - Spinach w/ fried homemade cheese). Both of the dishes were DAMN GOOD. I think that it's really easy to make mediocre, watery, bland (even w/ all those spices) South Asian food...but this is the real deal. Flavorful, spicy depth, full of creamy texture...I could swim in and drown in this stuff and not care. We also ordered the Aloo Paratha bread, stuffed with potatoes and sprinkled with cilantro, which was very good despite being a bit overcharred. Man, this food made me think, "Hmm, maybe I COULD do the vegetarian thing." And then I started salivating over the Tandoori Chicken of the people sitting across from us. Nevermind!

I love how you can watch and interact with the owner/chef Guddhu, who suggested the Fish Tikka Masala for next time...Delicious food + rock bottom prices + friendly service = a new SF favorite!
author: Steph P.

description:
Whatever you do, don't you wear your favorite jacket/hoodie/sweater/anything to this place, it will smell like indian food for DAYS. Even if you step in here for like 5 minutes, TRUST.

The food is fantastic, and it's ultra mega super cheap. Also, all the beverages and stuff are self serve, makes things easy. Staff is nice and will help you with ordering. Especially if you come with an entourage. That's all I really have to say about this place, if I lived closer, I'd probably be here more often.
author: Richard T.

description:
Service is not great. The kitchen is messy and right in the middle of the dining room. But who cares? The food is amazing.

I usually get something to go. It's a simple order and always done perfectly. Chicken Korma with a side of rice. And if you like your food spicey, just ask. He'll kick it up a notch -- and it'll hurt so good. The rice by itself could be a meal. It's delicious and perfectly spiced.

To summarize: If you don't mind putting up with a little bit of disorder for a great meal, eat here. Or be like me and get it to go.
author: Brendan K.

description:
Hot hot hot, that's how they do things at Lahore. The owner, a good-natured fellow, is 9 times out of 10 the guy also making your food. He takes his time, but the results showcase the quality, flavor and freshness of the dishes.

The tandoori fish is a standout, but I also was impressed with the spices in the biryani rice dish our party also ordered. 

There is enough seating for a casual meal, and the food is delicious enough that you just might forget you are in one of the more run down areas of the Tenderloin.

BYOB, there is a convenient corner store on the block, and Indian/Pakistani food without beer should be a crime.
author: Nish N.

description:
After getting me tipsy at Bourbon & Branch, Megan W. took things down a notch and bought me dinner at this joint. GODAMN. It is wonderful. Owner/chef is always smiling but his waiter/slave looks emaciated. I have no idea how he could be with the off the hook food that is coming out of this kitchen. Spicy, full of cilantro, chicken vindaloo not covered in that weird red sauce other places use, creamy chicken tikka masala (a little too sweet, actually, but nothing some raita couldn't fix), DIY chai station, lovely, spicy samosas and FRESH papadam. I rarely go to places that are worth the Yelp hype, but Lahore Kahari brings it. It's been brought.

And becuase I know you fools love gossip, I didn't put out. Megan is gonna have to work a little harder.
author: Maria D.

description: Bad customer service. Ordered to go, then 30 minutes later, nothing. Went up to the counter, inquired about my order, and my food was just sitting in a tucked away corner. Walked a couple doors down to my apt and food was cold. Disappointed. Will have to go farther for Indian now.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
Awesome, just awesome pakistani/ north indian food. I'm generally very picky when it comes to eating restaurant Indian food, but this is one of those places that made me feel like I was eating back home in India.

I had the grilled meat plate, the lamb curry and the chicken biryani. The lamb curry was to die for. Good stuff. I'll be bringing more of my friends here.

The location may be of concern to some people because it's in the Tenderloin. But if you go with friends or in a group, you'll be fine.
author: Savio A.

description:
All the raves you've heard about Lahore Karahi are deserved. The food is outstanding. Three of us shared the saag chicken, tandoori fish, rice (spiced with a cinnamon stick) garlic & plain nan and chicken kebabs. Our samosa appetizer was so fluffy and light we were taken aback by the subtle quality - delicious. The saag chicken was the best any of us has ever had, only tiny flaw was a touch of dryness in the chicken kebabs, easily offset by the side chutneys. The sizzling tandoori fish on a bed of lettuce and onions was very tasty, but we felt the saag chicken was even better.  This is one time when you really want to saag!

No corkage fee, friendly service and casual, convivial atmosphere (aka hot guys & gals eating cheap, tasty dishes in close quarters) made for a fun, lively evening. You may have to do a little scurrying to receive your check quickly - but who cares - it leaves you more time to sit around the table and nibble on the delicious food.
author: wendella a.

description:
WOW.  I never thought I'd say this, but I think it is better than Shalimar.  I need to go back a few more times to be sure...but wow.  Where shalimar feels like they just threw some curry into a dish and served it to you, the food just felt...crafted here.

First of all, unlike the other places, you actually have a waiter, and he actually takes your order and serves you your food.  The chef Guddu makes GUDDU FOOD!!!  (har har har)  but damn he's aptly named.

We started with those little cracker-like, naan-shaped pieces of unrisen bread and chutney, on the house.  Took a while for the food to come, and there was no beer in the fridge (I'm guessing it's BYOB like shalimar), but it was worth the wait.

We had the chicken karahi, the eggplant dish (starts with a b), and the tandoori chops.  I couldn't believe the lamb chops could be better than shalimar, but they were actually better marinated, and well grilled.  Served on a hot iron plate, it gets that nice korean bbq smell in your clothes, so BE WARNED.  But it was really tasty.
The chicken karahi was perfectly stir-fried--just chewy enough, yet still moist, with some flavorful pasty stuff all over, and some good bite (we got all the dishes "spicy"), and some good balance of sweetness and flavor in general.
The eggplant dish was very tasty!  Perhaps a little too sweet, but overall well balanced and flavorful.
The naan was just right, and we saw Guddu kneading and throwing around the dough as we walked in. 

Prices were good, not quite as cheap as shalimar, but still inexpensive.  I believe the tandoori chop was $8, chicken was $6, eggplant was $6.  But I can't remember, so don't quote me on that.  Total for the meal was $25 before tip, including a coke, garlic naan, and rice.

I'm definitely a fan now!  One of my bengali buddies introduced me to shalimar back in the day.  I'm gonna have to take him here next time he's in town!
author: Fong L.

description:
i have been here three times but this is the first time i wanted to write a review. the first time i wasnt really impressed with the food. the naan is doughy and burnt....dont know how that happens...but it just wasnt that appealing. the first time i had the chicken tikka masala. again...not too happy with the quality. last night i got the following

garlic naan...ehh....no thanks
fish tandori...bomb!!! but hella spicey.
butter chicken....on point.... its sweet with some nuts. great texture super yummy.
lamb biyrani.... the rice is soo good! i would just get this alone next time.
rice...it was okay but not the best i have had.

its ok. it reminds me of naan and curry which i am not a super fan of either. i think some people might like it but im sure that if i dont mind walking one more block i can just go to chutney.
author: Ashley H.

description:
byob...grubbin' paki/indi food in the tenderloin....bit sketchy part of town....but good dinin' for perfect nan...and mm...charbroiled fish and chicken...excellent curry and rice dishes.....and..oh so good fried appetizers...even better....

turtle slow dinin'...suggest...bringin' a six pack to guzzle away while waiting for food...worth it?...yes..(if you have time to kill)....how much?....about $12 total per person to fill you up to the brim....with friendly service.....
author: Hen A.

description:
Lahore is the kind of place that's light on pretense and fancy shmancy decor and instead is heavy on the good, simple eats. The tandori fish and chicken tikka masala were greatt but the naan was my favorite. As for drinks feel free to BYOB or reach into the fridge and grab a soda or three and some straws for your friends.

Miriam W did a great job of choosing a great place to enjoy a simple dinner.
author: Maria A.

description: I rarely eat Indian food these days because I can find no other restaurant that compares to this place.  One of the things I most miss about the old neighborhood!
author: C S.

description: What can I say? Very cheap Indian food that is also quite tasty. I've certainly had better  Indian food, but not for $7. And yes, you order at the register and pour your own water. This isn't a fancy sit-down restaurant (though some people whining about the service below seem to think it is), it is somewhere you go for cheap, tasty, and fast Indian food.
author: Alison V.

description:
All I can say is don't bring your mama, cause this place is smack your mama good!!!!!  

BYOB!  We let the Sapporo flow all night.  Corner store about a block down sells libations.  My desire to drink beer out of a little brown bag became reality!

Crowded last night.  Happily waited for about 20 minutes because past experience has proven:

LINE = YUMMO FOOD

Okay, now to the GOOOOOOOD STUFF:

-Fish Tandoori
Comes out piping hot on this sizzling plate with the aroma filling the air.  The spices on the fish just merry so well together.  

-Vegetable Samosa
Best I've had.  Potatoes inside weren't mushed together, but separate small pieces with onion and spices, hot and jingling around in a perfectly fried pastry.  Woooo baby.

-Lamb Vindaloo
Leans cubes of lamb.  Sort of a faint lemony taste and not as spicy as I've normally had.  Very good.

-Chicken Tikka Masala
The added nuts, not sure if it's almonds or pistachio, gave it a more earthy taste.  Very good also.

-Barlic and Plain Naan
Nice balance between crisp, hot and chewy

-Basmati Rice
Soooooo fragrant.  The dish passed by my nose as he set it down and the smell was heavenly.  Tasted delish too!

-Mango Lassi
Served room temperature.  Great flavor.

Two guys who work the tables are super sweet and very helpful.  All in all, a really great meal, worth the visit and worth the wait.  If you like Indian, this is a must must try.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
You kids out here in San Fran know how to do BYOB right, and Lahore Karahi fits the bill. With a case of booze under the table and co-yelping workers around me, we dove into some spicy, tasty Indian food. A small spot, but if you get in, the tandori fish was an Indian dish new to these tasty buds and quite nice. 

Going in expecting slow service is probably the best defense - there are only literally a few people working here. Think of it like this: you wouldn't yell at your grandma in the kitchen for being slow churning out Thanksgiving dinner for you, now would you?
author: Deanna J.

description:
Gotta love the curries here. Tikka masala, vindaloo, keema and butter chicken are all fine choices...but I recently discovered the nihari (not on the menu) which is my new favorite. Nihari is a traditional Pakistani dish that's apparently served commonly for breakfast. I don't have prior nihari dishes to compare it to, but I thought it was damn good. It's a darker curry, a lot oilier, served with beef, (reminds you of Japanese curry) and packs a lot more punch with the spices. Ask your server if they've still got any nihari in the back because it ain't always gonna be around.

I'm not a huge fan of the tandoori fish (as I'm not a huge fan of tandoori to begin with), but it's still good. Naan's are solid here too, get them over the rice. 

I don't know where the old guy went (haven't seen him around the past couple times) but that guy's a character. If you try to get similar dishes - say CTM & Butter Chicken - he'll give you grief for getting the same thing and try to cajole you into ordering different tastes. Same thing with the naan - don't try to sneak in an order of two plain naan's or he'll get on your ass. 

When it's time to get the curry fix on in San Francisco, there's only one option - Lahore Karahi.
author: Tsubasa O.

description:
This place is one of the few reasons why I miss living in the Tenderloin. 

Aside from having an amazing BYOB rule, and the awesome 70's bollywood movies occasionally whistling from the corner television, this is some of the most flavorful, authentic, and well kept Pakistani restaurants I've ever been to. 

Contrary to what it looks like on the surface, this place has its shit together and it's true they pay more attention to the food than the decor, but that's what adds to the charm.

Don't expect loads of attention. Not because they think they're better than you. It's because they're friggin busy!
author: Sandra H.

description:
With a case of Anchor Steam in hand, we trooped  it over to Lahore Karahi and proceeded to feast on plate after plate after plate of spicy, sauce-covered, bread-dipping Indian delights. 

A newbie to Indian food, I have little to add in the specifics of why this is good Indian food. I defer to a higher power (aka Miriam W) who guided us to this under-the-radar restaurant that looked as if they couldn't serve a tennis ball, let alone a satisfying, belt-busting meal. 

The food came in rounds (just like cocktails at the bar when you're out celebrating with your friends). I just couldn't say no each time the plate was passed in my direction (just like at the bar, who says no to a good cocktail?) and each dish just got better. I appreciated the the creamy cooling sauce that counteracted the spicy dishes, the tender, juicy pieces of chicken and the speedy, polite service.

As I wade deeper and deeper into my experiences with this cuisine, I will most likely be measuring up many of my future tastings to the faire of Lahore Karahi.
author: Leighann F.

description:
My experience at Lahore was certainly satisfactory but I must admit I walked out scratching my head as to why this place is so hyped-up by the likes of 7x7 magazine and legions of Yelpers.

We started with the Veg. Pakora appetizer which was quite nice, not too hard and crusty like what you get at many Indian/Pakistani places.

I wasn't quite as impressed with my Chole main course.  The waiter specifically asked whether I wanted it mild, medium or spicy and as usual I opted for spicy but I'm convinced he must have brought me the mild instead.  It did have a nice enough flavor but no heat to it whatsoever.  This was also the first Chole I've had in which the chickpeas were not whole but broken up into a sort of mush.  

One more thing, this is definitely not the place for you if you demand a squeaky-clean eating establishment.  I'm personally willing to overlook a great deal in that regard but I should mention that there were quite a few flies buzzing around our table and there was a piece of old food stuck to my fork when I sat down, not a great first impression.

That said, three stars for some good and very inexpensive grub.
author: Mike J.

description:
For all the true culinary enthusiasts in the city, let me just start by saying LK is a destination that you must experience at least once in your lifetime, if you have any sense of gastronomic adventure.  

Let me digress for a moment to dissert one "David S." inexplicable review, which is arguably the stupidest ever in the history of culinary literature.
 
1.  BYOB is a bad thing?!  I'm speechless, you don't deserve beer or anything else wonderful and delicious in the world.  What, do you require that alcohol be stored and serviced to you, instead of simply walking twenty paces to the corner store?  Are your cubic zirconia shoes too tight?

2.  So by horrible service do you mean personal and unpretentious?  Did you not see the entire staff of one or two at most?  Ludicrous, yes your comment is.

3.  It took you 2 hours to order food?  Jesus, just pick one, they're all good!  And "initial" ordering, what a wonky concept.  You mean I have to choose what I'm going to eat?  Madness!

4.  Well, if you ask stupid questions, you're more than likely to get a non-response, which is what a non-stupid person would do in that situation, and Guduu is not a stupid person, he's a wonderful man and a cultural historian.

Glad you thought the food "rocked." HARDCORE!!!  EXTREME!!!

So Guduu came to see how enjoyed your meal, and he probably not only prepared all the food himself, but also invested the time to shop for all the ingredients at local grocers and vendors because he truly cares about what he does and the patrons he serves, and that equates to bad service?  You're dead to me.  

To conclude on a more amicable note, I pretty much disagree with everything our young culinary padawan David has stated about Lahore, and I give it my highest endorsement, Guddu's establishment is a true diamond in the shitty TL rough.
author: Michael P.

description: Food is good.... but i've called a few days in a row and they will just say theyre closed rather than take your order.  Such a joke.  Terrible business
author: Chris D.

description:
I think Megan W. is slowly trying to convert me to liking indian/pakistani food.  I hate to say this but it's slowly working...

I like the brown lamb stuff, the orange chicken stuff and naan.  

Megan knows what that stuff's called don't ask me...

Dude!!  The waiter is hilarious...don't ask him for anything extra cuz he may tell you that the cook may not want to make it OR he doesn't want to run out of what you want in case other customers order the same thing.
author: Jay H.

description:
They fry the basmati rice with peppers.   I can't go back to ordinary basmati rice now.  

Yellow Dal is great.  Saag is great.  The saag here is not so creamy and is sprinkled with cilantro!  Love cilantro.   
And, it's so cheap.  Why do I want to pay double for something inferior.  Well, you do smell after you leave here like smoke.  They don't lose to the Korean bbq fumes.  

Warning: One man show.  Don't go if you are inpatient.  Chef doesn't deserve your attitude either because he cooks alone, prepares everything as orders come in, and very proud of what he serves.  

Update: He hired someone else.  Now he has two helpers....though it is still all at chef's pace.
author: Wakako U.

description:
Hello my holy grail of curry fat, and spicy fare. Where the hell have you been all my life? Ah that's right you've been a damn good secret, and I hope you stay that way forever....not enough to close you down that is, but that doesn't seem to be a problem. 

There are so many great things about you, but here's one. You are open from 11am to 11pm everyday. Now for those who complain about waits, pish posh. I don't see a wait at 3pm ladies and gentleman. All I see is the smiling face of the owner as he prepares food for my friend and I, the only diners in the restaurant who funny enough are sipping on cold beer bought from the corner store (Bring Your Own Bottle makes a come baccccck!). Want some sparkling rose with your curry? Yes please.

Now on to the curry, the butter chicken and sagg paneer (or sagg ghost) are necessary as is the garlic nann. All are melt in your mouth, artery clogging heaven. I have never cared so little about my waistline as I have here. Three dishes and three nanns between two people? Usually a family could eat that, but two women who love Lahore Karahi can also do the job.

And then there's the tandoori fish. They won an award for this, but it was not my favorite. No not at all. It was good, but hello butter chicken! You're good enough to butter me up plump and get me walking bare foot with babies hanging off my shoulder. If I end up dying and I have one last meal, you better be it babe.
author: Alexandra M.

description:
Please accept my humble apology for the following novel in the guise of a review...

As a musician, I often fall into the trap of hearing only my favorite interpretation of a classic - such as Mozart's Requiem. Each crescendo or crack of the soprano's voice becomes the *only* way to hear the piece. My taste buds seem to have this dysfunction too because I kept comparing Lahore Karahi to Shalimar with each bite.

I was stoked to visit LK based on great feedback from yelpers with top notch cred. The delicious and filling food, super low price and my curiosity to find a new king of the hill over Shalimar beckoned my appetite.

I ordered Chicken Tikka Marsala, my Indian restaurant litmus test, and a chick pea dish, Lahori Chikkar Choley, along with rice and plain naan. What a bargain ringing in at $20 including tip - very nice! The Chicken Tikka Marsala wasn't the bright radioactive lava orange that I know and love - maybe that's actually a good thing! The familiar spices and flavor came through on my first bite - but it was much denser, creamier, sweeter and less spicy than Shalimar. It was a more subtle experience. The juicy chicken was cooked perfectly and it all paired nicely with the lightly oiled brownish rice. I enjoyed it, especially because it seemed less oily than Shalimar's. However I preferred the fiery kick and bolder flavors of Shalimar's orangey lava.  

The choley was another story. It was super salty, cloying, dense and pretty much unpalatable. I like chick peas in Indian dishes - but this one rubbed me the wrong way. The naan also fell short of Shalimar. Instead of offering a crisp exterior yielding to a delicately puffy and tender center, I gnawed on a crisp but dense hunk of flat bread. And what was up with that yeasty sour flavor??? In fairness it served its purpose to cut the dish's sweet richness. I shed a little tear cause I loves my naan.

I'll admit I avoid dining in the tenderloin. Walking from Van Ness to LK provides stereotypical tenderloin thrills and chills that I prefer avoiding. Unless we took a cab, I wouldn't be surprised if my girlfriend withheld sex because I made her walk in this crappy neighborhood.

I actually like the idea of hole in the wall restaurants, just so long as the cooking area is clean - or it's kept well hid. Nope, the kitchen's dirty and visible at LK. The show "Ramsay's Kitchen Nightmares" should film on location at LK. LK scores 80 on the SF Dept of Health inspection for exposed storage of food, unclean non-cooking surfaces and poor handwashing facilities. http://sfscores.com/#Yz0zNy43ODksLTEyMi40MSZ6PTE1Jmk9KDM3Ljc4NTU3MiwgLTEyMi40MTUwNjEpJmY9TGFob3JlJTIwS2FyYWhpJnMxPTAmczI9MTAwJm89cm5k

I did admire the Jackson Pollack-style art splattered behind the filthy stoves in shades of day old curry - oh wait! that is day old curry.  Dirty pans were everywhere and containers of ingredients were on the floor in front of the ovens. This sh** makes you go "Hmmmm." Aren't we all believers that a clean kitchen produces tastier, healthier food?

The owner of LK, "Guddhu" was really friendly. I liked the feel of the place and how Bollywood movies were playing in the background. You can tell this restaurant is part of the fabric of our fair city. For example, a customer came back and said something in an Pakistani dialect - perhaps she forgot to tip - and Guddhu smiled and waved a "no problem" and she thanked him.

It's not like Shalimar has a much better health score (86 and I've seen cockroaches there), but I'm still locked into hearing my Indian dishes conducted by Maestro Shalimar.
author: Brady K.

description:
I've been ordering Lahore Karahi a bunch lately, but last night was the first time (and probably last) that I'll eat there.

It wasn't a terrible experience, but somehow the overall vibe/cleanliness of the place left me disappointed. 

Also, something I ate made me extra regular today, and I'm one of the few people who you will never (except this time) hear complaining about Indian food making them sick. 

I think it was probably the shrimp. So, my bad I guess, for ordering it.
author: Jason R.

description:
I've had WAY better.  Saying that hurts because I was really looking forward to "the best Pakistani food in SF".  

Now before I get into my review, let me say that I do know a thing or two about Pakistani food.  Whereas I am not desi, I have lived on the food for weeks at a time and have experienced everything from the most flame-thrower spicy, yet clean and delicious, to the "I think I might spend Laylatul Qadr in the bathroom" fare.

Our evening started out a little strange when it took our waiter a good 5-7 minutes to get us our menu.  That was forgivable.  We weren't particularly crazy-hungry, so we opted for the Saag Gosht (lamb in spinach), Aloo Matter (potatoes and peas), two rotis and an Afghani Naan (naan stuffed with raisins, nuts, cheese, and cherries).  The latter really piqued our interest because my wife is Afghan and she had never heard of anything like it before.

The food came out really quick and we were pleasantly surprised at that, taking into consideration how others have complained of long wait times.  However, when the roti came out I noticed something different.  It wasn't roti.  Roti is made from whole wheat, at least that is the kind that I have had, and that is what is says it is supposed to be on the menu.  What was delivered was two pieces of naan.  Now, naan is not bad, but it's not roti.  When I brought this up to the waiter, he assured me that this indeed was roti.  It totally wasn't.  I said that I thought roti was whole wheat.  He said it was.  It totally wasn't.  But I wasn't going to argue further.  I settled with the naan, um, I mean roti.

The saag gosht and aloo matter were nice.  Both were very flavorful with the right amount of spice.  The food was also very clean tasting and fresh as well, and it didn't have a half-inch layer of oil floating on top either.  This I was thankful for.  However, there wasn't much there.  There was plenty of sauce mind you, but the actual ingredients mentioned in the name of each dish were surprisingly sparse.  There were about three cubes of lamb in the saag gosht and about the same amount of potatoes in the aloo matter.  Combine that with about nine peas and you have some disappointment.  Now I know that this is a recession, but come on.

I won't say much about the "Afghani Naan" except that if you don't like fruit cake, you'll want to stay away.

Again, this review hurts because 1) I don't enjoy writing bad reviews, and 2) I really wanted to like it.  I have frequented other spots in SF with expectations met and thought this would be another one.  Who knows, but I won't be coming back and could not recommend it either.
author: Nicolas W.

description:
My absolute favorite indian/pakistani restaurant in the city.  If they had south indian food (and mexican pizzas) i would probably move in.  The tandoori fish is wonderful and the lamb korma is probably my favorite indian dish anywhere (and i'm indian).

Desserts like the kheer and kulfi are tasty.

Only downsides are the wait (my friends and I have taken to calling in about 30 minutes before we arrive and we still wait 20  minutes for our entrees when we get there) and fact that the excellent and complimentary masala tea thermos is usually empty...

I wish i could come here more - but my friends all prefer shalimar - amateurs!

Thanks to yelp for helping me discover this place by the way. I never would have ventured off Jones street without you all...
author: D S.

description:
SPICY!! but delicious definitely. Somehow my group of 12 friends managed to snag a table here with no reservation on Friday night (our waiter was kind enough to move a few people to another table). We were expecting some slow service since this place was literally packed- almost every seat filled. But it wasn't bad at all! We all ordered and got our food at the same time though they did take a while to get all our naan out. 

The food is very rich, and according to my Indian friend- pretty authentic. We tried the Saag Gosht (lamb and spinah curry) and Prawn Vindaloo. Both were really spicy and went perfectly with the soft, freshly made garlic and onion naan. The lamb was perfect but the prawns were overcooked in my opinion. I also tried my friend's Afghani naan, which is supposed to be filled with raisins and nuts, but it tasted more like a fruitcake (guessing they ran out of ingredients?) Unfortunately, they didn't have any of the appetizers we wanted. 

Another bad thing was that toward the end of the meal, the restaurant started getting really smokey due to the open kitchen. Some of my friends really liked the smell, but it irritated my nose and made it unbearably warm inside. 

Overall the food is excellent (especially if you need to accomodate vegetarians) and the service is acceptable (given the restaurant was jam packed.) It's a great place to warm up with some HOT indian food on a cold winter night. (Chinese diners may find this place oddly homey since they use those dishes and coasters that you usually find in chinese restaurants- you know those blue and white fake porcelain plates.)
author: Jessie C.

description:
Any restaurant that serves me fried cheese gets 5 stars automatically.  But in addition to the delicious paneer pakora, everything else we ate here was fantastic.  It was nearly 11pm on a rainy Saturday night but the place was still packed!

Tip:  if you want to drink alcohol, bring it in - there's no corkage fee and there are at least 17 liquor stores within a block of this place.
author: mia s.

description:
Lahore Karahi has thus far been the restaurant I hate to love. Let me explain. My boyfriend and I stopped by Lahore Karahi for dinner last week after reading the Yelp reviews. We showed up and figured we would place a to-go order and be in and out in 20 minutes or so. Not the case. Yes, there were a handful of people in the dining area but by no means were they crowded. We placed our order and sat down at one of the large tables with our tasty little cups of complementary tea and waited for our food. And waited. And waited. The longer we waited, the more to shambles the service fell. We watched as tables were being delivered the wrong items and some items never came at all. The poor server (granted there was just one guy taking orders, delivering said orders and ringing people up) seemed to have no idea what was going on. After about 40 minutes, we decided to check where our 2 dishes had ended up. Still not ready. Another 10-15 minutes and, alas, our food was ready! We paid and busted out of there as fast as we could only to get home to find out they din't give us one of our dishes. All we wanted was chicken tikka masala, bengan bhartila (roasted eggplant curry) and garlic naan. But it would seem that we would have to settle for the naan, rice and eggplant. 

Yes, we were incredibly disappointed but, by god, if that wasn't the most delicious Pakistani/Indian food I have ever placed in my flavor-loving mouth, then I don't know what is. Curse you, Lahore! 

Of course, we had to go back. There was no way I could turn down the flavor town that is Lahore Karahi. We had to try the chicken tikka masala. This time, we placed a phone order and headed over. The place was empty and everyone working that night seemed super competent as our oder was packaged and we were rung up and out the door in minutes. This time they did not disappoint. Our food was everything I hoped it would be and more!

If you have the patience of a saint, I strongly advise you try this place!
author: Heather U.

description:
I got news for you:  This place is number 1 in my heart, and number 2 in my brain (i'm number 1 in there, sorry folks).  Shit is cheaper than a TL lady of the night, but doesn't wake up 9 months later with a child, ruining your political aspirations.
It's a 2 man operation (plus one sous chef, if you don't know what that means then go back to citysearch or menuism, douche), so it can take a while to get your grub on, but it's worth it.  You'll be in and out under 10 bucks a head, unless you eat a lot, then maybe it'd be more (the world is your oyster!).

I recommend basically everything on the menu.

This shit is better than Shalimar, so forget it.

Also, it's BYOB which is always super cool.  AND they have free chai tea.  AND they have bollywood videos playing.  AND it's BYOB!

Here's a note:  If you eat at places like Naan n' Curry on the regular, just stay away from here.  You clearly aren't capable of making rational palate decisions, and i don't want your bullshit up in my spot.

If you have a functioning pair of testicles, or want to act like you're one of the boys, order that shit spicy.  He'll fuck you up but you'll feel fine later.

Holla at'cha Guduu!
author: Michael P.

description:
...and I thought I was learnéd in the ways of the Pakistani mouth-love.  HA!  This place was dirt cheap, zesty, and encouraged me to drink outside beer.   What more could you ask of a relationship with a Tenderloin restaurant?

I went with about nine other people, all of whom carried with them 40's and 6packs purchased from the liquor stop around the corner.  We had a bit of a wait, but it was mostly because there were so many of us and the place was not huge.  

We ordered about one order of everything, which turned out to be way too much and not enough, all at the same time.  The potato naan was delectable, the sauces were fresh and sassy like a drag queen with a new pair of shoes.  It was pretty much an ideal meal.

The stars of the night were:
- fish tikka masala.  Even better than my usual chicken!
- Palek paneer.  I never really thought much of this plate at other places, but da-YUM this was a must-have here.
- Goat curry was a not-on-the-menu recommendation... makes ya feel special to get it.

Thank you to Tommy H and his wonderful comrades who opened my eyes to the new frontier of gustatory delights.
author: Mari C.

description:
My favorite Indian food in the city. Super friendly people, great food, casual and comfortable.

I highly recommend the Bengan Bharta and Chicken Boti. Yum!
author: Dinah S.

description:
This place is my Favorite Pakistani place in San Fran. The fish that has won awards speaks for its self. The tea is breath taking and the rest of the food as fresh and as close to home cooking you will ever find. 

As a Pakistani cook my self I have guddo (the chef) thumbs up for great quality of the food and a great experience. 

The Tikkas/ fresh naan and tandoori Fish are my fav. 

and ofcourse no visit to Lahore Karahi is complete without the TEA.
author: Farhan H.

description:
As if it was a hellish Sisyphean nightmare, I just cannot shake the memory that is Lahore Karahi.

I know I'm going against the grain on this one (and the reviews on Yelp are what led us to try it in the first place), but I would suggest that most people stay away from this place (and be afraid, very afraid!). 

I want to make clear that we thought the prices were very reasonable and we didn't expect much at all. Unfortunately for us, we did actually expect to be able to order and eat at some point in the evening. The waitstaff's unfailingly bizarre behavior sure dampened any notion we had of that actually happening.

We were initially able to place an order for some food, that's the good part, unfortunately, only a couple of the items we ordered actually ever arrived. While we were hungry, we were more than prepared to wait our turn, it's just that our turn never came. Oddly, the place wasn't even really busy when we first arrived, just a couple of tables filled but most were unoccupied. 

We really tried (and politely I might add) to reorder our food, but it was to no avail. At first I tried politely asking for the items we ordered, the waiter would sort of motion and then run off, but it was simply to no avail as the food never arrived. After trying that a few times, I next resorted to asking another waiter, again, I sort of got a nod and then.. nothing! Finally after that didn't work I tried using props, the menu, a straw, sign language, smoke signals, but nothing and I mean nothing worked. 

It was almost as if we were in some sort of alternate universe where the patron is explicitly forbidden from ordering food and if they try to order said food, they have committed some sort of mortal sin. I've probably visited India/Pakistan a dozen times and I've seen some pretty interesting things, but never have I encountered such outlandishness until I visited Lahore Karahi. 

As we arose from our table to leave, I whispered under my breath (to my companions), "the service is a bit lacking here." The gentleman at the table next to us heard me, looked up at me and said "the service is not lacking here, its absolutely horrible!" Sadly, after he made that comment, I knew that another person would now be suffering the same nightmarish trauma that we did. Don't let it happen to you.
author: Paul C.

description:
The best Indian veg food (restaurant) in town , without a doubt. The food takes a long time to cook, but its definitely worth the wait. 

For something closer to home cooked food, try New Ganges

Try the Palak Paneer and Garlic Naan here..
author: Brijesh K.

description:
Being a Lahori,  I can say with authority that Lahore Karahi comes close to real Lahori food.  

The Chicken Karahi is as good as you'll find anywhere - it's only better - well, yes in Lahore.  The chikkar cholay (garbanzo beans) are flavorful and have the pureed touch, which is exactly how they should be.  Naans are fresh and maybe a little too greased (though we were told, there the oil is cholestrol free! phew).  The tandoori fell a little short of my expectations, especially the seekh kababs.  However the fish was quite tasty, but I still prefer Rotee's tandoori fish.  All in all a great place.  Although I have to say the food turnaround was a little slow (25 mins) given that we were the only other table being served at the restaurant.  I guess it's all made fresh.

And did I say, I met Guddoo? The CEO, founder and executive chef.  Very personable guy.

God, I love SF...get to eat home cookin' any day of the year thanks to the Pakloin...not that I do given all the other great restaurants in this town, but it's so comforting to know that I can!
author: Mamoon H.

description:
Love the place! It's a hole in the wall.... One man show ...:-) the owner runs the place by himself... Really friendly guy!! 
Food is great.... I tried Keema once and then chicken masala... Both were great.... Bit too spicy for my palate. Place is kept real tidy.... Unlike other small Indian places. He starts to cook as u order... So it can be slow...I took away 1 star because roti is not all whole wheat or even close to being a roti as claimed.
author: Justyna R.

description:
No, no, no and NO!

I LOVE Indian food---whatever the region. If it's hot, well-spiced and tasty, I'm the happy girl; no needy for fancy decor, fawning service, or even speed. And you won't ever hear me complain about having to bring in my own beer either.

Spurred by the rave multi-star reviews, this low-maintenance girl grabbed the BF and headed for Lahore Kahani. 2 1/2 hours later (no dessert), we were utterly gobsmacked by the relentless mediocrity and the slow, and I mean paralytically S   L  O   W  service. 

I was forewarned, and, consequently, prepared to wait patiently. However, what I wasn't prepared for was an interminable wait for a crappy ass meal. 

It wasn't even remotely crowded, but  our waitron, though nice enough, just wandered around in dazed, absent-minded circles, serving no one fast. 

We ordered the Sabzi (frozen mixed vegetable mush), paneer w/nuts (cloyingly sweet tomato sauce), and choley (not choley at all, but an assortment of mixed dals.) We had asked for medium spicy and got bland---no spiciness whatsoever. Our plain rice came 25 minutes later. The one truly exceptional item was the super tasty sesame naan.

Perhaps it was a fluke, but with the abundance of truly superb Indian restaurants in the bay area, there's really no motivation to give it a second chance.
author: Astrid X.

description:
I really wanted to like this place. I even stood up for Lahore when my BF said that he preferred Naan N' Curry. However, 1.5 hrs later my stomach and I would be inclined to agree.

Taste and quality wise, I feel like this place is better than Naan N' Curry. It is a bit more on the sweet side; there was a strong taste of cinnamon in both of our dishes (Chicken Tikka Masala, Lamb Vindaloo). The BF did not appreciate that, while I didn't mind too much. I really liked the tender lamb and potatoes in our lamb vindaloo. The vindaloo also tasted more tangy than others I have had. I could care less for the CTM, but I usually do not care much for it in the first place.

But alas, I got a stomachache by the end of the night. I don't know if I can entirely put it on Lahore, which is why I am probably going to come back and why it still merits a 3 star rating.
author: Angela L.

description:
Oh, I'll be the first to admit that I am a tourist and called in a reservation for 6:30 at Lahore Karahi.

.....after the laughter subsides I'll continue.

After we made our way to our empty deli table located next to an nonworking door, we were quite impressed with the food! Homemade Indian food was the best thing in my boyfriend's last relationship, and he helped me find a love for it too. This place was pakistani, I'm pretty sure, but overall the food was DELICIOUS AND CHEAP.

The lamb saag and the 1.00 garlic naan were clear standouts. The shrimp masala was a bit too sweet for my taste, but nevertheless fun to try and quite tasty.

The owner gave us a cube of free "homemade curry ice cream" on a toothpick on our way out. Priceless. We left quite satisfied on our journey through the Tenderloin dodging homeless men sucking on curried ice cream on toothpicks.
author: A.J. S.

description:
Why is it the gems of the city are always in the tenderloin? This joint, a few blocks from Rye, is about as good as they come. The food: delicious. The prices: fit for a starving artist. My friends and I split about 5-6 dishes and we each paid about $12 (including Naan).

My first impression of the place was the smokey aroma coming from the Tandoor in the kitchen. My one regret is that I did not try anything from the grill. But no matter, the meal was still scrumtrulescent. 

My picks: the chicken tikki masala, dal masala, and aloo matter. You can't go wrong.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Only reason it didn't get 5 stars was that I felt a little illin in the belly the next day. I can't say for sure that the food was the culprit.

The Food:
Unique flavors and sauces in most dishes. Everything we ordered (all vegetarian) was really tasty. While the garbanzo beans were a bit mushy , the aloo mattar was great, like a mysteriously spicey jaunt down a dank Dehli alleyway.. The nan bread was like a simultaenously crispy yet chewy magic carpt ride over the Ganges at sunset. Oh wait, it's Pakistani food... I knew it tasted like unique Indian food.

The Drinks: We bought 40's of Budweiser (this is the only time I'll drink Bud) at the shady liquor store across the street. Note: There are 4 stores that look like liquor stores, but only one of them is. It's the one with all of the neon beer signs in the window and the last one we went into. Go figure.

The atmosphere: Cozy, very casual. Smoke from the Nan bread oven  scents the air. It's a pretty diverse crowd here usually. Many people bring in their own alcohol. Then they drink it. Did I mention that you can bring in your own beer? 

The waiter with the missing index finger was very nice, though he seems like he could get mad quiclky if you messed with him at all. We didnt. He gave us several very stern warnings about the powerful fruity sweetness of the fruit and nut nan bread. "It's like dessert, I'm telling you!" 

The price: Really good value. We got 3 entrees, lots of rice, and 3 orders of nan bread for $25.

The bottom line: Great food, great value, casual atmosphere, bring your own beer. I did feel a little strange in the belly the next day, but it couldve been the Budweiser.
author: Marky M.

description:
A NIGHTMARE !!!! 

Our whole evening (and our 4th of July) was completely ruined !! Went after reading a lot of good reviews on Yelp and getting a coupon. Got there around 6:45 planning to head for the the fireworks afterwards... 

2 1/2 hours later we finally got our food.... 

Worth the wait? NOT AT ALL some of the worst Indian/Paskistani food I have ever eaten. The only good thing was the naan, which came after we finished eating. We missed the fireworks, our evening was ruined, and to top things off, shortly afterwards my husband became violently ill with food poisoning. (The restaurant is filthy) 

I will be calling the Health Department on Monday. This has got to be one of my worst restaurant experiences of my life. Anyone who gives this restaurant more than one star is insane.
author: Erin C.

description:
Pretty good food.  I'm South Asian, so I'm really picky.

However, minus two stars b/c 

a) nonexistent service 
b) a dirty bathroom when I went to go wash my hands
c) I don't know if the food made me sick, or something I ate earlier.  but I guess it was something I ate earlier b/c my friend didn't get sick.  maybe she has a strong constitution in her favor.  who knows.  

anyway, not bad and a huge plus for showing bollywood movies during dinner!!!
author: F K.

description:
Lahore Karahi's motto should be similar to Zeitgeists', good food, friendly service, fine company--pick one.  The food here is delicious, prepared well, right there behind the counter pretty much one meal at a time.  Prices are dirty cheap, most dishes are between $4-8.  You can bring your own alcohol because this is a Pakistani restaurant and they won't serve any to you.  Bollywood movies play in the background to provide entertain should the conversation falter.

The only complaint I have about this place is that the service was pretty awful.  The waiter sat us down, then walked off and did who knows what for about 10 minutes.  There are only a handful of tables, and at the time, few were occupied.  He walked by our closed menus at least half a dozen times.  Then when the food came, he pretty much just shoved it onto our table, pushing the plates and glasses out of the way.

So the food was great, 7 stars(!), but the services was so bad I have to take three off just for that for a net of four out of five.  Not bad, just don't come expecting hospitality.
author: Eric M.

description:
I pass this place on the 38 bus every day. And the only reason I had the courage to go (since it was in the tenderloin) was because I had a coupon from the Entertainment book (xmas gift). So I gathered 3 other friends and went. 

Wow - it was really good! We had plain and afghani naan, lamb biryani, karahi chicken, prawn curry. Each dish was brought out separately, and not necessarily in order. Meaning, the naan arrived with nothing else at first. I asked the owner/chef and he responded that one must wait because everything is made fresh. Not exactly the answer I was looking for but ok. And I wasn't disappointed when he and his assistant (it was a 2-man operation) came with the curries. The sauces were flavorful, hot, and fresh. 

If you read my other review, you'll know I'm not a lamb fan, but my 2 other friends devored the biryani. Seems like a good sign. My only disappointment was the Afghani naan.
