I was thinking it would be more like this other sweet naan I was in search of, but this reminded me more of a fruitcake naan. Same colors and odd taste. But hey, what do I know.

I'd definitely go back, without fear nor coupons (the bill was $40 for FOUR people with a few non alcoholic drinks + tip). Be adventurous and go! Just remember to be patient or else you'll be reprimanded too.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Dig:
* The 'authentic' (read: low-rent) vibe
* The Indian musicals playing on a constant loop on TV
* The friendliness of the main man/ chef (owner?), who greeted me with a smile and suggested I try the fish vindaloo the next time.
* The taste of the lamb vindaloo & garlic naan I had.

Don't Dig:
* The fact that the chef had a cold and was handling my food.
* That I could see EVERYTHING happening in the kitchen.
* That I had to get up to get my own place setting (silverware, napkin, etc.)
* That the chef pretty much had to do everything himself - incl. take my order, make my meal, and figure out my tab.  Here's an idea: put those 2 latino gentlemen who mill about behind the scenes to work.
* The creepy dude with a bandage on his (recently?) chopped finger who sat by the door and watched me eat.
* I'm pretty sure I saw a roach running across the kitchen counter.

Whatever - the service sucks (he's only one man!) and it has all the ambience of a garage, but this is a cheap Indian/ Pakistani place in the Tenderloin.  What did you expect?  Lahore is flavor country, but I wouldn't bring my parents or any high-maintenance sorts here.

PS ~ Bringing your own refreshments is a GREAT CALL.
author: Ryan W.

description:
This place has by far the best Indian/Pakistani food I've ever eaten. Waay better than that bland, oily Naan n' Curry crap. I always order my favorite dish, which is the bengan bharta (eggplant curry..? eggplant something) along with rice and either regular, garlic, onion or potato naan. The eggplant dish is pretty consistent, very flavorful and yummy. The naans are freshly made and cooked to order. You can sometimes see and hear the owner/chef pounding the naan dough before baking(?) it. The rice, well you can't exactly go wrong with rice. 

I've also tried their chicken korma, chicken tikka masala, chicken vindaloo and saag paneer. No complaints about any of those dishes, although I still prefer the bengan bharta - it's THAT good. Every now and then I'll order the mango lassi. It's pretty good, but I can't tell if they use powdered mango flavoring or if it's the real stuff, nor do I really care. It just hits the spot whenever I feel like having one. 

Now for the gripe. Service sucks ass. I haven't figured out if this place is like Naan n' Curry where you have to get your own plates, silverware, water, etc. There'd be times when the waiter would get it for us and other times when we'd get it ourselves. Also, there would be times when the waiter would take our orders and other times when we went up to the front counter to place our order. 

Wait time for the food can take a while. There is only one or two chefs and from what I've noticed, they cook the food according to whichever party placed their order first. So if a large party ordered their food before you, then have fun waiting until the large party receives all their food.

Sometimes there is even a long wait to pay after you're done with your meal. From what I've experienced, it's because the owner is the only one who cooks (some nights there is another chef), takes the phone orders AND handles the money. With one person manning everything, a wait is bound to occur.

This place is a hole in the wall in the Tenderloin, and parking can be hard. So if a crackhead or bum points out a parking spot or guides you while you park, "tip" them a dollar or two. You'll never know what might "accidentally" happen to your car.

Oh, and they take credit cards =)
author: Maryann T.

description: I just realized that I am falling into the tendency to either be a 1 star or a 5 star type of reviewer. Oh well, fuck it. I love this place. Don't come on your lunch break if you are in a hurry (took a co-worker who pissed and moaned about the wait the whole time once, intolerable). Come if you have time to chill, want to have a drink and a conversation with a friend as you wait forever for your food, and then finally, want to enjoy the most delicious Indian/Pakistani place in the neighborhood.
author: Raptor J.

description:
This is my favorite indian/pakistani restaurant in the city.  The owner is the chef and the waiters work every day - they are the best people. Some people go in and expect american service - you aren't going to get that.  These people are salt of the earth and are very hard-working, but it may not translate to some five star tuxedo staff. (UPDATE: There is a NEW young waiter that SUCKS, but if you ignore him and even better yet, laugh at how bad he is, it won't be as bad.  UPDATE UPDATE: NEW WAITER AGAIN AND HE RULES!!!)

Now lets get to the food: everything is really spicy and each dish has its own set of spices.  You can go to the naan'n'curry's and shalimars and every dish tastes like each other.  NOT here.  Naan is buttery and fluffy, I've had the vegetable biriyani and it is SO yummy - full of interesting veggies.  Goat curry isn't on the menu but he always has it on hand.  Tandoor fish - best in the city.  Sheekh kebab - the lamb is mixed with these wonderful herbs and it comes sizzling to your table.  Saag, choley is great.  Dal Makhani is EXTRA spicy.  

The best part, if that is possible: the price.  We always leave HUGE tips because no one wants any money back.  

Perfect place for large parties (except you may not be able to get a table, this place gets PACKED), so try to go at an off time.
author: Priya R.

description:
I asked Guddu to marry me and he said 'No.'

He was smiling real big when he said it though, so more Tikka Masala for me.

Go to Lahore Karahi. Fill your own dang water glass if you need to and you might have to grab the waiter by the ankle to take your order, because this is some no-frills Indian food and you'll be rewarded in your mouth and on your bill.

Honestly if punctuality in water-glass filling is your make-it or break it with a fine dining establishment, please eat somewhere else. It's not a big place and we need the table space because this is the best grub in town, no shit.

This is ain't no damn Naan an' Curry. By that I mean, they don't make your tikka gravy in the morning and slop it on your mess tray when ya' get there. Dishes are made.. to.. order.  One spice at a time..

And if it's too spicy, you should just tell the owner, manager and chef. (His name, again is Guddu. Says so right on the menu.) Cause If ya' run out with your handbag flappin' you'll miss the free homemade ice cream and the hug or a handshake when ya' go.
author: Missy B.

description: Update: I have to take away one star. I love the food here and know that there isn't much atmosphere or service here. But we waited  over 45 minutes for our food, while everyone around us was served. (even tables that ordered after us) When we asked where our food was, we didn't get any real answer and there was no apology. When our food finally came, only part of the order came and one of the dishes was a mistake. The food we did get was delicious, so it's hard for me to say I won't be back. But I won't be giving the rave recommendations that I once did.
author: Christy Z.

description: Folks, I eat a lot of Indian food and this is hands down the BEST Indian food that I have EVER had. I had the LAHORI CHIKKAR CHOLEY and the ALOO BENGAN. It was so flavorful, some sweet and some savoy. The mango lassi here was unique, but very delicious- a little on the sweet side, but hey- It's mango lassi - It's suppose to be sweet! The best part about this place is the Chef/Owner "Guddu," you will like him instantly upon meeting him!! He's the one who will take your order, cook your food and check you out when you are done! You will not believe this food... Be prepared if going in the evening, it is in Tenderloin.
author: Jonathan D.

description:
Wonderfully prepared Indian food with Tenderloin prices - doesn't get much better than this.  The menu has all of the Indian staples you would expect, but also includes several seafood preparations (including a fish dish that gets great reviews).  

My dining partner and I stuck to the basics and ordered pakora to start off our meal.  The individual pakora were slightly larger than I was used to, but they were way more flavorful than the average preparation.  Sooo tasty with the mint sauce on the table.  We also had the butter chicken and lamb korma - each was made fresh (you can see the kitchen from the dining area) and filled with delicious spices.  The naan was crisp on the outside and soft on the inside - some of the tastiest naan I have ever had.  Prices were more than reasonable which allows you to order a bit more than you normally would.  Owner was there and was extremely friendly.
author: Dana H.

description:
440 something people said it before me. I'll say it again. 
Pure, massive, unadulterated carnage was had here on the night of my good friend's birthday.

5 of us ate for around $60? I think? It's also BYOB, and nobody looks at you funny with a magnum of wine and a six-pack of Bud in the TL. Nobody. If anything, they will want to travel WITH you.

We came early enough to where we had our choice of seating and service was somewhat prompt. This isn't a 5 star restaurant, so we got our own wine glasses, but the water was filled as we sat down. 

The pakoras were tasty, the naan soft, yet crisp, and the curries we had, amazing. We shared the bengan bhartha, the chicken tikka masala, the onion kulcha, lahori chikkar (wish it was spicier though) and matar paneer. It was worth the 10 block from happy hour and a good exercise on the way back. I'll definitely be back here.
author: Jessica P.

description:
My quest to find the best tikka masala among the Tandoorloin's many Indian places brought me to Lahore. Upon entering, we were promptly seated and given our drinks. We got fish tikka masala, chicken biryani, tandoori chicken leg, some garlic naan and basmati rice. 

The fish tikka masala is beyond superb. Chilean sea bass cooked in a buttery tikka masala sauce that has a great depth of flavors. Unlike most places where the TM sauce is very smooth and creamy (sometimes almost too creamy), Lahore's version is chunkier, has more texture to it (I think there were nuts in the sauce...or some other crunchy thing) and has a lot more flavor. Some people prefer their tikka masala smooth and creamy -- I was one of those -- but I'm now a convert for the chunkier and more flavorful sauce that Lahore makes. 

The chicken biryani is also good. We asked for it spicy though, which is a little too spicy for me. I must admit that I have a low tolerance level for anything hot, so I think I downed two cups of water for the small portion of biryani that I tasted. 

The tandoori chicken is yum-o as well. For $3, you get a tandoori chicken thigh/leg on a big plate of grilled veggies. It's moist, delicious and just has the right amount of kick to it.

The garlic naan is goooood. A warning though, they take their garlic seriously here, so if you're a faux or a semi garlic lover, I suggest going for the regular. The garlic and cilantro is just ooozing from the naan and since I love both, I was in naan heaven after having some. 

Oh and of course, forget about parking when you go here. Try walking instead. I know, it's the Tenderloin, but it's a short little walk from Union Square, the muni, bart, so getting here is no problemo at all. 

Just clutch that purse to your chest, have 911 already dialed on your cellphone -- you just need to press the call button -- bring that pepper spray and you're good to go. Just kidding. Seriously, the Tenderloin gets too much bad rap for what it is. You'll be fine.
author: Erika I.

description: If it was based on food alone I would have given it five plus stars. The food was amazing! The fish tandoori is out of this world. However, the place is filthy. There were dead cockroaches on the windowsill. It doesn't look like it had been cleaned in years. I had a hard time getting comfortable which made it very hard to enjoy the amazing food.
author: Michelle B.

description: This place is amazing. When you ask for your food spicy they actually make it spicy. No beer unfortunately, but that's never really stopped me. There's a liquor store right next door. Just be discrete and you are golden. 8 of us ate here and we split the bill evenly. $10 a person. So not only is the food amazingly good, it's ridiculously cheap.
author: Alfredo A.

description:
Forget about the touristy spots, this is where we take out of town guests to experience spicy, savory cuisine. There isn't an item on the menu here that we don't love (granted, still working through the list). The tikka masala is delicious but make sure to venture beyond and give something you might not regularly order a shot... it will be a safe bet here. And you do have to be patient if it's packed but it is worth the effort; prices are great, too. 

If you love Pakistani and Indian food, try this restaurant! YUM.

** The 5 stars are for the food alone, the service would lower it but focusing on the food (the reason we go). **
author: L. S.

description:
Absolutely tasty!  A little slow on service but in all fairness the little dining area was packed out.  Prices are very reasonable and the staff is more than willing to get you anything you want.  I asked for a small side yogurt sauce and I got a tub!  Naan bread is fantastic - ask for seconds.

Also, which won major points for me, when I called to tell them that they had accidentally forgotten one of my side dishes in my take out...they said come on over and it will be waiting for you, no questions asked.  I guess good customer service has just been a little lean in the city recently and this really went a long way with me.
author: Mark C.

description:
Where the brown peeps at? Went in tonight with some Lahoris and they were the only brown peeps in the room. I'm Asian, and there were two other Asian chicks, but that was the only "color" in the room. The other tables were filled with hipsters, including one wearing a hiking backpack who had brought his own IPA. 

Food is delicious, especially the prawn tikka masala and the chikkar cholay. Lahori friend says cholay is exactly the way it is in Lahore. But service is uneven and can be slow, especially on weekends. There's only one waiter for the entire restaurant, which is just not enough. The lone waiter often (understandably) forgets some items or doesn't bring an item until much after the rest of the food has arrived. This isn't bad when just a few tables are full, but when the place is hopping, it can detract from the experience and mouth-watering food. 

I'd go here on a slow weekday night, but not on a weekend unless I feel like jousting with the fixie crowd for a table.
author: Jemima P.

description:
I politely and forcefully dragged my friend here for dinner.  It was pretty late so few places were open and after reading so many great reviews and seeing the yelp stickers proudly displayed on LK, I knew we couldn't go wrong. ;( 

I was wrong. 

The ambiance is, well, non-existent.  Given the neighborhood and the cheap eats I would normally let such humble settings slide.  The prices are about the same as Naan'n'Curry, but even those guys put a little more into the decor.  I don't need much time looking on the menu because I always get chicken tikka masala and chicken tandoori.  In a way, I judge a place by how well they can prepare those staples for me (in Japanese restaurants hamachi is the litmus test).  Both items were not to my liking.  The masala sauce was sweet! (It was spicy too, as it should be) This pretty much ruins it for me.  I'm still appalled. 
The tandoori was not very juicy but ok, 3 stars.  My friend got a vegetarian dish and it had onions in it and it was spicy.  That was the night I found out my friend hates onions and can't stand spicy food. Ha! I'm glad it wasn't a date or I would have surely failed!

So, all in all, I would have let the lack of ambiance slide if the food was great, but it wasn't.  The server (and maybe owner) was very friendly, joked with us and taught us some Indian! Nice guy! Forgot my tea, though...my throat's been itchy, so that tea would have been great. Again, something I would not normally care much about, but I can't get over my sweet masala sauce.  Need-less to say, I finished my meat (not the sauce) because I was starving, but NnC is still my go-to cheap Indian eatery. 

Sorry, LK it just wasn't meant to be for us.
author: Aristocles P.

description:
My boyfriend was introduced to this place by some of his culinary friends and he in turn introduced it to me. And now this is my ultimate favorite indian restaurant, I really don't know what I would do without it. This food has a good dose of lovin', every ingredient is fresh, the shrimp are always cooked to perfection, the lettuce is crisp. Every dish is like heavenly creaminess, and luciousness on a plate. Once you try Ghuddu's Chicken kurma you just can't go back to those other restaurants (i.e. naan n' curry)
Downside as everyone else says the wait can get long, especially on weekends. Just keep in mind although he does have waiters on hand to take the orders and wash dishes, this is a one man operation.
author: X marks the spot ..

description:
Cheap and well-flavored Indian food. It's not cafeteria style, and it's better than Naan 'n Curry or Shalimar quality-wise.  Really the best tasting Indian I've had in SF outside of Roti Indian Bistro (which is twice as expensive). 

Among several good vegetarian options, the baingan bharta is outstanding.

Avoid the Afghani Naan. I got it once in a to-go order, and it tasted like some cardboard / fruitcake hybrid.
author: Fernando V.

description:
Lahore Karahi elevates seemingly ordinary Indian dishes to a whole new level of authenticity and flavor. Other Indian restaurants seem subpar by comparison. 

Is it the Pakistani influence that makes these dishes so amazing or just the magic touch of the chef?

I've never given 5 stars to any restaurant, till now. Here's why:
3 stars = tastes and quality of dishes were spectacular
1 star = Prices were ridiculously CHEAP for any Indian restaurant.
1 star = BYOB, they take Credit Card, Clean Restaurant

Things to take into account:
- Gets packed by 7:30pm, go earlier or for lunch
- There's one waiter and hes old and very busy so excuse his lack of hospitality. It is practically a one man show.
- It takes a while to get your food, so be prepared for a little wait.

My mom wishes she could cook this good! =) Sorry mom!
author: Venatius P.

description: Best spices hands down here, everything fresh and fantastic flavors on every bite. The chicken tikka masala was amazing there was some kind of crunch in the sauce (almonds?) and it was amazing, the best aromatic rice ever and the daal makhany nice and spicy and the garlic naan cooked perfectly, saag paneer out of this world and samosas to die for! Every single thing that I try is better than the previous one! This is my new go to indian even though I have to trek to the Loin to eat in or pick up and grub at home. And best of all is the fact that it is a bargain!
author: Chris D.

description:
Deliciously wonderful. Yes, you read that right.

It's true, the food takes awhile & the decor is sub par, but the food is so scrumptious you'll ignore the tiny flaws of Lahore Karahi! Never again will I return to my previous Indian joints, no no no!

We had an appetizer, 3 dishes, 4 pieces of Naan, and beyond stuffed bellies for $23! They also brought us complimentary dessert, some sort of ice cream we had no room for, but ate anyway. Can you beat that?! Doubt it!
author: Melisser E.

description:
This place has been on my to try list forever...but planning to eat in the Tenderloin is a delicate process. One that requires research of the proper public transportation to get to the TL, figuring out which stop to get off on and what streets to walk on that will yield the least amount of interaction with prostitutes, illegal transactions, sexual harassment, and/or general shadyness.   The process takes some finesse, but  over time, you'll know how to navigate the TL with the best of them. 

I visited India last April for a few weeks, in the Northwest region of Rajasthan, and Lahore is probably the only restaurant I've been to into the city that specifically reminds me of my dining experiences while I was in India.  The smells are the same, the simplicity of the decor is the same, the no ice with your drinks, the humble politeness and english barrier of the waitstaff...and the food.  Of course the food.  

We had the chicken tikka masala, which was a well done curry, with bits of almond that you could still taste in the sauce.  But to be honest, I never had chicken tikka masala in India -- I just didn't see it on the menu.  The naan was simple perfection...not too chewy...not too dense.  We also ordered the tandoori fish which was fabulous with a capital "F".  I have to warn you it's hella spicy, so if you're not into the whole mouth-on-fire thing, see if they can tone it down a notch.

I have to take one star off due to the intense gassy-ness I experienced after eating dinner and then again after heating up leftovers the next day.  But other than that, all I can say is that I more than appreciated the meal and dining experience, that literally transported me back to my time in India.
author: LaSha G.

description:
I adore this place and used to eat it for lunch twice a week, which was oh-so-good but sent me straight to a food coma at my office.  I now try to eat it once a week.  Beware that this is a one-man show (well, two, counting the waiter) and he cooks from scratch so the wait for your food can be about 30 minutes or more.  It's totally worth it once the smoking mixed tandoori platter, steamy basmati and milky curries make their way over.  

I once asked the chef at this place what is "halal" while hovering around the register counter.  He waved me into to his tiny kitchen and, while explaining, showed me his awesome tandoor in which naan was baked.  He also gave me a side of garlic naan for the road.  I absolutely love the unassuming goodness of this place.
author: Renee K.

description:
I'm amused by the wide range of reviews for Lahore Karahi because my feelings after dining here were all over the map as well.  First impressions were quite dismal.  For starters, It was a struggle convincing my date to walk through the questionable neighborhood but once we entered what appeared to be a converted soup kitchen, I thought she was going to have a panic attack.

The menu was appealing however and the aromas from the open kitchen were quite tantalizing.  Once the food arrived (which was surprisingly fast considering other's experiences),  I was drawn to the meal and our surroundings disappeared.   We had modest appetites and regrettably only ordered two main dishes.  The Chicken Korma was mild and inviting but the Lamb Biryani stole the show.  With a requested "medium" spiciness, the flavors were heightened and not overwhelming.  The rice was light and the lamb was not too.... lamby?.  The garlic Naan was outstanding but the lightly roasted garlic with butter was a little much for my companion.  She has very light tastes so we ordered some plain Naan too but upon its arrival she exclaimed "oh, it's so greasy".

I think our host was already a bit irked with us at this point.  My date's questions about certain dishes while ordering were met with some confusion and impatience.  There was a dual language barrier going on so I let it go at the time.  But, the greasy Naan comment seemed to truly offend him.  He grabbed a paper napkin and very aggressively dabbed away the grease right in front of her face.  To say the least, Lahore Karahi is not a place for service and ambiance but that's not the reason to go.  I would be impressed with the food at any price but this was a downright bargain.
author: Sean L.

description:
I went here tonight with my boyfriend after reading all these great reviews. I trust yelp, for the most part. Yelp has served me well in the past. But tonight, yelp, you failed me. FAILED. With a big fat F.

The service was soooooooooooo slow. There was only one server and I think he was also the delivery guy! We waited for the check for at least a half an hour after we were finished eating. I put on my jacket, I put a napkin on my plate, we exhibited all the universal signals that were ready to go and the guy never brought us our check. And I know it's not one of those pay-at-the-counter places, because people sitting around us got their checks brought to their tables. Finally my boyfriend had to get up and pay at the counter. Plus the guy forgot our naan and was kind of rude to us the entire night... until he decided to just ignore us!

But about the food. The rice was boring, the naan was yeasty and gooey, the chicken tikka masala wasn't nice and creamy the way we  like it. It was OK, but neither of us liked it that much. We got the fried potato appetizer which came so highly recommended, but it was mushy and too spicy for not really having a flavor. We wanted to try the deep fried cheese things, but they were out of them, so we ordered the samosas but they were out of those, too!

Also, the tables were dirty.

I'm sorry guys but it just wasn't good. It was bad.
author: Thea K.

description: Food was really good but took a very long time; I had my son with my and not a very friendly kid place, I do not recommend bring kids here order carry out.  People arrived 60-70 mins after us and got their food 10 mins after we got ours.  Only 1 person waiting tables, helping chef and cleaning tables. Again the food was really good but after waiting so long I just wanted to leave. We took home most of our food once it finally came.  I ordered 3 different types of naan, really good but used a lot of oil/butter on top which I was not used to.  Also you need to write down EVERYTHING you want to order on a check before sitting down, including drinks...
author: Ribec F.

description:
We went out with the intent of having some great Biriyani and some Kashmiri Nan (Our favorites). 

First off we arrived to find about 10 people standing around waiting to be seated at the empty tables, and 2 people waiting for their to go order that was sitting there getting cold. The waiter was walking around looking busy, but really just straightening the tables, and picking up napkins. 10 minutes later we got seated and the people waiting for their to go order finally got to pay for it. First sign of trouble.. 

We order Samosa, Benghan Bartha, Prawn Biriyani, and Afghani (Kashmiri) Nan. The waiter tried to convince us we didn't want Kashmiri Nan, and in this case we should have taken his advice. 

About 15 minutes later, The waiter brought us Some very doughy Vegetable Pakora.. Confused, we told him we had ordered Samosa,  and he said they broke the Samosas and could not make any more so we should just eat the Pakora Instead because "it is very good". It wasn't.  While the batter was hot and spiced, it was overly doughy and mostly onions.  Soon after our Prawn Biriyani and Benghan Bartha Arrived.  

The Biriyani was bland, and dry.  The Shrimp weren't even marinated in the Biriyani Spices and tasted not entirely fresh.  The Rice Seemed undercooked and rushed.

Benghan Bartha, overly runny. The waiter said this was one of their specialties.. I found it to be not so special. For a dish that's supposed to be made from blended Eggplant and tomatoes, this was the most liquidy, non eggplant flavored version of this dish ever. A Light brown gravy like liquid with a shred or 3 of Eggplant Skin.. 

And the Kicker was the Afghani (Kashmiri) Nan.  We were expecting a Nan with Cherry Paste and Nuts (similar to the description and what we commonly know and love as Kashmiri Nan). However what arrived (Another 10 minutes after all the food) Looked like they had picked the dried fruits out of a holiday fruit cake (you know the kind no one eats around the holidays). Little Bitz of fake wax cherries and those plasticky green mystery fruit were embedded in a paper thin slice of crispy hot nan like bread. 

By this time, the cockroaches had descended on our table (no joke). After shooing off a few we decided to call it quits and pack up our leftovers (which were not gong to eat anyways) and get the $@#^& outa dodge!

While the Waiter Seemed to be a really nice and personable (if not overly pushy) guy, the food and dirty decor were severely lac luster.

I left this restaurant in a daze.. wondering "WHY GOD WHY?"  How could so many people on yelp actually like this place? Did they maybe get some crack in their food or get hypnotized by the pushy waiter? I guess ill never know, because you will never find me eating here again ever. 

Compared to any other restaurant that serves Pakistani/Indian this was by far the worst I've had in the city..
author: Raphael P.

description: The food is very good however it is becoming increasingly difficult to find the place open during the posted business hours.  For the last two weeks we have tried twice to go there and found the gate locked on the front door.  It takes quite a bit to get there and back during out lunch hour and is very discouraging to get there and find the gate locked and then have to waste more of our time trying to find someplace else in the area instead to eat.  I don't think we will be making many return trips there in the future since it isn't reliably open on predictable times.
author: Carrie H.

description: I LOVE this place...awesome food, great prices, and located right around the corner from one of my best friend's apt..cant get any better than that!!  the service is great, and they always have a crowd, but still tend to get you in and seated as quickly as possible..
author: Gary H.

description:
Ummm...I like right across the street on the 6th floor of an apartment building nearby and I can't STAND the smell of Indian/Pakastani food.  It gets in your hair, it drowns you, and most of the time it smells like smelly feet and armpits.  But I have to admit.. i like their Na'an.  They have nice people working there, and the food's not THAT bad.  It just SMELLS bad. 

One major downfall: the service IS very slow, and english is NOT their first language, so you have to speak to them clearly.  If you're goingfor  take out, say that you need to order first if you haven't (or they'll give you someone else's take out they're preparing and you'll be waiting even LONGER), but if you're already ordered and are just doing a pick up, give them 5-10 minutes longer to prepare.  They're SLOOOOWWWW.
author: Jin B.

description:
Drunk and wondering the streets, we made a left into this spot with only a referral.  A 40 ounce of the champagne of beers in hand, we had no problems with the staff with it (then again we were 7 deep and they knew we must be starving).  Everything was pretty good, the naan was a little under toasted and the place seemed a lil filth.  
Ordered (I think):
naan, tiki masala, vindaloo, tandoori.
Like I said all was good but there was a few things missing.  But you could do a lot worse.  Give it a try.
author: Matthew M.

description:
Lahore Karahi would get 3.5 if I could make .5 stars. Gudoo doesn't f around with the spice, and I appreciate that. Two of three diners had a happy sweat going while the other diner was hitting the rice and h2o pretty hard. I like it hot, and when I asked for chicken tikka masala, the saag paneer (spinach), and lamb korma spicy! hot, that's what we got. 
Lahore could earn 4 or more stars if they baked the naan a little more, I prefer mine to be a tad more on the blistered side and if the samosas were hot (temp-wise) all the way through. Service couldn't be friendlier, and now I have a fond memory of Gudoo murmuring to my manfriend, "You like spicy? Mmm, try the tandoori fish!" He he, guess you had to be there, and the tandoori fish has me intrigued. 
Oh yeah, I love Bollywood movies, aight.
author: Candice L.

description:
OKay, I have to admit that the chef may be a bit OCD about cooking every dish by himself here, but I can't understand what the big deal is.  The food is freshly made, and very affordable - but the wow factor is just not there for me. 

I think I may have been secretly ruined by Shalimar - sort of like the first time you fall in love, maybe?!?  Oh well, to each his own.
author: Yelper A.

description:
Dining at Lahore Karahi is a most unique experience.
It's got a no frills dinner room where the owner/chef /waiter walks around, takes your order, chats with you then gets back to the kitchen to cook for you.

Any delay in having the food come out is simply because of that, the man who just took your order for whole wheat naan is now going to take out the whole wheat dough and get busy with making it.  I was quite surprised.  

So while there was no wait to sit, eating is a different matter entirely.   Thankfully, I had a dear friend to catch up with dinner so the length of time that we spent at the table waiting for food to come out was easily passed but still worth noting.  IF you come alone, bring a book.

I was surprised by how good these individually prepared meals were and when I asked for mild I did it as a protection against the crazy spiciness some Indian foods can take on.  I say "mild" at my favorite Indian joint and my mouth is still on fire.  So I was surprised that mild was mild.  

I was also surprised by the smoke that billows up in the place choking you and watering your eyes from the kitchen.  The attending server with replacement water was surprisingly curt "Give me those plates!" he demanded as opposed to "can I please take that out of your way?" but at $20 bucks for a filing meal they can hold the courtesy if it'd cost me more.
author: Sean S.

description:
the food here is UNREAL. BEST (and diviest) indian food in san francisco

byob
author: Dana C.

description:
This place loses one star for cleanliness because even though it's a hole in the wall, I don't like when my arms stick to the tables when I first sit down.

Otherwise, I had to write a positive, pro-veggie review. The food was delicious, ingredients were obviously fresh, and each dish had a distinctive flavor. They didn't just throw the same sauce on different ingredients. In fact, the food was so delectably seasoned that I couldn't stop moving from dish to naan to next dish back to naan then to dish 3, naan again, then back to dish 1 because it was so yummy and distinct... etc...  and leaving way too full. Anyway, veggies can easily find a satisfying meal here. That's all I wanted to say.
author: Surely I Am C.

description:
After reading fellow yelpers reviews of this place that is less than a block walking distance from my apartment, I decided to try it out. It is a small restaurant with about 10 or so dining tables. The wait staff and cook (i think he is the owner) are all very friendly and accomodating. Others have stated that the service is terrible. I disagree. The service is slow, yes (we waited about 10 min to have our order taken and about 20 for our food to arrive when the restaurant wasn't full at all), but the staff is eager and willing to assist you in ordering. Plus, the drinks are self service, so all the waiter really does is take your order and bring you plates.  The food is cooked dish by dish and I liked the fact that you could order everything mild or spicy (i like some things really spicy and some not so much). I liked their tea way better than naan and curry's.

So, the food. I'm going to start with their naan. I thought the naan was delicious, soft and fluffy in some spots, with a few crisp areas. A nice touch also is that they butter, and cut your naan into four pieces which makes it easy when you are sharing with others. We tried the chicken tikka masala and the lamb biryani. Both were delicious and I have since been back one more time and ordered the same thing, this time spicy. I liked the spicy lamb biryani better, but the mild chicken tikka masala was more flavorful to me. 
 
The next time I go, I plan to branch out and try a few new things. I am new to Indian and Pakistani cuisine, so I think I will ask the staff what they reccomend. The tandoori plates that I saw going to other tables looked awesome, and the mango lassy sounds really yummy. 

Basically, this is an awesome, cheap little hole in the wall kind of place with food that will blow you away. I wouldn't reccomend heading over to Lahore Karahi before an event because of the wait times, but it is a great place to go if you are hungry and appreciate fresh cooked delicious food.
author: Megan M.

description:
I am a fan! I've heard about this famously delicious place that you can bring your own alcohol! And besides that, the food is good!! Yes, it is sorta in the cuts, but it isn't that bad. And we found parking across the street, so that was nice.  I have no idea what our friend ordered, we had a table of 9, but everything was yummy. The sauces were so flavorful and you can definitely eat it with the rice or naan by itself. Between all of us, it was $13 a person with a generous tip. And it's all you can drink chai, but beware, it's pretty strong. I think I had it too late so I tossed and turned most of the night. 

You do leave smelling like food, so wear old clothes or tie your hair up.
author: Natalie S.

description: Chicken tikka masala was the best I've ever had. The lamb vindaoo was also very delicious. I didn't like he naan as much but thought it served well with the main dishes. Without a doubt, my preferred place for Indian in the city.
author: Mike L.

description: Fantastic Indian food, really the best I have ever eaten. The one drawback is this place has irregular hours! Call before you come and you wont' have a problem - if you're about to head out with friends, just check first and you won't be disappointed. Because the food will not let you down. As other mentioned, the tandoori fish is out of this world, the paneers are delicious and the naan is perfect. Overall, the food is buttery, flavorful, creamy, spicy, and delicious. Rock on, Lahore. (I have not eaten here since I heard there was a change in ownership. If this is true, I hope they keep it exactly the same - Lahore is a culinary treasure).
author: Justin A.

description:
A group of 13 from work went there for lunch today. Lucky for us, there were not many other people in the place when we went.  We started getting our food in around 30-40 minutes after we arrived, and it kept coming for the next 30 minutes. Tip: call in advance to give Guddu (the cook) some time to prepare.

The food was extraordinary. We ordered all sorts of tandoori items, fish, chicken, lamb, etc. The tandoori fish is Chilean Sea Bass, and was extremely good. All the curries and biryanis were wonderfully spiced, and FRESH. The naan was perfectly done, light and fluffy. The garlic naan was not overly garlicy, and probably the best I've ever had. The aloo naan had some bonus onion inside, which made it extra tasty.

My Indian coworkers, who always say that Shalimar is #1, actually want to go back here next time. That says a lot. Guddu rules!
author: Ron L.

description:
Well maybe I made a mistake going to a place that's known for its Tandoori more than it's Tikka (via the Yelpers yelping here), but I always have to wonder if places like Lahore Karahi make it so spicy because they hate me.  

I could hardly take another bite of the rice (that's plain rice, mind you) because the spice was unbearable.  I asked for mild, not "burn my tongue and make it so I can't eat your food".  The Tandoori fish was so-so because the spice seemed like an afterthought instead of being added in the preparation, and after taking a couple bites I spent the rest of my meal picking off the chili flakes.  

I'll stick with Naan & Chutney or Pakwan where they want the food to be more about the taste than the heat.
author: Lee G.

description:
Lahore Karahi is simply the best.
You've got to love this place!
No kidding!
You won't find the best chef (the owner), the most authentic food, the freshest spices and ingredients, the most polite counter person, and the most hardworking and decent people in other places but in Lahore Karahi.

I'd tried almost all Indian Pakistani restaurants, not only in SF and SF bay area but also in London's famous Indian restaurants and in south east Asia.
Still Lahore is the best. Without a doubt!
 
The biryanis, chicken vindaloo, and Daal Makhany(Mixed vege cooked with onions, tomatos, and spices are a must!!!
author: Pluviophile W.

description: great food at a very reasonable price. For a hole in the wall the place seemed very clean.
author: Gaurav M.

description: My buddies were talking this hole in the wall up. They know I'm a fan of hole in the types of places. However, I am not a fan after my first experience here. I knew that this place was popular, crowded and things would be coming slow out of kitchen. When it got to the table it just was not worth the wait. Our food came out without the other dishes we needed to eat our meal. By the time they did come out our food was cold. On top of that our Naan was burned. I'm not sure I'll make my way back here.
author: Dennis S.

description:
How many times have I asked my roomie..."Hey let's go to that whore place to eat" but meant Lahore Karahi? Many. I could not remember the name for some odd reason...haha.

But now this fine TL establishment is in my permanent lingo! I keep comparing other curries in taste, price and quality and most just don't make the cut. 

The downsides that everyone mentions is all true - sketchy neighborhood, sometimes messy, little bit of a wait - but hey well worth it when you savor every made to order bite and look at your bill with satisfaction.

$21 for 2, no corkage fee and my curry cravings simmered down... (for now :)
author: Charlene A.

description: One of my friends Edmond took me to this place.  Nearby Union Square, this is definitely one of the best places I've had for Indian in the SF area.  Very good chicken tikka masala.  Vinadoo was too vinegar-like.  Bread was good, rice was good, price is good.  Won't be disappointed.
author: Albert W.

description:
I give it 6 stars minus 1 for efficiency.

It was my first time here.  There was chaos and confusion everywhere.  A large party of 10 was just leaving.   There seemed to be one waiter and one busboy running around like chickens with their heads cut off.... really.  I would recommend they get a large bucket to clear off tables, or one more waiter to help with the load.  From what I could see they had enough customers and revenue coming in to justify another helper.

We were getting a little cranky waiting to be seated when I could clearly see the inefficient way the place was being run.  We finally got seated and then the one waiter was running around trying to get people's place settings to them.  We waited and served ourselves water.  We finally decided to take matters into our own hands and called the waiter over to let him know we were ready to order.  It's a good thing because we got our order in before the rest of the tables that got seated at the same time we did.  

When we realized this poor waiter was the only one waiting, bussing tables, and serving we just felt bad and chilled out a little.  We sat sipping our water and watching the very entertaining Indian musical on the screen.  Our food finally showed up and one bite of our food, we were blown away!

Vegetable Samosa (delectable)
Lamb Korma (indescribable flavor)
Tandoori Fish (amazing burst of flavor in my mouth)
Tandoori Chicken ( a little dry but good flavor)
Naan (yummm)

We went a little overboard with the food for 2 but it was all worth it!
If you see the overworked waiter doing his best to serve everyone give him a break, be extra friendly and patient and give him a nice tip.  He was pleasant throughout dinner and the completely full joint!  Just be ready to wait and be patient in getting service.
author: Blu n.

description:
This is my favorite Indian restaurant in SF. I give Lahore Karahi five stars for the delicious, fresh, lovingly cooked food. The owner of the restaurant prepare every dish from scratch himself, and it really shows when you taste everything - from the Chicken Biryani to the Bengan Bertha. I've never tried anything here that wasn't delicious. The food seems very healthy, and unlike other inexpensive Indian restaurants in the city such as Shalimar (where each dish is swimming in grease), at Lahore Karahi, you can tell that the food is made with care using quality ingredients.

Lahore Karahi is a casual place to go for very affordable, authentic Indian cuisine. I wouldn't recommend it for the atmosphere, but the place is still nice enough considering the prices.
author: Lisa A.

description:
I'm really sad that the waiter with terrible service (who was totally amusing as a result) is no longer here. The food remains amazing, I like the garlic naan and kulfi. The owner Guddu has a huge smile that brings me joy. Sometimes my friends and I wave to him as we're walking by just to see his grin. Yes, we're weird.

Best recent experience here: sitting at a table next to the window, a man on the street peered in, stared, smiled and waved at my friend & I for like five minutes. I love the TL its delightful character.
author: Meghan F.

description: Indian restaurant. It's authentic indian. It's listed at "divey" and thats def. true in the style of the food, but its good quality (not unhealthy like fast food) and authentic indian taste (there was a cinnamon stick in with my chicken saag dish, the basmati rice had one spicy pepper and some unknown spices (tree bark?) along with it.. There was def. some interesting stuff going on and the chef is also the cashier, etc. I'd  expect to wait a long time as there's three people running the entire show. But its tasty and prices are fantastic.
author: Alex S.

description:
I would like to inform that I know a thing or two about Indian/Pakistani food since I come from that part of the world. 

I went with some high hopes after reading Yelp reviews. I had looked at the pictures of the restaurant  on Yelp so did not have high hopes on the ambience. I ordered take out for Chicken Tandoori and Lamb Vindaloo. After eating it I have to say that any novice by just reading recipes from the internet could have done a better job. Indian/Pakistani food is not about getting Chicken Tikka Masala/ Butter Chicken right. I am saying this because perhaps they have those recipes down and I did not taste those dishes. I don't think I will go back.
author: Roshan T.

description:
I'm just going to go ahead and say it: if you're expecting fast, great service, don't bother coming here. Now if you're looking for really good Indian/Pakistani food without minding the mediocre service, then I definitely suggest Lahore Karahi.

I don't think I have tasted anything I didn't like. Their naan is delectable, the best I have ever tasted. The Daal Makhany is simply delicious, basically everything in the vegetarian section is good (since I've tasted those) and so is their mango lassi.
author: Emily C.

description:
I'd heard this place was good so thought I'd check it out...the food was fantastic, the saag paneer was tasty and spiced perfectly and the lamb korma was spicy and delicious.  Everything we had was awesome! 

The only drawback to this place was that they cook in the same room as you eat, leaving the whole room filled with smoke.  I left the restaurant smelling like I had just bathed in the Ganges, maybe it was just a problem with their ventilation, who knows??

Definitely worth checking out for the fantastic food!
author: Craig E.

description:
I've been going here ever since they opened and eager owner / chef / waiter / cashier called me off the street and convinced me to eat one of his tandoor wraps.  It took him fifteen minutes to make and it was utterly delicious, dripping with chicken juices and a tahini-like sauce.

Now it's a well known tiny little establishment and people go nuts for the food, which is typical Tenderloin pak-Indian in conception and low price but a little more fresh home-cooked and sit-down in execution.  The place manages to be warm and inviting in a tough part of town.
author: Gil S.

description:
"I care about every order - thats the difference". Ya know what - that is the difference. Guddu truly seems to care about all the dishes he serves up. Definitely the best Northern Indian/Punjab food I've had in the city and as good as most I've had in India proper.

The best Aloo Paratha I've ever eaten and their Naan is pretty much perfect. Hard to find Matar Paneer in the city to begin with, but it's really good here - uniquely sweeter. Chicken Vandaloo was like Holi taking place in my mouth - colors and spice jumping all around. Like others have pointed out - the fact that his cooking doesn't have a layer of oil floating at the top (standard most places) makes it even better and the flavor doesn't suffer at all.

I could seriously go on about the Kulfi, or how good the free Chai is, but i think you all get the point. You probably don't need to check this place out - after all one cook, smaller place, you don't feel like waiting for food. lol
author: Mike C.

description:
Fresh faced geeks looking to be the next Bill Gates, gossiping mental health counselors and budget-minded non-profit fundraisers wooing donors give a whole new meaning to "power" lunch. 

Although the service has been slow both times I've been there, the lentil dal and garlic naan are the best veggie options in a wasteland of dive bars and food joints. Bring a book or co-workers and pass the time watching Bollywood television.  Cheap & hearty, this grub will stick to your ribs.
author: Jasmine T.

description:
I ordered for takeout to bring to my room at the Hilton.  They told me it would be ready in 40-45 minutes.  Walking up O'Farrell, I could smell the spices and tandoori smoke from half a block away.  When I got there, the tiny restaurant was full, and a line of people waiting for a table or waiting to order takeout extended chaotically out the door.  It was unpleasantly cramped.

The food was tasty but cold.  (Clearly 40-45 minutes was a bad estimate.)  The best item was tandoori fish.  The fish itself was high quality, and the spices were wonderful; too bad it was cold.  They forgot to include the side of rice I had ordered and paid for.  In retrospect, I wish I had ordered biryani--a plate of it looked absolutely divine.

It doesn't surprise me that some people consider Lahore Karahi a great restaurant, and I suspect I would too on more visits, but on this one visit I was slightly disappointed.

Edit: So I went back and tried some more items, including the biryani.  Vegetable biryani is one of my favorite dishes, and Lahore Karahi served up one of my favorite renditions of it.  Very spicy, incredibly flavorful and complex, interesting textures.  Also terrific was the garlic naan, which tasted much like a tasty Italian "garlic bread" except on naan.  I wasn't that thrilled with the shahi paneer, which tasted too earthy for my tastes--lots of onion and tomatoes, not enough rich dairy fat.
author: Anonymous P.

description:
Lahore.  Yes, I know Lahore is the name of a city, but it's still an epically unfortunate name for a tenderloin establishment.  But the food is amazing, the spice just right, and the price cannot be beat.  It's BYOB, and the staff is very welcoming, so you can really linger and have a great meal -- which is great as long as you're not the one waiting on one of the five tables.

The waiter once recommended the tandoori lamb chops as one of their best dishes.  It's very good, but the tandoori fish is my favorite dish, followed closely by the saag.  Unlike most indian restaurants I've been to, Lahore uses some sort of greens for the saag, rather than spinach.  Friends tell me that saag in India is made with a cousin to colllards or mustard greens, and the Lahore version is the most authentic they've had in this country.  I don't know about all that, but I can tell you that the saag is outstanding, as is anything eggplant.  Don't miss the butter chicken.
author: Ben A.

description:
if you like bugs with your dish, go ahead.
This is literally a hole in the wall... and they take that to a literal extreme. Dont know who that hole is for... i guess for the bugs to come in and go.
BTW there is no such thing as Pakistani-Indian cuisine... this type is called "Mughlai cuisine" after the folks who used to rule over that region a few centuries back.
The owner if he is from Pakistan should just call it Pakistani cuisine or if from India, vice versa and stop this hyphenating crap.
In any case, SF department of health should pay a visit.
author: andy n.

description:
This is some of the best tandoori food I've ever had. Its hard to rate Indian restaurants because some of their food can be real good, while some of it can really suck. And I mean REALLY suck. And cause you to suck because of the food. So, I came here a couple of days ago, and upon the chef's recommendation, had the Tandoori Fish. I couldnt just eat the fish, so I also got the Chicken Tikka Masala, which I've forever consider an Indian restaurant's litmus test - if their tikka masala is good, their food's gotta be good. Which is what I thought till I got here. WRONG. Bottom-line :

Tandoori Fish : ***** (5)
Chicken Tikka Masala : (0) (no stars - sucks, dont eat it!)
Tandoori Chicken : ***** (5)
Lamb Vindaloo : **** (4)

Everything's served hot and fresh. And if you're going there, be prepared to wait, because the chef prepares everything himself, right there. And he admits it too. He's a very nice, down-to-earth individual. Nothing's premade.

All in all, I'd recommend it, but not for the curries, but for their tandoori stuff.
author: Anand I.

description:
This place is probably one of THE best Indian places I've been to in this city. The neighborhood totally sucks beyond belief, but every mouthful is worth the smelly people you have to walk over and through to get here! 

I had the lamb biryani, which, suprisingly, did not come with raita but was still really good. I also ate some my friend's bengan bhartha, which was sooooo good I took her leftovers! The naan, in addition to everything else, is made fresh in front of you and is super delish. Next time I really want to try the Afghani Naan (w/ raisins, nuts, cheese & cherries). The owner says this is more of a dessert naan.

Speaking of the owner, he was as friendly and helpful with suggestions as he could be! We had constant refills on our drinks, even with a little bit of a lunch rush. He even served our table with complimentary kulfi for dessert!! That was also really yummy.

Despite the location, it's close enough to work that I will most definitely be going back as often as possible!
author: Amy B.

description:
Delicious on a Friday night.

One could arguably remove a star for the Tenderloin ambience and slow service (based on the traffic, they should have no problem affording another person, or even bumping up their prices).

Chicken tikka masala was different but good. Less tomato-y than I'm used to having, and sweeter (cinnamon?).

Bengan bharta (why does eveyone spell it differently?) was also good. We ordered spicy and it came to our table spicy.

Naan is very puffy. Like, puffy and fluffy enough to make a chicken-tikka-masala-bengan-bharta-gyro with it without getting your fingers dirty.

The food is not greasy at all.
author: Rob T.

description:
Yummy and cheap in San Francisco? Only in the Tenderloin.

Love me some chicken tikka masala... and that's exactly what I had (devoured) at Lahore Karahi a couple of weeks ago. I won't bother to add to the already bountiful glowing reviews about the food here, though I fully concur, and will instead limit my 2 cents to advising that you get it to go. 

Last time we stopped by, they were so busy that the food took half an hour to appear before us (and we got lucky, it seems, though not without a little friendly insistence). There were most definitely a few awkward instances when a couple of customers got impatient and angry, and the chef proceeded to blurt out that this was a take-out place only, though I'm not sure what that has to do with the speed of the cooking... which does, in turn, have a lot to do with the fact that there is only one -- one! -- cook (albeit a talented one at that). 

The truth is that LK seems to have become popular fairly rapidly and just hasn't had the chance to catch up to its own significantly expanded fan-base, what with its single chef, naan specialist, and two overworked busboys. Moreover, the restaurant does feature a sign on its window that states quite clearly "take out only" but has several tables and chairs inside as well, which lends itself to sedentary customers. So the restaurant is certainly undergoing a severe identity crisis which, until resolved, may taint customers' experiences... However, I do recommend that you arm yourself with patience and venture into this tasty Pakistani gem, because the food is positively worth whatever hassle you may have to endure.
author: G. J.

description:
If I would ever write one yelp review, it would be a review for Lahore Kahari, so here is one yelp review (so far).

It truly pains me when someone wants Indian/Pakistani food and they suggest Naan n' Curry. That's not a joke, my brain and entire body begin to hurt.

Naan n Curry serves a purpose for fast, half-decent food; but why settle for that when you can have really amazing food, cooked by the chef/owner virtually every time just a hop, skip and jump away from all your favorite Naan n Curry and Shalimar locations?

I almost always get the chicken biryani- it is truly f-ing amazing and delicious. There's so many different flavors, some delicate, some big, that I can barely comprehend it.

Also, good Naan and everything else. Enjoy.
author: Bob H.

description:
update:
I am soooooo sad they are closed for lunch now... But Gudu has paid his dues and deserves some rest.





I eat here at least once a week, so it is only fair that I make it my first review. (that is after having my account of 3 years close suddenly when yelp decided to change a policy without notification...still a little bitter, yep)

I eat mostly vegetarian, so I can't speak for the rest of the menu, but what I get, I love. Samosas, Vegetable Pakora, Muttar Paneer, Pappadam, and Naan. 

The naan bread is only a buck so get plenty...I like to take the rest home and make pizzas...

The service can be slow at times as Guddu sometimes is the cook, server, and cashier.

I love the space...growing up in So.Cal. ,I saw plenty of the sterile big box type stores and restaurants and felt they lacked heart. The kitchen here extends into the dining room and it has a real feel of authenticity.

Guddu takes great pride in his food and it shows. I spend the better part of 15 years in kitchens, so when we got to talking, I realized how much of himself Guddu puts into this place. All his food is Halaal and he drives pretty far to get the best.

Thanks for all the great food Guddu...
author: Kane M.

description:
Actual rating: 4.5

I used to be fearful of Indian food, but recently had a change of heart.  The food here was absolutely amazing!  We ordered the deep fried potatoes and peppers, butter chicken, lamb roti, garlic naan and regular naan.  

Even though the garlic naan was good, I still think Shalimar's garlic naan tops Lahore.

I would take .5 stars off because the flatware was a little dirty and the staff was a little slow.
author: Jon T.

description:
Five stars for the food--it's spiced in a way that indian food at every other restaurant just isn't. Cinnamon, nutmeg, probably complex indian spices-all are surprising in the dishes you find. Their naan is also the best, it's not dry or stale.

I've only gotten to-go here because I have heard stories about the service, but even that is spotty. They have an unmentioned limit on cards, and the staff can be brusque but the cook/owner is very nice. I would get your food and go--don't dawdle.
author: Luke J.

description:
Came here with my co "Maharani's bitch" and really really really liked the food. 

Everything we ordered was really good and not greasy like most of the other Tandoorloin places (Shalimar, take note!). 

Sadly, the gulab jamun, as noted by Anjali V., was sub-par. It tasted stale and was cold in the middle. Bleh! I am really obsessed with the sticky brown balls and I like 'em hot and melty inside.

You're better off getting an It's-It from one of the corner stores for dessert, but don't miss Lahore Karahi's Aloo Methi or Paneer Tikka Masala.
author: Vandana M.

description:
fast, cheap, so good and so nice owner! definitely wrong place for boring "chic" people. let's keep them away from us! ;-)

GO GUDDU!
author: Davide milidolo R.

description:
Really, people? What's the big deal about this place? We went in for an early dinner on Sunday evening. The place was pretty empty and we were seated on the big table in the middle, even though there were only two of us. Next to a us was a little table in the corner full of dirty dishes. I looked around to see four tables that still had dirty dishes...all this was a huge turn-off, but we decided to stay anyway since the reviews were so good. The place is small, and only a few tables were taken, so why the waiter/buss boy was so damn slow in doing his work was beyond me. 

It was irritating to see him walk around, answering his phone every few minutes while doing everything in slow-mo. I asked for a straw...he actually looked around for one when there was a container full sitting in a prominent place next to the drink glasses. Anyone who's been to this place knows how tiny it is...I'd never been there, but still, I knew where the straws were! Near the entrance, somebody was peeling potatoes and onions on a small table. It sure didn't add to the already crappy ambiance.

The food was not so great, either. We ordered vegetable pakoras which were overdone. The butter chicken had a weird consistency and tasted nothing like any butter chicken I've ever had. The chicken karahi was nicely spicy, but all you could taste was dry chicken and green chillies. The garlic naan was ok, but the regular naan was really good. Mango lassi was watered down and they had no ice for our Cokes.

Needless to say, dinner sucked. The kitchen was dirty, the owner kept coming and going indoors and out...he actually met a friend at the front door and played with her dog...eeew! The waiter was incompetent, and I've had better Pakistani food elsewhere. Actually, I wouldn't even call it Pakistani food...that would be an insult to Pakistani food. Guddu needs to learn how to cook!
author: Benjina D.

description:
After wanting to go here so badly my BF and I finally made the trek the other night.

Ordered chicken tikka masala, lamb curry, and potato patties. The potatoes were amazing. Lamb was cooked to perfection and the sauce was great. But the tikka masala was lacking. I think it was the ground pistachios that threw me off but... it was okay.

Bill came to 24 which isn't bad... it'll do in a jiff but.. we'll see.
author: laura f.

description:
Thank you to everyone for recommending this place.  (Although my waistline will no doubt wish it remained undiscovered.)  Yes, there is a wait and it is disorganized.  But the food! And the service! The chef is an amazingly friendly person and he does wonderful things in his kitchen.  We had the samosas (I'm generally not a fan, but I would get these again); saag ghost; the butter chicken; plain naan and the Afghani naan.  We were served a complimentary ice cream (All of this for $22.00) If I was standing the saag would have brought me to my knees. It will restore your faith.  Butter chicken was also divine.  The Afghani naan was similar to a cross between panetoni and nann, but it was killer this morning toasted with my coffee.  

The only downside - apart from having to wait - were the feelings of guilt that I was taking advantage of Guddu due to his insanely low pricing for the quality of his food.
author: She-Ra ..

description:
It was my friend's birthday and he said he wanted to go here because they had AMAZING Indian food.  I'll preface this by saying that I'm pretty ambivalent to Indian food - I don't love it but I don't hate it and I wouldn't choose it if it were my birthday.  Onwards...

Finding parking in the Tenderloin is creepy and a pain in the ass.  We parked two blocks away and passed a woman putting shiny, silver underwear on her head as we walked to the restaurant.  Nice.

The place is small and not much by way of decoration.  The tables are equally small and grouped pretty close to one another.  The menu was ample for us vegetarians and it was gloriously cheap.  Like $5-7 a plate cheap so we ordered 3 veggie plates and 2 orders of naan.  

The food arrived and, upon seeing that it didn't come with rice, we ordered 2 plates of rice.  The server wasn't friendly and  made sure to remind us that we didn't originally order rice.  "Yes, I know, but we would like some rice now, thank you."

The food was fine.  Nothing to write home about but I'm not much of a connoisseur. 

We had finished our water before the food even got there and were never offered more.  This is frustrating since I'm a pansy for spicy foods and, dammit, i just like having sufficient water at dinner.  I walked up to the pitcher at one point, only to have a waiter swoop in and take it away before I got there.  I had my friend flag down the server since I'm not keen on rejection.

The server sat someone at the table behind us and reprimanded us for putting a food basket on the table.  First, we didn't even order anything that came in a basket.  And second, even if we had put it there, it wouldn't have been malicious - the tables are very small.  Just pick it up and go on with your business.

There were only two or three people working there and I don't really mind my food taking a little extra time, but I appreciate normal service like refilling water.

I paid and we walked back to the car, past a woman beating on some guy with a pillowcase and yelling at him.

total: $25+tip

Pros: very cheap
Cons: unfriendly/unhelpful waitstaff and location
author: Lindsay D.

description:
I love this place!  I had came here for dinner with a friend and left my sun glasses here.  By the time I realized this, I was half way back to San Jose, but I called them the day after, and they saved it for me!  I was so happy to get them back because I just got them a month ago and when was the last time something actually got returned from the Tenderloin?  

The food was equally great.  We got the Saag Paneer and Lamb Gosht and they were both excellent.  The lamb was tender and the cauliflower soaked up all the juicy tastiness from the curry.  The Saag Paneer had a nice sweetness to balance out the spices.  This is now one of my favorite places to eat!
author: May C.

description:
This is an absolute gem in the rough.  With over 500 reviews, I guess it really isn't so much a hidden gem anymore.  A go-to Indian spot for my friends and me.

Down to earth, home-style cuisine that packs a punch.  The best dishes are the lamb gosht (flavorful, mild to little spice) and korba lamb (mild-spicy, all delicious).  The naan is one of the best in the city -- crispy on the outside, soft on the inside -- and never greasy.  Going with the rice though, really completes the home-style flavor. 

BYOB.   Guduu does the fish dishes RIGHT, by the way.  He's also created this homestyle Indian ice cream we tried the other night (mango, cardamom, pistachios...), so rich and so good. 

It really can get cramped sometimes because of all the other hungry and devoted patrons, but chef/owner Guduu brightens up the wait with his easy smile and lovely personality.  He and his staff are so friendly and generous, it makes our visits awesome.  Great food and great people?  Sold. 

I've grown to become a loyal patron, willing to brave the TL on foggy nights, just for this deliciousness.  I've never been disappointed and I always leave happy and full.  Guduu, you rock!
author: Melissa H.

description: worst food ever. Stale meal, never seen a worst service than this place. I would like to give -ve 5 but yelp won't allow so have to give 1 start. Please stay away from this place.
author: Salman K.

description:
It looked so promising.

Everyone on Yelp loves the joint (usually a good sign).  I got the food and it looked delish - dare I say better than my favorite Pakwan?  I did say it to sweet baboo upon the visual treat that awaited me.

And those first few bites...I was prepared for my new best friends right across the street.

Then, something went terribly wrong.  I noticed my drink was empty.  I got another.  A few more bites and I got another.  After a while I noticed the unpleasant and lingering burning sensation on my tongue and the sides of my cheeks.   From samosas?  I wondered.  I ceased eating the yogurt cucumber sauce believing that to be the culprit.

No dice - the heat overwhelms (and outlasts) the flavor.  Such a shame as the ingredients are very fresh and lovely.  I love hot food - as long as it compliments and enhances the flavors - not the case here.

I'll give it another go at Lahore Karahi, but for now I have to stick with my buddies over at Pakwan (which now delivers!!!).
author: Suze C.

description:
Sometimes, Yelp is dead-on about great places to eat. However, more often then Yelp, your co-worker of the ethnicity in question is even more dead-on. When I saw 4.5 stars on 190 reviews I thought "this is promising". When my co-worker said "The only Indian food that compares is my mom's. I lived in England for 10 years and never had Indian food this good" - then...I drop everything I'm doing and proceed to the restaurant immediately. Simply put, this is best Indian food I've ever had. Some places have been close, but Lahore Karahi is the new standard-bearer. 

LK is in the Tenderloin. So, get your dirty, grimy, SF reality on, and go on a foggy, windy, and freezing summer's evening. The place is BYOB so bring some wine or some beer. When my friend and I arrived, a group of 6 people had already gone through a 6-pack of Fat Tire and were working on a 6-pack of Red Stripe. Two other guys across the room each had one of those large cans of Sapporo to drink with their meal. That alone shows how knowledgeable the patrons here are. They understand that Light lagers, pilsners, and weak ales are the only acceptable beer-forms for Indian (or any other type of equatorial) food.

Now, to the food - My friend and I, seeing that all entrees (other than 3 items) were priced below $7 immediately went into a binge-fest. We ordered an outstanding roti ($1), we ordered naan ($1), we order Butter Chicken and Lamb Vindaloo ($7), and lastly, we ordered the much-hullabalooed Tandoori Fish ($11). Everything was outstanding. The Tandoori Fish was perfectly spiced, perfectly cooked. The Lamb vindaloo was incredibly complex and rich. And of course, the Butter Chicken was butter chicken - but unlike most places they let the chicken shine, not the sauce. We ate until you could not possible eat ever again. I am writing this around lunch-time of the day after and I'm still full.

The owner/chef/waiter greeted us and, at first glance, was slightly eerie. But if you get into your SF cultural acceptance and tolerance mode, you've got no problems with the service. It was timely, efficient, and (somewhat) unintrusive. 

I will be back here many, many times. Oh..and Bourbon and Branch is like 5 steps away. It's an odd to think of these two places, which couldn't be more different, but who both practice their craft with such perfection, both setting up shop in the ghetto a mere block from each other. The joys of San Francisco never cease...
author: Tolga E.

description:
Food is delicious and authentic.  The place is totally ghetto fab.  The fish tandoori is the best thing on the menu.  My favorite indo/pak place in the bay area.  

Make yourself comfortable cuz your food's gonna take a while.
author: Shyam P.

description: Best Indian food in the city!  Plan on waiting a few minutes if you want to find a seat.  Definitely worth it though, and you can bring your own Booze so drinking while you wait makes it all the more fun.  If you have to choose only one Indian food place in the city to go to this should be it!  Don't let the kitchen probably smaller than tyhe one you have at home, paper cups galore, and smoke-filled air of the establishment deter you from the AMAZING food and fun environment.  So cheap and so good.  CASH ONLY. BYOB.
author: Gabriel C.

description: Fish tandoori, shahi paneer, tikka masala paneer, and potato naan are all amazing dishes. I diligently wait 40 minutes every time for the amazing food. Sometimes I even wait days. Warning: Guddu opens when he wants, but he can. His food is that good. Every person I've brought here converts just as I did when I first tried the fish and the curries. This is one of the best spots in the city.
author: Jen Y.

description:
I've been burnt out on North Indian/Pakistani food for awhile, and have been sticking with South Indian places.   My coworkers swear by Lahore, though, so I thought I'd tag along with them.  And I was not disappointed . . .

We got the tandoori fish, chicken tikki masala, and matter paneer.  I'm not a big fan of fish, but if I was, I would've loved the tandoori fish.  The chicken tikka masala was wonderful -- really juicy chicken, and fresh flavorful saunce.  The mattar panner was probably the best I've had -- no cubed panner straight from the freezer here -- it was so fresh, it squeaked!  

Normally, I will eat a couple of naan on my own.  So when we ordered only two for the 3 of us, I thought that wouldn't be enough.  My coworkers assured me that the naan was huge, and indeed it was . . . I generally don't care for garlic naan, but it's excellent here . . . lots of seeds and other tasty stuff in addition to the garlic.

It's true that the service is slow .  There was only one other party in the restaurant when we went, and it still took about 20 minutes to get our food.  But everything was timed perfectly, so nothing was cold.  

I'm giving 4 stars since I've only been there once, but if future visits are as good, I'll definitely be upgrading my rating to 5!
author: J S.

description:
I figure that if i use yelp, i should also contribute. So from here on you will be seeing more from me. I tend to visit a new restaurant every weekend and i am a big fan of food\cooking myself.

My first ever review and sorry that it has to be a negative one. But here is why:

This is what i feel when i follow a Yelp review:

When it comes to food, there is a difference between good tasting food and ORIGINAL tasting food. 
Yelp reviewers can agree on good tasting food, but not on the later. For example, I have found myself loving certain
Chinese &Mediterranean restaurants which are detested by my Chinese &Mediterranean friends. Reason: I liked how the 
food at these places tasted, but had no exact idea as to how they were supposed to taste. It is like going to a sushi 
place and enjoying a sushi with cooked fish(Might be exaggerating a bit :-) ). 


Lahore Karahi will probably fit the former(In my case not even that). Here are reasons why:

My order:

1)Sheek Kebab
2)Lamb Biryani
3)Garlic Naan
4)Butter Chicken

In this case, me being from that part of the world(Indian& Pakistan) and being an avid food lover, I know how each of the above should taste like, or how each 
of the above taste in the best restaurants, cooked by the best chefs in that part of the world. let me explain how
it should have been cooked and how it should have tasted, and how it actually did.

1) Sheek Kebab: Ground lamb kebabs which when pulled out of the tandoor(grill), should never be overcooked.
When served, the meat is tender and juicy and is still cooking from the heat. at Lahori: burnt on the outside, really
dry meat, overcooked. spices were not bad.

2)Lamb Biryani: usually cooked in a big pot\vessel with alternate layers of 
rice and meat(Slow cooked for a long time and simmered and when served, the layers are mixed and a serving portion is taken out of the big 
pot/vessel). At Lahori: rice and meat mixed together in a frying pan(I saw him do this!).

3) Garlic Naan: Naan usually fluffy and super soft bread with garlic and cilantro pretty much melting on top with the heat of the Naan.
At Lahori: dry bread, garlic not fresh.

4) Butter chicken: Creamy sauce, with butter floating on top with super soft chicken pieces. At lahori: Not creamy at all, 
but rather like a paste of onions and tomatoes. the texture was so that i could feel the onions and tomatoes in my mouth.
the color which should be bright red or orange is just red. can barely taste the fresh butter. 

A lot of you might be thinking if should expect all this in a small restaurant in tenderloin. But as a matter of fact, Every good\well known
street side restaurant in that part of Indian/Pakistan serve the above dishes just as explained above.

Reasons why my 2 stars: The use of spices were pretty decent .But failed in all other aspects (texture, the way it is 
cooked, served, size, taste) . The service was friendly and good.

Also to note, probably a reason why this place gets great reviews, is the service part. The old man serving tends to do a great job
in hyping up the restaurant. I hear him say things like "No one cooks this dish as good as we do" and it seems to be working with the
customers as well. i don't rate restaurants on decor unless it fits that category. The decor in this place seems to be good enough for this
place. 

As it is my first one, i hope you enjoyed it and also be easy on me!
author: Karthick S.

description:
The vegetarian food per se is alright,nothing to write home about but my friends tell me the tandoori fish here is super awesome. Maybe,I'm a veggie so I wouldn't know. The food is also slightly greasy which can be a slight turn off ..I would give it 2 stars. Can be rather picky when it comes to food.

Their dessert section wasn't too appealing either,till I tried their kneer.They dont have it always though.Once you try their kheer you would be inclined to bump the rating to 4!!! Seriously the kheer is Mmmmm..Spoon of heaven.Almost magical.
author: Natasha I.

description:
Terrible food. Terrible service.

I really wanted to like this place,since I live across the street from them.  But their ordering system (or lack there of I suppose) was terrible.  I'm pretty sure I didn't get what I ordered, and I was only able to choke down what I did get because it was 7:30pm  and the only food I'd had time to eat all day. The naan was the only palatable part of the meal, and even then, it was not that great.
author: Brody B.

description:
So after moving to San Francisco from India, I have been starved for the perfect Indian food and I have literally tried every Indian restaurant in the city. Without a doubt, Lahore Karahi is the BEST. The owner, Guddu, makes completely authentic, delicious food. You almost feel like your sitting in your mom's kitchen.
