After eating at this place atleast once a week for the last one year, I am surprised that I still haven't gotten tired of this place. Oh and I love how they have a cute, tiny but clean place..unlike Shalimar and some of the other lower end indian restaurants in the 'tandoor'loin. 
Bottom Line - for real, good, cheap Indian food go to Lahore Karahi
author: Meenaxi P.

description:
Made it back there for take out this time.  This place is busy most nites and this nite was no exception.  The service this time was pretty good, except that Guddu gave me a normal Seekh instead of Chicken but the food was pathetic except for the Daal Makhani which reminded my Mom of her Grannies Daal.  Guddu must buy cinnamon on sale or grow his own as he puts this in everything and extra doses of it.  Saag Paneer had 3 big pieces, Bengan Aloo had 6 huge ones as well.  Shit, even the rice had a few of its own.  For those of you who dont know, cinnamon tends to sweeten the food along with giving it this really nice aroma if used sparingly.  Overuse makes it sweet and yesterday, everything was sweet.  I was dissapointed.  The Seekh was excellent and so was the fish tandoori that I had on the drive back home but everything else was really bad.  Will not return.

Food is aight, Guddu is aight but the older server gentleman is an idiot fo the first order.  Arrogant, ignorant, incapable etc. etc.  The food's OK, has gotten worse than before, the ambiance is generally nice.  The server, again, an idiot.  We ordered an extra Roti while eating and once he brought it to the table, he said we should have ordered it together in the beginning.  So, we can't change our mind and order an extra Roti.  My friend is lactose intolerant and instructed them not to put any cream in any of the dishes.  When the daal came, it looked a little white so he asked the server if there was any cream to which he said No.  We then asked the bus boy if the dish had cream and he said yes.  They did bring out a new daal sans the cream.  I do not recommend this place and it's not because of the food.
author: A K.

description: Really f-ing long wait for food. Seriously. You need to devote like 2 hours if you're getting food here.  Butter chicken was good, but not as good as the eggplant (can't remember if it was the aloo bengan or the bengan bhartiia). Tasty. I just wish it was faster. Also, friend suggested sizzling fish, which I don't think they had the day we were there.
author: Karena Q.

description:
Best Indian in the City, hands down.  We always get a big order from Lahore when having people over & don't feel like cooking--and everybody RAVES about it.  Mild spicy = still plenty spicy.
Worth the round-trip drive from the Sunset.
Super nice owner. Takes very good care of each & every customer.
Get it to go; place order a good hour before you want it.
author: A S.

description:
What a place!! The food is delicious served piping hot and consistently good EVERYTIME! The Afghani Nan, Chicken Tikka Masala, Chicken Boti (comes steaming on a hot skillet) will keep you coming back for more! It is extremely addictive! Not to mention very affordable! The area is straight up 'Loin but this particular block is sans (without) the crack-heads... so don't sweat it! Come on down...I promise you'll keep coming back for more!

P.s. Make sure you have time to wait though Gudu, the master chef is alone in all preparations and some plates like tandoori take a while (but hey it's worth it!)
author: Mira L.

description:
This our first experience here, we picked it because it was so highly reviewed on Yelp. Let's start with the positive, lamb tandoori came hot and sizzling, chicken biryani was spicy and well flavored, our naan was soft and fluffy, and the curry was up to standards.

Now for the bad part. We walked in, party of 5 on a Sunday early evening. It seemed pleasantly busy, a good sign. We were sat right away. When no one had brought water or offered to take our order after about 20 minutes we realized there was only ONE person taking orders, serving, and busing. We also observed that for some odd reason, plenty of other tables were being served before us (and later receiving their food well after we had placed our order). Long story short, we felt for the man who was doing EVERYTHING but the cooking, so we tipped him generously but this place needs to work on their service. Had the service been up to standards at least, this place would have been great, unfortunately we left the place pretty unhappy and all 5 of us don't believe it's worth ever going back.
author: Jamie W.

description: Very modest atmosphere here.  Probably would have avoided it if it wasn't for the high reviews.  My entree and naan were good but not great.  Service wasn't terribly friendly either, but prices were fair, and there's no wait for a table if you dine early.  I believe I had the aloo muttar and it was very creamy, which I thought was odd for this dish that normally isn't so rich and creamy.
author: Albert H.

description:
i've heard about lahore, but had yet to try it.

sf loves to eat at places like this, and i fall into that category. there's some mom+pop feel with the vibe that rundown places serve incredible food. i'm no exception.

but we ate here when there was only one other table. our food took a bit longer to come out than i felt necessary. the food was decent, but there's a lot of indian/pakistani restaurants in sf, so the competition is real stiff.

i'd go back, but only if i was nearby already for something else.
author: Ameer N.

description:
For down-home Indian cookin', look no further. The prices are super low, the windows are dirty, and the ambience is nothing special. 

The food is divine. The food is divine. The food is divine. 

Go next door and buy some beer, bring it with you because they don't serve it inside. It's totally okay to do this.
author: Amani Ellen L.

description:
The food is very good. The guy who appears to be the owner/manager is very freaky. If I didn't know better, I'd say he hates his customers. Maybe he's trying to introduce the manners and customs of his country/neighborhood to us heathens. Maybe he's been behind the stove too long. Anyway, I like that he plays those surreal Bollywood movies in his restaurant; I can lose myself in them and ignore him. I'll be back.


Good if you're getting an early start in the TL.
author: Jabe N.

description: There is a long wait so be prepared. I think along with byob your should bring your own water. I felt a little grossed out by their water and cups. I guess there might have been some other "friends" that joined because another table squealed in the corner.  Apparently, there is only one cook for the whole place so it literally took an hour to get our food. I would say 90% of our dishes were spicy. My favorite dish was the butter squash chicken. The sauce was tasty and the the meat was not dry. I also like the naan. I cannot really say much about the other dishes because the spiciness took over my mouth.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
I went here with 2 friends on a busy Saturday night, having heard "better than Shalimar" raves.  Ha.  I should be generous and assume that they are better on a slower night, but based on the food I can't see them getting more than 3 stars.  Rather than narrate the story, let me lay out what went right and wrong.

Right:

-Made us a very good off-menu salty lassi, by request.

-Waitress was helpful and friendly

-Food was fresh, including freshly made samosas

Wrong:

-Long wait for food (admittedly acceptable on a Sat night)

-Friction between male proprietors and female waitperson seemed to make transactions difficult.  Those guys seemed really disrespectful.

-As others have mentioned, the Tikka Masala is sweet.  Worse yet, so is the Saag Paneer.  Yuk.

-No chai.  It ran out before we could get our first cup.  Every time we asked for it, another staff person would practically roll their eyes and tell us we had to get it ourselves, and every time we would point out that THERE WASN'T ANY CHAI TO GET.  Sheesh.  And we were there for almost 2 hours.  Totally unacceptable for a Pakistani restaurant.  Chai should flow like water.

-Took forever to pay.  We sat around waiting at our table for the change.  We were eventually told that the owner is the only one who handles the money, and thus there was a bottleneck.  Later, the older gentleman working the floor was so flustered at the fact we were still taking a precious table that he rudely told us that we were in the way of of people waiting for tables and we'd need to pester the owner ourselves for change.  When I went to do that, the owner spent several minutes pulling bread out of the tandoori oven before making the change.  I guess the owner is the only one trusted to make the bread too.

Now, I am used to the Shalimar / Naan and Curry model of self-service, where there is no table service and all ordering happens at the counter.  In my experience, those places do that fine, and I am completely satisfied.  Their service is excellent if you accept that the terms and conditions.  I don't need to be pampered.  

But I've never been to a Pakistani place that is out of chai for two hours.  And if a restaurant offers table service, it shouldn't push people out of their tables to go get change.  Especially if the only reason for the hold up is that the owner can't trust his staff enough to delegate.  Overall, this place was seriously dysfunctional, and until they get their management together these sorts of problems will continue.

Mind you, I am the sort of person that would overlook it all if the food was good.  Sadly, it was not.
author: Jim C.

description: Best Indian food in the City. The butter chicken is incredible. I always bring/send out of towners here when they ask where to go for Indian food and they have never been disappointed. The hole-in-the-wall ambiance adds to the appeal as does the Bollywood movies playing on the TV.
author: Johanna S.

description: Best Indian food I've ever had. This is a simple family run restaurant. It's no frills, you literally write your own ticket. The food is sensational.
author: Renee R.

description:
After hearing so much about it - quite ordinary. I am a huge fan of Kabana (Pakistani restaurant) in Berkeley and people told me to try this one. But the two places are incomparable. 

Tandoori leg was served on a sizzling hot plate but turned out to be soggy and drenched in water. and the gravy in Shahi Paneer had raw onions. Service was very poor too. On an absolute scale, it wasn't that bad but no where close to being the "best in the bay area".
author: Amit P.

description:
First and foremost: the food was delicious!

secondly, we waited so goddammed long it should have been. We didn't realize at first that the dude cooking the food was also our waiter..  We had plenty of time to look around since our food took forty minutes!  I would definitely consider taking take out from here but don't think i would sit there for dinner again..
author: rukshan b.

description:
The owner/chef is real sweet.  Know that he cooks all the food, so it will take awhile.  The first time I came here was for takeout; I was the only one there, and it still took awhile, so imagine how much longer it'll take with a few of the tables filled.  

Knowing that, the Indian food that is served is worth the wait.  And it's good and cheap--always a nice combination.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
Like this place needs another review...but wow. What the heck kind of Indian/Pakistani food have I been eating?

My friend strongly urged me to order the Chilean Sea Bass, which came on a sizzling platter. He had the lamb kebab also on a sizzling platter, and we shared some chicken tikka masala & palak paneer. The fish was hot, spicy, and mixed with vegetables. Super tasty & not greasy. EX-cellent.

The papadam came out fresh & hot (up until now, i have always had it cold), and they had potato naan, also fresh & hot. Mmmm...naan. A rare treat for me.

The complimentary chai was hot, flavorful and rich. Not like that watery drivel at Naan n' Curry.

From what I understand, one of the servers is a little quirky at times, but although he was busy, service was still good for a little divey place--though it was much cleaner than Shalimar. Just don't go expecting to get in & out quickly. Like another reviewer says: just enjoy the bollywood film playing--or the company you're with. It's part of the charm of the place.
author: N B.

description:
Well went here after getting the urge for some different Pakistani and to take some time to relax and eat.  This place is perfect if you want a leisurely meal and it's a pretty good deal as well.  It's run by a guy who is also pretty much the one man show.  The food was delish and the naan is really light and crisp.

The dishes are very tasty and the two I had were not greasy at all like at some other places.  Definitely a low key interior and it's sorta self serve (or at least that's what I did) so if you are up for something chill then check out Lahore!
author: Gene X.

description:
Oh jeez. So yummy. I went here on the recommendation of a lovely friend, and ordered some take out so my fiance could enjoy the nom-ness with me. It took about 20-25 minutes to get the order together, which is totally fine but just a heads up if you don't call in first. I ordered rice, regular naan, lamb biryani, chicken tikka masala, and some raita. The damage was $24. It smelled amazing and it was very difficult to resist eating right then and there, but I strapped the mess onto my bike and made my way home. I'm the most excellent fiancee ever. 
Holy indian food, it was SO.GOOD. The tikka masala was especially amazing. It had a smoky-sweet flavor that I haven't noticed in any other tikka masala I've ever eaten, and I wanted to eat it ALLLLL but I refrained. Also, hot damn this food is spicy! I'm so thankful I thought to ask for some raita. My poor little tongue was on fire, and yet I still plan on eating the leftovers for dinner tonight. In fact, if I get home before my fiance, I might be able to eat them all before he gets home, hahaHA! 
And that is why you should eat here. Because this food caused me physical pain, and yet I still want to eat it. Yum.
author: Steffany F.

description:
The owners remind you of 'Babu' from Sienfeld.. LOL. But they are very friendly. 

The food is absolutely amazing, even the veggie options. You can see them prepare everything from scratch in the kitchen so it probably takes slightly longer than say naan-n-curry but it tastes a lot fresher. And you can have it made as spicy as you like. 

The garlic naan was to die for.. we ordered just another naan after we finished eating. :)

The taste beats all the restaurants in the Tandoorloin and its probably the best Tandoori/Punjabi food I have had in the US so far.
author: Kaushal P.

description:
After all the positive reviews of this place, I decided to hit it up last night.  I was craving Butter Chicken and was so excited to try it after all the glowing comments.
Unfortunately, I was less than blown away.  The food was pretty good, but just that.  My boyfriend described it as "edible."  The Butter Chicken was very sweet, which was not what I was used to.  I liked that the sauce had little bits of nuts, however.  But, overall, it was a bit flavorless and nothing amazing.
The garlic naan was my least favorite part of the meal.  I like my naan with crispy bits, but this was all quite soggy and it tasted very sour.  
Lastly, we tried to order samosas and were offered Pakoras instead.  When I asked if we could just have samosas, he evaded acknowledging that they didn't have any.  No samosas?  At an Indian restaurant?  Weird.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Though I'm no major connoisseur of fine Indian / Pakistani food, this little place really has me hooked.  The overall ambiance of the restaurant is quite humble on average but can become somewhat chaotic when the restaurant starts filling up and customers may have to wait a few minutes for a table.  The service provided is what I feel on a more casual level where you may get your own drinks and the waiter will come by when it is more convent rather than quick.  Employees are friendly and helpful in ordering food and providing special requests for meals with no problems.   The meals may take a bit longer than most places, then I remember that it is being cooked with care and time rather than just throwing a bunch of already cooked items together.

The prices are certainly decent and the ability to bring a couple of brews down to enjoy with a nice spicy meal always makes for a good night.
author: Paige C.

description: This place was a gem! My boyfriend and I were desperate for Indian food and I believe this spot was the third one down from the list of Indian restaurants recommended by Yelp users. It was the only one with good reviews open on a Sun. The wait was a little long...but the food was absolutely delicious and worth the wait. We ordered the Chkn Kabob, Tandoori Chicken,  CHICKEN TIKKA MASALA, wth an order of Garlic Naan and a side of Basmati Rice. It was plenty for the two of us.The staff was friendly and the food was fresh....YUM! Definitely would visit again the next time I head out to SF. ^^
author: Kitty L.

description:
Overall - 3 Stars
Now I realize why they have a lot of take out orders.  The food was good, but not enough for me to wait there.  I would recommend take out unless you have a few hours to kill.

Location/Place - 3 Stars
Like most places in or near the TL it was kinda small.  It had tables that fit 2/4 or more if you combine them for larger groups.  No ventilation so it got kinda hot and stuffy especially from all tandoori dishes, but it looked clean.

Service - 2 Stars
So we got there before 7 on a Sunday.  The place wasn't full at all so we got seated but then had to get our own menus.  Our order was taken pretty quick after that but then the waiting game started.  It took almost an hour to get all our food and drinks and the place wasn't even busy.  They had a lot of take out orders though which might have explained why, but I can't imagine what the wait would be like it if was busier, but they were nice.

Food - 4 Stars
The samosa and pakora appetizers and mango lassi was pretty good.  Naan was really good along with my Sea-Bass Fish Tiki Masla.  My friend got the biryani dish with lamb, which I didn't care for.  It was too spicy and kind of dry.
author: Manohak S.

description: It pains me to say that they are under new owner/management and they not only have raised their prices to only slightly less than the SF going rate (with the same small entree sizes as before), but the food is also just mediocre at best. The lamb vindaloo was bland(!)--not even spicy--and the bindi (okra) masala was oily and soggy and they didn't even pick over the bindi to remove the woody, overripe ones, which I actually had to spit out. Pretty much the only reason I'm giving them 2 stars instead of 1 is that they kept their naan prices the same ($1 for plain; $2.50 for garlic) and they still have free chai. And you CAN still do worse in SF (read: Aslam's Rasoi). Also, it's now self-service a la Shalimar and Pakwan, with the food worse than Shalimar, but better than Pakwan. Oh, the sadness. This used to be my favorite South Asian place in SF but I guess I'll just go to Shalimar from now on.
author: Andrew I.

description:
Best Indian/Pakistani restaurant in SF.  Flavorful, spicy, fresh and not greasy. 

Don't believe me?  Try some of the other restaurants in the area and their food will pail in comparison.  We were forced to try a nearby restaurant when the owner of Lahore Karahi went on vacation earlier this year and we were sorely disappointed. 

We always order to-go, and our order is ready in less than 30 minutes.  I hear that service can be a bit slow when eating in the restaurant.
author: April W.

description:
Now this place rocks.  Chicker Cholay, Saag Gosht, Keema, and Karahi Chicken ... classic Paki dishes, done right.

And the best part about this place?  They read their Yelp comments.  Put some feedback in here, and they'll see it...
author: Omar S.

description: Completely underwhelmed. Three of us ordered 3 plain naans, 2 plates of rice, lamb curry, bengan bhartha (eggplant), and chicken tikka masala. The naan and rice were fine--you can't really go wrong with them. The curries however.... the chicken tikka masala is my staple, I always order it. This one had a peanut-y taste to it that did not taste like any other chicken tikka masala I've had (in a bad way). The lamb curry had a strange aftertaste...The bengan bhartha was bland, even though we ordered it spicy. The server was polite and cordial, but a little busy attending to everyone else in the restaurant. Eventually we got up and got our own water because we couldn't even get his attention to ask for water. $36 for three people. Not really worth it in my opinion. I'll probably never eat here again.
author: Kimberly S.

description:
This is my favorite Indian food.  Period.  It's just unfortunate that I live 500 miles south of there.  

A couple of weeks ago I was up in SF and asked a cabbie for an Indian food recommendation.  He took me to Lahore and at first I was skeptical.  The decore is on the dumpy side, they don't serve booze, and the prices seemed awfully low which makes me suspicious.  

I am forever grateful that I went anyways.  My typical meal for two at an India restaurant easily runs into three figures.  I went here with one of my biggest friends, we ordered a coupe apps and three entrees and our total tab was $40 bucks.  We feasted like kings.  

All of the food was delicious with the average entree in the $7 neighborhood.  And the no booze worked out great too.  There is a little store next door where we bought a few beers that we drank with our meal.  This alone probably saved us 15 bucks.  

Oh Lahore I long for you.  My one dining experience made me want to forsake my San Diego lifestyle for the Bay, if only so I could eat there weekly.
author: Douglas N.

description:
The food is amazing.  Really the best indian food I've had in the city.  The dishes are flavorful and thoughtful and (I'm told) very authentic.  They are interesting spins on what you'd find at any indian restaurant.

The one major downside is this place is way understaffed.  Given that its becoming really popular the dude really needs to hire some additional wait and kitchen staff.  Sometimes you go in and its literally one guy cooking and taking orders - it can be something of a cluster fuck.  But on the right day - its truly amazing!
author: Daniel H.

description:
5 Stars are not enough.

Quite possibly the best meal I've ever had, and I've eaten some amazing food internationally...

Long waits, but well worth it.  Sometimes you have to be patient for near perfection.  Every dish is made fresh and to order.  Bengan Bartha melts in your mouth, Butter chicken blows any Chicken Tikka Masala out of the water, and the onion kulcha is to-die-for...  Seriously cannot stress enough how AMAZING each dish is.  I don't even like lamb and it was pretty good here...

Please tip here because the kitchen is run by the owner, Guddu, 6 days a week.  He makes every dish you eat as well as the Naan and rice... 

My mouth is watering and my almost weekly visit might be early this week!!
author: metal m.

description:
I used to despise Indian food, after several really bad encounters with some other Indian restaurants. So when my friend Andrew said, "You don't understand, you have to try it." I reluctantly went. 

All I have to say is, "Wow, have you ever tasted love?" The food is so amazing and Guddhu (the owner and chef) is such a great person that my wife and I had our rehearsal dinner for our wedding here (Yes in the middle of the Tenderloin!!! Guddhu actually shut down his restaurant for us on a Saturday night!) If you're looking for the best Indian food in San Francisco and frankly a new home, then go to Lahore Karahi - where you'll be treated like part of the family. Yes you may have to wait a little while, but that's the idea... Guddhu likes you to slow down, hang around, talk with your friends, have a good time, enjoy your meal like your at home with family. 

And if you become a regular, I'd recommend getting to know Guddhu and Abdul personally, they're really great people! And thus is part of the charm of Lahore Karahi!!! And did I mention the food is amazing and very affordable!!!!! So what are you waiting for, go now before everyone discovers this wonderful place!!!
author: Christopher E.

description:
Lahore Karahi is that "little spot" you bring your new girlfriend or boyfriend to in the city to show off how you, too, know a quaint family- owned joint in the heart of the Tenderloin that only a true San Franciscan would know about. One time, I showed up with a group of friends for dinner. We decided we were to have a feast of epic proportions and after checking out the menu, we ordered whatever sounded good.  The waiter totally indulged us, making great recommendations on the menu and helping set up a SERIOUS spread of INEXPENSIVE food.  

Even though the wait for food can be a little long (I wouldn't recommend Lahore if you're in a rush, but definitely must after seeing a show at the Great American Music Hall) because of the two-man crew that runs the restaurant, you don't mind because you're either a) completely engrossed in the Bollywood movies playing on the tiny monitor in the corner of the restaurant or you're b) enjoying the view of a crack deal outside.    

Thumbs up for: Bengan Bartha, Butter Chicken, Garlic Naan, Aloo Saag.  Enough options for the meat lover AND the humble herbivore.

Pick up beer or wine from one of the liquor stores just outside.  And don't listen to the waiter when he gives you a hard time for refilling your own water.  Enjoy.
author: Heather R.

description:
There once was a place called Lahore,
But it was not a French Whore,
With Kebab-n-Curry,
Naan in a hurry,
You'd leave it screaming for More!

I agree with everything the two Mike P.s said. This place is awesome, read their reviews if the Limerick isn't convincing enough.
author: Dmitry S.

description:
I really like the food here and it offers stiff competition to Shalimar and other Indo-Pak restaurants in the Tenderloin.

Guddu is the manager and the chef and he pretty much cooks everything himself, which is a really nice touch. 

My favorites here are the chicken curry, daal and channa. I'd even say that I prefer eating their vegetarian food because frankly, the meat dishes aren't fabulous.

Downsides: Location, location, location (Tenderloin). Food can sometimes get way too spicy. And when you come out of the restaurant, it almost feels like you were barbequed inside a tandoor.
author: Aanand K.

description:
I'm salivating right now just thinking about those two beautiful words that come together at Lahore Karahi.....Butter Chicken. I'm usually a Tikka Masala kind of girl, but here, it's all about the Buuuutter Chicken. Seriously, get it!

Go down the street and pick up a beer for your dinner and call it a night. A long, delicious, buttery night.
author: Kara S.

description:
Just ousted Pakwan for best value Indian/Pakistani.  Higher quality, great service. 90% as good as Mehfil for about 60% the price - that's value.

Funniest thing about this place is when they ask you how spicy you want your food.

Waiter: Mild, Medium, or Spicy

Me: Spicy, please. 

Waiter: Medium is spicy.

Me: Ok, but I want the spicy option 

Waiter: Trust me, medium is spicy.  (translation: Listen whitey, we don't serve "spicy" to your kind 'round here)

WTF? "I'd like a large drink please". 
            "Sorry sir, medium is large"
author: Val U.

description: 4 people order food. More than an hour later no food had arrived. We asked why? Answer not forthcoming. Eventually one dish arrives. We politely ask if any utensils are available to consume it. Answer not forthcoming. One dish that arrived tasted really good (not a surprise.. we'd eaten here a ton of times before). By this point we were super hungry and a little tipsy as we'd been sipping beers from the honesty fridge on an empty stomach. Politely enquired why the kitchen had closed and we were still waiting. Shrug of shoulders and 'it would have been better to get take out like other people'. Incomprehension. A threat that we'd leave without paying for our one dish and beers fell on deaf ears so we grabbed some more honesty beers and walked out. Such a shame. This place used to be awesome. It seems now to be a rude, poorly functioning take out place.
author: Matt G.

description: A solid 4.5 stars which I will conveniently round up to 5. Myself and a friend ate here tonight. Lahore Karahi is a little hole in the wall restaurant which one would easily pass by and not give a second thought to. We settled on 2 dishes- the chicken vindaloo and the palak aloo, both of which were great! The vindaloo was rich and spicy. And the palak aloo was creamy and packed with flavor. Possibly the best spinach dish I have ever had. If all vegetarian dishes tasted this good, I could possibly be a vegetarian for a week or so. The service was a bit slow, about 30 minutes for us to receive our food, but the servers and cooks were hustling, as this place was packed at 9pm with a line out the door. Total price- $27 for two people- this included our 2 main entrees, rice, and 2 beers. How can you beat that?
author: David D.

description: No trip to sf is complete without a visit to Lahore.  This makes our 4th or 5th visit here in as many years.  Get there early, be patient and you will be rewarded.  Once you have a table grab an order pad, write up your order - don't forget to include the table #  - help yourself to a complimentary chai tea, grab utensils and plates for your party then sit back and wait.
author: dan m.

description: Good stuff here. The spicy is not too spicy and the flavors are great. A word of caution: your clothes will wreek of tandori when you leave this place.
author: Scott M.

description: Really good indian food for cheap. A group of 7 of us went and ordered a bunch of dishes and spent under $10 each including tax and tip. This place is also BYOB which is awesome. My favorite was the Lamb Vindaloo and the Chicken Korma.
author: Debbie C.

description:
Hey, we've been working our way around the City, eating Indian food every chance we get, and this is about as good as it gets! Chicken tikka flovorful and smooth, naan crispy-soft, chana masala so flavorful it knocks my socks off, and the rice, just one word; WOW! This isn't your subtle saffron rice, it's spicy and warm and when mixed with the chana masala, out of this freakin' world. And our bill came to 18.50. 
Jeez, we spend that on burritos and don't have any leftovers for another meal. 
This is a "will go to again and bring my friends" I've already told all my co-workers...
Thanks, Lahore for a lovely Valentine's Day lunch! Double yum!
author: Liz B.

description: Whatever you do, get the tandoori fish.  It's the most amazing dish I've had in a long time and the prices--for what you get--are stellar.  Customer service is also top notch with the owner taking part in everything from cooking to making sure everything is okay.
author: Jimmy C.

description:
A wise man once told me that the Tenderloin may become the next up-and-coming place in the next ten years, and I believe Lahore Karahi may be sending them in the right direction. I was recommended to come here by a culinary expert. She reported that this place has excellent food though not so great service, and she absolutely right. We ordered the usual Chicken Saag, Tikka Masala, and Roti. Delish! And get this: they are inexpensive!

I did notice that their health inspection grade card indicates they score only 78, which is alarming. For now, my stomach's saying "Who cares?  What's done is done."
author: Lily T.

description:
What a gem!  I think Lahore Karahi blows Shalimar, Naan 'n' Curry and other low-budget Indian joints out of the water.  Delicious and a screamin deal.

I went here with some friends and shared 4 entrees, the naan and rice.  All the dishes were good, and I was absolutely wowed by the Baingan Bhartha (eggplant curry).  I'll update after I come here with someone who will share a spicy dish with me.  I expect to continue raving about it!
author: David N.

description:
YUM!!!  This was some seriously tasty good food.  The dishes (at least the ones I had) all had their own flavor.  Not too strong or spicy, but very tasty.

We asked for spicy, and it was certainly that!  It wasn't blazingly hot, but it was well past the wimpy hot that you might get that won't burn the tourists' tongues.

Oh, and a great value!!
author: masa s.

description:
This place is some of the best Indi/Pak food out there!  
Everything that comes out of their tiny kitchen is super fresh and exquisitely flavored.
Their secret?  Everything that comes out of Gudu's kitchen is made with pure LOVE.
author: claire l.

description:
My favourite, favourite, repeat FAVOURITE Pakistani/Indian food joint in the city.

Specialties include their tandoori, and seafood (though I wasn't personally too impressed with it - I guess it's hard to impress a Cantonese food connoisseur with seafood dishes from other cuisines), their impressive selection of curries (vegetarian or lamb, avoid the chicken).

The ingredients are fresh, every dish is served piping hot (spicy, too!) and cooked personally by the chef - you can tell he puts his real heart into his cooking.  We get on great with Guddu and Abdul too - guess we kinda stick out because I've never seen any other East Asians eat in their restaurant....

They once let us try their kulfi (ice-cream), and now, we always go there for dessert every time after we have dinner in the area...  chai with kheer and kulfi...  mmmmmm....
author: Haywood H.

description:
You've heard of or experienced an emotional roller coaster, well how about an intestinal roller coaster?
Ordered some takeout, didn't specify the spiciness,  but this stuff was rocket fuel (as this is coming from a manly man who crushes rocks in his hands :) )
The prices are some of the best I've seen, $1 for a Naan, (it's like 2.50? at Little Delhi, another yelp fave)
With prices this low, what does your avg red neck peckerwood American do? over order!, and this city snob is no exception
Seek Kabab looked like hand rolled sh!t on a stick, 2 yelps one cup style, very spicy but tasty
Naan was good
Chicken Tikka Masala was a bit darker and random looking that what I'm used to with dark stuff interspersed throughout, perhaps some of the stains on the walls/floors/counters/windows fell off during food prep
The whole takeout order came in under $14
Decor, there was a nice dark shade of grease-stained plywood that complemented the smoke filled box
Staff was ethnic, but not Indian, rather Hispanic
Location? I think Kurt Russell was filming Escape from the 'Loin, do not wear open toed shoes, do not converse with the surrounding residents, check yourself and clothing for infestation before returning home

Needless to say, excessive food consumption, plus through and through spicy food can lead to dire consequences, as in the opener of this review alludes.

Bottom line, food was decent and cheap, location is semi-convenient, but surrounding hood is the pits.
author: G K.

description: I did come back and had to give it one more star for the DIVINE chicken tikka masala they have! It's my favorite Indian dish and I have had it many times, but never the sauce had been so creamy, really tying the dish together, like this one! I already got it twice this week. It's definitely a new love! :-)
author: Simone W.

description:
My wife and I wanted some good Asian food (Indian, Pakistani) and we read the great reviews on yelp.

The food was REALLY good and REALLY cheap.  Thanks yelpers for the hint about BYOB.  Bought a beer right across the street (as recommended) and that made it more fun for me in some strange way.

We got chicken vandaloo, saag paneer (the waiter told us that the cheese is made fresh on the premises), rice, naan, and samosas.  We watched the smiling chef in the open kitchen actually making our vegetable samosas which came out all hot and crispy on the outside and all mashy on the inside.  Dude gave us our tamarind sauce and the other one in squirt bottles.  As a condiment freak this scores major points.

Food came out in bowls that must have been bought at Wal-Mart.  They made me feel like I was eating at a friend's house.  This tugs at my "hard-core, authentico" heartstrings.  

Bill was $25.  Did one of the other yelpers say that they only take cash?    LIES!!  LIES!!!
author: Joel K.

description:
I'm sorry I yelped this place.

I've been going here for years, and it used to be sparsely populated with real live indian people.  Now its full of hipsters with their annoying children.  I blame the yelp effect.  I went last night and I was with the only indian client in the joint; the rest was a multicultural rainbow of obnoxious yuppies.

Still 5 stars, great cheap food, but god damn.... annoying clientele.
author: Anthony L.

description:
Alright, so what the place lacks in ambiance it definitely makes up for in delicious food.  Have you seen Ratatouille, the movie with the cute little rat that makes you question why you always hated rats so much and then you realize its just a cartoon and that you still hate rats? Well, Lahore is exactly like that - an explosion of flavors.  Their curry's are amazing and the garlic naan, well lets just say you should definitely order at least one per person.  The only draw back is that they tend to serve the curry dishes before the rice, which is actually pretty damn annoying. (Imagine finishing half of your curry before you have any rice!) Nonetheless, this place has amazing food and I doubt there are any better Pakistani curry venues in the city.

Oh and I would recommend ordering:

Tikka Masala
Lamb vindaloo
Saag paneer
Bengan baarta
garlic naan
rice

In regards to size portioning: One curry entry per person, one garlic naan per person and get two rice orders if you have over 3 people.
author: E-dough R.

description:
Crushed pistachios on top of buttered chicken, yum.  I have a method to trying out a new restaurant.  I order a very basic dish and see how they make it.  If they fail at a basic dish I don't go back.  Lahore Karahi makes great buttered chicken!

I'll definitely be going back here.
author: Josh V.

description:
Mmm, curry and lots of it. If you order your food spicy, be prepared for food that is actually spicy. I LOVE their lamb vindaloo. Too often you'll get something that is a pot of really spicy meat, but not a lot of flavor. Somehow they get the burn to be a little delayed so you can actually taste the really yummy spices before having to douse your mouth in water. ;)

The service can be a bit slow when they are busy as people have mentioned, but the whole staff is very friendly and conversational. Definitely worth wading through the loin!
author: Rebecca S.

description:
Comparable to the other two joints in the Tender-nob. Not my fave, but it has its strengths.

The area that Lahore shines in is the kebab. It came out on a sizzling plate and was juicy, tasty, and simply surpasses the kebabs from Chutney and Shalimar in every aspect.

Saag paneer had way too much cilantro in it. For those who love cilantro, then great, but I HATE cilantro, so it was a little overwhelming. Overall, I found the curry dishes to be slightly below that of Chutney and Shalimar. 

I do like how they give you papadams when you order.

One thing that I'm not as big of a fan about is how this places seems to be more of a sit down/waiter service kinda place. I really like the concept of Chutney and Shalimar where you order at the counter (instead of having a waiter take your order here). I don't mind tipping since I tip at the other places too, but I feel more obliged to tip more here just because they come by and take my order instead of me ordering at the counter.

Prices are similar to the other two, so its still a good deal.
author: Rocky K.

description: very good food but rude service (if the guy with a beard is there)
author: Khurram M.

description:
THE LONGEST WAIT EVER FOR FOOD!

my friends and i went here last night hoping to get fed quickly.  we waited 1 hour before our food arrived.  

the naan was the best i've had so far, all the other dishes were good, i have to give them at least 2 stars for that.

will i come back here again?  not very likely.  i understand having to wait for my food, but 1 hour is TOO LONG.  the food might be good, but it's not worth the wait.  i'll have my indian food fix somewhere else and be just as satisfied.
author: Almira C.

description:
Cockroaches and terribly run. You have to understand that I loved this place but my experience last night was the worst, enough to make me get up and leave.

Started with a long wait, which I didn't care.  Twenty minutes.  Then it took twenty minutes to get seated bc the two waiters had no idea what they were doing by not clearing tables off. Then it took another twenty to put in our order.  We went and got our own water and forks since the waiter was clearly to busy to serve us.  As we waited for our food, we watched some cockroaches crawl around on the wall and the server wipe all the crud off the table onto his hand and then grab a bunch of plates and utensils  for table without washing  them.  I remembered how much I liked the food here so I decided to be ignorant and justify it by saying even high end places prob have roaches and dirty servers.  

After forty minutes and several people who ordered after us received their dishes, we got our first dish  which was saag paneer.  Shortly  after we got our lamb korma.  Yet we didn't have dishes.  These are both dishes that you easy with rice or naan which we ordered but went to the tables that ordered after us.  At this point I was fuming.  An hour and forty minutes had gone by after ordering and only half our order had come out.  It was like getting a burger without the bun, no plate and trying to flag down the waiter to get the bacon, bun and lettuce and tomato.  Am hour and forty minutes went by since arriving.  

After sitting there and being ignored I decided I had had enough and got up and left without waiting for the rest of the food. I did not feel bad doing this.  It's actually the first times I've ever done it. Makes me sad bc the food is fantastic.  I wish the other yelpers who had the same experience would do the same so they would clean up their act and the gross restaurant.
author: shar d.

description:
I *really* *really* *really* wanted to like this place. I like spots like this, that are total whole in the wall, greasy spoon type places.. The food should have been much better tasting. I thought the Chicken Biryani was dry and tasteless. I ordered 2 other curries, the Butter Chicken and the Lamb Vanadloo. Both were good. Nothing to write home about, but good.

I was very hopeful when after placing my order the waiter turned and asked, do you want that mild or spicy? I immediately responded excitedly.. "SPICY." When the food came, everything was  about as spice-less as possible.

I've been in a 3 Star rut of trying new spots lately, I checked the reviews well on this one and had high-hopes. Unfortunately, maybe I got them on a bad day.

The Naan's were smaller than I'm used to but had a much more home made-taste to them. The Onion Naan, actually had a good amount of decent sized chucks of onion cooked in the middle of the bread. Big plus for any Onion Lovers..

No Beer or Wine either..
author: Paul V.

description:
My girlfriend and I were visiting San Francisco and Napa last week on vacation and had a major craving for something spicy.  Lahore Karahi was a short walk from our Union Square area hotel so we set out on Thursday night.  The food was awesome!  It was better than almost all Indian food I've had living in NYC for 10 years.  We had aloo gobi (amazing with almost caramalized onions), chicken tikka masala (nicely spiced, more earthy and less spicy than all other tikka masalas I've had), and naan (warning, regular naan here comes with butter, be sure to ask for no butter if you are expecting plain naan).  

This place filled up on a Thursday night, so come early or expect to wait. My only complaint was it was really smoky from the grill and we left smelling of smoke all night.  I wish this placed existed in NYC and I'd be there once a week.
author: Megan H.

description:
This place is the essence of the outer-Tenderloin. It's got the kind of authentic, cheap, exotic food for food's sake that restaurants charging twice as much can't even begin to conjure. The decor is bland and you'll have to put in a real wait for the food, but Lahore always delivers on rich, textured tastes which make you wonder if some of the crack from the streets has made it into the food. The vegetarian options here are also the absolute best I've had in SF. 

I second some of these other reviews - my favorite experience of this place is to order for take-away and show up a the end of the 20-25 minute time frame the chef gives you. Take home and enjoy. This place won't make 5 stars for me until it improves the decor enough that I can be comfortable sitting in there with a first date through the made-to-order wait. 

Favorite dishes are: Chicken Korma, Lamb Vindaloo, Lahori Chikkan Choley (garbanzo beans in yellow-tomato curry), and my favorite: the Bengan Bharta - it's a sweet roasted eggplant mixed with other richer spices which is a major mind-blower every time. All these go great with the cinnamon-infused basmati rice which can be eaten as a stand-alone (very tasty, light rice). 

I know this place is a winner because my friends will often visit me in the tenderloin just to get some Lahore Karahi and indulge in my living room. As if I'm not exciting enough on my own!
author: Matt T.

description:
4 solid stars.

The neighborhood and decor are nothing to write home about, but if you're looking for quality food at the fairest prices, I would recommend this place. The service was quick enough, and they actually responded to my request for spicy!
author: Basil B.

description: Lahore Karahi is my favorite Indian/Pakistani restaurant in San Francisco. It is always delicious and very consistent in its flavor. My personal favorite dishes are the Chicken Tikka Masala and the Karahi Chicken. Both go well with rice and naan.
author: Colin C.

description:
Lamb curry is quite possibly the best in the City (wonderfully soft meat, perfectly pungent sauce). Tandoori fish is also a treat (if not somewhat pricey for the 'Loin), as is the Chicken Karahi.

The wait, however, is the reason this place does not get 5 stars. With an unwavering insistence on keeping the cookstaff at one person (the owner), Lahore Karahi will make you wait for some time before you eat.
author: Zubair J.

description:
Oh hell yeah this place is good. 

I've been crazed about Indian food recently and I just remembered why: Lahore Karahi.

Delicious, affordable, and they play ridiculously funny Bollywood movies. What more can you ask for?
author: Nick H.

description: I would love to give this little guy a 4 star, and I would if it weren't for the lack of soap in the bathrooms and the cockroaches of various sizes.  The food, good, the cockroaches... not too much. I'm surprised that more people haven't mentioned this. We had already ordered when I went to the bathroom to wash my hands and was greeted by a roach on the doorknob, and again, welcomed into the bathroom by many more. I would probably order again but would get it to go whereas I was afraid the roach on the wall by our table was going to crawl into my purse and bring home a problem of our very own.
author: courtney l.

description:
So many people and so many Yelp reviews told me this place was good, and I was so sadly disappointed when trying to dine here one evening while in the TL.

We went in around 7:30, and the place was packed and the food smelled good.  Indicative of good things, right?  Yeah, definitely not.  After waiting for 25 minutes for a table, putting our order in about 10 minutes before we were seated, we were stuck at our table for about 45 minutes without any food.  C'mon, it does not take long to fry up a Samosa.  I know they don't make those to order, no Indian restaurant does.

After the first roach crawled by, we decided it was time to leave.  If there's one thing I dislike more than bad Indian food, it's cockroaches.

To be fair, I didn't exactly get to taste the food.  Maybe it's delish.  But there's no way I'm braving the roaches to go back and find out.
author: Ambika C.

description:
The best Indian/Pakistani food I've had since I've been in San Francisco, hands down! This place is a real dive to eaters be warned: This place can appear to be...a little dirty. But their food is clean and they are always busy. The Tika Masala is probably what put them on the map. Spicy, creamy, and packed with flavor. And if you don't like it too spicy, just let the guy know, and he'll make you a mild batch, but where would the fun be in that? 

Pros: 
Authentic, delicious, and spicy pakistani/indian food. Very friendly owner/chef, cheap.

Cons: 
Small place--if you show up later in the evening you'll have to wait a while for a table, or share one with another couple or something. Can appear a little dirty, but it's worth it. Can get a little hectic when they are really busy.
author: John H.

description:
Worth the wait, and there will be one because this is pretty much a one man affair with occasional busboy/runner help.

The chef-owner, Guddu, has a big heart and this is evident in his food.  He will always have an off-menu suggestion worth a go.  I usually go as part of a four-to-six person group from work including two Indian nationals who rate this as #1 in the Bay Area.  Never had a bad dish of anything but the Saag Gosht (spinach & lamb) and tandoori fish dishes are just to die for.
author: David P.

description:
The first time I came here I thought it was pretty good. Then we came a second time and it was medicore. The rice was super dry, the nann burnt, and the food not as spicy as the first time. 

I decided to give Lahore Karahi a third try just to even the playing field. Same as the second time. 2 stars for the service, which is very good.
author: Erin D.

description: Probably the best Pakistani/Indian restaurant in the Bay. The fish is amazing!
author: Zeenat U.

description:
Random facts about Lahore Karahi:

* It takes a lot of work to fill the $15 minimum for credit card payments. One entree, rice and naan will go for $11. And, trust me, that is a lot of food already.

* There's that In Rainbows poster by the balcony, although they only play generic indian music.

* It's only a matter of time until someone gets a third-degree burn while washing the hands in the crazy hot water coming from the restroom sink. In fact that might be your ticket for free chicken tikka masala galore.

* It's officially recognized as the good indian restaurant with weird name. People will refer to it as Lakoriharari, Kahori Lakari, and others.
author: Pedro B.

description: At 9:15 pm, I had to wait 30 mins for the food.  I was by myself and ordered only a fish dish.  They should hire more people.
author: Victor H.

description:
This place is cheap, which it should be given the location.  the palak paneer was actually quite tasty, creamy and unusually sweet.  the pakora also had a nice batter and veggie mixture.

the nan was below average, and the paneer masala sauce had a very unusual flavor, very sweet.  there were also pieces of CHICKEN in my vegetarian dish, and even the chef acted like he didn't know how that happened.  uhm, you didn't wash the pan and/or change the sauce when you prepared my meal.  no apology, and very poor service.  come on indian rest are one of the few places that tend to really respect vegetarianism.
author: Carla K.

description:
DO NOT GO HERE. its mine... ALL MINE!

about two months ago i was walking to chutneys to satisfy some serious curry cravings, and on the way, i passed by lahore karahi. the place looked unassuming and hole-in-the-wall-y, but was lively and packed. i thought to myself, 'man i gotta check this place out.'

the other day i finally went for a late lunch and, i shit you not, as far as indian food goes, it was so F*ing good that i wanted to go to the bathroom to jerk off. my man guddhu is a genius, does all the cooking himself, and god can the make some serious food. sex on my tongue type of stuff. no, there arent any real suprises on the menu, its all pretty normal indian fare... but better...fresher... tastier. 

the place was empty when i went since it was right between lunch and dinner and guddhu came out from behind the counter to check up on us. my friend and i ordered a lot of food and i ate every single bite. i was so full that i wanted to puke, but figured if i did, then id have room in my stomach for another round of food.... so i headed for the bathroom.
author: N. B. K.

description:
The Whore is quite good. tastes good, too.

+Nice atmosphere, it feels like what I would imagine (from all the splendidly accurate american action movies I have seen)  a typical neighborhood Indian/Pakistani(same country, am i rite?) eatery might feel like. 
+Its casual but clean, a bit understaffed in the off hours but makes up for it in preparation. 
+Bob Barker...the price is riteeee, am i rite?  naan is a dollar, meals are from 5 to 10 bucks...you cant go wrong unless you're retarded
+BYOB... its fun to do if you're  a big fat yuppie
+The food is remarkably tasty, very hot, nice flavors, feels home made but with love...top notch all the way...the simplicity of the meals speaks to their quality.
+Yes the guy who works here looks sort of like a muppet but he is very genuine, nice, and cares about making a good meal happen..this shows in every aspect of the service.

-DIARRHEA OH MY GOD STOP USING GHEEEEE (this last point refers only to those with Irish/English/Scottish heritage)...seriously though it felt like a firehose was shooting out of my ass...nobody told me about the free post-meal enema.  This is the major drawback for me keeping it from getting five stars.  If your'e weak in the stomach don't get anything oily and eat plenty of naan to soak up the juices.  


Summary:  It turns out to be worth wading through the urine, crackheads, and one legged pigeons to find this diamond in the rough (which is actually a cubit zirconium...just as good but half the price lolz)  Just be prepared to take a magic carpet ride to the bathroom about 34 minutes after you put down your fork.
author: Frank S.

description: Thanks Miriam W. for introducing this place!  I dream about their tandoori fish.
author: Paul M.

description:
The best Indian food I've had - I'll admit, I'm not an Indian food expert, but everyone I've taken here LOVES the food.

I'm sure others have commented on the ambiance on this place, but please know that this isn't probably the best place for a 1st date if you're looking to get laid based on the quality of the restaurant's decor.  It really has a hole-in-the-wall feel and the place could use a lot of touch up, but everyone comes here for the food.

I love the potatoe naan (aloo paratha) and everything else that I've ordered was orgasmic - tandoori fish,  chicken/fish tikka, etc.

The service isn't the best, but the owner (and chef) is friendly and means well.  His picture is on the restaurant's website in case you wanna know what he looks like.  Definitely worth risking your life walking through the Loin.
author: Michael P.

description:
Absolutely scrumptious.  

Funny that it's BYOB... bring your own opener in case the waiter has religious reasons for not wanting to open it for you.  

Can't wait to go again.
author: Angela T.

description:
Ok ! I think I've found what I've been looking for. 

For those who are less familiar with Indian/Pakistani food, there is a real difference between Indian and Pakistani food. I've been to a few Indian restaurants masquerading as Pakistani and Lahore Karahi is not one of them.

Taste: Very flavorful. I highly recommend the Chicken Karahi. It's the best Karahi I've had.

Spice: It is extremely hot so if your not into spicy food you can consider yourself warned

Value: I ordered the chicken biryani, chicken korma, chicken karahi, lamb vindaloo and two naans = $33.50 

Ladies and gentlemen of Yelp....It doesn't get cheaper than this and the food can easily serve 4. 

I noticed that some reviewers complained of the slow service..but hey..at these prices..you cannot expect a Ritz Carlton. It's a hole in the wall and I would gladly wait an extra 10-15 mins.
author: manoj r.

description:
Lahore Karahi...great Indian food! Probably some of the best I've had. Good enough to return?! No way in hell. Maybe if I order to go or something. Looks like Brad L. beat me to the review! Damn that Yelper Elite!!!

We were sat at what the waiter called a "special table" he arranged just for us. Did it come with an invisible cloaking device b/c once he sat us, he forgot about us for 40 minutes. YEAH! 40 minutes. Other tables that were sat AFTER us got their orders taken and their food served before our order was even taken. Come on now! Every time we flagged down our waiter, he averted his eye contact. One person in our party actually went TO the counter to give him our order, and once she was done, his question to her was... (get this!) "Is your order for here or to go?" *Puzzled look* You're kidding right? I can understand the restaurant was packed, but there are only about 8 tables. So what gives?

The mango lassi was definitely the worst I've ever had in my life. Once sip and I tossed it aside.

The only reason this place is getting 2 stars is that the food was excellent. Just the right amount of spice, heat, and meat in each dish. We had a group of 5 and ordered Butter Chicken, which was almost the exact same dish as the chicken tikki masala we ordered! Lamb Vindaloo, Tandoori Fish, Garlic Naan, Vegetable Biryhani, and Eggplant something or other. Out of everything the Eggplant was by far the best! Yummerz!

2 Yummerz stars for this place..and I'm hesitant for even THAT!
author: Ann T.

description:
I've been here exactly once. And I'm hooked.

I stopped by for their Vegetable Wrap (to go), on my way home from work. Incredibly delicious begins to describe it. 

The staff is smiley and friendly.
And, my wrap was only $5. Have I died and gone to heaven?? Oh, wait no, we're still in the Tenderloin, sorry.
author: Chadwick M.

description: I saw a coupon on restaurant.com and confirmed with the manager at Lahore Karahi that they accepted it before purchasing it.  I then came the next night with my hubby looking forward to a nice dinner.  The owner sent over a waiter to tell us that they no longer accept those coupons. I told him about my conversation the day before and he replied "I'm sorry". We simply got up and walked out. I am not going to eat at a restaurant that sleazily attracts customers under false pretenses to them. I'm predicting that your restaurant will not do well under your bad practices.
author: C L.

description:
Now I am not an expert in Indian or Pakistani (Punjab? see?!)  cuisine by any means.  I have been to enough to know what the dishes are and how they are prepared.

This place is the bomb.  

We ended up here last night after a long bike ride and I KNOW not to come here on a Friday night at  8pm, but I hadn't been here in awhile and it's worth the wait.

When I tell them to make it spicy they make it proper spicy.

Only one guy doing bussing/waiting/to-go orders/ taking names/ expediting food is absolutely ridiculous on a busy night but it it SO worth the wait, just sit back and byob!
author: Michael L.

description:
Did not have a good experience here.  Yelp, you let me down this time.  

Vegetable pakora was almost all breading.  Naan had a strange, almost toothpaste-like flavor to it.  It also had patches of charred, crunchy (not in a good way) remnants from the grill on it.  Makes me wonder if they ever scrape the grill.  Chicken tikka tasted bland.  Chutneys were watery.  

You can see the kitchen clearly from the counter.  It's definitely not clean.  Service was almost non-existent.  

Maybe I arrived on an off night.  On the bright side, the prices are cheap....back on the dark side, maybe it's cheap for a reason.
author: Tom J.

description: I enjoyed my meal here. Lunch on a Tuesday around noon and no one else here, but the cook made everything fresh and was friendly. Reasonable price.  A nice alternative to the jam-packed Indian places downtown for a mid-week lunch.  And just outside of the real trouble-zone  portion of the tenderloin so no smack addicts to navigate around.
author: Marc S.

description: I think the saag paneer and chicken korma is pretty good.  The Butter Chicken and tandoori fish and bengan bartha is also quite good.  The Saag Ghost was the most tender lamb I ever had, the sauce was a little salty.  Chicken tika masala was delicious albeit a little oily.  The garlic naan was freshly baked and tasted very good.  I had the takeout so didn't have to wait.  Just call to make sure your order is ready before going to pick up since the guy told me 15 mins and it turns out to be 1 hour!
author: Jim J.

description: Spicy for the sake of being spicy - excessive. Potentially good food that one can't eat. Sub-optimal hygiene in the dining room and kitchen. Abysmal speed of service.
author: noflaps c.

description:
I guess 210 people already said this place was great. I also think it's great. Everything is super-cheap, and the butter chicken is very tasty. Next time, I'll try the biryani -- looked good.

Wow, this is a really boring review. I'll add that this is a good place to go if you're eating in this neighborhood on a Monday night. Tons of other places were closed. And it's near the Great American Music Hall.
author: Ellie P.

description:
Darlings, you must trust me as I am an Indian food snob. 
If your are looking for proper North Indian heat and spice, by all means necessary, come and gorge here.  They take a while to prepare your food, but what do you expect with one guy preparing your food from scratch???  Take someone you need to catch up with or come to be amused by the old Bollywood blaring from the TV.  It's nothing like the Americanized majority that is available around the city.  Veg or non-veg...try everything.  It's quite cheap too.
author: Jessi B.

description:
4.25 stars.

I have a serious issue with Lahore Karahi. I ate dinner here on my first night in San Francisco, a foodie city I have dreamed of visiting, and wanted to do nothing but return for dinner each subsequent night. It didn't matter that thousands of other places were waiting to change the way I think about food, I wanted Lahore's casual, lovingly prepared bowls of goodness! Guddu, I am holding you personally responsible.

The tandoori fish is incredible. Truly, this beautifully presented dish of spice-crusted butter fish is something special. The hot chai (deeper and more intense than I expected), chicken tikka masala, cheese naan, and paneer tikka were also memorable: comforting, perfectly spiced, and cleanly flavored. I also enjoyed the lamb saag, but wanted something a bit spicier. Still, I absolutely can't wait to return.
author: Brianne C.

description:
Immaculately clean.
Smiley owner who cooks everything himself...Get ready to wait!
5 or 6 paneer dishes, mmmmmm, paneeeer.
Cheap.
author: Melanie C.

description:
More like 4.5, but I'll bump it up to 5 because of the attention that the chef and our waiter gave us, asking if our meals were tasty. All the raving of the buttered chicken was overhyped, but I think the lamb korma was delicious. Also, the cilantro potato naan was pizza-like, and also delicious. Furthermore, our mango lassi's were great.

Update: 8/26/2007

Earlier this year I went back and I thought everything about our meal was divine, from the thin-pizza like naan and the sweet butter chicken which meshed well with the beer we brought in. Hopefully the wait times improve, but overall one of the best Indian/Pakistani places in SF.
author: Anthony K.

description:
Just when I was on a 4-5 star roll....

I dunno what all the hoopla's really about.

My roommate and I trekked all the way down to the Tenderloin since we were both craving Indian food, however we weren't super blown away by our average dining experience.

We ordered the Chicken Tikka Masala, Vegetable Samosas, Naan (plain & garlic), Mango Lassis, Basmati rice, and Aloo Gobhi (cauliflower & potato). So, figuring that there was a long wait for the ppl behind us, we were thinking... this place must be THAT good. However, everything was satisfying, but unfortunately wasn't mind blowingly good. Everything seemed to have sauces with more of a sweet base, even their Basmati rice which had cinnamon sprinkled on it. A bit odd when you're looking for something w/ lots of spice. Their Mango Lassis though were just to my liking. Not loaded w/ sugar, it made a perfect addition to the meal. I even bypassed the opportunity to pop open a few bottles of wine just to enjoy the Mango Lassi that much more!

Despite the so-so food, our server was pretty entertaining. When my friend asked if the mango drinks were freshly made, he lowered his eyes, stared right at her and gave her "The look". Like: "Are you kidding me?? Of course." Both him and the owner seem like genuinely nice guys that are passionate & proud about their food.

If I'm in the area I'll give it another shot (i didn't get to try their specialty, Tandoori Fish!), but I won't be going out of my way.
author: Tiffany M.

description:
Wow.  This place is amazing.

First of all, it is the best Indian Food in the city.  The meat is very good, always perfectly cooked, very tender and delicious.  Every dish I have tried has been incredible, and made it hard at times to eat indian food anywhere else.  The samosas are just right, served very hot, with a beautiful flaky crust and very good chutney and julep on the table in big squeeze tubes.

Another thing I love about Lahore Karahi is the atmosphere.  This is a perfect place to come with a medium sized group of friends.  It's BYOB, and after a short wait you can usually take over the larger tables in the middle of the restaurant.  Because the entrees are so cheap, you can get a big variety of dishes and pass everything around.  It's hard to beat for dinner with friends, the kitchen is open and it's always fun and lively inside the restaurant.

While Lahore Karahi appears to be a typical funky Indian joint, there is nothing funky about the food.  It is nothing short of top notch.  The guys who work here are very sweet too, and you can tell they enjoy their job and take pride in their cuisine.  I can't believe it took me so long to find this place, it is one of my favorite restaurants anywhere.
author: Adrian L.

description:
This is a little place on a not-too-desirable stretch of O'Farrell.  It offers all your standard Indian fare, and does a not-bad job of it.  There's nothing particularly unique or special about it, but for the price they charge, the food is satisfying.  No Alcohol service.  

And, they have the  little TV in the corner looping Indian dance numbers.  How could you go wrong?
author: K. B.

description:
First of all I've been wanting to try this place forever and something always comes up for some reason or another. Went with some friends on a cold and crisp Sunday twilight session and let one person do the ordering since she is somewhat of a regular. We got the Papadam appetizer to start. Everything here is made to order here mind you. Paper thin and served with a buttermilk sauce and also a sweet plum sauce if my taste buds serve me right. 

Next up was the cheese Naan which was super tasty I must say. For our entrees we ordered Spicy Chicken Boti, Lamb Boti and Bengan Bhartiia   all savory and mighty proper! Also we got Lahore Karachi Rice which   was amazingly spiced and flavorful. Nom nom nom nom nom... For desert we tried the Gulab Jaman which are deep fried dough balls dipped in a honey like concoction pretty good but I think I'll try something else next time. Had a little Chi to wash it down also. The service was decent and the owner/chef bid us farewell from the kitchen as we left. This place has comfy mellow feel to it and is TOPZ in my book. I'll be taking some other friends here very soon if I have my say.

Oh yeah white rice ='s boring people fyi... Chowmerz..
author: Timbo G.

description:
Awesome! The nans were the best I've ever had, so soft and fluffy. The curries were at just the right level of spiciness (I don't have much tolerance for hot food). My friends were very impressed even though the shabby exterior of this place made a pretty poor first impression.

We seemed to be one of the only two tables in use for at dinner time on Sunday. The waiter was funny, and took good care of us. A little too much care you could say, I felt he confused us for his long lost children. He was very accomodating and willing to make changes to the menu for us (e.g. gave us an extra samosa so we could share easily, and offered raita on the house even though it wasn't on the menu). He was a bit forgetful though, as he eventually forgot all about the raita after twice telling me " *wink wink* don't worry about it ". I don't mind, the experience was great.

Oh and this place is REALLY that inexpensive. Just unbelievable. Enjoy it while it lasts.
author: Aman B.

description:
The only reason I'm giving this place two stars is that the service was bad enough to be comical.

I don't know that I can fully elucidate the incompetence of the two guys who were supposedly there to take our order and bring us our food.  It was like the Keystone Kops decided to give up police work in favor of waiting tables.

45 minutes or so after ordering, my ravenous friends and I watched as they took our food to every table in the place one by one, asking the people seated at each if they had ordered it.  Before completing their circuitous trip to our table and rendering unto Caesar, they took everything back to the kitchen and looked through their pile of order slips frantically.  This was only the beginning.

The food is enough like Shalimar that I don't feel the need to return.
author: Ficus K.

description:
With the high average rating for this place, I had high expectations. Unfortunately it under-delivered, primarily because of the service. 

There were only two men working there -- the manager (maybe owner?) and the chef/busboy. So we found ourselves refilling our own glasses of water and walking up to the counter when we wanted to check in on our order. Our dinner ended up taking twice as long as we anticipated since they could only cook so fast. With the popularity of this place, they should consider hiring more help. 

Service aside, the food was pretty outstanding. My Indian food staple is Chicken Tikka Masala and Lahore's was unlike any I've ever had -- deliciously creamy and buttery. There was just enough spice to tingle my tongue and not too much to make it unpleasant. 

Overall, I recommend ordering takeout here since you can wait in the comfort of your own home. Or if you eat here, be ready to wait on yourself and most of all... be patient.
author: eileen b.

description:
Cheap and good. The man behind the counter does take his time, but if you have time, aren't too hungry when you walk in, it's well worth it, especially on a cold day in the city. It's very cozy inside.

And it's all good.
author: elaine m.

description: Went here for lunch recently after some recommendations by friends. The food was good quality and tasty. I ordered the Seekh kabab (came steaming hot on a grill plate and was one of the best I have had), also the Karahi Chicken which was pretty good and garlic naan (tasty, but thinner and smaller than most other Desi restaurant naans). The chai was very good too. The service was a little slow (but since it was lunch time rush with a lot of people I understand why). The interior of the restaurant is small and a little cramped when full, so not good for large groups. The restrooms are small and dirty. Typical for most hole in the wall desi places- great food, but lacking in ambiance.  Halal meat is served here.
author: Irfan R.

description: Love this place.  Great tikka masala.  The service is hit or miss but the food makes it worth it.
author: Annabelle K.

description: I expected a lot more.  The masala sauce was decent, but the attention to detail was not there.  The naan was dry and hard like a cracker or stale bread.  Although the chicken used for tikka masala was at once point cooked on tandoori style, it was not fresh, and literally pulled from a large plastic bucket kept in the refrigerator, which deprived the chicken of flavor and moistness.  The cook also works the register and seems put out.
author: Henry J.

description:
The best Indian/Pakistani cuisine in SF, hands down.
Some tips:
Expect an excruciating wait.  
Bring your own beer, and they're happy to keep it cold for you.
Don't get up and help yourself to water - the waiter gets mad.
Order the black daal.  And the butter chicken.  And the lamb korma.  Skip the appetizers.
author: Pamela D.

description:
For those living in the "TL" Lahore Karahi is the only Indian restaurant that cooks their food fresh. The chef cooks it for you as ordered, somethings are prep...as they are in other restaurants...but no other restaurant in the "TL" compares to the freshness. Sanitation may be a problem there, but the food quality makes up for it. 

Anyone in the "TL" that puts down Lahore Karahi hasn't been to the bad Indian restaurants that are around....this is the best your going to get in the "TL"

Try the Garlis Naan, Tandoori Chicken!!!
author: Sepideh S.

description:
The place was 80% full at around 8:30pm when we showed up. The chef-owner greeted us warmly and pointed us at an open table.

We ordered Lamb Vinadloo, Bengan Bhartha, Tandoori Fish, 1 naan, and 1 onion kulcha. When asked if we want spicy, we said yes, please make it as spicy as you like it.

It took a while for us to get our food, but having read reports we were prepared for this. Thankfully we weren't starving so we didn't mind waiting. I picked up some beer from a nearby market and we drank and waited patiently.

The lamb arrived and was unlike any vindaloo we had ever had before. It was shreddy and succulent, immersed in a complex and delicious sauce. It was definitely spicy, but was also excellently spiced bursting with a plethora of flavors.

The bengan bhartha was extremely spicy. Easily the spiciest dish of the night. We were both happy and impressed with the level of spicyness. It's nice to find a place that's not afraid to bring the real heat. The dish was also quite tender and tastey.

The naan was great. Hot out of the tandoor in all its crispy-chewy glory. The onion kulcha tasted good, too, but I thought it could have used a bit more onion.

Lastly, the tandoori fish arrived sizzling on a cast iron hot plate. Flakey and tender chunks of sea bass with nicely charred edges, on a bed of lightly fried onions and lettuce. One bite and I knew it was the best Pakistani-Indian flavored fish dish I had ever laid my mouth upon. "Wow", was all I could muster up. The fish was fully flavored with lots of cilantro, coriander seeds, and fresh chilies.

Totally sated I walked up to the front and thanked the chef for all the glorious and amazing food. I asked him what kind of fish was in the tandoori dish and he told me it was seabass. He mentioned that other chefs use salmon or catfish, but that he finds sea bass to be superior in taste. As I'm not a fan of cooked salmon, I totally agreed.

He offered us some homemade kulfi, but we could not eat anymore, and so told him we would gladly take some home. We wrapped up our leftovers and after paying, the chef gave us an additional complimentary dessert of bread pudding.

Later on that night we delved into the kulfi which was creamy and superb. And yesterday we broke out the leftovers and bread pudding. The leftovers were just as good the next day, and the bread pudding was another winner.

It's really amazing how much good cheap food there is to be found in the Tenderloin. If anyone has any other dish recommendations for Lahore, I'd be glad to hear them.
author: Brian J.

description:
Amazing, cheap, central (for us Lower Snobs), but gave me the sensation of having dinner with a very codependent family member.  (Not my date  -- he was smashing.)  Every choice that was suggested was fantastic, but a part of me just wanted to be left to my own devices to flirt to the background hum of Hindi satellite teevee.  

This is its own beast, incomparable to Chutney.  Do I still heart Chutney?  Yes, and the guys there would be furious at me for knowing I went astray for a night.
author: Melissa G.

description:
DELICIOUS!!!!!  my #2 favorite indian restaurant!!!!  enjoyed the following:

- mango lassi -- soooo goood!!!!  nice, thick, sweet & mangoey --  perfect on a warm, sunny day!!!!
- chicken tikka masala -- sooooo goood!!!!  different from any other one i had.  this one was thick & chunky........
- tandori chicken (boneless, breast) -- came out sizzling on an iron plate -- looked, smelled & sounded good but i didn't really like it as much as my hub.  kind of plain to me.
- garlic naan -- yum!!! tasty & garlicky!!!
-  rice -- good flavor, agree w/ other review, had nice crispy bits 

on our way out, we got to talk to the owner -- who was INCREDIBLY FRIENDLY & was very proud of his restaurant.....i really loved his sense of warm, open friendliness.........he told us to try his specialty tandori fish (sea bass).   voted the best tandori fish in sf weekly (forgot what year).  he proudly pointed to the framed best of sf weekly & showed us a laminated article review of his restaurant.   he also gave us a sample of his kufta,  homemade icecream (the owner makes it himself).   that day's flavor was cardamom, pistacchio & mango.  YUM!!!!

we will definitely be back for the tandori fish, more chicken tikka masala, garlic naan, rice, mango lassi & kufta!!!!  i left with such a WARM, REAL FEEL GOOD FEELING due to the owner's incredible genuine & sincere friendliness.  so will be back because the owner also makes me smile & feel good!!!!
author: Cindi N.

description:
I lived in the 'loin for too many years.  I hated the sidewalk outhouse that is leavenworth from mcallister to geary.  But I loooove this restaurant.

caveat:  service totally sucks.  but the owner/cook is always smiling and a look of intense "gotta make the food tasty" concentration.  Plus its really cheap for the quality.

Lamb that nearly melts in your mouth with a hint of smoky delight.  Bengan Bharta full of rich veggie uh richness.  chicken that is soft and alskdj.  whoops.  drool got into my keyboard.

Look for $20 you can get handmade naan and 2-3 dishes (2 meat and 1 veggie to make yo momma proud).
