So when that old waiter-dude suddenly decides he doesn't like you and ignores your request for water, or if the take-out is 10 minutes later than they originally said, for the quality of taste to the price ratio you should just keep quiet and be glad you're not stuck in NY where equivalent tandoori chicken alone is like $15.
author: PJ S.

description:
The first time I eat at every Indian food place, I just get vindaloo.  It's like French onion soup or anything else that everyone can make and will never be the same twice.

It was totally nice here, especially considering how inexpensive it was.

I also got the aloo paratha, and it was gorgeous.

Also big up the wifi I am stealing and the yelp crew for letting me know it's BYOB, and the heat being on and the waiter being a good guy.
author: Max I.

description:
Just like the other reviewers said, this place is great.  I had the tandoori fish, saag paneer and garlic naan.  Rice pudding for dessert.  I thought the fish, though cheap, was a bit dry due to the pieces of fish being a tad thin.  The saag paneer was delicious as was the naan.  The rice pudding is of the drier variety, be warned.  I tend to favor the runnier kind you find at some indian places.

There'll definitely be a next time, though I am going to try chicken and gulab jamun instead.
author: william c.

description:
Some of the best Indian food I've had in San Francisco, paired with some of the worst service I've had anywhere. 

It took so long to get our food, two of us actually left the restaurant to buy beer. I bet we waited 40 minutes. In fact, the service was so slow that we sent someone from our table up the counter to order. I'm not sure what the problem was. The place only has 8 tables.

The Butter Chicken and the Chicken Tikka Masala were almost the exact same dish, but delicious none-the-less. The Tandor Fish was good too, but not so good that I'd want to return, deal with the service and leave smelling like I've been cooking Indian food for an hour.
author: Brad L.

description:
A basic restaurant, therefore a basic list from me!

Bad List
1. BYOB.  Seriously, you'll need it and they don't charge or care.
2. You'll need it because the service is horrible verging on ludicrous.
3. Plan at least 2 hours, due to the initial ordering process.
4. Don't ask questions....he won't answer them well if at all.

Other than the above, this place rocked..food was very good if a bit spicy, chef came and asked about the food, portions were reasonable.

4 people had way too much food, overtipped for bad service, and it still came to about $16/pp.  Hopefully it stays that way.
author: David S.

description:
Went for lunch thinking there was a buffet for some reason.  And so glad there wasn't.  Ordered my standard - saag paneer and chicken korma. Completely changes my perception of chicken korma - spicy and a very complex flavorful sauce.  Big cinnamon stick floating in there as well.  Everything was brought hot off the stove and straight to the table so we had no wait, but it was lunchtime on a Tuesday so that could explain it.

Since it was our first time dining here, we were very complimentary to the chef/owner as we were paying and then we asked about how the rice pudding was.  His response was to give us a very large sample so we sat down again to finish it.  I don't like rice pudding much, the texture doesn't do much for me.  This rice pudding is AMAZING.  I will return just for that.

Great food, I wish it were closer to my neighborhood and had some ambiance but the food makes up for it.
author: Amy C.

description:
Lahore Karahi gets one star for their chai, and what a unforgettably good chai, served hot and perfectly spiced/sweetened. Other than that, the service was slow to the point where we felt ignored, and the food either very dry or bland. "It was the WORST chicken tikka masala I've EVER had" (Eric's quote).

Well, hey, you could stop by for their chai and leave with a smile...
author: Kirsten L.

description:
This is the best Indian food I have ever had in my life. 
Everything is spectacular. I don't live in San Francisco anymore, but this will always be the #1 most important place to go for me & my friends. Hands down.
author: Vida S.

description: I came here originally because I had a coupon... little did I know I should have been coming here LONG before!  It's right in the TL and I was able to find parking right away.  The food was so good and even before the coupon it was really cheap!  Meat items are under $8 too and Naan for $1, can't beat that.  For 3 people we got the Veggie Pakora - I love fried anything!, 2 orders of Naan, rice, Chicken Tikka Masala and Lamb Vindaloo.  We even had tons of left overs for the next days lunch... and all that was a whopping $22, before the coupon!  I will be back as often as possible because the food was fantastic, our server was so nice and it was full.. showing people know whats up!
author: Megan L.

description: Fantastic homestyle cooking in a small location. Food tends to come out slowly, but it is worth it! Prices are relatively cheap and service is friendly. Most importantly, flavors are authentic. For a casual restaurant, I think Lahore has the most authentic Indian and Pakistani food in the city!
author: Nancy F.

description: The best  Ind/pak food  I have in bay area .  It was prepared exactly the way I like it and guy on counter was very friendly . Only issue might be the locality ,but since I was staying in hilton and after bad experience with Naan n curry I was grt to find this place.
author: Ronnie R.

description:
The food here is amazing. Our group ate lunch on an average business day and it was full. Incredibly there was one guy cooking, seating, serving all of these tables. He was fun and friendly and made some really incredible food.

Recommended for great food....and a bit of waiting, so don't go in a rush!
author: Tyler F.

description:
The food is prepared with true passion. I adore the tandoori fish, and any lamb dish is to die for. Naan, warm and fluffy....so good. I live just south of Market St. and my boyfriend and I are always willing to wait a few minutes here if we have a craving for Indian food.

I lived in NYC for eight years and frequented many Pakistani and Indian restaurants. Lahore Karari is totally on my top list of restaurants. The chef is certainly very talented and passionate about the food. It's very, very, very good:)
author: Alyson A.

description: The new owners changed the menu (no more Afghani naan) and the food just doesn't have the same flavor...now it's just alright. I do love the bottomless chai though.
author: Rae D.

description:
Fantastic place!

At first I was a little scared of trying this place, but I have learned over the years that small, out of the way food is generally good, and it wasn't wrong this time either.

We had the tandoori lamb and lamb vindaloo, with some garlic naan. The tandoori was pretty good, but I wasn't that impressed with the naan.  The vindaloo though.....SO FUCKING GOOD! Seriously, we're still talking about how good the curry was.
author: Brittney H.

description:
This is by far one of the tastiest indian food in the city! The tandoori fish, samosas, naan, channa are delicious! I can't get enough of the food from this place! The owner takes great pride in the food. Keep up the good work, Lahore Karahi!
This is a small restaurant operation (in another words, not a lot of open tables), so be prepared to wait during busy hours.
author: Raman H.

description:
For how amazing the food is, the price is more than reasonable. In fact, it's extremely cheap. But did I mention that the food is AMAZING????????!!!!!!!!!!!
Every dish, down to the mango lassi was the best I've ever had, the chicken tikka masala sends chills down my spine when I put it in my mouth. The food there just tastes richer and more flavorful than any Indian food I've ever had, and I've dined at highly rated Indian restaurants in Chicago, Boston and Austin, TX.
My stomach is very sensitive, and I didn't get sick from the food, so I'm hopeful that it's going to stay this way forever so I can eat there everyday. Hopefully the restaurant never gets popular enough to turn into a chain, so it doesn't turn into Naan-n-Curry.
author: Yi Y.

description: I came here after checking into my hotel that was nearby based on the good reviews.  I was in the mood for Chicken Tikka Masala, so I ordered that and a couple of naans.  The Chicken Tikka Masala was ok, nothing to rave about.  It was a yellowish instead of the typical orange color which leads me to believe that they used different spices than what's typically used by the Indian restaurants.  It was cream based, but more spicy than sweet.  The naan was round, thin and crunchy which I didn't care for.  I am used to the long oval, soft and fluffy naans which facilitates eating with your hands and also enhances the flavors of the dish.
author: Asif S.

description:
My FAVORITE desi food in the city...Yes the wait is loooooonggg but Guddu takes pride in his food.. and unlike other desi places refuses to let anyone else cook the food! Guddu is awesome.. works super hard and always has a smile on his face. Please take a moment to chat with him, he really enjoys talking to his customers.

For vegetarians - try the dal masala (ROCKS!) and mutter paneer!
author: Kin J.

description:
(12.1.07) 

I love this food, best indian fare around, everything is so genuinely good.  

5 stars for takeout and cheap and so purely indian good.
4 stars if you remove takeout from above.

**** (previous/first) ****
Mmmm... so good...

Almost 5 star... 5 star awesome taste, 5 star awesome prices... atmosphere-n-service, jury still out...

(run-on-sentence-warning) Service was a little quirky-not-quite-right and the tenderloin is annoying to walk through but it almost doesn't matter and that is why i will hold off on 5 stars instead of give a forever-4 stars because i will have to come back and try again.

I am still craving more because it was so Indian-scrumptious-good and not too Indian-oily-mushy.  I loved the saag paneer (spinach with cheese cubes) best, but there was so much i didn't get to try that will have to wait for the next visit.  The mango lassi was super good, and the veggie samosas were the best samosa's ever (i'm not a huge samosa fan though).  They were light-and-fluffy-like inside (for potatoes and such), not just fried potato rocks.  a certain soon to be ex liked his salt lassi, and i did too, it was refreshing with the food, but he was shaken when he found chunks of chicken in his shrimp vindaloo, as he was not in a chunky chicken mood.  

So all in all, 4 stars for now, because of the surprise chicken and the quirky service, and the divey tenderloin (the inside is divey, too, but mostly is just part of the character of it all, and for the awesome prices, it's an even trade off).
author: Today Y.

description:
5 stars for having the best Indian food I've had in San Francisco.

-1 star for forgetting an item from our order the last 3 times we got take-out here. We paid for it, but they forgot it. First they missed a rice, next time it was a naan. After we told them about these incidents they supposedly discounted us for a rice and naan in our next order, but then forgot to give us rice again.

-1 star for using Styrofoam instead of cardboard containers.

This place is really good and I'll be eating here often, but my friends and I are pretty annoyed when we get back home with the food only to find that something we really wanted is missing.
author: P A U L.

description:
Ambiance it lacks.  And the owners cousin who helps serve the tables wouldn't be hire-able or impressive anywhere else, but this place is still deserving of five stars because when you're eating the food you don't even care about tacky Indian music videos or slow service.

Gudoo, the owner, is dedicated.  In every way.  After quizzing him incessantly during my last meal he coughed up the truth:  Every morning buying fresh ingredients, staying until midnight and only takes one day off a year.  He makes the place.  I wish for him a day or two off, but man would I be disappointed if I every showed up and he wasn't there.  Every meal you order you can watch him chop it fresh.  

The Naan bread is so amazing here that I've stopped ordering rice and just use my bread to get every bite to my mouth.  The best I've had.  An extensive vegetarian menu keeps me trying to talk everyone into "family-style" meals every visit so I can justify dipping my bread in their selection!

My out-of-town guests always look a little nervous walking in that neighborhood on our way there.  But I swear that I have taken friends and family there at least 20 times and always had them wanting to go back on their next visit.  It's that good.
author: Shasta N.

description:
My favorite pakistani food. better then anything else in the whole
tandoori-loin. It's that kind of small restaurant where the "owner/cook/waiter" is often the only one working (very hard of course), so don't expect to be hovered over by a flock of waiters and bussers, you might have to get up and re fill your water once of twice if you drink as much as i do..  bottom line = the food is phenomenal. get a little curry, some of the rice and naan and watch what's happening on o'farrell and leavenworth
author: Pflip W.

description:
This place is the fucking pits. Stay away.

I can't believe so many Yelpers are tolerating the hour-long wait for their food to show up. The service is the worst. The old guy (he sucks) gave our sheekh kababs to another table, waited for them to eat one and then snatched it from the other guys and gave it to us. And said the dish was untouched. LIAR! The other table had one of the four kebabs -- cos they thought they ordered it! So, he gives it back to the other table. And then they finally serve us the  food and forget about the bloody naans. 

And the dude kept fucking asking us what we ordered. What happened to the piece of paper he wrote our order on?

They screwed up the order of every single table that was occupied. The food wasn't bad but what tiny servings.

If you're a decent/good cook that doesn't mean you can run a restaurant. And hire a real wait staff. Or fucking train them.
author: Vivek S.

description:
Finally found the meaning to  "Love your neighbor as much as you do thyself". It's all about the food. :) Perfect place to be at after  downing oodles of the new Shakers. (I had no idea that they drilled vodka in NA). 

Anyways, the grilled goods are some of the best that my palate can remember. And compared to Shalimar, pakwaan etc. .. well .. this place certainly ups them. 

We were 18 of us. Lots of kids. (not mine). I think we pretty much ordered everything on the menu. 

I wasn't sure if it was the alcohol fermenting the food into yumminess, so I did end up getting a lot of take out for the week. Just to check and ofcourse I was the only bachelor  so it helped. 

I felt excellent around the tandoori fish and lamb biryani.

BTW - I just microwaved & ate this (After 2 days). Brings back images of joy and goodness. Will visit this place again.  You should too.
author: Ajay J.

description:
The food is ok. I prefer the onions that create the sauce to be a little bit more cooked.  The naans are nice.
2 stars because the ventilation is awful.  The whole restaurant is full of smoke so you walk out smelling like you've done the cooking.
author: A B.

description:
Best Pakistani/Indian food I've ever had. My friends and I have been having "Lahore withdrawals" since they were closed for a whole month.

So we went this last Friday nite. I noticed the carpets have been replaced with hardwood floors. All the tables have been scrubbed down. Place is lookin A LOT better.

My friends and I ordered...
- Seekh Kababs ( perfectly seasoned, juicy morsels of ground lamb )
- Tandoori Chicken Breast ( Well seasoned and juicy piece of meat )
- Chicken Tikka Masala ( This is the best I've had. Sauce is freshly made; you can even hear the food processor chopping up the spices and pistachios right before he makes the sauce. )
- Lahori Chikkar Choley ( Curry garbanzo beans which my friends and I found to be a bit too salty. The only down side to our meal. )
- Tandoori Fish ( Juicy Chilean Sea Bass! )
- Garlic and Reg Naan. ( Garlic is the best. It's loaded with garlic. )

Better than any of the other Pakistani/Indian places I've had in the city. Anyone know a better place than this. Let me know. =)
author: A.D. L.

description: This place was amazing!  I loved how small it was and that we got lucky enough to get right in without waiting.  The fish was great and I cannot wait to come back here again!
author: Christine K.

description:
Possibly the worst Indian food I have ever had.First of all had to wait for an eternity till we were obliged by the waiter with another infinite wait till the food was delivered.Ordered fish and a dish with paneer..The fish  tasted stale.The paneer was simply terrible..couldn't eat it all..never ever am I visiting this place again even if its the last restaurant on earth.

PS:How do I give 0 stars to this place??
author: zethuz z.

description: A very nice Pakistani/Indian place. Everything is good here. The restaurant is a bit cramped but otherwise the food is so awesome you'll forgive everything else.
author: Sankara R.

description: I love the fish tandoori here. Actually I have never tried it anywhere else but this place makes it really really good. The only reason I didnt give it 5 stars because you have to burn your clothes after you leave here. You stink like curry and smoke afterwards. kinda small and dingy but the food is great and so are the prices.
author: Yoli B.

description:
LOOOOVE the food! The service, however, is bizarre (if you go there you know exactly what I'm talking about).
The naan is delicious, so is the mango lassi. Some of my favorites are the chicken tikka masala and the karahi chicken (I think that's what it was called). Plus, it's cheap, so now this place is my favorite Indian/Pakastani spot in the city!
I would definitely give them 5 stars if they figured out their service a little.
author: Adelle W.

description:
One word: Overrated!

I have a friend in town and wanted to show her some truly wonderful San Franciscan Indian food.  My first mistake was going somewhere I hadn't been before, but I've trusted Yelp! so many times before, that I couldn't help it.

The first problem is the phone number on their website is the wrong number, but I won't count that against their food.  The second and biggest problem was their food.

I went for my staple Chicken Tikka Masala...while my guest had Lamb Korma.  The Tikka Masala (which was supposed to be extra spicy) was bland and, more upsetting, didn't taste like and Tikka Masala I've ever had.  The Lamb Korma was much better...though still not that great.  

I ordered take out, which may have contributed to the following problem - but again, I've had take out many times before that avoid these pitfalls.  The bread and samosa were in a paper bag (not in foil) which essentially left the samosas, naan, and paper bags saturated with grease - and though naan is ok in a greasy state, I prefer my samosas crispy.

Also - the curry meals were in Styrofoam takeout boxes that don't seal - and therefore spilled all over the plastic bag they were in as well as the paper bags which had the samosas and naan.

Ugh...won't go back for a variety of reasons.  Good food could have saved the packaging they prepared for the takeout.  But it wasn't good.
author: Marc L.

description:
The previous reviewers seem to complain about lots of things regarding this place... except few of them have to do with the food itself. Yes, like most Tenderloin places, Lahore Karahi is not about friendly or even timely service. Neither it is about cleanliness, great location, or impeccable take out packaging. 

No. This place is strictly about food. After you are half-starved waiting for at least 40 minutes for your meal to arrive, it strikes you with its aroma and then - its unique taste. This place is no regular Indian restaurant. It is Pakistani-Indian, which really means Pakistani, and unlike most similar joints in the area, it seems to take pride in it. Chicken tikka masala is indeed very different here from most places in town - it is more flavourful, richer in taste and just right in consistency of the curry. Aloo ghobi is delicious, rich on coriander and other spices. Lamb korma is similarly great. Even rice is more earthy, more hearty and again, different from most other places. Finally, nan and kulcha are krispy, fragrant and delicious. 

I used to get frustrated about the extremely slow service, cockroaches on walls and the wrong order of food being brought to my table. But all this is irrelevant compared to the actual quality of food. Think of this place as someone's home and come here as a guest, not a demanding patron. Then you will keep coming back for more.
author: Evg R.

description:
Being that it was my boyfriend's first time eating Indian food with his Indian girlfriend (me, not some other girlfriend), I was excited to eat here because of all the fabulous reviews. 

But dude, for realz....

The choley looked and tasted like baby food. The chickpeas looked like they had been purposefully smashed up. Not cool. The chicken in the tikka masala was just OK, not melt-in-your-mouth curry goodness like at, say, Mehfil, arguably one of the best Indian restaurants in San Francisco.

The saag was pretty dec. (that's decent for all you older peeps.)

The gentlemen running the joint are an absolute joy, which is why I feel pretty salty about giving this review. But it is what it is.
author: Nina S.

description:
Not fancy (yes, it qualifies as a dive) but is he food ever good. I think this place has the best Indian food I have ever had.  I came here with a large group of people.  The owners were very accommodating to us.  The service was very slow (mainly because how big our group was), and the neighborhood is a little sketchy as you are in the Tenderloin but the food was totally worth it.
---------------------------
Sometimes when you go back a second time, you have a different perspective... The service was super slow.  The drab, run down atmosphere really seemed to be more depressing then I had remembered.  I am changing my rating from 4 to 2 stars.
author: Scott S.

description:
So it's Friday night after work, and we're starving. Indian food sounds fabulous. Something spicy. And cheap. And Yelp-approved. Lahore Karahi it is.

As soon as the menu hits my hands, my eyes are frantically scanning the page looking for anything and everything that sounds delicious. Dammit. It all does. So we choose a little of everything: the papadam ($1), wafer-thin flatbreads with a texture reminiscient of potato chips, paneer pakora ($3.50), deep-fried, French fry-shaped wedges of cheese, seekh kebab ($4), a very spicy lamb sausage on skewers, chicken tikka masala ($7), mildly spicy pieces of chicken in a creamy sauce, lamb vindaloo ($7), a very spicy stewy mixture of lamb and potatoes, plain naan ($1), garlic naan ($2), a side of rice ($1.25), and gulab jamun ($3.50) for dessert. 

The sole server, who had a room's full of hungry, needy patrons to attend to and therefore whose sympathy I had from the get-go, was quirky and odd but kind of fun. The food came out all out of order and sporadically but you know what? I didn't care. It was all just so good and satisfying, and it was a ton of food, but we cleaned each plate. Oh and P.S., mango lassi is my new favorite drink. 

My favorite moment of the evening came when our server dropped the check. I'm like, okay, I know this is cheap eats and all, but that was a crapload of food we just ordered, and S. has slipped into some comatose, food-drunken stupor that he will not have recovered from until the next afternoon. But somehow, after plate upon plate of deliciously satisfying food, the grand total of the evening was.... $38.78. What?!?!?! I began to loathe and regret each night we had spent $100+ on an appetizer, two entrees and a round of drinks at other, sub-par establishments. The value of this place just blew my mind.

So go here, it's delicious, amazingly priced, and my new go-to place for Indian food in the city.
author: Meghan P.

description:
yum. Yum. YUM!
This place was amazing...it's like one of those neighborhood dive joints that ONLY locals or hard core food enthusiants know about. I loved it. The waiter is extremely friendly but sometimes I felt like we were talking to a blonde...is that policitically correct/incorrect? 
The food was AMAZING though. We got the lamb biryiani, chicken vindaloo, egg plant and chickpeas curry dishes, samosas (yummmmmmy), and three types of naan...garlic, cheese and potato.
I would def come here again, on a regualr basis if my tummy and wallet could handle it. 
BYOB...no liqour license...but they water which I found to be helpful when dipping the samosa into that green sauce...it was FIRE! 
Oh---and the mango chutney is worth ordering over and OVER again. yum
GO NOW!
author: Mary B.

description:
absolutely delicious. This restaurant should get 5 out of 5 points for that. Finger licking delicous food. However, it is very crowded and very dirty. Because of this I will only give it 4 points.

this is a must visit restaurant for Indian / Pakistani cuisine.
author: Rakesh S.

description:
The place has a decent ambience . First the guy would not give us a bigger table - then he agreed. The service was ok . The food was terrible - chicken boti - sizzling and succulent but tasteless,
The aloo paratha - tasteless again 
chicken saag - i tried eating the saag / spinach out of it but it was way too bland and oily 
The chicken karahi - did not taste like karahi at all - put lahore to shame 
naan was chewy and cold
author: champa m.

description:
The wait was a bit long BUT definitely worth it. Good food can not be rushed and it's not a surprise the place is always packed. The naan is delicious and the smell of the kitchen adds magic to the meal. 

Simply lovely and I will be back sooner than later. Yummy!
author: Jennifer O.

description:
I had to Edit this review after ordering to-go this weekend. The chicken was not warm and the chicken breast was burnt. I guess you have to dine in the get the 5 star treatment. I was very disappointed with my food. The next night I took out from Salimar.. they never seem to fail me they are always consistent. If its one thing that these other indo/paki places need to learn from salimar is cooking your meal like its your last. 


Salimar offers consistency thats why they have been in business for so long you know what you will get night in and night out. Too all my cousins that told me salimar is the best , you were right I was wrong.
author: shoel s.

description:
I love this place and I love Gudhu.  

Nevermind the weirdness or freakiness as mentioned in the other reviews.  I come here every week, and the chef and staff are super sweet and always accomodate all of our needs and bring us special desserts.
author: uly n.

description:
YAH.  Spicy goo after spice pile of stewed goo...

Friendly service, decent portions, decent prices, large menu.  Since when did comfort-food for me become associated with spiciness?  I will ponder this over my next helping of tandoori fish.
author: Maxwell M.

description:
The best g-ddamn Indian/Paki food I've ever had outside of Pubjab.  They use so much cilantro and it just works.  

Love it.  Go there.
author: Maiya S.

description:
Lahore Karahi Restaurant is a pleasant surprise amid the noise of the Tenderloin area. Food is good, service friendly and while setting is small it is clean.

Parking is not easy to find as the Tenderloin are is busy.
author: Jonathan F.

description:
I am always reluctant to share my absolute faves, mostly cause I am a selfish b-i-t-c-h, but Guddu is a rock star, and I like to see him prosper.

This is the best Pakistani food this side of London. Hands down.

The ambiance? What ambiance? It's the TL - don't ask for ambiance, you might end up paying $20 for 10 minutes behind a Dumpster with a  guy named Aura.

This is the real thing; slow food. It's just Guddu, making it fresh from scratch all on his lonesome for your sorry self. Don't get all in a hizzy. This dining experience will take at least 2 hours. Maybe three. Enjoy the Ballywood and learn a little culture. And help yourself to water and stuff.

If you're real nice, maybe he'll give you free ice cream (like me)!
author: Mari C.

description: Loved it. The chili naan dipped in the sauce from the fridge...the garlic naan soaking up all the goo from my lamb bhunna. I am still a bit of a newbie to Pakistani food, so they may be getting by on my ignorance. But, as far as I am concerned, other places will have to live up to the expectations that this place has given me.
author: Craig H.

description:
Compares to the best Pakistani food anywhere in the U.S. and very reasonably priced.  The guy who cooks the food knows his craft. The big plus: the food is made fresh.  The chicken karahi, daal, kadahi rice, and more, all just amazing.  Will try the seafood (Tandoori Fish and the like), the next time. 

Don't expect quick waiter service. Order at the counter and get your own plates, cutlery, etc.   You can request spices according to your taste from mild to hot.
author: John S.

description:
Me and My SIG FIG other got four dishes and naan for take out, which we ended up waiting around about a half hour - 45 mins for. Not a problem, we wanted indian and this place de-LIVER-ed (and we had a coupon! oh goodie!). Its in the tenderloin so yeah, you know the drill, one patron broke out a joint while he waited, I read the multitude of reviews pasted on to the window, raving about the place (and its tandoori fish)  which we ordered. We also got spinach cooked with potatoes and kasoori methi, and  eggplant  with onions, tomatoes & cream, and the Chicken Korma. 
It was all very good. The vegetable dishes were not that spicy ( we never specified the level of heat), but the fish was. What is there to say, the vegetable dishes were mashed up curry style, the chicken was doused in curry sauce, and the fish came on a bed of lettuce and cucumbers. I have to say, why does everyone rave about the fish? It fell apart (good), and was cooked well, but it just tasted like.... fish. Void of spices, which made it pretty good... but nothing amazing.  The chicken was tender, fleshy, good, and the vegetable dishes were good, naan was  soft and good, not doughy. This is the place I will go to when I want indian. The interior is grungy, but next time I go, I want to sit inside, even though its loud and cramped as hell. 
bye
author: nathan z.

description: We waited in line for about 30 mins. It is very small inside. Many people ordered the tandoori dishes that came in the skillets so it made the room quite smokey. Naan bread was ok...Chicken tikka masala was not very good. The chicken was very tough and chewy. The lamb pieces were hit or miss. Some tender pieces some very chewy. The tandoori  fish however was amazing! Melt in your mouth good! I would come back just for the fish if there wasn't a line. Very affordable!
author: Chauanh D.

description:
My good friend Lori and I went to dinner at Lahore Pakistani restaurant for dinner, she had never been and wanted to try it out. I have been coming to this location back when it was the German Cook  and have eaten at Lahore probably 6 or 7 times and always had a good meal.
We lucked out and grabbed the first table to the right as  you entered which could sit three persons, great for sharing food and having a good conversation. Unfortunately, as soon as we sat down we noticed a little roach on the table slowly crawling up the wall........not a good start but not enough to make me walk out the door.
The owner and waiter were very attentive and friendly but the service was slower than usual but I think that's kind of nice so you can visit longer.

This evening we shared the Vegetable Samosas, Tandoori Lamb Chop, Tandoori Fish, Lahore Karahi Rice and garlic Naan.
The Vegetable Samosas were big and stuffed full, fried perfectly and served warm. I liked the mint sauce that accompanied them, I thought these were the best part of my meal.
Next up was the Tandoori Lamb Chop, these were the smallest lamb chops I have ever seen. To say there was a mouthful of meat on each chop would be generous. 
We followed with the Tandoori Fish which I will say looked beautifully cooked but I wasn't a fan of the type of fish that was used, maybe it was Catfish? It had a muddy taste to it that just took away any desire to eat the rest of the fish. The Karahi Rice was rice with some spice in it, nothing that caught my attention to make me order this rice dish again. I did enjoy the Garlic Naan, I'm amazed how each Indian/Pakistani restaurant has their own way of making Naan. Lahore's Naan is flat vs puffy and moist with lots of garlic and cilantro.
 I like the location of Lahore because it's in the Tenderloin, it's a perfectly safe neighborhood although it looks sketchy but this seems to weed out the "Oh so trendy" from the "Gotta have authentic food" folks like me. I like the size of the restaurant, it worked when it was the German Cook and it seems to work well for Lahore. I do wish they had a liquor license or at the very least we could bring our own. I was going to give Lahore 2 stars because of tonight's meal but because I have been here before and have had some great food I am giving 3 stars.
I'll come back to Lahore even after this mediocre review but will order something different.
author: David P.

description: This place is the cat's meow! You'll probably have to wait in line to get in but it's totally worth it. It's a family owned place with free chai, friendly faces and delicious food. Order to share and don't forget to order naan bread, it's perfect for soaking up the perfectly spiced food. If you like food with flavor and don't mind dining in a small but cozy place, you should go!!
author: Zoe M.

description: Delish Indian dishes. Have yet to have a bad dish yet. The community table seating can be annoying and the service definitely is slow and sometimes moody but the food more than makes up for it. Great for noisy groups if you can get in.
author: Allison L.

description: The food was very tasty.  Not as oily as some other Indian restaurants.  There was free chai, which was pretty good with a little sugar.  We had three vegetarian dishes and one chicken.  They all hit the spot.
author: Kip W.

description:
Just got through with a lunch from Lahore Karahi and it definitely deserves all the love. It's the best of our Little Calcutta fo' sho'!


 The chicken tikka masala was unlike any I've ever had and their choley and palak paneer were leaps and bounds better than so many others.


 Give it a shot. You'll be happy.
author: RugJones

description:
Guddhu (johnny carson) and Malik (ed mcmahon) keep it very real.

The best curry in San Francisco. Period. In the heart of the TandooriLoin, no less. Guddhu makes everything to order, and is it ever worth the wait in this 70's BollyWood flickering O'Farrell Street haven for lovers of 1000 spice meals.

Their biryanis are a mountain of flavor, and the Bengan Bharta (creamy eggplant+carmelized onion) is simply the tastiest curry I've ever had. It rivals what I've had traveling around the Arabian Gulf. Oh yeah: their achar is  killer; my wife and I have to get our own portions to avoid snarling like dogs over it.

Malik brings everything to the table with swift efficiency and if you're lucky, you'll get a culinary history lesson on what you've ordered.

If you have any room left, there will be no disappointment in their rice pudding (an ode to cinnamon and pistachio) or their ice cream (a saffron+cardamum dream).

I love it and am compelled to evangelize, though I've only been there about 40 times over the last couple of years...
author: digiTED ..

description:
This is the best North Indian / Pakistani food in the city and is up there for the best in the Bay Area.

Garlic Naan, Butter Chicken.  For when I'm feeling white.  Saag Paneer, Chole are great as well.  I don't get the hype about the Chicken Karahi.  It's not that great (neither are the Tandoori or Biryanis), but there's plenty of other great stuff on the menu.

The place is BYOB, but I don't.  I don't think Guddu the chef really approves of drinking in his place.
author: Srini P.

description:
Guddu has done a great job with the food here.  Been there twice in a week already, after being introduced to the place through a friend.

You need to be in the mood for some spicy flavorful food, to really enjoy the dishes.  The atmosphere is casual and laid back, and the servers and food will be slow.  Thats cause the chef takes the pain to oversee each dish at it cooks.  

Go there with friends and order a bunch of different things.  We loved the Palak Ghosht and Lamb Biryani.  The Fish Tikka is out of this world.  I asked Guddu (the chef) how he made it.  He says that unlike other places, he uses only whole spices, and no "garam masala", which brings out stronger flavors in the spices.  Added to that, he uses Sea Bass for the fish, as it gives a flavor closer to the fish from back home.

We plan to go back regularly and bring more friends.
author: Amit M.

description:
This place is off the hook.  The food is SO good.  I live nearby, and there are times when I don't eat here because it's SO INTENSE.  It's an onslaught of tastes.  I can only handle it once in awhile. Fantastic.  Friendly staff.

Here are the things that might turn people off.  These things are ultimately irrelevant as this place is so effin' good:  1) It takes a long time to get your food  (they're actually COOKING it for you, not just heating up a bunch of pre-made sauces).  2) this place is a dump  (but it's so effin' good).
author: shoo b.

description: I am still totally obsessed with Lahore Karahi.  The food is magical.  That is all.
author: gaby g.

description: Saw this restaurant on the tv show "check please" , so Idecided to give it a try . It was exactly as they described it . It  was a hole in the wall spot,  and not the cleanest looking , or best neighborhood around. But the the food was off the hook . The prices are  great. I  ordered the tandoori fish, the chicken tikka masala, the naan , and some rice. All exceptionally prepared. If  I lived around the area I would definitely come back again . Prepare  to wait  a little bit because it seems like everyone around comes here, and don't be discouraged by  the first appearance !
author: Vincent R.

description: Yummy and cheap....what more do you want. Best place for Indian food. I have many favorites and every time I try something new I'm never disappointed. It gets kind of cramped at times, but its bound to happen at a yummy place!! Another down side is the area its in....the TL, but its okay. Order the samosas....a must!!!
author: Fritzi G.

description: Stopped in for lunch yesterday. Service was slow because I managed to end up right behind a table of 10 law students, bummer but not really the restaurant's fault. The Lamb Korma was AWESOME, freshly cooked, very tasty, great stuff. I'll be back on one of my cross-town journeys.
author: Bowen D.

description:
Good cheap Indian food.
Bangun Bhartha is best in SF.
author: avani a.

description:
I'm not going to lie.  I was a little scared going to this restaurant.  My beautiful Indian friend brought me to this little family-run place in the Loin, and I was kind of weirded out.  It was late evening, and I'm just an easily scared person.  So, I was prepared not to like it.

BUT I loved the food.  Spicy without burning a hole in my stomach.  I couldn't stop eating!  I had chicken korma and naan, and I almost finished everything.  I also was drawn to the family-run nature of the place.  The ambience is very bare bones, but somehow it is cheerful inside - well-lit and very bustling.  I definitely recommend it.  

For you ladies out there that are scaredy cats like me, I would recommend not wearing heels so that you can walk FAST if need be.  Also, don't be stupid like me and come laden down with shopping bags.  It made me stick out and look dumb.
author: Carol R.

description: Another great (cheap eat) joint in the city for Indian Food.  Glad we tried it finally.  Comparisons with Shalimaar are bound to happen.  So here goes few similarity and differences... as far as we could make out.  Both are "hole in the wall" joints.  I think the kebabs, tikkas & naan are better at Shalimaar but Karahi / gravy dishes are undoubtedly better here at Lahore Karahi.   Missed on the Tandoori Fish this time, would have to go back to try that.  Also surprisingly this place takes your order and accepts credit cards - unlike Shalimaar.  Would be definitely going back again and again - just for the karahi's :)
author: Rajit J.

description: I loved the home feel of this place u know???? It just felt like walking into someone's house and having them cook for u except the awkward part when ur done eating and u realize u have to pay them...uh....lol hey it's not too bad cuz i didn't really feel rushed or anything. anyway, the chicken tikka masala was to quote my friend brian who spoke of claim chower once, "absolutely divine". my cousin and i thought maybe there was squash in it or something???? doesn't matter, it was effing delicious!!! and the naan, like hello, what else do u ever need in life???? o and free tea yaaaay!!!!!
author: Lea N.

description:
This is a really nice little indian restaurant that gives you an experience that you won't get from those chain restaurant. There's no waiter to serve you. The own=chef=waiter. We went around lunch time. So the little restaurant was full of business people (my friend was staring @ one of them! XD).
We waited for the chef to tell us where to sit. Seating wasn't totally comfortable, but this is just what you get from tiny privately-own restaurant like this.
We got the garlic and cilantro naan. It was gooooooooood! Soft and fluffy! Super tasty! I personally hate cilantro. But I still like it with the naan!
The we got the Lamb Boti. I didn't really like this one. It was one of the sizzling plate. However, the Lamb doesn't really have a lamb taste to it. And it was sort of tasteless, oily dish....
We also got the chicken tikka masala. My friend and I LOVED it! It was really creamy and tasted great with rice!

I think i would go back to try a few more dish!
author: Shirley F.

description: I came here a few weeks ago . I got the spicy chicken with potatoes curry ( I forgot what it's called ) . It was very spicy and yummy . The naan and rice tasted okay . The lassi I got was disgusting !!! It tasted like there was some grease in there or something . I took one sip and threw it away . It makes me wonder if the man spilled grease in my drink . Yuckkk !! Even though the drink was disgusting , I still give this place 4 stars . Just be prepared to wait a little while for your food because there is only one man serving everyone .
author: Eileen L.

description:
Have been about 5 times now since starting a new job in the TL. Food is amazing--have focused on saag paneer, lamb korma, chicken tikka masala, and an eggplant curry.

I like my food spicy, so no disappointment here. Ask for spicy and it's the real deal. If you DON'T like spicy, def request mild...

My experiences w/service have been good so far. The wait for your food can be a little longer than usual, but that's b/c the owner makes each order fresh and on the spot, even the naan.

Def. recommend.

UPDATE: Totally addicted...and get the sesame naan.
author: Carmine D.

description: I love this place. The food and service are really great. Do not be turned off by the Tenderloin address, it is always worth the trip!
author: Amy M.

description: I love places like this.  Family run. Small restaurant.  Small Menu. BIG flavor.  Plan to return when I'm back in the bay area in August.  Bring on the HEAT!!!!
author: Michael R.

description: I was really excited to go here because of the good reviews I had read and because I could walk here from my apartment instead of having to go to the Richmond, West Portal, or the Mission for some tasty Indian food. The service was attentive (that's why I gave two stars) but I thought the food wasn't very great. We ordered the vegetable pakora which I did like because unlike other places where they consist of just dough you could see and taste all the veggies. We ordered the vegetable sabzi, saag paneer, daal masala, a side of rice, and one piece of naan. Nothing really stood out and I didn't like the naan, it was too crispy. I'll have to try it again before I really decide to dislike it.
author: Lucia V.

description:
[sigh.]  

It's been a week & I'm still fantasizing about the Aloo Mutter & Chicken Tikka Masala.  Oooh, & the thickest, creamiest, most cardamom-y kheer I've ever had.  

This cramped corner in the tenderloin has ostensibly the best homestyle Indian/Pakistani food I've ever had.  The sauces are thick & cooked down, none of that anemic, runny tasteless soup masquerading as sauce here!  The Aloo Mutter is so delicious I found myself licking anything that came near it--fork, fingers, naan...oh, I so wanted to pick up the plate & lick it clean!  Lots of onions cooked down into a thick, gingery sauce with starchy potatoes & sweet little peas.  [sigh.]  As for the Chicken Tikka Masala, loved the tangy dense sauce filled with cinnamon tomatoey goodness & tender chunks of chicken.  Ordered everything medium which was more mild-medium but all good.  The naan is a bit oily & chewy but it makes a great vehicle for carrying sauce to your maw.  Don't pass by the kheer even if you're about to re-enact a scene from "The Meaning of Life."  Get it to go & moan & slurp in the privacy of your room.  

[sigh.]
author: Cam T.

description:
this place is AMAZING 3rd time in one week HIGHLY recommend!!!

grilled tandoori chicken breast
sesame nan
butter chicken

OMG never going to shalimar again !!!
author: Nikola B.

description:
When I went here, I was damn hungry. It had just been a long day of shopping. I had bags and I was tired. It should have been the perfect time for cheapo Indian in the Tenderloin (Tenderloindian?). But instead... I lost both legs and three fingers to a biryani gone bad and a poppadom of pure evil beat me and stole my wallet.

Either that, or the waiter here was just fucking weird.

After my hot date and I had taken our seats, the waiter walked up to us and gave us our menus and, first thing, asks, "Where do you live?"

We told him. San Francisco. He nodded, but gave us a look like we were totally lying, as if we were tourists who were scared of a non-white person knowing we were tourists because when non-white people run into tourists they abduct, rape, and murder them. That, or they try to sell you postcards. Same thing.

Anyway, since he thought we were tourists, he started telling us how good his restaurant was. According to this waiter, Lahore Karahi has some very good reviews on some website called thaifoodreview.org (I shit you not!). And also, according to this waiter, Yelp *loves* Lahore Karahi. On Yelp, Lahore Karahi has over 150 reviews. On Yelp, Lahore Karahi has a 4.5 star average. I was almost like, "Dude, on Yelp, Ben P has 27 local photos. On Yelp, Dawn M has regular conniption fits 'cause she thinks Ben P had a fake profile named Mister E. So take that!"

Once we were sufficiently briefed about the glories of Lahore Karahi according to the internets, he concluded his speech: "So um yes. Order whatever you like." 

Which was, dear reader, like the most ironic thing he could have said. When he came to take our order, the first thing we asked for was an appetizer of aloo tikki. He said, straight up, "No." He explained, "If you order that, the chef will have to stop everything he is doing and make them for you. Better you eat samosas. 1 order of samosas, OK? They're better anyway." 

I saw his point: it *is* pretty whack that a chef at a restaurant has to drop what he's doing (currently: scratching balls) and cook something that you ordered. 

Then, we ordered some curries, a biryani, and some naan. Including "Afghani naan." He raised his eyebrows when we ordered it. "Do you know what that is? You don't want that." He then told us what it was, which was pretty much exactly what the menu said it was: naan with some fruits and nuts and cheese. He said that we ordered way too much food, and then he walked off.

A few minutes later, he brought out an order or poppadom. "DON'T WORRY," he said to me, as if I had actually acknowledged his presence in any way. "IT'S FREE. ON THE HOUSE. You don't have to pay for it." I said thanks.

Then he asked us if we knew what it was. We said "Yup." Then he said, "WHAT is it then?" 

"Uh, poppadom," we said.

"Good. You know, this is not just a rice cracker. Entire families slave all day to make this that is sitting here before you. The children, the parents, the grandmothers. They sit on the floor all day and roll this dough that is as hard as a marble. Twenty hours, maybe, they work."

There was a pause. As I tried not to pee into my underwear from holding in my laughter, he continued:

"Nowadays, we have machines. They make it." Then he walked off.

For the next ten minutes or so, Mr. Waiter looked for every possible excuse to return to our table. Since we had already ordered and our food wasn't ready yet, these excuses were limited, and included: refilling our water, or refilling our water. I can say this for Lahore Karahi: my water glass was always 85 percent full. This is mostly a good thing, but it had its downsides: 1) it made it harder to talk shit about the waiter without him hearing because he was always hovering around with a water pitcher, and 2) he refilled our glasses in a different way each time. Seriously, this guy had read a book on how to fill water in different and inconvenient ways. The best one was probably the time he filled my glass and set the pitcher down on the table and then held out his hand that was holding the glass. And held it. And held it. Finally, he coughed *ahem*, and motioned for me to take the glass out of his hand myself.

Pretty much the same thing happened with the food. He brought every plate over by itself, even though they were ready at the same time. There were two of us at a table meant for four, but by the time he had brought the third dish, he stopped and wouldn't set it down. "I can't set this down you have too much food MAKE SOME ROOM FOR ME PLEASE!" 

The food was fine. Maybe not worth all the hype on thaifoodreviewnation.gov, but definitely nothing to complain about. Although the biryani did taste like pilaf, and I personally prefer poppadom that is made by sobbing child laborers instead of soulless modern machines.

Oh, and Mr. waiter, you were right: the Afghani naan tasted like stale fruitcake.
author: Ben P.

description: Decent service and prices, but the food was nothing special.  An overall average experience.  With all the other options nearby I probably will not return.
author: Lily C.

description:
This place was absolutely phenomenal! A friend took me and my dad here last night and I already can't wait to go back. They ordered the chicken vindaloo and the tandoori fish. My dad couldn't stop raving about how good the fish was. Maybe a hint of lime right at the end? Being a veggie I ordered the matar paneer. Just a little bit spicy which I liked. So good I couldn't stop eating it. I wanted to save half for lunch the next day but ended up finishing it instead. Plus, the ice cream that came with the bill was just the right way to end the meal.

We did have to wait a little while for the food even though the restaurant was only half full. But you can see them working and there are only two guys so it really wasn't that long. Don't go here if you're in a rush but the food is definitely worth the wait!

And the prices are right too.
author: Katie K.

description: Delicious kebabs. Went here today for lunch - we had chicken boti and seekh kebabs, naan - it was cooked to order and super fresh. Definitely a keeper.
author: Kate T.

description: The chef here is really nice, the food is awesome, this is definately real indian food unlike naan n curry. The dal makhani is my favorite thing here it is lentils in a curry sauce, yum! The naan is soft and buttery. The staff are really nice and polite! definately a 5, would of give it a 10 if possible.
author: Lovi K.

description: I have recently been to this plc, it's a small plc but the food is amazing...
author: Dhara A.

description: Much better than many of the surrounding Indian restaurants in the area. The curry dishes are much tastier and less greasier than Naan N Curry. The naan's are delicious and the free chai (tea) is appreciated.
author: Shrini V.

description:
oh good god. 

bengan bharta + roti.

byob.

might as well be byod. as in bring  your own diaper cuz you'll be crapping yourself at how good it is.

throw in samosas, eat till you sweat and have to loosen the top button on your jeans, and call it a night.

and i honestly have a hard time bitching about the service. the owner/cook/ who knows what the hell that one dude is doing behind the counter... whatever, they're basically cooking made to order, home cooked food. so what if it takes a long time?

thats cuz its made with love.

hungry and getting frustrated about having to wait longer than 5 minutes for your food? well cut the negativity, be a little proactive about the situation, pull out that bottle of kingfisher and start padding your stomach. thats why god invented beer in the first place, so we never have to be hungry and cranky while waiting for food at lahore karahi.
author: Steph-a-saurus, Grr. J.

description: Best damn Indian food I've ever had.  Better than all the rest on Jones Street too, by far.  Go here.
author: Gregory S.

description:
When you want a semi-uncomfortable meal after spending most of the day hopped up on ecstasy and 2CB then this, my Britney Spears-esque friend, is YOUR place.
I came here after LoveFest 2007.  Minus my glittery stripper shoes and white fishnet thigh highs with the bows.  I think I still had my lavender jacquard corset on though.  Which might be why I didn't eat as much as usual.  Drugs and tightly laced corsets make it hard to dine heartily I've observed.
All seriousness aside, me and four friends had a bunch of good food here on the cheap.  Two of my dining companions were (and are still) assholes and were mildly insulting to the disgruntled curmudgeonly owner which DIDN'T result in our food being spit into.  I think.  If there WAS spit in our foods I can only believe it's a delicious secret ingredient that I'll allow.  The tandoori was tender and yummy, the naan crispy and delicious, the cheese and spinach dish (whose name I forget and am too lazy to look up) is creamy and the aloo gobhi made me extremely happy.  It's a tiny place but the portions are large and the prices are cheap.
BYOB and be prepared for a hot and spicy night.
And stares.  I've learned that people stare at you when you eat Indian food in elbow length white satin gloves and white sunglasses when it's night-time.  What can I say?  They went with the tiara and parasol!
author: Jill D.

description:
no no no.

don't let the name fool you! its not a restaurant its a whore house. wait no it is a restaurant nevermind. 

connie took me to try the food here. i heard chinese food and indian food is really good in the bay so i had  chinese so time to try their cousin to the west, or south, i mean north, i mean east??? dude what is this a pop quiz?

anyways the food was good! really good! some of the best. service is kind of whatevs, kind of slow you know. but i kind of think that makes it more authentic? or i am just tripping.

so the lamb korma great, chicken marsala great, the pea soupy thing great, and the naan great. and the convo was great! it went something like...

sam: so tell me how handsome i am
connie: sam i see you like a cousin
sam: like a kissing cousin?
connie: i don't like you in that way
sam: i lost my puppy. can you help me find him? i think he went inside your apartment.
connie: it's not you it's me.
sam: you mean it's me.
connie: let's be friends
sam: wait didn't i used to see you at this one place before a lot?
connie: yeah thats why i don't go there anymore.
sam: what are you trying to say?
connie: i'm not attracted to you.
sam: tell me how handsome i am
perci: sam you are one handsome korean man.

oh yeah perci was there too!
author: Sam Y.

description: So I've eaten here about 5 times and if I had written this review after the 4th visit i would give Lahore Karahi 5 stars. I always order the chicken tikka masala (requested spicy) with rice and sometimes naan. I ask for it spicy and its usually a greatt amount of spice except for this last time. I called in my order and ordered the usual food only this time I'm pretty sure Guddu put lava in my food. I think maybe he was having a bad day and wanted to play a joke on a white boy asking for spicy indian food. But whatever, I still ate it. Still my go to indian food place in the TL.
author: chris b.

description: Why god why must all my favorite places reveal themselves on the stankiest corners of the tenderloin? And Indian food is my favorite food. Its all too much. Lahore karahi, cheap and diviiine with a bamn! of flavor. soooooooo good. For vegetarians, I recommend- paneer shahi - garlicky, creamy, spicy, and the best baingan bartha I've ever had. + roti. Whoa greasy somosas, will probably skip in the future.
author: Liz S.

description:
I ordered food to go, so got only food that could travel the fifteen minutes home without getting dried out.  But that food (chicken tikka masala, lamb curry, rice with this and that mixed in, garlic naan) was all very good.  The location's classic TL:  scooted right past the O'Farrell theater and the New Century (and who knows what else) (got a nice shout out from some customers leaving the O'Farrell for the Obama '08 sticker on my '86 Honda Elite 80 cc) (yeah, I'm cool) (not so much).  The owner/chef was terribly nice (hospitable and charming) (by contrast to the more detached service at the also-very-good Shalimar on Polk) (though this ambiance is homier), and he definitely cemented my return visit (he says the fish tandoori is great).  I got the food medium, which was perfect, and it was terribly complex in flavor(fruits and pistachios and all sorts of subtle flavors rolling around).  They have mango lassi (probably one of my all-time favorite drinks).  If the fish and other tandooris are all that on my return visit, this could be five stars.

Update:  Hmm.  I did like it, but there have been suggestions on the consuming front (those I consume with) (he I consume with) (yeah, that's right:  the BF) that they (he) prefer(s) Shalimar for certain reasons that perhaps one should refer to delicately and not in a review.  Publicly, well, he thinks Shalimar is better on the merits, too, as in, the quality of the tikki masala and so forth.   So I am back to take-out from Shalimar on Polk (and lunch, too).  

Update May 2008:  And now we have found Meftil, which not only delivers to Potrero Hill but also is super high quality.   Scooting for take-out may be a thing of the past.
author: Laurel B.

description: This is hands dowm my favorite restaurant! The wait is bearable but longer than most places, however, AMAZING... Gudu is a guru, and works so hard, it almost feels as if you are eating at his personal dinner party... of course where you brought your own wine and beer! Couldn't rave about it enough, it is a classic place to also take people when they are visiting SF for a few nights... afordable, centraly located and more importantly, a quality dinning experience
author: LA R.

description: It's always a treat coming here, the food is so good! The best mango lassi's, the color is so bright and sprinkled on top are pistachios, gaah, definitely #1 in San Francisco. I love the chicken tikki masala, the butter chicken, the fish dishes are delicious and sweet.  At the end of every meal Guddhu hooks it up with a sweet, isn't that nice? On weekend evenings you can catch the bollywood videos.
author: Glu C.

description: The decor is dirty and run down and the drinking water is tepid but otherwise this place is AWESOME!!  Wow! Talk about a mouthful of spices.  Just about everything is very good and the tandori fish (already difficult to find on any menu) is to spectacular.  This is not hyperbole, its that good.
author: J H.

description:
its kinda weird this place gets reviews as good as it does.  i guess the reason people might like it is because everything here is made in a unique way. but i wouldn't call it amazing. its almost as if the guy who owns it has synesthesia or some kind of taste dyslexia.

Like the chicken tikka masala tastes like its made with pumpkins, and even something as simple as aloo gobi is some sort of twisted mad hatter tea party interpretation of the dish. The service is some of the slowest around.

If you want to eat indian food through a taste babblefish, then come here.
author: christopher a.

description: I was in town and had a MAD craving for good, authentic Indian food. Needless to say, I had high hopes and expectations after reading a plethora of positive reviews for L.K. Well, I was mildly disappointed with the outcome.  Contrary to the reviews my roti and naan orders came out BURNT =(  In all fairness, they were sadly under-staffed that night.  I saw the chef and 2 of his assistants working in the kitchen while ONE WAITER was trying to stay sane (the place was fairly full).  As for the food, it was A-Okay.  Their self-serve, complimentary chai tea was surprisingly good.  Don't bother trying their Mango Lassi...you can definitely taste the mango..just no hint of lassi (hahaha).
author: T. T.

description: I don't know why I haven't written a review before. But after my experience tonight, I really don't have a choice. Lahore is delicious. I've never once been disappointed. This evening I called in an order for pick up and there was a small mishap with my order. The owner gave me an extra naan and a dessert. He is the sweetest man! Bent on making sure all of his customers walk away happy (and full). I love that he is in the kitchen cooking and smiling whenever I stop in. Oh and it's damn affordable! Please go and eat this food. Beware of the crowd!
author: Sarah M.

description:
awesome food, cheapest prices around, and slooooow service.  i know we came on a saturday night and all, but it really did seem like they didn't want us to pay or something (seriously, we asked for the bill twice!)  that said, the food (especially the daal) was great, and i would come again, i would just never come when in a rush!

update: there is a new addition to the staff, which helped incredibly time-wise.  five stars!
author: Jill k.

description: stomach ache: all 4 of us.  It was tasty but all four us felt very odd for 24 hours.
author: Noel J.

description: Hands down the best Indian/Pakistani food I've had.  I loved the lamb, and it's halal! Plus, a friendly owner, free chai, and you can bring your own bottle of wine with no corkage fee.  What's not to love? Well, maybe the service can be a tad slow at times.
author: Cara J.

description: Anything but "Amazing haven like food " would be an insult for this restaurant. I wish I could eat there every day. One thing to Keep in mind is don't go for the there look or the seating arrangements. it looks pretty bad but all of there focus is to provide the best food you would ever it. They do a pretty damm good job at it.
author: Sami S.

description: Outstanding Indian food.  Everything is perfectly spiced: aromatic, filled with flavor, and just enough heat.  Do not come expecting a quick meal, but know that when you can see your Samosa being constructed behind the counter moments before it reaches your table, you will not think twice about investing a bit more of your time for a meal here.
author: L W.

description: A friend took me here the other day. What a surprise! Chilean sea bass in the tandoor -- soft, spicy, delicious, and brought to the table smoking hot (literally!). Totally worth Yelping about. But then you find the place on Yelp, see 300+ reviews for it, and know nobody is going to read this. So fuck it. This is all I'm writing.
author: Cris L.

description: This is my other go to place for Indian (numero uno is Pakwan).  The flavors here are so different than what I have at Pakwan.  It's so fragrant and flavorful.  I order the usual Chicken Tikka Masala, Lamb Biryani, Saag Paneer, and Naan.  Everything tasted so good I even ordered extra Naan to wipe the bowls clean.  The time I've ever tasted something so good and flavorful was when I was in London.  Of course nothing ever beats Indian food in London, BUT this sure comes close to it.  The service here is a little bit slow BUT it is all worth the wait.  They cook everything right on the spot.  Just expect your food to be ready in about 30-40 minutes.  Trust me it's worth the wait.  The chef/ owner of Lahore uses the freshest ingredients.  The fried cheese in the Saag Paneer was cooked just right and the chicken and lamb were not dry at all.  It was tender and soft, just the way they should be.  The only downside of Lahore is that their Naan always tend to come to my table with a TON of oil. It's so much oil that the Naan can have it's own pool party. LOL.  Aside from that, the food is always good here.  Oh just beware, this place is VERY popular so get there early if you want a table and eat at a reasonable time for dinner.  No matter what day of the week it is, it's always busy.
author: Bertie Y.

description:
had dinner here on a friday night with some fun people.  we tried the butter chicken, chicken biryani, chicken vindaloo and the tandoori chicken.  everything was delicious.  the chicken vindaloo had more cilantro and was less creamy than i have had at other places.  i loved it.

the service was a bit slow and they forgot at least one dish but it was a full house and the bill was low so i let it go.  the conversation was scintillating and i'm pretty sure we gave a newly single guy some questionable, but probably effective, dating advice.  sorry, ladies.
author: Seong P.

description: Metal M. hit it the nail on the head. Five stars are not enough.  I have seriously not had any Indian that has compared to this place in S.F..Or in the U.S for that matter! Get the Benghan Eggplant). It is simply amazing. That mediocre bright red Tikka Masala you are used to is brought to life at Lahore..Absolutely to die for!  The slightly scruffy decor and warm smile of the owner gives it the authentic feel of a roadside Pakistani/Indian Dhaba.   Lahore Karahi, the new curry king of S.F.... Bar None.....
author: Tim E.

description:
i want to yelp about it, but sometimes i feel like my yelp doesn't matter when there are already 434 reviews! here goes opinion #435...in the hopes that it helps at least one person out there...

FOOD:~best samosas i ever had! puts other samosas to shame.

~mmm the rice was yummy...perfect compliment to our meat dishes.

~eggplant was great! practically tasted like a meat dish...

~butter chicken had the most delicious sauce..is that cream cheese i tasted?! but the chicken was a little dry...perhaps because it was white meat & i prefer dark.

~mango lassi was yummy...i usually find lassis too thick, so i had mine cut with ice. i felt bad because our lassis were taking forever, then we saw why when a worker returned carrying a bag of ice--oh no, i didn't mean to put them out! but how very very sweeet :)

SERVICE: very kind.

DECOR: plain.

BATHROOM: n/a

OVERALL: would go back, definitely solid & affordable indian food!
author: miss b.

description: I do not get this place or the reviews?  We have been here a few times and each time it gets worse.  Last time we had rancid oil added to our kabobs...  Basically, with so many great Indian spots in town or nearby I say keep moving.
author: J R.

description: The food was pretty damn solid.  The Tandoori fish was one of the best that I've had, and the Karahi Chicken was pretty good as well.  It's not as greasy as other more lower fare Desi options.  The service could've been faster, but given that it was primarily a one-man show, I'll cut him some slack.  Plus, he seemed very nice, so I'll look past that for now.  Enjoy!
author: Chintu R.

description: I like this hole-in-da-wall for numerous reasons.  For one, this place serves up some authentic Indian dishes that are very good and very cheap! Two: No alcohol here, but not to worry - simply bring your own six pack or bottle and enjoy the dining experience even more! I could ramble on and on and on about this place but I've decided to keep this review good and simple - just like Lahore Karahi! Wahoo!
author: Scott G.

description: This is the kind of the restaurant I like.  Good food made by nice people with a sense of pride about what they do. Super cheap and has great service considering there is one waiter. It might take a while but its made to order. If you want fast food go down the street.
author: Stephen G.

description: Came here and had a wonderful time. The owner/host/waiter is really friendly and funny. I asked if they had any beer, got the expected no, and headed out with my date to the liq to grab some brewskie. Came back with a 24oz Becks and he asked if I wanted a wine glass! haha. I like it. The food came out after not too long of a wait and it was great. Both the Korma and Tikka Masala were very good. The naan, however, was really some of the best I have had. Rice was fine, nothing special. The food is damn cheap as well. Bonus! I'll be back here soon.
author: Sven S.

description: Too spicy but delicious!!!!!!!  I go here every time I am in San Fran, usually with a big group of people.  For  approximately 10 dollars per person, we got a range of decent dishes, naan and rice pudding.  And there is always old Indian movies playing on the TV.  I never want to leave.
author: Anu Y.

description: This place redefined Indian/Pakistani food for me.  This is one of those places I never would have found were it not for Yelp.  And thank God I did find it.  It's a small place in the Tenderloin with a one (sometimes two) person staff.  The owner does all the cooking and serving, and he smiles happily the entire time.  He is very modest about his talent and loves hearing compliments about the food he prepares.  The food is seriously off the hook.  Everything he brought to the table was excellent, and just when you think it can't get any better, he serves us mango/banana/pistacio ice cream.  Did I mention he also made the ice cream himself???  Oh, and it's inexpensive, to boot!  I may have found a new addiction...
author: Erica G.

description: I waited a long time to write this review, because I feared that nothing I could write would do this place justice. It's just that good. Thinking about it right now gives me a flashback of the wonderful food we ate. Maybe the best Indian food I have ever eaten, definitely the best in San Francisco. It doesn't look like much, just a little hole-in-the-wall, but looks can be deceiving. Gudoo is a culinary master, a god almost.
author: Dana L.

description: The most fantastic food west of Pakistan! Try the butter chicken with sesame naan, or the goat curry with Afghan naan. Everything is delicious, and perfectly spicy. The cook is the nicest man on the planet--if I were president he would be the White House Chef.
author: Denny S.

description: Not only the best Indian food in the city, but honestly the best I've had period. Most of the establishments I've visited have the ubiquitous lunch buffet, with food sitting out at barely warm temperatures. Decent enough, but nothing to make you crave more. Lahore changes all that. Four of us ordered more food than we could eat, all for about $50. We had two kinds of lamb, the lahore chicken, tandoori fish, mixed vegetables, samosas, 3 kinds of naan, and rice. This was my first time eating fish at an Indian restaurant and now I feel like I've really been missing out. The tandoori fish was easily the best dish and I can't recommend it enough. All of the food is cooked by the owner/chef, so if you are in a rush, don't be. Its all fresh and made to order so, grab some beer from across the street and enjoy yourself bitches!
author: Nicolas H.

description:
I like my Indian restaurants like I like my women: small, cheap, dirty and delicious.

Lahore Karahi bears all the physical characteristics typical of an Indo-Pak restaurant in the Tandoori-loin.  This place has a truly authentic atmosphere.  I almost felt as if I were back in the motherland: eating out of a thali with one hand, cold bottle of Limca in the other.  Mmm... I can taste the snake surprise and the chilled monkey brains even now...

HA HA HA HA HA!  I'm just kidding, you stupid Americans.  We Indians stopped eating that junk ages ago, like in the early 90s.  I mean, when that movie came out it was super embarrassing, so we gave it all up, along with tandoori dog and masala camel vagina.

So what, exactly, can you eat at Lahore Karahi?  I recommend the pakoras, which were outstanding.  The paneer was also quite amazing.  Both had a really subtle, flavorful spiciness that made my tongue cry for mercy and beg for more at the same time.  A few of the dishes are pretty Americanized, which may not be best for a lesson in authenticity.  The cholay was really runny and tasted decidedly different.  Maybe I could grow to like it, but I really enjoy chewing on my chickpeas.  The sesame naan was excellent, but I wasn't a fan of the Afghani naan (Afghani naan, of course, is the new, politically correct name for Kashmiri naan, which, of course, refers to the disputed region straddling the Indo-Pak border; and which, of course, is a terribly impolite topic to bring up between Indians and Pakistanis, even within a forum as seemingly innocuous as a menu, though I'll bet you, dear reader, have precisely no idea how many wars have started over menus; at any rate, I would like to take this opportunity to suggest a new name for our favorite flatbread: LINE OF CONTROL NAAN), which was overly sweet and looked like a flattened fruitcake (oh, the geopolitical irony).  Overall, the food, which comprised the bulk of the judging criteria for this review, earned a well-deserved 4.5 stars on my grading sheet.

I will certainly return should I find myself in the 'Loin and craving solid Indian/Pakistani food.  I urge you to do the same.
author: Rajiv B.

description: Bad service and so so food. I'm not well versed in Indian food, but I didn't like the skewer platter. Homey decor.
author: bill l.

description: The food here is AMAZING. Absolutely AMAZING. The guy who takes your order, cooks your food, brings it to you and checks you out.  He is happy all the time.  You can't help but like him. I think there is a picture of him already on here.  There is no decor, but who notices, because the food is just so INCREDIBLY DELICIOUS and SO FLAVORFUL, you will wish you were a cow with more stomachs so you could just keep eating.  The seating area is small but who cares, because the food is AMAZING. I don't think it was incredibly sanitary, it is in a kinda dangerous neighborhood and I don't think there was any air conditioning but who cares, because the food is AMAZING.  I just cannot emphasize enough how incredibly good the food is--and I am very picky. You order at the counter and then they bring your food to you. You can fix your own drink from the fridge or wait and they will fix it for you.  You can eat out of a paper plate from the counter, but if you don't get one, they bring you a real plate. It is a little weird, the semi-self service, but I think that is because he gets so busy.  The prices are very reasonable.  And again--AMAZING.
author: Artsy X.

description:
Curry unlike any I've ever had before.....and it's awesome.  Minutes after taking my first bite of the Chicken Vindaloo I ordered, the words "Better than Shalimar" were bouncing around in my head...

Halfway through lunch I decided that comparing this place to Shalimar was comparing apples to oranges.  It's a COMPLETELY different style of cooking, but one that kicks ass nonetheless.  Where Shalimar tends to blend their Tiki-Masala sauce to contiguous form, Lahore Karahi's vindaloo included larger, visually discernible bits of whatever was used to spice it up.  Nan breads are the size of salad plates instead of steering wheels, with a whole-wheat taste and texture that's more chewy instead of flaky.  One won't last though lunch...order two if you tend to go through a lot of it.  The chicken used is awesome, and cooked perfectly.  It's all tender chunks of white meat that shear effortlessly under your fork....and no drumsticks.  The rice was interesting too....instead of the usual scooped-from-the-steamer Basmati, the chef seasons it with an odd brown spice that gives it a truly interesting texture and  flavor.

Don't let the neighborhood scare you off....the surrounding area can be iffy, but this stretch of O'Farrell between Hyde and Jones seems to be something of a DMZ that the 'loin's indigenous army of street-urchins steers clear of.

The entire place is a one-man-show, and he's a heck of a nice guy.  I got the usual warning of  "Vindaloo is spicy" that's de-rigour for white boys...and he winced visibly with a smile on his face when I ordered it "extra hot".  Heat-wise, this guy delivers.  It wasn't the cheyenne-type burn you get at most places, but one that comes on slow.  Regardless, halfway through lunch I was sweating bullets....and loving it.

Lahore Karahi is a must-visit for anybody who feels they've done-it-all on the South-Asian food circuit.  It's truly unlike anything else I've ever had, and it's deviation from the norm is a rare example of coming out on top after breaking rank with one's peers.
author: Mike W.

description:
I had not heard of this place before trying it.  I was walking down O'Farrell looking for a place to eat late (after 10:45p) on a weekday night (Lahore is open until 11p).  Mekong Thai -- which I've never tried but have wanted to -- was closed except for takeout.  This was one of the only places open.

My initial impression was that this place is filmy and grimy.  This doesn't necessarily dissuade, as sometimes these hole in the wall places are quite a pleasant surprise.  Additionally, the reviews in the window from Yelp and the newspaper made it seem like a perennial favorite.  Furthermore, I've eaten at numerous grimy places overseas without issue.  There is a difference between grimy and dirty.  This was the former.  Prices were cheap.

Despite the numerous reviews that report lousy service, my experience was diametrically different.  True -- I was the only table when I arrived, but there was such a graciousness about their willingness to accommodate.  There was no "it's almost 11p, please don't eat here."  I was not rushed.  They were happy to serve and happy I was there.  Another couple entered just after 11p, and they were also greeted with warmth and openness instead of disdain and contempt.  It was a most pleasant experience, with my water glass constantly being refilled every time it was empty and always with a smile.
