The waiter even spoke to me about his hometown in Pakistan, its size, and his pride and humility of his origins.  The gentleman who appeared to be the owner spoke to me about other entrees I might enjoy should I return.  If every experience at a restaurant were this positive in terms of service, it would be utopic.  I acknowledge that service may be markedly different during peak times, and this may help to explain the disparity between my experience and those of other reviewers. 

My primary reservation with Lahore Karahi is with the food.  It's really not bad, but I'm confused about all of the five-star reviews this place has received.  The vegetable samosas were served piping hot and not greasy, but the filling was a kind of indistinguishable mush and not evenly cooked.  The tikka masala was thin and had an institutional flavor, as if the sauce itself wasn't prepared in-house but came from a can.  The onion kulcha -- normally one of my favorites -- was not fluffy but rather dense and filled with what appeared to be (by taste) onions that came from a jar (similar to those found in 7/11's hot dog condiment bar).  It is possible that they were chopped in the food processor (which was on the counter and constantly being used -- but I think to blend ingredients together, not necessarily prepare recipes from scratch).

The restaurant has an open kitchen -- not the kind in the chic modern hip places that is the current trend -- but rather as if one is eating in their kitchen.  You see mostly everything.  What I saw, principally, was that a lot of their food comes from cans.  It appeared as if little was fresh.  I don't know, but it makes sense from the way the food tasted, its texture, and quality.  One can typically tell when respectable Indian food is made fresh and in-house.  I'm sorry: this food seemed like something that could be found at the supermarket in the ethnic foods aisle.  This seemed more akin to frozen pizza:  it could never compare to freshly made and tossed dough, homemade sauce, and crispy fresh toppings.  I would be surprised to learn that this kitchen makes its sauces from scratch.  Of the multitude of Indian food I've eaten, this was among the least fresh preparation I've ever encountered.  It wasn't consciously crafted.  That being said, I've had worse.

Quality aside, this place is inexpensive, and may in fact be the cheapest Indian restaurant I've been to outside of India.  Perhaps that is part of its appeal.

This is one restaurant where I think the Yelping community has simply gotten it wrong.  A 3-star review I could understand, but 4.5 stars???  It's unsupportable and frankly irrational.
author: SalsaBoy S.

description:
Hi,
My best friend introduced me to this place several years ago and I look forward to every visit.   We have been going there for lunch nearly every Friday for the last several months so I can strongly attest to the consistency of the high quality of this food.
Guddhu knows us and always takes care of us.
If you like Thai, Chinese, Indo, Pakistani or Indian food then you must try this place out.

Best Dish - Fish(Sea Bass) Tandoori

Pros - Great fresh (halal) food
        - excellent value for money
        - consistency of quality

Cons - its not the most updated interior - the original hole in the wall restaurant.
         - its a really dicey neighborhood and if you can't stand the tenderloin then don't go.
author: Daniel B.

description:
Bengan Bhartha and Saag Paneer. Delicious! Must get.

Still yet to try the Tandoori Fish.
author: Jimmy N.

description: This is my favorite indian restaurant.  I try to eat here whenever i'm in town.  the chicken Tikka masala is the absolute best, a must try for any one trying this restaurant.  A couple of other good dishes that i like are the palak paneer, butter chicken, chicken korma and the tandoori fish.  the food is alway fresh and made to order.  an absolute delight to eat here.  the owner/chef is very friendly and makes a spendid meal.  Keep it up!
author: Jon H.

description:
I hesitate to give this place 5 stars only because the service is horrible.  That being said, I still return to Lahore all the time because the food is amazing and is a great bargain.  The amazing chicken karahi, nan and tandoori fish more than make up for the poor service
This is definitely the best indian/pakistani restaurant in SF and is an amazing bargain.  As long as you go are prepared to wait to wait an hour for your food and repeat your order to the waiter multiple times, it is more than worth the trip.
author: Niraj P.

description: This is the place to go for Indian food if you're not in a rush. You may also want to make sure what they bring out is what you ordered. The service is super slow, but the owner (or manager?) is very friendly as you'll find out when you bring your check up to the register cause you're too impatient to wait any longer. You'll be full and completely satisfied but ready to get out of the Tenderloin. Watch out for the Tenders!
author: Merri K.

description: Do not miss the naan and chicken tikka masala! Only two stars though because I don't think I will return due to the extremely sloooow service. I can get comparable Indian food elsewhere with half the wait time.
author: Nathalie L.

description:
Lahore Karahi represents what I love about SF. You get a guy like Guddu who comes to the US to share his love of authentic Lahore cuisine, and he finds primo TL real estate, and then serves up some hot, fresh and delicious Pakistani fare. It's a simple story of the American dream come true, with Bollywood shaking it's proverbial ass in your face on the overhead TV. 
On a relatively quiet monday night, I was surprised to find this serene sanctum in the otherwise rough and tumble TL.  After grabbing bottles of beer for our table we sat down to some incredibly hot peppers thanks to an overzealous dining companion. 
I highly recommend the Tandoori fish, the garlic naan, sesame naan, vegetable biryani, and ask for raita to quench the heat. If you're at all sensitive to spicy food, let them know because in Pakistan the heat scale is logarithmic. 
Out of the many Pakistani/Indian restaurants in the TL, Lahore Karahi stands on the top of the hill for quality and service.
author: Phil M.

description: The Tenderloin is where you go if you wanna score some crack. There must be some in the food here. Dang yeah!
author: John F.

description: I could not get over how nice the owner was. He was more than patient with my horrid slaughtering of menu items... everything we ordered was fantastic (I highly recommend anything they do with eggplant.)
author: kristin n.

description:
the setting: saturday lunch.  
the menu: butter chicken (order this...you will not be sorry), naan (of course), alor matter, and vegetable biryani (2 of us...we're BIG eaters)
the outcome: pure happiness and a stuffed tummy.
the owner/chef is amazing...so nice.  the decor, not so, but hey, i'm here for the food (thus the 1 less star).  can't wait to come back to try the Tandoori Fish.  this is definitely on the rotation.
author: Sonia C.

description: My new favorite of the Tandoor-loin joints. Cleaner than most and more friendly than the others. Shalimar may have better nan and somebody else might have better Saag Paneer but across the board this place has the righteous goods. Possible caveat: they use more cilantro than most so you cilantro-hating congenital defective unfortunates please take note.
author: patrick g.

description: Lahore has hands down the best Saag in San Francisco.  Their naan is also perfectly fluffy and fresh.  One of the cleanest Indian restaurants I've been in, too!
author: Wendy T.

description: Terrific tasting Indian.  The service was fast and the guys were very kind and friendly.  We had the palak paneer, the butter chicken and the best dal makhani this side of the Imperial.  The prices were terrific and the atmosphere was about what you would expect.  We loved the Bollywood on tv as we ate and enjoyed our beer purchased from across the street.  I was all prepared to name this my new 'loin favorite.    Despite all this goodness, why the low rating you ask???   Minus one star for each panic filled trip to the bathroom at work the next morning.   I checked the health rating online and it is a very respectable 82.   I am not sure what the deal was, but I am in no hurry to experience it again.
author: Matt T.

description: Lahore has taught me how to eat spicy food...i love their dishes. So flavorful and such a bargain.  The only bad thing I have to say is that he puts so much cream in some of the food. I have started ordering ones that dont have the word "creamy" in their description.  Excellent pakora too. Used to be BYOB but not anymore, and that's a shame.
author: maggie c.

description: Four score and seven years ago I walked into Lahore Karahi looking for food. I waited ten million years, created the earth the moon and the sky, and erected an elaborate play structure for my cats. My food has still not arrived, so here I continue to sit and toil, waiting for "Guddu" to pony up and get some Guddamn backup.
author: Nicholas E.

description: we only ate here once while living in SF but it was definitely the best Indian food I've ever had the pleasure of tasting. flavors were outstanding, service was atrocious. it was borderline insane how many times we had to ask for our check (I lost count but close to 4-5) and they were pretty indifferent overall.  the food did win over in this round and I would go back if I had a lot of time on my hands.
author: michella s.

description: Hmm .. My neighbors!! Of course they freakin' ROCK! Gudda always bring us goodies and WE ALWAYS LOVE IT! Honestly, I'm not a big fan of curries and stuff but LAHORE changes that all the time! REAL HOME COOKIN'!!!
author: Frankie L.

description:
The food here is absolutely great curry-house fare but the service is nearly non-existent.

We went here just before the dinner rush on New Year's Eve and as soon as we walked in I was a bit dismayed that most the tables were really messy. However, I knew from the beginning that this was a curry joint in the Tenderloin not an upscale restaurant

The Lamb Vindaloo (often a benchmark in my evaluation of curry houses) was extremely flavorful and the lamb perfectly cooked. However, I ordered it "extra spicy" and it wasn't hot at all. The Aloo Saag was also had great flavor and a rich, creamy texture. The vegatable pakoras were perfectly fried and not at all greasy and the garlic naan was also excellent.

The price is right so I will definitely return if I'm in the area. The only detractor is that the service is awful. Expect to ask for things like silverware, your bill, etc. and don't expect them to honor any special requests. The upside is that this saves you from having to leave a big tip!
author: Aaron S.

description: My favorite Indian food restaurant, hands down. Its true, I've never actually been to India but I've eaten at Indian neighborhood restaurants in New York and London and this place still holds the number 1 place in my heart. Everything is good and it is SO cheap! They also let you bring in beer from outside vendors since they don't have a liquor license. Casual, friendly, delicious, cheap. What more could you want!?
author: Natali M.

description: I love Gudoo.  He thought that I was only 22 years old.  His Aloo Ghobi is out of this world.  His nan is fresh and right out of the oven.  He always gives me a free dessert.  Heaven.
author: Joanna S.

description: hmmmm...i love Indian...and after reading the rave reviews on here, I decided to make a trip over to the 'Loin and eat at Lahore Karahi. I have to say, I was a a little disappointed! Maybe I ordered the wrong things! I ordered a lamb dish, and a chicken dish. I found the texture of both the meats to be dry, and not all that tasty. I did however order the fried cheese appetizer, and it was good. Although the prices are unbeatable, I don't think I'd go back anytime soon.
author: Kevin D.

description:
when i was planning out my conference trip to sf, i realized that it's been months since i had quality indian and that sf is the place to fulfill my indian food craving.

i came here, based on yelp reviews, to catch up with a good friend over some chicken saag and baigan bharta.  medium spice was perfect heat and full of flavor (was that cardamon in the saag?)  naan was fresh out of the oven and perfect was to sponge up the saag and eggplant that did not disappoint.  the baigan bharta was different than what i have had in the past, this one had much more spice, garlic and onions.  the afghani naan was a perfect end to our lunch chat- fruit and cheese baked into the middle of fresh naan. 

service is kind, but the kitchen can be slow if the restaurant is full.  the food took quite a while.  which was okay this one time, since we had a lot of catching up to do.
author: Karen Y.

description: I have been to almost all the other places and this is undobtedly the best Pakistani/Indian place in the city. "Guddu" owner, chef of this place knows me n my friends very well now n talk to us very friendly and its really interesting how he manages that place so clean with such a little help when he s cooking, taking checks n also taking orders sometimes. Try his Tandoori Fish, Lamb Kheema (in the menu you'll see Lamb-Alu kheema I always ask him to make it without Alu aka potatoes) n naan n garlic naan o n last but not the least Rice Pudding (best rice pudding I have ever had n very similar to what you get in India @my house)
author: Vik P.

description: A small but quaint restaurant.  This is the best Pakistani food I've had outside of Chicago's Devon Avenue district. Eat up.
author: Devon A.

description: I live very close to this place and, being a big fan of Indian food, go here alot. It is awesome, not too expensive, and has a very kind waiter who makes us feel welcome and even gave us a bunch of free stuff for my birthday! The free Chai tea is delicious as is every dish I've ever tried here, which is many. It can get a little crowded sometimes, which puts a strain on said waiter, but even then the service is excellent. I literally have no complaints and can't wait to return.
author: Jesse R.

description:
Chicken Korma....mmmmm
Spinach with cheese....mmmmm
Eggplant with cream sauce....mmmmmm even more
regular naan, onion naan, garlic naan.....Mmmmmm!!!

I "mmmmmm" so many times my friend told me to stop MMMmmm-ing!  
My other friend said it was like eating baby food...well that was the best damn baby food I ever had.  The texture does resemble baby food since it is nice and chunky.   I can't describe the food any better than that.   It's baby food and a lot of "MMmmms"  Anyways, they rarely ever refill water, but like some indian places, this joint is 'self service'.  So be the cool and polite guy by walking up and grabing the pitcher to  fill all your buddies up with some H2O.  You'll probably need it if you order spicy foods.  They also have indian tea which is quite unique too.  Ok one last thing before I post this.

MMMMMmmmmmmmmm!!!!!  *breaths in* Mmmmmmm!! 
Ahhhh my belly is happy.
author: Nelson W.

description: Visited Lahore on a Friday with a girlfriend.  We were lucky to grab a table before the crowd packed the place!  We ordered vegetable samosa, tandoori fish (caution to the oil spatters as it arrives on a sizzling iron platter), chicken tikka masala,  and two garlic/onion naans.  My girlfriend and I stuffed our faces until capacity and still had leftovers to divvy up.  We ended up walking the nearby shops in downtown to let the food digest and all I could think about was looking for a fork to finish up my leftovers!  The food was amazing and I would definitely come back and order the same thing!
author: Lisa C.

description: Lahore is amazing.  I love how flexible Guddu is in preparing whatever it is you want - & if you like spicy, he will make you the best spicy Dal Masala you have ever had.  He and his staff are friendly and Fast.  Whether eating in or taking out, I highly recommend this wonderful TL gem.
author: Deb Doran D.

description: Superb tandoori fish; absolutely top notch! The quality of the fish completely compensated for the fact that they didn't bring my mum the tandoori mixed grill she ordered (apparently it would take 45 minutes, so they brought her a mixed vegetable curry instead... eh?!). Will definitely go back again. :D
author: Amelia I.

description: This is the first Indian restaurant where I would like to try everything on the menu. I tried to get the fried potato patty appetizer but the chef insisted the samosas were worth it, and he was right. Where else does the man cooking your meal also make sure you're going to enjoy it? Everything was what I wanted for lunch and more. I love it when I'm satisfied.
author: Kim G.

description: I hate to do this cause i used to be a big fan of Lahore Karahi i think they have the best and most tastiest authentic Indian food around and there naan is to die for, the guy who owns the place cracks me up good guy but cheap he wont hire any help he is the owner,cook,waiter,bus boy,etc and if there was valet parking he would probably do that as well the guy is litterly taking your order turning around and Manning the stove and running to a table and clearing it off refilling waters all at the same time dew too that sometimes you have to wait a while for your food, but the last time a went was the last time a went I've said before in my previous reviews I have a zero tolerance for roaches and this place is full of them i just never notice like I said i hate to rag on this place but maybe if he cleans up his act and restaurant I might consider going back.
author: Nader F.

description: How dare Lahore be closed on Mondays! Although the economy has us eating at home more often, this is the one weekly pit stop I refuse to give up. There's always a line, and with good reason - the food is phenomenal, reasonable and then there's the BYOB part of the deal. (And conveniently, there's a liquor store just next door.) The owner/chef "Guddu" is always in good spirits and his recommendations are always spot-on. He told us to try his special garbanzo bean blend and the catfish tandoori and both are in rotation on our weekly Indian pig-out.
author: Janine K.

description:
Tried this place for lunch today for the first time. The service was very slow even though there was just one other table. The people at the other table got their food and were finished before ours even all arrived. The waiter did give us a free nan I guess as an apology although he never actually explained or apologized for the food taking so long.

We ordered butter chicken, sag paneer, plain nan and I got a sweet lassi. The sweet lassi had a very strange sharp sour taste like no other lassi I've ever had before. I couldn't drink it. The butter chicken was very bland although no place in SF seems to know how to do butter chicken. The sag paneer had a sweetish taste that I didn't really like although it was okay otherwise. The nan was fine.

I would'nt go back. Overall this was one of the most mediocre Indian places I've tried in SF. At least the prices were cheap though.
author: Kristin B.

description: I don't usually stray far from tikka masala, so I was excited to have someone more knowledgeable than me ordering this time. The saag paneer was excellent. The karahi and biryani chicken were also very tasty. The daal... enh, seemed boring in comparison to everything else. Service was also a bit... odd. The couple times we tried to ask a question, the waiter looked at us blankly, mumbled "I'll give you more time" and shuffled off without offering an answer. He also asked us to leave right after we paid. I guess to make room for other diners? But the place didn't seem that busy. Weird. In any case, the price was right, and the food was yummy. Just wish I didn' thave to walk through the TL to get there.
author: Lorin M.

description:
the best indian in SF!  i've been to indian oven, chutney, shalimar, and pakwan and i think lahore karahi is the best!  this place is tiny, but def worth a trip to the 'loin for some tasty indian cuisine.  this place doesn't have great ambiance, just really great food.  :)  

the lahore chicken is my fav dish so far, lots of fresh corriander (aka cilantro) and diced green chili peppers.  YUM!  the chicken tikka, choley, and saag paneer were all excellent.
author: Wendy S.

description: Yeah for real Pakistani food! I am extremely picky about Indian and Pakistani food, and this place is incredible. Serious flavors and complete authenticity.
author: Sara W.

description: Truly excellent food, and very reasonable prices.  As with many Pakistani Indian restaurants, dinner can be very reasonable since they allow you to bring in your own alcoholic beverages without a corkage fee.  Their truly interesting (and I would presume, regional)  take on Saag Paneer is absolutely fantastic.   The chef is apparently a one man show, and quite skilled at his art.
author: Jaime R.

description:
So this experience made me realize the limitations of a rating system purely by user review cos this place actually has a lot of good reviews which is why I tried it. But frankly it was a disaster and embarrassing to take someone to. Reminded me of a python sketch (cheese shop:)
In chronological order:
Its a bit of a dump but no matter, I can maybe get in touch with my young, days of enjoying roughing it in funky places - as long as the food impresses.
No wine or beer, fine except nor can you bring any in, even if you pay corkage, which frankly for a curry house is an immediate removal of a star in my book.
 Menu, for me a bit limited but they had a bunch of vegetarian dishes that I personally wasn't that interested in.
Popadoms while we take in the menu? Dont have them any more.
OK, we ordered: Lamb vindaloo,(not too crazy hot)  tandoori chicken leg, Chicken Tikka masala, lime pickle, garlic and Sesame nan.
The Tandoori chicken was best. Sizzling hot, tasty dry marinade though I doubt it ever saw a tandoori oven. The lamb Vindaloo was beef, I had asked for not too hot but it came out completely emasculated -possibly my fault-should have said nothing but I was thinking of an English vindaloo heat level. It was also just kind of granular texture sauce with a mainly stock cube kind of taste. not at all good. Tikka masala was OKish but probably on a par with the worst I've had, again with a granular texture, sauce with no really interesting flavor notes and it was pepper hot. Hotter than the vindaloo, which is not to style. 
The Nans were disappointing. They look like flat crust pizza in shape and texture. Confirming no tandoori oven but even so, just flat like a chapati. Flavor was OK. Instead of lime pickle, we got mango chutney - whatever at this stage. 
When the bill came I was curious if they thought I ordered beef but no, Lamb Vindaloo was stated so I couldn't let that pass entirely and told the kid waiter. He vehemently insisted not and that beef wouldn't be allowed in the restaurant for apparently religious dietary reasons which was odd since it is a Pakistani restaurant and why would you expect it to be strictly Hindu? But mostly it was just funny how this 18 year old kid was insisting to this lamb loving 50 year old that we couldn't tell the difference. I believe he believed it was Lamb but that hardly excuses such a basic error/apparent deception. Good job I wasn't Hindu!  So why all these good reviews? I think it must be a large volume of younger clientele that really don't know or have had, any better. The flavor and prep of the food just wasn't fresh and vibrant with the exciting spicy notes this cuisine can offer. My date asked why we hadn't gone to Dosa again which is southern Indian menu but several orders of magnitude better than Lahore Karahi.
author: Mark W.

description:
Hooray for my first review!  So take this with a grain of salt.  This is so far my favorite Indian restaurant to go to.  To put it in perspective for some of you, I have been to 6 different places in the city and I know there are way more out here.  But of these 6, the food here was the best especially for its price.

The food was the right amount of spicy for me (maybe a little more since we asked for mild) and it was flavorful too.  Unlike other Indian restaurants, the portions of meat in their dishes are pretty decent.  And I really like their mango drink.

The service can be pretty bad.  I think the waiter thinks he can be rude, because he knows there are 5 other parties waiting out the door to take our seats.  The place is also really cramped where the back of my chair was touching the back of the other table's chair (which was kind of annoying since it was some hyperactive kid behind me).  

Overall, I am very happy with this place.  I would definitely go back again.
author: A W.

description:
OK now I had to change my review.  I have been there twice, but the second time was even worse than the first time.  

I had an impression that this chef does not know how to cook Indian food by picking right amount of spices mixed well.  

I had Chicken Tikka Masala and I seriously doubted why so many Yelpers love this place - it tasted like wrong spice mixes, and just made the flavor "simple" so that more people will accept it even if they are not familiar with Indian food.  This curry tasted so horrible that I did not even want to finish - I wonder what makes it "creamy" but NO, that's NOT curry!!!  That is not Tikka Masala!!!  

This may sound arrogant but I just do not think it is real Indian/Pakistani food.

Lassi was way too sweet although the server mixed with water before bringing it to me.  

The first time I had Lamb Vindaloo but this was not good either - it just below being OK, it tasted too sour for some reason.  

Their naans are certainly OK, could be better than other places but for me, not better than Shalimar's one.  It may be better than Pakwan's naan though.  But my garlic naan should be simpler than naan + garlic + lots of spice mixes.  I just want naan + garlic, maybe a hint of cilantro.  

So I don't know - it is possible that I went there on bad days.  Some people talk good things about their Tandori, so I may give them a last chance - but so far, no I did not like it.
author: T T.

description: I ate here last year after reading a great review on SFgate, and I have to apologize for taking so long to let folks know that this is some damn good Indi-pak food.  It's also spicy enough for my blood, which is sssstttt hot.  I really need to go back- soon.  It is the TL in so many ways.  Why are all of the best places to eat in the TL?  I guess Tranny gals have to eat well too.
author: Andre S.

description:
OK - five star food, two star decor.  Imagine an Indian/Pakistani taco truck - amazing authentic food, but not quite a restaurant.  But, you're there for the food, and the food is tremendous!  Big servings, authentic dishes, cheap prices, and amazing value.

When we were there, it was only two people running the joint, one cooking, the other doing EVERYTHING else.  Quick service, friendly recommendations, and the only complaint is they are too far away from my office to go to regularly.
author: David G.

description: When I'm craving Indian (Pakistani, whatever) grub I come here. You get some spicy bang for your buck and the owner is nice too. There's better naan at other places. There's better service at other places. But this might be my favority Indianish place in town.
author: Tim K.

description: Before this place, I didn't even like Indian food. Now I know what I was missing.   Service can be pretty slow when its busy, but just relax and enjoy the Bollywood films.
author: Sam P.

description:
i went to lahore kahari for the birthday party of fellow yelper andrew k., who i imagine is getting the shakes while guddu is on vacation this month, he frequents the place so much. they essentially closed down the restaurant for him, and i'm sure they weren't disappointed, since like 50 people showed up to throw down for andrew. 

the food is outstanding. i would be a happy camper if someone filled a bathtub with their saag ghost and just gave me a spoon. light and fluffy naan, cool and creamy raita, and spicy but flavorful curries. obviously, since andrew is a regular and brought them 50 new customers, they treated us like kings, but i suspect they would do the same even if you didn't bring an enormous entourage. 

hands down the best indian i've had since i arrived in the bay area.
author: Kris G.

description:
the gentleman serving us [i'm thinking he was the owner] was very nice and helpful as to recommending dishes.  that evening they were out of samosas and paneer, but he tried to accommodate my veggie needs.

we asked for spicy, and they are serious about their heat.  i think that we were unprepared for this... thinking we could handle it.  although the food was tasty, it was kind of hard to enjoy because the flavor was too hot.

we both ordered tikka masala dishes.  her's prawn, and mine a veggie one [since they didn't have paneer].  although the flavor was tasty, it was not the tikka masala sauce that we expected.  it was a little sweet, more of an orange color.  and not that tomato/cream sauce that we had anticipated.

we shared the mixed daal dish that was good.  i enjoyed the naan that was cooked to perfection.  not too doughy, crispy on the outside.  yummmm!  

i like the joint.  you feel like you're eating at someones house.  very personable and homey!   next time i'll have to ask for less heat...thinking that we could handle it and all, i guess we weren't ready!
author: Sheri N.

description: Thank you, Yelp!  Went to a show at the Great American Music Hall last week and relied on Yelp for a pre-show dinner recommendation.  Me and my party couldn't of been happier with Lahore Karahi.  De-lish!  Everything we ordered was fantastic-- I especially loved the eggplant.  They take their time preparing the food, but it is definitely worth the wait.
author: Mara H.

description: Lahore Karahi still keeps blowing my mind. I love the owner - look pathetic (i.e., hungover) and he'll give you free rice pudding! He has a smile plastered on his face, I swear.
author: Brittany L.

description: So on the walk over from my boyfriends place to LaHore, I was slightly uneasy..I thought to myself Indian food in the TL? No thanks. As we approached the restaurant I felt even more uneasy, it kinda resembled a shack in the TL. Anyways once we entered I initially noticed how packed this place was, nothing special about the inside, no decorations everything is very simple, not even nice dishes. We ordered the food, an eggplant dish, chicken tikka and plain naan. The food was delicious and so affordable! The only thing I was disappointed with was that they ran out of samosas but the waiter who was incredible nice recommended another appetizer and it was just as tasty as the entrees. Oh and they don't serve alcohol however you can run to the liquor store and bring it in (they dont charge for any corking or alcohol fees).
author: Eva C.

description: Wonderful food.  The owner is also the chef as well as the waiter. Service is not quick, so don't go in a rush. And make sure to ask for recommendations. Evidently the chef creates some specials from the Punjab region where he is from, but they aren't on the menu.  Very reasonably priced as well.  We had a spinach and chicken dish, a cauliflower dish, garbanzo beans and naan. Everything was super.  BYOB.  Yum.
author: Tristan C.

description: Where else can you get tandoori sea bass? With rotis not just the usual naan? And this isn't wimpy curry, I requested "garam" spicy so he knew I wasn't a wuss. It's not senseless heat, you can actually see the ingredients and taste all of the flavors distinct and intact. The aloo gobi still tasted like fresh potato and cauliflower and it wasn't drowning in cream. (Why do they do that in the US? They don't in India). The owner-chef Guddu is very hospitable and makes excellent suggestions -Chikkar Cholay (garbanzo beans). We didn't wait long, our service on a Saturday afternoon was perfectly acceptable and frendly. This where I'll be going for Indian for the foreseeable future unless I'm crossing the bridge for Vic's.
author: Brandon R.

description: Fantastic.  The food was a bit too good, a mid-meal induced food coma.  Service was decent and every table was booked.  We ordered chicken tikka masala, and a couple of different na'ans...and wow we were full till the next morning!  Even the chai tea over in the corner was great.  The only thing that kinda sucked was that the tea ran out after our first glasses, and the people working there are so busy that they didn't either notice or bother to make more.  Oh and yeah the neighborhood is pretty sketch, so two girls going there alone on a Saturday night was uhh interesting.
author: Meredith N.

description: The best Pakistani restaurant I've been to in the Bay Area. My fav is the tandoori fish but most of the dishes are pretty good. Make sure you specify spice levels though :)
author: Zeenat U.

description: Definitely some of the best Indian food I've had! Very flavorful and rich and real spicy if you want it!  Very good naan, excellent rice and plentiful servings.  Friendly and easy to order take out from.  I'll be returning soon to sample some of the other menu items.
author: Derek D.

description:
best. funking. indian. food.... ever!!!!

i always always always get something with spinach, and i'm not even really into cooked spinach!
the garlic naan is delicious! 
kulfi cubes? yes please!
special non-menu dishes, funk yeah!

don't expect a quick meal though, when there's only one chef [the owner] things take a little longer, but it's so worth it! 

eat here. and often!
author: Tara A.

description: cheap good naan. curry tasted good with rite amount of spice. the curry was a bit expensive that it also didnt come with rice....we busted our own table and waited 1hr for our food.
author: Norman W.

description: I'm so glad this place is thriving in a difficult corner of the TL. The food is spicy, cheap and wonderfully fragrant. I love the butter chicken and naan bread, could eat it every day if I didn't worry about my cholesterol. The chef/owner is always smiling and friendly despite a busy atmosphere. I call in my order to avoid a long wait...though I have waited 10-15 minutes. All is forgiven after the first bite.
author: Edward L.

description: After recently moving to San Francisco, I consulted Yelp for the best Indian around and it definitely delivered.  A Sunday dinner for two around 6 PM seemed to totally solve what I expected to be terrible service.  It turned out that not only were we in an out in less than an hour but we were given personal recommendations.  The taste of the food itself was stellar.  Unfortunately, it wasn't what I imagined because I was expecting nothing less than exactly what I would have at other Indian places that I would frequent in Cincinnati.  So with the understanding that all Indian food can so easily vary I had to say that great service plus great food equals love.
author: Adam S.

description:
I ordered the following dishes:
The lamb roti,  which was too hard and too dry.  It was not tasty at all.  We do not enjoy this dish.  Perhaps this restaurant is better known for its other dishes.
Tandoori fish: a dry iron plate.  Also too dry.  There was some flavor, but overall the dish was too dry.  Where is the juice, the sauce, the flavor?
Lamb Vindalo:  This curry is OK.  Perhaps we should have just ordered curry.  It seems like everybody else ordered curry.  I would try this restaurant again, but next time I would just order the curry.
The good thing about this restaurant is that the food is cheap.

A lot of people were ordering to-go.  This restaurant seems to have a lot of business. I am sure that the recession is not hurting this business much.  If you were to wait, you would have to wait 15 minutes or so.  The seating is very cozy because the place is very small.

Actually, I really want to give this restaurant another try.  I probably just ordered stuff that was incompatible with my taste palette, which are the dry iron board dishes.  Their other stuff may be better for me, like curry.
author: Y E.

description: Cheap, delicious, flavorful Indian and Pakistani food. Way better than Pakwan, if you've been there. I love this place and it's great for a small dinner gathering. You can definitely spend about $10/person and be extremely well-fed.
author: Natasha F.

description:
I had the fish tandori, which was not overly red from tandori paste, I felt the flavors were wonderfully pungent. The savory aroma from these spices steamed the area. And just as I was in a deep concentration enjoying the flavorful meal, the naan arrived, it was fresh, made to order, and had a texture that was slightly crispy on the outside and ever so moist inside. The rice was also flavorful and tender, it had some brown pieces inside which I didn't eat because I thought it could be beef, but whatever it was seemed to give the rice a buttery flavor.
See a video of the place @ http://sf-lunch.com/2008/03/24/lahore-karahi/
author: SF Luncher z.

description: I thought it was good, but nothing to be brag about. All homemade. The garlic naan is good and the lamb saag is fresh although needed more taste. The food is cheap and good, the owner is friendly, but seriously, the food could be better! But, hubby likes it a lot. So, I guess, we are coming back for more.
author: Daisy S.

description:
The food here is off the charts, the service I'm afraid is awful. You need be prepared to eat at least an hour after you order. The owner insists on making the food himself which means there is no fast turn-around time. 

The chicken karahi is particularly tasty. And the chai is quite good.
author: Faisal G.

description: This place was just okay for me. Although I did read about its slow service from other posters, it was just painfully sooooooooo sloooow. As for food, I say I had better from other TL establishment. We tried butter chicken (good but it did not resemble butter chicken at all. I'd have liked it more if I was not expecting creamy, sinful butter chicken), bengan bartha (okay dish but lacking the smokey eggplant flavor I usually enjoy), tandoori chicken (good but not great. Much better version could be had in Punjab on Eddy) and naan. Probably won't return to Lahore Karachi anytime soon when there are so many other Indian/Pakistani restaurants in the neighborhood.
author: Yuko K.

description: My new fav. "desi" joint.  The food at this place is awesome- authentic, not greasy...in my books a winning combination :)  It takes a little longer to get your food here, but the quality is undoubtedly better. The guy with the mustache (owner I believe) is very pleasant, and that make me want to support him that much more.  Check it out and decide for yourself.
author: Vivek N.

description: Stop forgetting to give me my chutney! Non mais! Other than that 5 stars because it truly is as good as it gets.
author: Elsa T.

description: All I have to say, is that this place is the best Indian/Pakastani food I've had in San Fran. I mean this dude (Gudu) does most of the stuff himself. Everything is great, but the one that gets me, is the chicken vindaloo. I mean it is the best I have ever had anywhere in the world that serves thus dish out of the countries thar I have been to. this is. Good get in and get out spot although some jerks come in with like 8 people take over half the place and have no courtesy of other people waiting (and Gudu the owner loosing out on money), but other than that it's perfect btween the bollywood music and movies playing and Indians and Pakastanian laughing and enjoying there food and of course it's byob! The food here is made straight up with love!
author: Jaimito R.

description:
We went here on 09/12/2009, and as another reviewer mentioned, the service was extremely slow and in a disarray. We drove 50 miles just for the restaurant and none of us were satisfied at the end of the day. 
Will not go back to this place.
author: Nandhini S.

description:
You go for the food, not the scrappy decor, not the scarce service, not the sketchy location.  But the latter three sure add to the charm of Lahore.  

We love South Asian food (the spicier the better).  Lahore comes through every single time.  

But this is NOT a fancy restaurant, so don't go expecting what you would at a fancy restaurant.
author: J K.

description: This place had good reviews and certainly the food was pretty good, but I wasn't blown away. I thought it was better than, say, Little Delhi, but not as enjoyable as some of the Indian restaurants in Sunnyvale. Perhaps we went there too late (around 8pm), because the restaurant was practically empty, and the rice that we got seemed to be scraped from the bottom of the pot. Still, I wouldn't say the food was bad. Pretty good, just not super good.
author: John C.

description:
Originally found Lahore Karahi by mistake in the rain when we were unable to find another restaurant...what a find! Since then, I always make it a point to make a trip here even though the Loin is not the best place to be at in the evening. Though they usually have at least 5 groups ahead of us and at least a half-hour wait for food, the food has usually been spot on great and well worth the wait!  What I like about Guddu (the owner) is that he tastes his sauces and knows what they taste like before sending them to his guests.

By far, one of the best Indian-Pakistani places in the bay area! Go here!
author: Ben S.

description: Great Indian dive in the 'loin. Very tasty.
author: Chris S.

description: This is the only restaurant I have ever been to that I had to wait an hour for my food and still wanted to hug the guy when I left because the food was so good!
author: Maureen S.

description: Food is amazing, the wait was not. I knocked off a star because they didn't have a list of who came first, and we had to fight it out amongst ourselves out front. Granted, you know a place is good when there are 5 parties waiting outside for 45+ minutes in the freezing ghetto air!!
author: K. C.

description:
*update july 2007. this time, i came back with bf and a friend. without so many drinks in my system and with a heightened sense of culinary awareness after a viewing of ratatouille, i felt like the food was all laced with this weird sweetness. hmm. maybe it's not good after ingesting a ton of movie theatre popcorn. also, my friend asked for some water, and the waiter got a bit defensive, and throughout the meal responded by coming up and asking to refill his water glass about every five minutes - being overattentive, in a passive aggressive kinda way. hmm. i'll come back but i've dropped them a star. 

original review:

i've been wanting to go here for a year, and never found a good reason. it was the perfect counterpoint to cocktails at bourbon and branch. right up the street, far cheaper and less pretentious. 

the quality of the food here rivaled some of the better pakistani-indian restaurants i've dined at in london and nyc  - we ordered the usual suspects - chicken tikka masala, bengan bhartha, saag paneer, papadum, and fresh sesame naan. 

i soo cannot wait to go back and try more of their food!
author: Winter R.

description:
The tandori fish was AMAZING!!!  It is worth checking out for that dish alone.  However, the rest of the food we ordered (Chicken Korma, Lamb Massala) was delicious as well.  I loved that the chef asked me how spicy I wanted each of our dishes.  It is great that every patron can have the dishes adjusted to their taste buds.  We went with spicy and it was great.  

The owner/chef was super nice.  We will definitely be back (and next time with some beer)!
author: Tammy S.

description: Pity the fool I am for not trying this place earlier. Last time I lived in the TL, Naan and Curry was the cat's pajamas, but methinks this the spot now. The service was a bit slow, but our meals didn't disappoint. I actually liked Pakwan's lamb biryani better than this place, but the spinach tofu (sang paneer?) was way better, i also liked the layout of this restaurant too.
author: wayne s.

description:
Yes. Go there. Eat there. Enjoy it. Best Indian food in town that I had.

Very well done, bravo!
author: Rahul T.

description:
Dishoom baby! Haven't had Indian food this good since I was fed through an umbilical cord!

So, because I actually care about where you eat, and instead of brandishing loud opinions, I'm only writing this glowing review after my 5th visit. Every time, it's been the same. Dishoom. That's all I can say.

It's Indian food like its supposed to be. Slow, unconcerned about presentation, oblivious of timeliness (have you heard of IST - Indian Standard Time?), and overwhelmingly flavorful.

All the naans and kulchas are good, everything is made to order - none of last nights mulch heated into a buffet. All the veggie dishes are great, but I have to admit partiality to the Karahi chicken and the Lamb Boti kebab. You really can't go wrong, though. The paneers are bomb.

The man behind the counter is a kind, simple, honest man whom I've had the pleasure of interacting with in Punjabi, a language he's much more comfortable in. He feeds his friends, who come in regularly, but his smile is the same for every one of his customers. 

DISHOOM, BABY!
author: Ashwin S.

description:
A friend of mine kept talking about this place, saying it was the best Indian in the city. So one day, when another friend and I were in the mood for Indian, we went. We knew it was in a shady area but we didn't let that stop us - we wanted to give the Tender a chance. And a chance we gave it...and Lahore took it away. Very, very quickly. We order two chicken plates and rice. The chicken was decent, not amazing, but ok. But the rice...oh, the rice. Granted, it's Indian, so you have trouble deciphering what you are eating anyway - but there was one easily recognizable thing in our rice - a dead beetle, antlers and legs and whatever all hanging out and chilling, right where I had grabbed a spoonful. Thank God, I didn't look at it because I would have had a fit and ran out of the place - my friend found it and went to show the owner, who acted like a cooked beetle in rice was nothing new. (Maybe it was part of the special seasoning...?) He just took the plate, and ordered us a new one (umm..which we declined, thanks). At least we were courteous - we didn't walk out, but politely finished our mediocre chicken, paid our bill, and left.

I mean, maybe we were unique. Because as we sat there, groups started walking in with their own bottles of beer and wine, laughing, devouring food, acting like this place was *the* hippest spot in town. So maybe, somewhere hiding in the rice with a beetle, we missed something about the place...but I don't think we are ever going back to find out.
author: Stacey A.

description:
this is my favorite place in the city for indian/pakistani food.  now, which is it.. indian or pakistani?  i admit i am still a tad ignorant about indian/pakistani food, but all i know so far is that i love it, especially at this place.

i'm not sure what i'd recommend.  seems like everything that i've tried so far has been excellent.  i was just there yesterday... had the chicken saag, potato naan (i think it's called aloo paratha on the menu) and the vegetable biryani.  in the past i've also had the lamb korma, saag gosht, and galoo gobhi  BYOB and cheap.
author: Christy I.

description:
it needs to be said that i only got a yelp account to rave about one item on this menu.

needless to say, this is some of the best indian food i've had... but the best part is the item that is NOT on the menu... a secret item, if you will.

CHEESY NAAN.

the waiter was a darling and kept insisting that we broaden our naan-horizons and try something that he said was special for his special guests. it was to die for and i've been back twice solely for this order. your tastebuds will be forever grateful. various types of  naan have been known to bow down to this one.

le enjoy!
author: Coco E.

description: This place is literally the best Pakistani/Indian joint in San Francisco, and perhaps the Bay Area.  Guddu is the chef, and he personally prepares everything himself, and not only is he a wonderful cook, but a lovely gentleman that takes pride in serving the finest dhaba food anywhere.  Make sure to try the Tandoori Fish, it is a house specialty.
author: Vivek A.

description:
Lahore Karahi simply rocks. Guddu bhai is simply great in dishing out tasty Indian fares. I would highly recommend Tandoori Fish and Chicken Koorma for spice fans. Try asking Guddu for the specials- he is a genius and he tries making new items not found in his regular menu.
The service is slow but its worth the wait because he cooks everyhting fresh and is not stale stuff that likes of Shalimar, Pakwaan, Nan and Curry and chutney dish out. Guddu is generous with his proportions too.  To top it all he is the freindliest guy and I have been to his place more than 50 times and I have never seen him anything but jolly.  He always has customer satisfaction as his motto and I have seen him bend his back even if it means customers eats on house. He has always been generous with the free delicious treats at end. Try his mango kulfi - its mind blowing. His tea though his very milky but very tasty and flavorful.
Malik the only server though slow due to health reasons- Guddu has taken kind interest in helping Malik to good health. I am impressed by his good character and his kindness to help a person from his country- Pakistan. Lot said- the ambience is ok but its definitely much cleaner than Shalimar and Pakwaan. If you seen the rest room of Shalimar and Pakwaan you will simply faint. LK's rest room is much cleaner.
author: Ashish M.

description: One of the best places for Indian food.thanks to Marcelo and Guillermo for taking me to Lahore karahi.Ever single dishes are different in taste,so Delicious,makes you eat more but you never feel full.
author: Hasan A.

description: This is by far the BEST Indian Food restaurant in SF!  Be ready to make your own call on the sitting, serving situation.  Sometimes it's pitchin in for help.  Go on the earlier side and it's much faster.  ALWAYS worth the wait though!  BEST BEST BEST!
author: Jester Swink J.

description: And, just a day after I was told they only do take out, plenty of people were spotted inside enjoying their dinners....WTF.
author: Laura C.

description:
Very flavorful north Indian food at a reasonable price The flavor is really intense. I am a vegetarian and can therefore comment only on the vege stuff. Even though the menu items are the same as any north Indian restaurant, the taste is many times superior than the traditional indian restaurants; throw in the fact that this restaurant is very reasonable and it suddenly looks very attractive.
The ambience/setting could use a little updating, personally it doesn't bother me. The owner cooks all the food himself and is very cordial kind of a fellow. I like Lahore much more than Shalimar or the place across.
author: Murli R.

description: This place is amazing if you come in on the right night.  I've been here on 5 different occasions and was disappointed once because they were training a new cook.  It makes me hesitant to go back but regardless, this review still warrants 4 stars because overall the food is great for the price.   Two words that are a little bit of spicy sizzling heaven: Tandori Fish.  OMG, I mean, I have no idea what they do to the fish but its unlike anything I've ever had.  The flavor is so different and the texture is perfect.  ALSO, the owner is the shizz.  He's so cool.
author: Al N.

description:
best indian in the city. 
okay, but get real, its actually pakistani. i did my fair share of eatin during my stay in india and never had any of what lahore was cookin up. a great eye for keepin the flavors a little unconventional, fresh, not just sauce and meat slapped together. 
and last time i walked out thinkin I had it all figured out:
"So that was coconut in the such and so curry right?"
"No, pistachio actually."
"Shit really? Okay, you put some banana in your potato naan right??"
"Nope."
"shit."
author: Jeremi M.

description: Thanks yelpers! (and chowhound...) discovered this place before a trek to the 'loin to explore more indian food options. Definitely a keeper. small place, really good food. would return.
author: Margie L.

description:
I am sorry my love, I was weak. I was tempted by something new, I should have learned by now. It seemed so promising, so adventurous, so exciting. I couldnt help myself, I needed a break, I thought I'd found something worth risking it all for. All my friends told me I was stupid, reckless and naive, they were right. I realize that now. I regret it so much. Forgive me. 

Chutney, I will never do it again.

Yours forever.
author: Maggie X.

description:
First off, the water we were served had a mosquito floating in it.  Yes, a mosquito.

The Naan was extremely burnt, completely black and charred.  Both curry dishes had human hairs poking out of them.  The service was practically non-existent - it took about 45 minutes to receive our food.  Almost no one else was in the restaurant, too. 

What went wrong? Well, the whole time the single chef was just talking to some friend of his, and he was extremely distracted.  Everyone in the restaurant stared at the kitchen, waiting for their food.   Both waiters 
took off almost immediately after we sat down.  I guess you get what you pay for - the bill was about 20 bucks. 

I know one star looks harsh, but after reading a bunch of other reviews, I honestly kept an open mind, and gave this place a chance.  For cheap Indian food, go to Chutney.  It's just around the corner, and has consistently been an awesome spot.  

Wish my experience was better at Lahore.  Avoid this mess.
author: Steve C.

description:
Went to the Fabulous Food Festival this morning expecting to be somewhat full from all the samples of food but I was sorely disappointed. It wasn't worth the $10 per ticket we paid for. Anyways, I was pretty hungry when we decided to go to Lahore Karahi for an early dinner about 5:30pm. The place is pretty small maybe seats about 30 and only a few people were eating when we got in. We sat ourselves and ordered right away. I was surprised that it was an open kitchen. I actually got to see the chef/owner prepare our dishes. Big plus. Ordered the veggie samosas, grilled platter, chicken tikki masala, lamb korma and mixed veggies. Our waiter ask if we like it mild, medium or spicy. Of course, we went for spicy. Also, had two regular naans, one onion and one garlic. Highlights were the samosas, chicken tikki masala, mixed veggies, grilled platter and the regular naan. Lamb korma was not to my taste but the girlfriend enjoyed it. The onion and garlic naan were not worth the extra price and the garlic naan didn't seem to have fresh garlic in it. The regular naan were plenty good: crispy outside and airy inside. Grilled platter had tandoori chicken, lamb roti and two lamb kebabs. All were flavored very well. The chicken masala did not have as much tomato flavor as other places but it's good nonetheless. Veggie samosas were pretty big and delicious, spicy too! Goes well with the mint yogurt and tamarind sauces that you get. I like to eat them mixed together. Another surprising thing, other than the open kitchen, was that the food was not overly oily. 

I would definitely head here again when I'm in the area. A nice mom and pop feel to it. The chef/owner asked what we thought of the food, a very nice touch. I am a sucker for those type of gestures. But the best part of the dinner? The price. $45.50 with tax and all four of us were full. Good place to go after shopping at Union Square and the price will still leave you with money to shop after, if you don't go into a food coma that is.
author: Andy B.

description:
Grilled chicken.

$3

HELLA GOOD.

Garlic Naan, the best ever.

The rice is not so much. Don't bother ordering it.

Overall, the dishes taste very home cooked and I love the prices.
author: Ali W.

description: I am so glad my friend suggested we go to this place.  Everything was tasty.  I am glad I tried the tea.  It is strong and spicy the way I like it.  It was super busy so isn't that a sign of a good restaurant.  The service was friendly.
author: Darlene C.

description: All I can say is, get there earlier than normal dinner hours.  Otherwise, you're going to have to wait outside in a line to get a table.  The vegetarian dishes here are so flavorful and so reasonably priced.  We had the Daal Masaia, Palak Methi, Lahori Chakkar Choley, Saag Paneer, Aloo Tikki (appetizer) and, of course, Naan - and, all of it was excellent!  Definitely a very casual setting.   No liquor license here, but you can bring a bottle of wine or a beer if you'd like.  Great eats, trust me!
author: R M.

description:
Lahore Karahi was incredible. It is the reviews on Yelp which led me to try this place.

I have been an avid Shalimar-er for the past 4 years. I literally go three nights per week. A few weeks ago, I decided to engage in some Indian/Pakistani food adultery and tried Chutney. Nothing at Chutney even came close to Shalimar. The gravy just was not there. Ahh--but that is for a different review!

Having ventured away from Shalimar once, I figured cheating on it twice was no biggy. I pass Lahore Karahi on my drive down O'Farrell every time I go to Shalimar. I have been curious about it for some time.

Parking was easier than at Shalimar even though the two are separated by just a block or two.

Walked into a restaurant with about 6 tables at about 7pm. There were only two couples in the restaurant. The server and the chef seem to be on equal levels within the Lahore Karahi hierarchy -- both look to be men in their 50s, both are jovial and extremely kind. It was the chef from whom I ordered --

I say:

"One cholay"
"One Saag Paneer"
"Do you have Nihari?" (I had read good things about the Nihari here on Yelp but could not find it on the menu). The chef smiles back and says
"Yes, for you we have Nihari"
"Great! One Chicken Tikka Masala"
"One Chicken Boti"
Chef interjects: "My chicken boti is excellent, but try the fish tandoori -- it is really special". Methinks let's give it a whirl. The chef adds that the fish (sea bass) is fresh.
"Oh, and one plain naan, no butter."

After about 15 minutes, the tandoori fish has arrived. Oh man, was it good. I don't usually enjoy dishes like this made with seafood, but I am in LOVE with this dish. It comes on a hot skillet, simmering, covered in a zestily-dressed lettuce. At first I was avoiding the lettuce as though it were a garnish. After a few bites I started mixing the lettuce with the fish -- now THAT is the way to have it! This was one of the most incredible dishes I have ever had. I think the chicken boti at Shalimar is divine -- literally made by gods. This is equally good, but completely different -- different spices and, of course, fish instead of chicken.

Next come the other dishes, minus the cholay which never came-- the chef must not have heard me order it -- which is just fine since I ordered way too much food.

The Nihari was incredible. Much tangier than at Shalimar and Chutney and, instead of being a block of beef in a stew-broth (as the dish is prepared at Shalimar and Chutney), the entire dish is shredded (and not-so-shredded) beef in a wonderful gravy. Very little sauce because the beef IS the sauce. It was incredible, though admittedly heavy.

The saag paneer (other restaurants call it palak paneer) was equally good. It was cream-based, but not too creamy. The flavor was out-of-this-world, much more complex than what one finds at Shalimar. As one reviewer wrote below, all the dishes at Lahore Karahi are something of an art -- not simple, but very complex and balanced. The paneer (cheese) in this dish was definitely homemade and quite different from any other paneer I have tasted -- it had almost a crisp exterior but was butter soft, almost melted inside. Imagine well-roasted marshmallows. That was the texture.

The bangan bharta was also incredible. I usually find bangan bharta to be one of the so-so dishes at Indian/Pakistani restaurants -- always good, but never something I am dying to eat. This was different. This was good enough that one might just come to Lahore Karahi for this single dish.

The chicken tikka masala was the disappointment of the bunch. It was great, certainly better than at Chutney and Naan'n'Curry (like it is at these restaurants, the CTM was cream-based at Lahore Karahi), but it was not orgasmic-kiss-the-floor-take-a-bath-in-it-good like at Shalimar. It was much more normal and non-special. Still excellent, though.

The naan came very heavily buttered -- tasted great, but clearly some of my order instructions were lost in the kitchen!

The chai was also quite good (and free). It was spiced so as to have a  much more interesting and flower-like flavor than the chai of Shalimar, N'n'C or Chutney.

After paying, on my way out, the chef and server INSISTED that I try their rice pudding, which was incredible. They dished it out for me on the house and watched me eat it with glee. It was like white grout (for laying bricks). Incredible. What gracious hosts!

Overall this place is excellent, incredible, and I would return to have any one of the dishes I ordered (except maybe the chicken tikka masala) -- I would also return just to see the gracious smile of the chef and the server. So kind.

Lahore Karahi is an excellent place with which to supplement Shalimar, and will surely become part of my weekly restaurant regimen. It's not better than Shalimar but certainly not worse. Just different. Each dish is so good and so different from Shalimar that my mood will determine which place I visit!
author: John G.

description: the food here seems like it has more onions in the dishes in comparison to other places. i really like onions so its great for me. i usually get naan and a curried chicken dish. service is friendly as well. will definitely go back. expected bill $8-$10.
author: Tushar K.

description: Omg cockroaches EVERYWHERE! in the bathroom, on the floor... climbing up the walls! eeee!
author: S K.

description: Since I last wrote about this place in August, my subsequent visits have proved why I love this restaurant.  Very homey feel, and EXCELLENT food.  Guddu and the rest of the staff strive to make everyone feel welcome.  The service takes some getting used to, but be patient and you won't be disappointed.
author: Nene K.

description: OH YES it is that good. Don't doubt it. Spicy, delicious, warm, inviting. The only thing wrong with this place is that it's in SF and I'm in shittiest-Indian-food-capitol of the world, Santa Cruz. Le sigh.
author: Annee T.

description: This is a some good Indian food. Not the creamy gloopy curry you get at Naan' n Curry (although that's good too), but just very well seasoned and cooked. The tandoori fish is awesome. Put in your order and grab a bottle of wine or some beers at the licquor store across the street.
author: Jon S.

description: Less than zero ambiance and at-times excruciatingly slow service (small  kitchen combined with FIFO cooking method and pretty big range of menu options can mean disaster).  Even hard to get your check when you want to scram to get to movie etc that you were planning to go to after a yummy cheap eat outing.  But I digress -- this place reminds me of what Shalimar was 5-10 years ago or whenever it first opened and was actually good.  Fresh hot cooked-to-order food, great flavors, terrific bread.  And while service is often slow, sometimes it is incredibly fast (if of course you are there early and no other diners are present!) -- and the main waiter is unfailingly friendly and a bit of a jokester.
author: Xander S.

description:
Borderline 4 star joint. Food was pretty good. Chicken Boti (portions of white chicken breast meat marinated and tandoori oven'd) come out like fajitas on a sizzling platter on a bed of veggies. Very nice. Naan was pretty good, although not the best I've had. Lamb vindaloo was good, but could have been a little creamier. Daal was pretty good, no complaints. 
Minus one star for the service. I mean really. There wasn't that many people in there, I had to ask twice for doggy bags, and if you want something you need to make eye contact with the waiter or you will likely be waiting a long time. I'm well aware this is not a "nicer" dining establishment but if waiting tables is such a pain in the ass, they should go to the Shalimar method, where you order at the counter and then they bring it out to you. Strange but it works better than this. I also think the food is better there so I won't say Lahore is not good because it is but my personal preference is for Shalimar. I would definitely reccomend Lahore to any Pakistani / Indian food afficionado though as you may find the flavors superior to other similar joints (and that is what it is, by the way, a joint). 
I went to clear up a nasty cold I got and it did the trick. It didn't help that it was 85 degrees out but I was sweating profusely throughout my meal to the horror of my wife and to the gluttonous, giddy delight of me. Ole.
author: Matt H.

description: The place isn't bad.  Food and selection could be a little better.
author: N N.

description: Good quality dishes.  Not too oily/greasy.  Decent prices.  Playing oldies but goodies classical Indian/Pakistani music videos.  The waiter might appear standoffish to some, but after my friends and I spent an evening with him, it just seems that he has a shy/quiet personality that needs some time to open up to guests, so ask the waiter about his experiences working for Muni and you ought to be able to get some entertaining stories and a few laughs.
author: Atif Q.

description: Take your own favorite beer (liquor store across the street) and plenty of TIME (waiter is pokey). Great food, FREE CHAI (help yourself). Amazing food, inexpensive, and staff with attitude. Can't beat that.
author: Thighmaster M.

description:
Began barta, dal masaia, saag paneer, rice, onion kulcha. Began barta tasted exactly like the topping on Zantes veggie indian pizza - which is a good thing. The saag paneer was fresh and the cheese cubes had a great flavor and texture. The onion kulcha had a lot of large pieces of white onion (too much). The dal was a little thick and had a very earthy taste, different from other dal I've had.

I had stomach issues from 6am - 10am the next day, the food wasn't that spicy so it might have been the cream in the saag paneer. What ever it was I'm not going to risk it again. Too bad, I really liked the began barta and saag paneer.
author: Sarah J.

description: The price was right and they served, check that you can serve yourself Indian beer.  The food was strangely bland with no POP in the flavors.  The naan was over cooked and dry and only 2 of the 5 entrees were better than average.  The Aloo Bengan and Chicken Kaboob were the winners.  The Lamb Vindaloo and both the Butter and Tikka chicken were just okay. Shalimar in Fremont is very similar but the menu selection, location, food and service is so much better.  I am a little shocked considering all the high marks and don't see myself going back soon.
author: Tim M.

description: Not only is the food really freaking good (we had chicken tikka masala, eggplant, garlic naan, lamb kebab, and biryani), but they play Bollywood movies while you eat! Could anything be better? I think not. =) Being there made me feel like I was in India all over again, even though I guess it should make me feel like I am in Pakistan, whatever, it was rad.
author: Rikki D.

description:
Just ate here for the first time tonight.  Exceptional food.  We had the Saag Paneer (best we've ever had) and the Bengan Bhartiia (great eggplant dish).  The naan is warm and perfect.  

Because the place is small and they make the food to order, the wait was very long.  But the food was worth it.  Will order out next time.
author: Peter R.

description: Great sesame naan - cheap too.  Not the best, but still mighty tasty
author: Joshua S.

description: This place fills your every indian food need!  Super good spicy fresh grub, and not too greezy.  Great light naan, maybe the tenderest lamb korma I ever had, and very interestingly spiced.  The tikka masala has more of a yellow color than the typical orange, but it was quite good as well.  Really hits the spot, service can be a bit spotty with one guy serving the entire place, but he gets it done nicely.  Get here for sure!  No doubt if you want some indian, this is high on the list.  Beware of the crackheads in the neighborhood, they are lingering about...
author: Jon S.

description:
We ordered saag paneer and lamb vindaloo. The saag paneer was AMAZING. It was perhaps the best spinach I've ever had. It was sweet and flavorful. The naan was delicious.

However, my lamb vindaloo tasted waaaaaaaay too vinegary. I know I ordered it spicy, but the spiciness covered the taste. The vinegar flavor was just too overpowering as well. It was kind of disappointing. 

I would definitely go back to try more of their curries and give it another shot. However, with that said, I would not order the lamb vindaloo again.
author: Will S.

description: if you really want dirty dishes, grease coated menus and lukewarm chai this is your place!  Service with a smile though and super cheap...you certainly get what you pay for...
author: Tata K.

description: There are many fish in the sea, and there are many Indian restaurants in the tenderloin.  This one is not worth the time or the money.  I was excited when we went in as there was an Indian family eating there and talking with the owners, so I thought that would be a good sign.  But there was a Mexican guy making the food.  My baigan bhartha tasted like eggplant salsa, the lamb was really really weirdly spiced and had giant strips of hot pepper in it, which wasn't cool and isn't very Indian.  Maybe we just went on a bad night, but it was bizarre tasting and in a bad way.  We had bad service too, due to the people running the place socializing with the family that was in there, although I did enjoy watching the Bollywood movie on TV while we were in there.  Hit Chutney or Shalimar, both just a block and a half away on Jones between O'Farrell and Geary instead.  This place was just... bad.
author: Green T.

description: By far the best Indian I've had in SF.  It's an instant favorite for me (reminds me of Punjabi Dhaba in Cambridge).  The area is not the greatest, but if you get in, you will not regret it.  I liked the chicken tikka masala and saag paneer a lot.  the lassi was not that great.  i'd still go here over shalimar any day of the week.
author: Rohit G.

description:
This place RULES! 

Went here after drinks at Bourbon & Branch and I think my friends and I spent way less on dinner than for 2 rounds at B&B. 

Great paneer that they make on premises.
author: J K.

description: I am about to have a torrid affair with a restaraunt.  While we've never been exclusive or had "the talk" Raja has been my main squeeze for as long as I have lived here.  . . . until today when my friend introduced me to Lahore Karahi and WHAM - just like that .   This place floored me with the best butter chicken I've ever had. . . garlic naan that was the perfect texture and covered in garlic and saag paneer that was neither too sweet nor too creamy.  The chef was also our waiter and - call me a sucker for a pretty smile - but he knows exactly what to do when some white chick and her lunch pal request in unison "Spicy!!"  We're in the TL so there's nothing fancy here. . . just incredible food served in dishes that look like they're from an actual kitchen.   Perfect.
author: Valerie D.

description:
I was pretty impressed by what I had read in Yelp and within the Chron's bargain bites list. Despite the tough surroundings (the 'Loin) and the spartan atmosphere, I had a good time at Lahore Karahi. 
I had some issues with the service as it took a while for things things like drinks to arrive (imagine: reminding our waiter about the lasse that we ordered, watching him tell a coworker and then having having the waiter and the coworker stand around doing nothing for about 3 minutes before one of them poured the premade drink-- yeah, that should have taken 30 seconds)
The food was very tasty and cheap which was a plus. We had the garlic naan, veggie samosas with some great sauces and a collection of chicken and veggies.
The atmosphere was a bit on the creepy side but the old Bollywood movies in the retro tv was a nice touch. Definitely a good hole-in-the-wall spot but not really the hot spot for a date. Especially if you are going to park in the neighborhood.
author: Gil L.

description: Great Indian food that lives up to the hype. Service was gracious and friendly, prices were fantastic, food was delicious. I especially liked the saag paneer. Three curries, three mango lassi's, and a buttload of naan, all for only $42 (tip and tax included). Definitely will be back!
author: Joy C.

description: This place ROCKS.  I'd give it five stars if it didn't take so damn long to get your dinner.  The first time I went, I was absolutely famished ,and we somehow ended up being served after the massive group that had arrived behind us.  One overlooks those sorts of idiosyncracies when the food is this good and this affordable, though.  I can even overlook the slightly unsavory neighborhood!
author: nicole l.

description: My brother and his girlfriend took us here, I was a bit apprehensive at first because of the location but as soon as I walked in I knew I was wrong. The owner/waiter is super friendly and it was packed!! It's not a fine dining establishment, but the food is so tasty and the prices are ridiculously cheap. My brother had brought a bottle of wine and I am pretty sure there is no corkage. What a great find!
author: Carson H.

description: Lahore is my favorite Indian/Pakistani food in the city, and it happens to be in my neighborhood! When I walk in and see Gudu, the owner and chef, he's always smiling and happy which makes me happy. I just sit down and get ready to wait for the most delicious mix of curry spice. The wait is usually excruciating - definitely don't go when you're starving. Plan to get there about an hour ahead of being hungry, so the wait won't be so bad. It's definitely a 5 star for the food. Get the fish tandoori!
author: Kathy M.

description:
Very good indian/Pakistani food. When you first walk in, you think "wow cozy" and we thought we had to wait since it appeared to be full but a gentleman lead us to a little table in the corner. It was a pretty tight fit but it wasn't too bad. 

I really wanted to try their samosas but they were out!! so he recommended this potato pattie appetizer so we went with it. We also ordered chicken tikka masala (of course), an eggplant dish with tomatos, all with potato naan and sesame naan. While we waited, they came over with this cracker like thing which i guess is equivalent to bread and butter that other restaurants usually come with. Then the potato patty app came and mMMm...it was good!! highly recommend it! unfortunately i don't know the proper name of this but it is described on the menu. Right away everything else came out and of course there wasn't enough room for it on our tiny table. If you ever ate at naan and curry, the naan here is just soooo much better. Small, but tastes so much better!! Both curry dishes had this sweet taste to it. One con about the food is that we requested to make both dishes spicy but i didn't feel like it was spicy at all. At first i thought it was just me since i eat so much spicy food my sensitively to spices are low. But my partner is usually quite sensitive to spiciness and he said he didn't think it was spicy at all. So that was a little disappointing.

But all in all, very good! Food is better than Naan and curry. Definitely better service than Naan and curry. Different service since they come to your table and take your order rather than you placing your order prior to sitting down. Prices are reasonable. 

Highly Recommended. Will go back.
author: Bevo T.

description: I have a bit of a mixed review for this place, as some things were great while others were far from that. Perhaps the ultimate measure is whether there is any food left on my plate, although with a guy my size that usually isn't a problem. At this place there was food leftover, why do you ask? The chicken tikka was really dry, unbearably dry. I think they overcooked it, now normally with a dish done this poorly I would give the place a lower rating, so why 4*? A lot of the stuff was really good, and the lassi was excellent, I think I had 2 and wanted a third :) Maybe they just overcooked the tikka as well as some of the other meat, I would go back here again, perhaps next time everything will be great.
author: Brent F.

description: The food is great here!  The service is pretty good too!  I think they only have one server. He's pretty good, but if it gets to busy he might need to be reminded of some food you ordered.  The chicken tikka masala is yummy!  You can pretty much get up and get the drinks yourself.  The owner/ cook is really nice!
author: Laura H.

description: A gem of a find on Yelp.  A family run hole in the wall... really spicy, homemade food.  Crowded and took a while, but worth it.
author: Sue G.

description: Cheap. Really good. Hole in the wall. What more can you want from an Indian restaurant?
author: Mike D.

description: After a year of avoiding this place, and a friend, from India, pleading with me to go back - especially if we were nearby or hankering for Indian, I finally went back. I did avoid the mint sauce and mango lassi. It's not something specific to this establishment- all of the tenderloin places- I avoid the dairy. So it was good- nice peppery lamb korma, and good gritty dirty rice. I didn't try the grilled mixed meat plate, but it seemed good too. Good for the money. My instinct says that it's more authentic than Pakwan, but I haven't been to India/Pakistan so have no real comparison.
author: Anna B.

description:
i slipped in silently, before the wave of sucka hipsters. booked down a few blocks the wrong way just to make sure i beat any impending friday night rush.

ordering went just right...
  me: "and could i get soup with that too please?"
  you: "this not american restaurant."
  me: "ok but lots of pakistani restaurants serve soup. soup isn't american.
  you: "let me explain."
  (time passes, pointing, ordering, eating ensue)

later: wholy, holy, full. veggie samosas, lahori chikkan choley  (c.f. channa masala), naan, and soda.

perfectly peaceful, especially spicy, totally heavyweight meal. solid kitchen with prep and cook done visibly on site. A+, great transaction.
author: John M.

description: As my roomate has said already, this is by far the best Indian and Pakastani food that I have found as of yet, in SF!  The tikka masala is killer and the biryanis are to die for....the owners really care about their craft and they do a damn good job at it as well.  The mango lassis are also probably the best in the city.
