My one caveat is that this place gets hot and cramped...luckily it is only 3 blocks from our place, so takeout is a wonderful and quick option....another bonus is that they accept credit cards...GO!
author: Francis K.

description: Simply the best in the city.  Just don't leave your table to grab some more water, napkin, or utencils.  Oh, and if you like it spicy, say it with a full heart and without hesitation, otherwise Brother will big brother you and take it down a notch (me suspects).
author: Jonny L.

description: Absolutely the best Pakistani food you will have.  It is amazingly good.  I had the tandoori fish, karahi chicken and lahori cholay- all ordered spicy.   The karahi chicken was outstanding with perfectly cooked, moist chicken and onions that were soft tender.  The tandoori fish was delicious as well with big, meaty pieces of fish on a sizzling skillet.  The cholay were unbelievably tender and the sauce was silky.  I will surely go back to try other dishes that looked tasty.  Especially the fresh samosas that were being painstakingly folded into perfect pyramids.  The food was hot, fast and flavorful the service was super friendly and quick.
author: Jones D.

description: My clothes still smell of smoke and spices from this place.  Aside from that and the rather slow service, the food was pretty good.  The naan was charred and chewy, the sauces creamy and flavorful, and the biryani light and fluffy.
author: Ming L.

description: Very good Pakastani food - it's in the Tenderloin technically, but a much better block than Shalimar's. The staff is friendly enough but they work at a different pace from a different time. The Tandoori is very good - especially the fish tandoori. I've never had Tandoori Fish, but it was delicious and not overdone. The naan was fresh and tasty. And I like the fact that there's free chai on tap. Dishes are kind of spicy, so make sure to let the server know if you can't take any spice at all.
author: Adrian J.

description:
Great food, great price, ok service (hence the 4 instead of 5 stars).

Very good place to sit and enjoy conversation with several strangers at your table.  We got seats pretty quickly at a table for 6 with 4 other friendly diners.  The waiter got slightly confused when we asked for a special kind of naan, but he ended up bringing us a combo of regular and special naan.  We recommend the Lamb Korma and Chicken Saag, and the baliwood movies on the tv the whole time provided entertainment for lulls in conversation.
author: L F.

description: I don't get the hype about this place, maybe I caught them on a bad night.  I went in for take out with my roommate and was not impressed.  We had vindaloo (beef I think), saag paneer and naan.  It was greasy and bland - even the vindaloo.  They get one star for the naan which was really good and one star because the service was quick.  I have to say that I prefer Chutney but I will give this place another try.
author: Julie P.

description: best indian i've had in sf. sure, there's usually a wait, but the food is made to order and there are only so many tables they can fit in there. i've just learned not to go when i'm too hungry. butter chicken is always a must when we go, along with the garlic naan. the portions are solid and the prices are good. this place is always worth the wait (when i'm not starving, of course).
author: Meredith K.

description: Horrible food, lousy lousy lousy service, dirty place they should be shut down, i will never go back sucks is putting it mildly???
author: Sam H.

description: Went with a friend during the week for dinner - our expectations were pretty high but the results were a little disappointing. Pleasant enough service, the food came quickly. The chicken tika masala rated about 3 stars, saag paneer was not spicy enough - garlic naan was tasty and vegetable pakora was too doughy. Fair pricing, plenty of food but not exciting enough to go racing back.  The neighborhood is so dicey that one might not want to walk around there after dark, let alone in daylight. It, the neighborhood speaks of the sadness of run-down San Fran. Maybe former NY Mayor Guiliani needs to clean up the slums of SF!
author: Chloe M.

description: This place serves some great Indian food.  Although I do agree that the service is a tad slow, otherwise this place is 5 stars for sure.  If  you have time, then this is the place for Indian food.
author: Denny M.

description: Retarded good.  The garlic nan superb.  Healthy portions, and tender meat.
author: Eric W.

description:
This place has the yummiest comfort food. The tandoori fish is my favorite. And it reminds me of The White House, this nutty chinese rest. from my hometown (easton, pa.) where you had to fetch your own water, silverware, (and sometimes entrees) from the kitchen on account of the drinking going on back there. The place was owned by this couple Tommy and Kathy. He was from Hunan Province, and she was from County Cork, IR.  Oh they were the sweetest most hospitable drunks that ever ran a restaurant....but I digress...
Lahore is right down the street from me, so I drag my boyfriend in there regularly. One night I was so tired, I left my purse in the back of the chair and didn't notice for over an hour at home. When we marched back down there, they were counting out the till with the door open (!) and Guddu was smiling and counting. Without a word
exchanged, he reached under the counter and produced my purse, still smiling and counting. I thanked him and went home and dreamed of Lahore... masala tea, tandoori fish, yum.......
author: e w.

description: An enthusiastic five *****. The samosas were the best ever, light and flakey, like puffed pastries. Food was hearty, rustic, and flavorful.
author: Bruno B.

description: I used to eat here multiple times a week when I lived in the 'loin  (yes I lived across the street) and now that I'm in the sunset I find my self craving anything and everything on the menu!  The service is fabulous and after a year of not having been we were still remembered!  Cheap and tasty!
author: Blair F.

description: Great food.  Just don't go there for the ambiance.  The service is slow (one waiter) and the presentation is very basic.  But if you want good service and presentation, go somewhere else.  If you want great food and a very reasonable price, this is your place.
author: Anthony L.

description:
"Have you ever tasted love," he said. Now we have. There is a giant hug in every bite. The food will make you smile on your saddest of days. And the owner, Guddhu, is a great guy. We went Jill and Chris Eickman, friends of Guddhi, and he made us his "trust me" meal. Talk about wonderful. If you are even considering dining out tonight, you absolutely have to go to Lahore Karahi.

BEST DISH: Everything we were served
author: Ian S.

description:
Well, so much has already been said about the food. It's YUM!! and it's cheap. And it makes great leftovers... I had it for breakfast today!
Really, I want to write this because the owner is so awesome!! The other night 2 of my friends and I walked in at like 10:40 (20 minutes before closing) and he let us stay to eat. Not only did he let us stay to eat, he was soo attentive and sweet, and didn't rush us at all. We ate leisurely while they closed up the place, and we felt bad at first, but he assured us it was completely fine. He even gave us a free samosa, since the order comes in 2 and there were 3 of us! I love him, and we will definitely be back.
author: R D.

description:
Wow!

As an Indian-American, this is the only place I've found that does both Veg and Non-Veg food equally awesome!

Cost: $36.00 for 6 ppl plus tip

What we ordered:
Chicken Biryani - a little spicy for people with mild tastebuds
1 Plain Naan
1 Aluu Paratha (Potato)
1 Onion Kulcha (Onion Bread) - It's cooked but the onions inside are still raw. It was ok.
1 Began Bharta (eggplant) - creamy 
1 Saag Paneer (Spinach and Cheese)
1 Dal (lentils) - well done and I don't personally like Dal
2 Orders of Samosas (total of 4) - spicy but freshly made and fried
**Yogurt - totally necessary for anyone who has mild tastebuds.
Rice Pudding (Kheer) for dessert - not as liquid as other places but still tasty.
Unlimited Free Chai (Indian Tea) while you're sitting there.

No reservations so you might have to wait.  On a Sat night at 8pm, we had to wait for 20 minutes for a big table.
author: Happy D.

description: This place has the most delicious Indian/Packistani food in the city.  The curries are so rich, creamy and perfectly spiced.  Everything is home cooked on a tiny stove in the corner of the restaurant, which brings me to the only downside of Lahore---you might have to wait quite a while for your food.  It's totally worth the wait though and you can bring your own beer to pass the time.
author: Laura C.

description:
This place is AMAZING! I've been hearing about this place for the longest time from my coworkers and I didn't believe them, but everything I tried here was delish.

It's ONE guy who does ALL the cooking and usually the serving, but I think he just recently hired someone to serve the tables for him.  You have to try the fish there, good quality fish cooked just right because it just melts in your mouth, and so flavorful.  

One star off because of the wait.  It's a really small place, but because the owner cooks EVERYTHING by himself, service takes a while.  So if you don't have at least 2 hours to spare, don't bother.  Also, he does take reservations, so make reservations ahead of time.  I'm not even sure if I should be taking 1 star off because this guy is passionate about making GOOD food, and that's why he does everything himself when it comes to the cooking...so it's a good thing actually.

Now for my must-haves at Indian restaurants, the chai.  I absolutely love indian chai, and the one here was delish.  The owner brews it himself at the back and it's heavenly (you can definitely taste the spices).  Would definitely go back!
author: Connie Y.

description: We ordered medium hot and it was pretty spicy. The Tandoori fish was amazing. Actually I am rating this place 5 stars for the Tandoori fish alone. The nan was nice and fresh and the Biryani was pretty good too. Definitely come with a group and order a bunch of food.
author: Mohammad M.

description: We are on a hunt for take out Indian that we can export to the East bay  because there is no good Indian here.  To that effect, we hit Lahore, which had gotten good reviews on Yelp and was relatively near our hotel.  When we walked in we knew we were in the right place: filthy, crap all over the floor, the carpet and tile stained and we were glad the lighting was bad so we couldn'ts ee too closely in the corners. The signs of good Indian food and we were not disappointed.  We tried several things (after they were out of both samosa and aloo tikki) we ordered aloo paratha, baigan bhartha, aloo gobi and saag paneer, rice  and naan.  We took it back to the hotel eagerly anticipating the greasy meals. And they were just as greasy as we expected and just as tasty (with a few exceptions). Aloo paratha was kind of like wonder bread with potatoes stuck in it (not so good). The eggplant was smoky and flavorful, no peas and limited tomatoes. The aloo gobi was just swimming in grease but sooooo tasty and cooked just right with a bit of a bite to the caulfiower but the potatoes fully cooked. The saag paneer was excellent too (no tomato), lots of spinach, smooth, creamy and tasty.  The naan was almost inedible. But the real surprise was the incredibly excellent rice.  And all we ordered was "rice".  But it was like a pilaf. I usually don't eat rice, but this stuff was so flavorful I could have just eaten that.  And, we had enough leftovers for three or four more servings (and we ate far more than we needed to because it was so yummy!).  Now, I do have a caution. The food gives me an upset stomach--not terrible but noticable (too much grease? too many germs? who knows) . . . but that's something I'm willing to put up with for such tasty food. We'd go back, but we would never, ever eat in the restaurant itself. Having said that, the place was packed, so many people must not be bothered by the dirt.
author: Vivek V.

description:
We went here and tried Prawn Tikka Masala ($10.95), Fish Tandoori ($10.95), Onion Kulcha ($2.00), Seekh Kabab ($4.00).
The food taste a little different than the Indian restaurants we usually go to such as Chutney or Naan 'n Curry.
Perhaps because Lahore Karahi is Pakistani cuisine(?)
I mean... tandoori in Indian restaurants usually has reddish color but at Lahore Karahi, the tandoori is brown.
The Fish Tandoori and the Seekh Kabab were served on a hot plate. What a nice surprise!
The food are excellent although they are different from what we used to, and the owner is nice and I will definitely come back again in the future.
The service was a little bit slow though. It took about an hour of waiting to get table, to order, and to get the food.
I will definitely upgrade the rating once the service is a little bit faster.
They accept Visa and Master Card.
-----
Despite of the slow service, we decided to come here again only 2 days apart because of its good food.
It took 5 minutes to be seated (great!) but 25 minutes to have the waiter - the guy with the index finger amputated - came and took our order (!!).
He was like in dazed and confused or something!!!

When finally he came and took our order, starting with: "What do you want to order?"
Us: "I want... (point at the menu)..."
He just turned around left before I finished the sentence and talked to another customer that just came without even saying any "excuse me, please", or "would you mind to wait a second?" (if that customer is so important to talk to right away)
Then, he went talking to another customer, then walking around and around, and bringing a couple of plates for another table, then again, walking around and around (yes, we saw all the process because we were just sitting there watching him), then went to another table (that came after us) taking order, then again walking around and around, bringing water jug here and there, before finally coming to our table again without even saying sorry or offering explanation of what happened.
I'm not sure why he did that. I do not mean to insult, but either he was negligent or rude.
Negligent means he did not realize what he did, he lost track, he does not have good memory which table came first, and therefore he was not capable to apologize.
Rude means he meant to do that to ignore us.
I hope it was the first one.

We ordered Bengan Bartha ($5.50), Butter Chicken ($6.00), and Garlic Naan ($2.00)
Bengan Bartha was good but Butter Chicken was many times better.
Garlic Naan was good too.

The food came pretty fast though within 15 minutes.
Now that I understand that Zulfikar "Guddu" Haider is the only guy cooking the dishes, actually we do not mind waiting for the food to be cooked to its excellence but we do mind being IGNORED with that waiter (not Guddu).
Overall was supposed to be 5 stars minus 1 star for the bad service from the waiter.
author: Oribel ..

description: OK, if your looking for super organized service head to toe, you might not like this place.  However, if you are in the mood for some real Pakistani food, served and cooked by Pakistani folks who make the food with love, as you can see while watching the head cook/owner put on his show in the kitchen, then this is the right place for you.  I love this place.  Usually I only go when I'm not in a huge hurry and have the patience to enjoy the full experience of it all.  The old guy who waits tables is a bit cranky, but I kind of think it's part of his charm.   I don't like mean waiters, but I don't mind an old guy getting cranky when he sees a diner getting a bit too entitled for their own britches.
author: Warren M.

description:
yes! add Lahore to my list of "favourite places to eat in my new neighborhood"! totally delicious and cheap! and god help me, i love booze and i love that i can bring my own!

only one mishap while i was there though. the line was out the door and i was waiting with a party of seven. another party of seven was just finishing their meal and getting up to leave, except for the two at the end of the table. they stayed put for a solid half an hour, hogging the only available table large enough for our group, without eating, drinking, or ordering any more food, while the whole table was bussed and we're standing there dying of hunger. absolutely not Lahore's fault, but still totally lame!
author: Jaei P.

description: I love the food here even though it can take forever.  I'm a huge fan of the seekh kebab and the chicken tikka masala. They have great naan always play super cheesey Bollywood films, which always sets the mood right.  No booze, but they're happy to let you byob.  Which is good, cause if you're in the loin, you're either there to get fucked up or you need to drink to deal with the fact that you live there.
author: Gianpaolo P.

description: By far probably one of, if not THE best, place for indian food on the western seaboard. Me and my buddy went to Vijs in Vancouver not too long ago, and that place is highly rated and wildly acclaimed, but we both found Vijs to be very good, but not amazing. Granted Vijs is indian fusion and not authentic like Lahore, they are both categorized the same unfortunately by a lot of other food critics. I dream of this place sometimes, because the food is very authentic. Eating here, reminds me of every single time I was eating in India. The service is slow due to the fact its almost a one man show, and that was when the place was fairly empty. If its packed, get ready for a ridiculous wait time, however, if you dont mind waiting for an hour +, the food is definitely worth it.
author: Bala H.

description:
The food here is really good, but last night their service was horrible. Clearly there weren't enough people working. The people cooking our food were the same people to take our order and bus the tables. There were a build up of dishes and bottles in a corner by the table we were sitting at. It's ashame, they could really be something great if they cleaned it up a bit. I looked into the kitchen from outside, and they were scooping some ingredients that sat in buckets on the floor. 

They still use styrofoam to-go boxes. Last time I checked, those boxes were banned in San Francisco. It's against the law.
author: August S.

description: the food here is different (from most non-southern indian places i've gone to, namely Naan-N-Curry, Pakwan, Flavors of India, Favorite Indian Restaurant, yes that's the name, and a few others). for better or worse, quick-serve indian food all tastes similar in deliciousness to me.  here, though, the food subtly suggests another style, familiar but distinct.  takes a while to get used to but a few bites later you start to believe you're in someone's living room, being served a home-cooked meal. mostly because they do cook all dishes to order (from the looks of it).  hard to beat!
author: Dee C.

description: If the Bollywood flicks on t.v. don't steal your heart, the palak paneer, aloo ghobi, garlic naan, and samosas will! Truly a place where my Tandoori-culinary-love can roam! Lahore Karahi is, hands down, the BEST Indian/Pakistani food I've had in San Francisco! (And Gudu is a real charmer too!) ;)
author: G D.

description:
i like this place because its got character. the guy who takes your order refuses to do it any other way than the way he wants it. the food all comes at once, no matter if you kinda wanted it to be an appetizer. the guy is kinda short tempered but in that nice, loving, grandfather way. all the other people are real friendly. the food is reeeaallly well priced. its real good, but theres alot of good pakistani food in the city. it didnt completely knock me over as being totally inventive and unique and better than everyone else, but it was nonetheless real good. the portions were fair. the lamb was tender an excellent.
_________

update. 

the best place for indian pakistani. at first i just thought it wasn't particularly great, but i went back again last night and realized that their food really is better than most other indian food. and freakin amazingly priced. its super small, the two owners are always there smiling and cooking. the main server was soooo nice to us last night. he even brought two free things for us to try just because he liked us so much.  i love the environment here. these guys make alot of their stuff from scratch, its not overly greasy, and they really make every dish with care and excellence.
author: Alissa S.

description:
After hearing all the hype about this place, I had to try it myself.  I consider myself quite well versed in Indian cuisine, having traveled all over Asia, and having been privy to some of the best Indian chefs on the world (in Michigan, no less).

And I was quite disappointed.  The vegetable pakoras were doughy and pretty unimpressive, though the tamarind chutney was good.  The naan was well made, but a little sweet (why would someone put sugar in naan?).  I ordered the mataar paneer, and it was downright bad.  More slimy onions than peas, and the sauce was boring and not nearly spicy enough despite my asking for it that way.  My companion ordered the shahi paneer, which was the highlight of our meal.  A quite decent sauce there.  The rice was good, though I wasn't expecting brown rice, I was happy with it.

At least it was dirt cheap.  And now I'll go back to fantasizing about Shalimar in Ann Arbor, Michigan (simply the best Indian restaurant I've ever been to).  :)
author: Jeff W.

description:
I need to update this more once I have had some more dishes, but my quick fist impressions;

- the place was noticeably cleaner and nicer then some of the comparable no budget/no frills pakistani food places (like shalimar on jones)
- The naan seemed like it was maybe brought in and just heated/toasted at the restaurant.  It was avg/ok (no better than the pretty good frozen ones at Trader Joe's), but doesn't hold a candle to the naan at Shalimar.
- I had a dish I hadn't had before (Nehari, not on the menu) so I can't objectively say too much on that front.  The raita was pretty plain without any onion and other bits like what I usually got when I was in India.  But since being in India I have noticed it is surprisingly hard to get a comparable raita.

I am a little surprised that it has so many really high ratings although.  It is decent, but doesn't live up to the rating and there are so many other options nearby.  All I can chalk it up to is the cleaner nature of the place and bit nicer ambiance for eating in than say Shalimar.  After all when I first walked into Shalimar on Jones I was a bit surprised the place hadn't been shut down.
author: K B.

description: Yes, the wait is long. But its so well worth it! I have never been disappointed by anything I have had here. Try the chicken boti, chicken vindaloo, and the tandori fish if you ever get the chance to stop by at this crackin spot! Also the appetizers are good as well(samosas).
author: Vilen G.

description: Not a big fan, although I have heard a lot of the buzz.  Even when it's empty, this place takes forever.  I know, we should enjoy one anothers company and take it slow.  Maybe it's the Midwesterner in me, but I think this place is simply too slow.  I've tried it about 3 times and live close, but haven't really liked anything I order.  Not really sure what to recommend instead, as I haven't found the world's best Pakistani food yet, but still trying.
author: Derek S.

description:
Disappointing, after the good rating. I suppose the flavors were maybe slightly better than those at the Naan n'Curry down the street. But even though we knew it was a hole in the wall, we were expecting minimally decent service.

At 5:30 PM on a Saturday night, half the tables were empty when we (a group of 5) arrived. Still waiting for one more friend, we decided to try the appetizers. They were out of samosas and told us the cheese pakoras would take 30 minutes to prepare. Hmmm, strange. The vegetable pakoras were quite good, the potato fritters were too dry, and we had to wait about 10 minutes after asking the waiter to bring us plates so we could share these appetizers (he seemed surprised that we wanted plates). 

Main dishes: The lamb meat we found in the korma, buried in a lot of lamb fat and bone, were tasty but all too rare. The other dishes were fine, but small portions. We were never brought our rice, and decided to forget about it (got lots of naan) until we saw that in fact, we had been charged for it. We were also one water short the whole meal, despite asking a waiter to bring another one.  

I can't think of many excuses for the indifferent service we received at a time when it wasn't even very crowded. I guess the food was good, but definitely not worth the inconveniences in my book.
author: Mariana C.

description:
Me and my wife decided to go to Lahore Karahi based on Yelp reviews but we were little disappointed with the taste and quality of the food, may be we went with too much expectation. 

Service was good in general and particularly the server who served us did a good job, which is odd for Indian/Pakistani restaurants. 

Based on one review I tried tandoori fish. It was OK, I think it is better to get tandoori lamb or chicken than fish in most Indo/Pak places.

Chicken karahi was good but the two veggie dishes that we ordered were below average. I understand that these types of restaurants are not the places to order veggie dishes but when they are in the menu they should taste moderate if not good.

Not sure whether I'll go to Lahore Karahi again.
author: Venetian P.

description: Clean, conveniant and above all inexpensive. Went there last night after a trip to the Safeway on Filmore. Showed up 20 minutes before closing for a take out order and was made to feel more then welcome.The gentlemen behind the counter asked me and my friend if we wanted to dine in, to which we responded no AND on top of that threw in a free soda. This is a great spot and now I know why the SF weekly voted it best Indian Food in 2007.
author: Salvatore R.

description: Unbelievably great !   I knew about Lahore, which is in my neighborhood, but i had never eaten there, due to having so many good options in the TL for food. After reading the reviews for this place on Yelp, i decided to check it out and man, what a smart decision that was.. The Naan was out of this world. I also had the Butter Chicken which was so flavorful and had a nice portion of protein in it. My buddy had the Basmati rice (we were told by the busser that the rice was organic, kudos...) and Aloo Ghobi (extremely delicious, perfectly prepared) The Chai was nothing special, but the busser, owner, price point, and food all get 5 stars from this chef....
author: Samuel J.

description:
To all those who complain about the service here: 

This is a hole in the wall restaurant with 1 waiter serving everything to everybody in a small eating space and all of the dishes are cooked from scratch.  What kind of service can you expect?

Anyway, the food here is probably the best indian you can find in the city and the prices are phenomenally low for what they serve. If you go to a restaurant like Al-Hamra in the Mission, you'll pay 6.99 for Chicken Tikka Masala that has the consistency of a bisque that is as bland as it is runny. If you go to Lahore, you can get yourself a true Chicken Tikka for the same price and it is a thick, flavorful curry that is both spicy and sweet. (pick Butter Chicken if you're not into sweet CTM) 

Stop going to gross Indian places that serve pre-made, watery curries and go here and get the real stuff.
author: Hal C.

description:
Took me 4 months before I could tolerate this dirty interior, though I's my favorite food in town.  
Pros: you can bring your own drinks, have a wonderful meal.  Tandoori fish is to die for
Cons: dirty, sub-par service
author: Anastasia V.

description: Meh.  This was my first totally Yelp-based decision.  I used the site to help me find a well-rated Indian restaurant within a 5-block radius, and then I dove right in, blind faith.  I called ahead and the food wasn't quite ready, which was fine because I was early, and in any event I appreciated having a few minutes to scope the place out.  There were like two trendy city couples eating there, so I took it as a sign that this place pulls from the locals, meaning it can't really suck too bad, because there's a good amount of Indian competition in the Tenderloin.  Although, given that logic, Chutney would be on the outs, and clearly it's not.  Actually, I don't know where the people who eat at Chutneys come from.  Must be from some place where the Indian food sucks.  But I digress.  This guy, the guy in the picture, he is actually there slaving over the grill, just like in the picture.  So there's some truth in advertising there.  Cool.  I appreciated that my bag had been well-packed, and was totally impressed by the total amount of the bill.  It was like $24 and change for Chicken Korma, Aloo Gobi, Chicken Boti (Tandoor boneless chicken), rice and naan.  Value!  For me the Chicken Korma is like a barometer dish I use for sizing-up Indian restaurants.  It's not that any of them make it well.  They don't.  It's that you can tell a lot by how they "interpret" Chicken Korma, which is a hard dish to make.  I had the best Chicken Korma of my whole life in Marbella, believe it or not.  For the record, it's supposed to be thick and milky and betray just a suggestion of coconut.  Overdo on the coconut and you wind up with some common, heavy-handed Thai concoction.  Whew, I'm really having a hard time reigning-in this review, lol.  The Chicken Korma at Lahore Karahi tasted like Mexican food.  I swear you could have served me that sauce on my enchilada, and I would have scarcely noticed anything was amiss.  Not bad, mind you, just not Indian food.  Which was odd, given the authenticity of the guy in the picture and all that.  The boneless chicken was dry (sorry, honey, I lied when I said my piece was juicy).  It was really dry.  It was so dry there were bits of chicken that hurt me inside my mouth.  The Aloo Gobi was indistinct, but that may just be because it tasted a lot like the Korma.  There were two highlights, however!  The rice is funny-looking and brown and tons of fun.  Order 2!  And the naan was gummy but totally delish.  Order 3!
author: Jack M.

description: This is a great little place to go for authentic curry.  Curry is the pretty much the national dish in the UK, so I rarely go for curry outside of the UK (India excepted!), but this place is special.  Naan, Saag Gosht (extra spicy but still with the taste of creamy spinach and lamb) and a mango lassi.  Great.  Will certainly be going back.
author: Samuel B.

description:
Perhaps I'm biased, as one of Lahore Karahi's original customers when Guddhu took over in 2004 and my son considers Guddhu to be like an uncle to him, but there is just something very special about this place and I'm always happy to hear when others have discovered and become loyal fans as well. 

I'm not sure who did the website that is listed above --- Guddhu isn't quite sure who the person is either --- but I frequently have been updating for two years: http://www.lahorekarahisf.com for Guddhu. 

As you can see, customers love this place so much that we make competing websites! Prices and menu options with take out information is current as of today. There is even a great photo of Guddhu in the kitchen. 

For those nervous about he area, I live 1 1/2 blocks away. I'm a young female. O'Farrell and Geary around the Leavenworth area is NOT going to give you any grief if you're walking around before midnight. Don't be scared, act like you own the block and you're fine. Yes, the guys hoot and holler if you're cute and someone is bound to ask you for some change, but thats about as far as its going to go. Shrug it off. :)
author: Mari W.

description:
Went to early dinner on Saturday night, and immediately sat down. We started with the vegetable pakora, which was flavorful, but not crispy, like most restaurants. The garlic naan was delicious, as well as our entrees, the lamb vindaloo and chicken karahi.  Both were spicy, but not overwhelming.  Almost as enjoyable was the rice, which, according to the owner, is their specialty.  The rice is cooked with cinnamon sticks, and contains serrano peppers, although they don't crack the peppers to keep the heat down.

Parking is a cinch, though given the neighborhood, that is not a surprise. Be alert, and enjoy the fare.
author: Erwin C.

description: soooooooo good! every time i eat here i can not believe how tasty everything is. By far the best Indian food i have had in the city. It is in the loin so one gets a cozy and raw urban experience that is unlike any other (for better or for worse).The butter chicken is addictive and full of juicy white meat the garlic naan is hot, fresh and delicious. I don't like my food spicy and they always honor my request for very mild. Plus the hospitality is unbeatable; it's like dining at a friend's house, home cooking and all.
author: April H.

description:
After reading  glowing reviews on Yelp and a strong recommendation from my cousin, I went there with fairly high expectations, prepared to being blown away by the food. 
What a disappointment!
The food was not spicy at all. Not at all. I mean, not. At. All. This was after we had asked the waiter to make it "extra spicy". Everything else about the curries was good, but the absence of spice was a deal breaker. I hope tonight was an exception - I am ready to give it another chance and I will update my review if things change, but until then, two stars is all it'll get from me.

*EDIT*
Went there again, and the food was spicy (not as much as I would have wanted, but I can live with that) this time. Yay!
I am upping the rating to 4 stars.

*EDIT #2*
It's been 5 stars for the past few time I've eaten there.
author: P G.

description: If you love curry, this is the place. Though small in capacity, their tasty food and nice people that work there make up for it. Me and my boyfriend used to always get their chicken korma until I order their Chicken tikki masala (another type of curry they have) SOOOOO GOOODDD...It taste wayy better than regular curry, this one has a tang to it. I like to order 2 sides of their garlic Naan bread to dip in the sauce, hella good. And the owner is awesome, he's always smiling!
author: kirehleen f.

description: Now, if you like that nontraditional Nan-n-curry Indian crap then you MIGHT not find this as good as people may think. Or, you may be like me and come here and be pleasantly surprised by the difference. It is 'real' Indian food. I mean, if you go to India THIS is the kind of tandoori, chicken and rice you'll find. The service is great and they are very friendly. 'Gudu' is the owner and he is great. What I find the most awesome thing about this place is that they don't mind if you bring booze in, whether it be a 40oz, a bottle of red wine or a champagne. They will bring you out glasses and don't mind it at all...How cool is that??
author: Lou C.

description: Fresh ingredients, flavorful, not greasy, consistently delicious. After ordering your food the wait can be long, but the food is well worth the wait. I don't come here for atmosphere & great customer service (although I have always found the owner to be very nice), I come here for great tasting food.
author: lenka l.

description: I love love love the biryani here, it's spicy and delicious. Don't come if you're in rush, but if you have time for a leisurely meal with friends, you won't notice anything except the deliciousness of the meal and the good company of your friends anyway.  I've been several times, and have luckily never had a long wait for a seat, but sometimes it takes awhile to take or get your order. My ideal meal here is a vegetable biryani, curry, and naan.
author: Helen H.

description: The best Indian/Paskistani food - hands down!  There is usually a long line after 7pm but worth the wait. Every dish is so flavored and cooked fresh. My favorite is the "Fish tandori" and I miss eating at this place all the time since we moved to Sunset. But we still make an effort to stop by this place once in a while, especially with the SF visitors.
author: Milli G.

description: As this place has gotten more popular, the quality of everything has gone down a bit.  The food doesn't have the same exceptional flavor (less love, more haste?). The portions aren't as generous.  The food comes out in a worse order (salad after you're done with everything else?).   The only thing that's better is that there are actual servers/assistant cooks most times of day.  This place is still really good Indian and a great price, but it's no longer the OH MY GOD AMAZING experience it used to be.
author: R A.

description:
mixed feelings....

food:  spectastic!!  curries bursting with flavor, i couldnt get enough!  the aloo gobi was superrrrr!  i've never eaten so much naan in one sitting before, trying to scoop up as much curry as i can.  at the end of the meal, i only wished that i could be hungry again so i could eat more..... 

service:  not atrociously bad, i suppose.  the waiters were there.  we had to get our own tea though.  and the waiter didn't find it necessary to tell us that.  so we sat around complaining about our parched mouths before we asked for hydration.  the waiter proceeded to.... point us in the direction of the tea and cups.  it also took unreasonably long for us to get the check.  and then my friends and i were asked to leave because others were waiting for a table.

hair count:  i found a 4 inch hair in my curry.  i picked it out and continued eating (see section on "food" above for explanation).

mmmmm i probably wont be seen here again because there are similar restaurants nearby that have yet to serve me hair.  (see http://www.yelp.com/biz/shalimar-san-francisco#hrid:iw0vFqtOwv73Wfj9gt2B-w)

but i will abstain from recommending...... i give u the facts, u can weigh the risks.
author: Christina L.

description:
yes, yes. this place dominates the quadrant. that free kulfi he gave us at the end was magnificient, my cholay rich and filling, the best green sauce i have ever tasted. my friend said that the lamb saag ascended above, all these marvelous things. dont pass this one up, give naan and curry, shalimar, chutney and pakwan a rest for five minutes ( listen, i know, its hard. they are go to places that have all the accolades and what have you. just do it, once.)
DUDE, UPDATE: 3/22/06 OH MY GOODNESS! Gudoo really went overboard tonight. I brought in three friends, and both chef and patron went to town. Starting with samosas, we went traveled a saag ghost, dal makhani (extra spicy, no cream. MAMA SEITA), dal masala, beingan bhartha, 4 garlic naan, an order of rice, a salad and my friends shared the patented fish tandoori, which they said reached emperor status. He topped it off with free kulfi and bannana pudding, homeade. my friend uttered: "this man is the god of the moment." Doesn't everybody want to be, just once? this guys hits that every couple of minutes. Are you still eating at shalimar?
author: Christopher J.

description: Lahore karahi to me is the quintessential representation of good, cheap, indian/pakistani food. All the dishes here are awesome from the fish tandoor to the lamb kebabs to the kheema. The perfect flavors and each dish cooked for the most part individually. Served hot with onions and chillies. The place however is tiny and does not seat too many, also the popularity of this place has quadrupled in the last few years that being said there is always a slight wait time to get seated. We for the most part get the food to go ... never have the patience to sit there and gawk at the people stuffing their mouths with tender morsels of meat and the oh so lovely nan. Sigh... need to visit the place soon.
author: Ash O.

description: samosas, pakoras, garlic naan, rice, dal masala, a chickpea dish, ice cream (on recommendation), and a can of pop for 24  dollars.  the best  thing ever. it tastes like paradise. even though i hate the walk, if you wear headphones it's not so bad. on a skateboard (or im sure on a bike) it'd be easy.
author: aerin w.

description: Good food, service so so. The tandoori fish had spices that weren't mixed as well as they could have but great value for money!
author: Jag P.

description:
without a doubt the best indian restaurant in the city.

the owner is both chef and waiter, and the food is amazing!  bright, flavorful dishes, unlike some of the curry slop youll find around the city.  also super old bollywood movies are always playing on the ancient tv (love it!) and everything is stupid cheap.

sadly, its no longer byob :( 

i always spring for the lamb vindaloo, i swear it gets better every time.  and when i ask for spicy, i get it.  if a curry doesnt make me sweat, its not curry :)
author: CC C.

description: Absolutely my favorite Indian/Pakistani restaurant in the bay area.  Every dish is wonderful and fresh tasting, never swimming in a pool of oil.  Best to go when you've got some time since it can take a while. But it's worth it!  My favorites are the choley, tandoori fish, bhindi masala, naan (chewy and tangy), malai kofta.  Misses are few but include the Afghani naan and the lamb boti which, while very flavorful, was also a tough cut of meat.  I hardly ever go anywhere else when I'm in SF anymore!
author: L A.

description: Several of my friends said this was THE best Pakistani food in the city. I tried it and all I have to say is, "Meh". We got there and were seated at a dirty table (I realize we didn't go to this place for the ambiance, but come on) and it took us FOREVER to be served. I think there was only one server, but still, it was frustrating because we were hungry. We finally ordered and received our mediocre food. It was ok, seriously, just OK. And the server had the worst BO ever...sorry, I just had to throw that in there because it really added to my dislike for this place. We ordered about 6 different items (chicken tikka masala,tandoori chicken,  saag paneer, naan, cauliflower and potato, basmati rice, etc) so we could try different things and make a good assessment of the place, but that STILL didn't get us very far. I would def. pick Shalimar a million times over this place. And to my friends who recommended this...I'd have to say, "Really??? Thanks Alot!! =P"
author: danae k.

description: as with most indian food, great vegetarian options here.  possibly the best indian food i've ever had.  the garlic naan alone is worth a trip from new york
author: John M.

description: I used to love the place. Then I found out about their DECEPTIVE TRADE PRACTICE! I bought a number of certificates on restaurant.com in the beginning of Oct. While reading reviews on here I noted that a couple of Yelpers said they refused to honor them. I called the restaurant and was told that "shortly after they signed up with restaurant.com they canceled the contract and had no idea why they were still being sold on there. They REFUSED to honor them." I explained that they should at least honor those that were sold during the period they were under contract and if restaurant.com made a mistake by still listing them for sale it was not their fault. They refused to honor ALL of them. OK, so I am out a few bucks. A month goes by and what do you think I see as late as today.....they are still listed on restaurant.com. In short, they are selling worthless certificates to lure people in only to refuse to honor them. Oh, and restaurant.com said their contract was still active and that they should honor the certificates that were sold. So there you go.....amazing food and a completely underhanded approach to luring people in. I'll go elsewhere.
author: John B.

description: The dubious wait time. It was almost bad enough to walk out and grab some mediocre, americanized, ubiquitous Thai food around the area. Almost. Yeah, there's only one guy serving the food, one guy/juggling act fabulously dishing out awesome Pakistani/Indian food and one inconspicuous lonesome guy washing the dishes. Yet a table of 8 people managed to get their food before we even got our naan though my friend and I arrived long before they got there. Now that's just awesomely bad...service? The food eventually arrived and I can't remember whether we shrugged off that incident first or realised how delicious everything was. I mean, we're talking about reaching some rarified air in terms of taste. Both the sesame naan and the spice potato & cilantro flavored Aloo Paratha were freshly made of course, pipin' hot and ready to dip and sop up the sauces from...our main dishes which were even tastier--the roasted eggplant from the Bengan Bhartha and Prawn Masala that were so spicy yet savory, mouthwatering and simply outstanding that we almost forgot how long it took to get to the table. Almost.
author: Chris C.

description: Best restaurant in the city for flavor, price and consistency. While the ordering process can be chaotic at times the food quality and taste more than compensate. I came here for lunch one time and the owner/chef/waiter danced around the full restaurant with tenacity and grace. Thank you for being the establishment that you are, I will keep coming back.
author: p a.

description: Superb food, ok service, basic ambience. Chicken Tikka Masala highly recommended. Change in alcohol policy???
author: Oscar C.

description: loved it.  came here with the bf.  and i loved it.  the food was a tad spicy for me.  but it was delish .... the service was a little slow (thats one star off) but the owner/chef/waiter/cashier does it all by himself.  he only has one other guy who cleans up the tables for me.   so i cant blame him.   and the tandoori chicken was so awesome ... so i recommend coming here but be prepared to wait for a while for your food ....
author: Edith L.

description: Indian food as good as it gets.  The nan is out of this world, the lamb vindaloo is the best I've had.  This place is a whole in the wall and it is far from fine dining.  But if you just want excellent indian food, you must try Lahore.
author: G A.

description: It must be the human morbid curiosity that brings people to this place.  It is everything every other commenter wrote, both good and bad.  Tasty food, horrible service and unsanitary appearance.  We went because we saw it on Check Please, not even looking at Yelp.  Probably would have went out of morbid curiosity if we had looked at Yelp.  We fortunately got there right at opening.  We only waited about 45 minutes for our food.  He was in the weeds from the get go.  Overall we enjoyed it, but one thing truly bothered me:  we ordered everything Lamb and the tandoori sizzling platter was obviously Lamb, but not the chops we ordered, but chunks.  In the two other dishes, where the meat was obscured by sauce or rice, the meat had the strange likeness to pork.  Not saying it was, but just that it had the exact likeness.  Obviously from the other comments, you can surmise that we did not have the opportunity to inquire about this curiosity to any of their competent staff.
author: Tom S.

description: bring a bottle of wine. eat to your heart's delight. find that you still have 20 dollars to waste down at whiskey thieves as you weave your way back to a night of the polk street blues.
author: diana m.

description: Maybe I shouldn't get extra street cred because I am of South Asian decent, but trust me...if you want good pakistani food go here! Its my favorite in the city (slightly edging out Shalimar on Polk).
author: Sam H.

description: food was choice and i love that the chef takes your order, makes your food and brings it to you.
author: Markus B.

description: This place is el yummo.  Good Pakistani food in the tendernob and it gets better every time I go.  Now there's a lot of hipster cool people there though which is kinda sucky, but good for the owners of Lahore.  The nan and kulchas are really good.
author: a y.

description: We decided to try Lahore during a recent visit, but left as soon as we noticed that all of the tables were covered with dirty plates and cook was using the same spoon to taste each dish he was cooking...yuck!
author: Monica G.

description: Not a good idea to drink BYO in here. It has been raided by the cops and you can get into serious trouble. The food is great though.
author: Estevan M.

description: can't remember the dishes we ordered, but the samosas were really good. i think they were the standout of the night.
author: ML N.

description: AMAZING!!!  I have gone to countless Indian restaurants in San Francisco and this is one of the best!!  All of their dishes are good, I'm sure, but the chicken tikka masala is excellent!  The naan is perfect and a little on the sweet side.  All lamb dishes are excellent as well!  They are very generous on the amount of meat they give you when compared to other Indian restaurants.  Service is great too, and the food comes pretty quickly. I go here all the time because it's that great!
author: Blushed M.

description: Love it, love it. Perfect potatoes, stellar naan, idyllic fish dishes & lively biryani's!
author: Luda F.

description: quite possibly the 2nd best indian meal i have had in SF.  my co-workers adore this place and know the owner very well and always get the hookup.  so on to the food.  wasn't too big a fan of any of the chicken dishes asides from the chicken saag which was on point.  the tandoori fish has to be one of the best indian dishes i've ever had in the city!  not a big fan of goat so i won't rate that.  the lamb vindaloo was incredible as was the bengan bertha was so d-e-l-i-c-i-o-u-s!  and top it of, the mango lassi and mango kulfi excellent.  this was all in a lunch w/ 16 people today!  needless to say the productive at work after lunch was non-existent...
author: Swarup B.

description: my fave choley and naan in the city.  the chicken korma, daal, and lamb biryani are good.  i didn't care for the tandoori fish everyone loves, it was too dry and fishy for my taste.  it's best to pre-order your lunch, especially if you don't have 2 hours to spare.
author: jane d.

description: Great food and the owner is so friendly. If you're looking for drinks brown bag it from one of the corner stores, or home.
author: ceaseless

description: Just had dinner here. It was a mixed experience. Fortunately there wasn't much of a wait. Ordered my food and had a chai while waiting. It took about 15-20 minutes before the food showed up. The Chicken Tikka Masala gravy was a bit sweetish, which was weird (I prefer the CTM at Pakwan). The Dal Makhni was decent and the Garlic Naan was good. Finished off my meal with another chai. Would I go back? Maybe if I am in the neighborhood but I doubt that I will make a special effort to go there as I did tonight.
author: Sanjay C.

description: i didn't eat here. i sadly came here with friends when i was in between graduating from xray school and a job. "broke like a joke" so to speak. but i watched them eat and it sounded like it was good stuff! i did get to check out the environment though. the server seemed rude and unattentive to say the least. but in the end i think he doesn't intend on being rude, he's just running the business as quickly and lacklusterly as possible. get your food and get out. hey if i were as busy as they were i'd try to make the turn over happen asap too! anyway, he added to the experience which became a comedic experience to me. it gave us something to talk about for sure.
author: Regina C.

description: it takes forever.  but its AMAZING!  the owner makes all the food.  so good!
author: pete c.

description: All in all, I don't believe there is a better restaurant in existence.  Yes, the service is slow and one waiter can be a bit flippant.  No, there is no beer or wine list, but I think that's a bit of a positive because it allows you to bring your own.  Gudhu, the chew-owner is very nice and if you come between meal times, he'll often come out to the tables and will sometimes even offer specials.  Now, the food:  this is the only Indian restaurant I've been to that is completely distinguishable from the others.  It's not just that the meat is cooked correctly, but that the spices used are a different blend that seems omnipresent in Indian and Pakastani restaurants around here.  The food is generally quite spicy, but that's right up my alley.  The lamb vindaloo is the best Indian dish I've ever had.  Even dishes I usually feel apathetic about, such as saag paneer is excellent here.  I have been here about a half dozen times at least, and I have not once tasted a single item that was less than fantastic.  Their desserts are all amazing.  The kheer is thick enough a spoon stands upright in it.  On the rare occasion that they make carrot pudding it is dream-like.  Even that breath-freshening mixture they near the door is way better than average.
author: Daniel F.

description: i waited a long time to write this review just so i could go to lahore karahi a few more times and easily get a table. if you go after the lunch or dinner rush, you can spend time with the owner and he might let you sample his homemade ice cream and other treats. this place is my fave for indian hands down.
author: amaymay l.

description: Went there after 2 years or so. The food was great. This place has cooked more healthy than most other Indian places. The breads were also great.. Parking is a pain, and service wasn't that great, but the prices compensate for that :)
author: Kuldeep T.

description: I've been a handful of times and really like 'em.  Whatever we've had has been excellent (including last night's lamb vindaloo!)  I'm  giving 4 instead of 5 stars only because service just wasn't quite there last night.  Granted they were super busy but it took a long while to place our order and almost an hour in total before we got our food.  But again, once it arrived it was excellent and we weren't in a big rush, so all good.  Can bring in beer/wine - go to Econo Market (or something like that) right nearby.
author: Jim K.

description: The bf and I were visiting SF this past weekend and upon the recommendations of fellow Yelpers we decided to check this place out.  (The bf is a Brit so I like to think that he knows his Indian food...)  We walked over there from our hotel- there was no wait when we arrived since they just had us sit at a table where three men were already sat and eating.  I guess good use of table space?  One big turnoff for us was the mound of trash next to the door.  There were at least seven plastic bags filled with trash.  Would it have been too much to ask for them to not leave them in visible sight?  As we've never visited here before, I have no idea if this is standard practice for them.  The food:  excellent.  We ordered the vegetable biryani, chicken vindaloo, chicken korma, and sesame naan.  The biryani was delicious!! Perfectly spiced.  The vindaloo (which we ordered spicy) was HOT!!  I was definitely sweating by the end of the meal.  I would definitely check this place out for the food.  I really would've given this place four stars except I had to take one off for the trash situation.
author: sunny k.

description: Absolutely terrific place! And Guddu is probably the most sincere, warm (and of course accomplished) chef I've known. The stars don't do justice. For the vegetarians out there, the place doesn't disappoint if you order the Lahore Chikkar Chole (my absolute favorite), Shahi Panneer (Guddu makes his own panneer!), Baingan Bartha's and plain Rotis. Sometimes Guddu will offer his 'special' dessert not on the menu, if you go often enough :) Great place, the only place I recommend for Indian food in the city.
author: D A.

description: Delicious! The service is really slow...but we ordered the cheese and peas dish as well as the eggplant and potato. Both were fantastic and I'll definitely go back. Prices were good too!
author: Cassie C.

description: Just to respond to Ambika comment re LK Samosas. They are indeed made from scratch  (a labor intensive process) by owner'/chef "GUDDU". Ambika is correct in observing that Samosas in other Pakistani and Indian restaurants are purchased from outside.  The pakoras and samosas at Lahore Karahi Labor intensive and worth waiting for (but NOT 45 minutes). Chef Guddu also makes his own yoghurt and cheese (paneer), from SCRATCH. Please give LK another try, it is a cut above the others if ONLY for the FABULOUS samosas which, again I repeat, are made from scratch.
author: Claudia S.

description: Ahhh, good stuff.  Just a couple blocks down the hill from my office, which Antigone G. has mentioned in previous reviews is an area definitely barren of lunch dining options (about the only reason I would actually want to office downtown).  I've been going here for a month (two?) since first noticing the Yelp reviews.  Just came back from lunch with Valerie D., 'Karahi didn't disappoint.  I would suggest coming in early (we did) and you will get personal, friendly, unhurried service from the owner/chef himself, but I've noticed as the lunch crowd started to show up service slowed down (and especially noticed this time).  It's not the kind of place to go if you expect to be waited upon hand and foot, and if a hole-in-the wall restaurant _doesn't_ sound attractive to you then again this isn't the place for you.  I do feel he (the owner, cannot recall his name at the moment) could use more staff and not ruin anything, on the other hand the food is so good and the prices perfectly fine that I don't feel I should suggest messing with something that obviously works on the off chance it might be ruined.  Anyhow, I like 'Karahi enough that I did the unthinkable; after being a longtime yelp Lurker, allowing other yelpers to do all the hard work of finding the best places, I broke down, created an account, and chimed in with another 5-star rating.  I like this guy, and I hope the word of mouth continues to spread for him.
author: - Joshua -.

description: The only great thing about this place is their tamarind and mint chutneys. Being a big fan of both Shalimar and Naan N Curry I was extremely disappointed.  The flavors were horribly out of balance - the tandoori dish lacked salt and the chicken karahi was too sweet. And the seekh kebab was a dry dense mass that needed to be washed down with a ton of chutney.  Needless to say, I will not be returning.
author: Felice L.

description: This place is dope... Spicey! The tikka masala goes off.
author: Derek R.

description: This place is ok, but save your time and go to Shalimar.  It's a better experience and significantly better food.
author: Michael M.

description:
I was so excited to try this place after reading all the rave reviews here.  I've tried many restaurants in San Fran based off yelp reviews and never been steered wrong. I really wanted to like this place, a fantastic Indian restaurant with in walking distance of my home... what a dream! Sadly, it was not to be. We ordered a an Aloo Matter and Butter Chicken as well as various naan and samosas. The samosas were ok, the naan was fine as well. The butter chicken was passable but nothing fantastic to warrent the glowing reviews seen here. The real disappointment for this place came with the Aloo Matter, for some reason it was sweet!!! I dont think I've ever had a sweet curry before and aloo matter is my staple dish that I've ordered at countless Indian restaurants.  It tasted like someone had spilled a full cup of sugar into it. It was the most disgusting curry I've ever eaten, I couldn't bring myself to eat more then four bites. 

I was so disappointed, finding good Indian in this city is so difficult. =( All the great reviews on this place lead me to wonder if Indian is too subjective of a  cuisine to trust reviews on yelp.
author: Anna M.

description: great food... the chicken tikka is the best I've had.. not like the usual cream tomato sauce, it hints at actually using a variety of spices... .the food here is great... and the flocks of business people from the financial district don't lie... the only bad thing is it is often very busy around dinnertime or even later on weekends..... they also show great indian films and shows on the TV
author: Young M.

description:
I've never experienced such horrible, super slow service as I did at Lahore Karahi.  It was like a Seinfeld episode, a cross between the one where they wait forever at a chinese restaurant and when they try to order from the soup nazi.  Honestly I would have preferred "no soup for you!" right off the bat and our night would have been so much less frustrating.  We could have just hopped over to Shalimar or one of the numerous other good indian joints nearby.

It started with about a 30 minute wait to get a table.  Totally not unreasonable, and besides we used the time wisely to go to a bar around the corner and also pick up some beers for our dinner.  Once we got seated however we were quite hungry.  This is where the trouble started.  It took a solid 30 minutes for someone to come over and take our order.  We tried to flag down the owner who was constantly shuffling around the tables but he would just avert his gaze and ignore us.  By the time we ordered we were all starving.  We were hoping some of our appetizers or at least naan would come out in say, 10-15 minutes, but no luck.  We had a very serious debate about taking some of the leftovers from other tables.  The worst part was the psychological torture.  We didn't know when (if?) the food was going to come - we could see the tiny kitchen, other tables that look like they have been waiting a long time, and other tables that you could swear arrived after you and already have their food.  On the other hand we've already invested a lot of time and patience and the food should be here any minute, right?  Wrong.  It took 40 minutes after ordering to get our first dish.  Also: they didn't bring one of the appetizers we ordered.  Anytime we asked a simple question we got lectured / berated for asking.  There weren't enough glasses of water for our table because they were "out of clean glasses".

I'm not going to dwell too much on the food because if you've read any other reviews you already know it is really good.  It was indeed very good.  But its hard to be completely objective when your leather shoelaces would have also tasted pretty good.  

So.. at least be warned it could be an all-night affair at Lahore Karahi.  Definately don't arrive hungry and don't make solid plans for later.  Don't be fooled by thinking it doesn't look that busy.  I agree good food is worth the wait and this was some of the best indian I've had, and about half the price of other indian places.  And I wasn't expecting top service from a cheap restaurant in the tenderloin.  But for me, the service was so incredibly slow and frustrating that it was totally not worth it.
author: Bill S.

description: went here last night and thought that portions were much smaller eating in than take out, about 1/3 ; is it just me? both rice and curry
author: Porkers T.

description: really had a nice evening out here.  not 100% perfect else it would have gotten higher... maybe a 4.5.  :)
author: Joe C.

description: holy crapoli is this shit good. if ya'll don't wanna wait for fresh food go eat yr greasy hearts out at naan and curry. but if you want good quality, DEELISH and cheap indan/pakistani food made to order, eat here or forever regret your existence.
author: Burleigh Girl G.

description: This place is great. We walked here from Powell before the show at Herbst and had a leisurely, great meal. We picked up drinks from the next-door market and the dude supplied us with a bottle opener when he asked. Very courteous service; a Mexican dude is the cook, and they treat him like family. We ordered the vegetable pakora, butter chicken, aloo mattar, a couple orders of rice and a garlic naan. GREAT food. the green chutney here is absolutely amazing. When all was said and done, we still were hungry, so I asked the guy for a chicken vindaloo. He said "right now?" and I was like "yes, please!" So the food comes 5 minutes later (the service is ridiculously quick, that's a plus), and it's lamb instead of chicken. Best vindaloo ever, and it turned out that the lamb was a good contrast--it was good quality lamb, too. The presentation is real homey -- the food comes in bowls that look like my cereal bowls at home. The kitchen area is right there in front of you, so the whole thing is real honest. You can see what's cooking right there and watch your food being prepared. Also, there's vintage, poor-quality bollywood on the TV. major yay. go here.
author: Ethan K.

description: just got chicken vindaloo and lahore karahi rice for lunch. ive been here dozens of times, its close, and the food is excellent. the service can take a little longer than most places but the staff is always really friendly. Guddu is awesome! Forget Naan and Curry, Lahore Karahi is the best indian food ive had.
author: A. b.
